rationale: This species is only known from the historical record from 1898. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No information about habitat and ecology of this species is available.
threats: No information is available about threats to this species.
population: No population data is available.
range: This species is only known from the type specimen that was recorded originally in 1898 from Sumatra (Indonesia) although the exact locality was not provided.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Research is needed to establish the current distribution, habitat and threats to this species.

rationale: Opisthotropis spenceri has been assessed as Data Deficient as it has only been found in one location and there is no information about the habitat preference, threats and habitat status of this species. Further research on this species is needed before a more accurate assessment can be carried out.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this species are not known. However, other members of the genus are well-known for living in forest streams with clear water.
threats: It is unknown if any threat process is impacting this species. Deforestation and water pollution are likely to be threats to this species, however, not enough is known about this species to assess if these threats are affecting it.
population: There are no data available on the population size and trends for this species as only two specimens of have been found (Cox 1991).
range: This Thailand endemic has only been found in the province of Lampang in northern Thailand; the type locality is Muang Ngow. (Smith 1918, 1943).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The area where this species has been collected is a protected area. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into the biology and ecology, threats, population numbers and habitat status of this species is needed.

rationale: Acanthopagrus longispinnis was recently separated from A. latus. The type series of A. longispinnis, includes two species, and further study is needed to resolve the identity of this species. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information available on the biology of this species.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: Acanthopagrus longispinnis is currently known from two localities in the Bay of Bengal, lower basins of the Ganges River and the shallow coastal area of Chennai. It is likely to be more widely distributed in the northwestern Bay of Bengal (Iwatsuki 2013).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). The type series of A. longispinnis, includes two species, and further study is needed to resolve the identity of this species. Further study is also needed to determine population trends and biology of this species.

rationale: Argyrops megalommatus is endemic to the Red Sea. There is limited information available on its population status, life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend further research on its biology and monitoring of its population status.
habitat: Little is known about the biology of this species.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: Little information is available on the population status of this species.
range: Argyrops megalommatus is known only from the Red Sea (Eschmeyer 2013, Golani and Bogorodsky 2010).
useTrade: Use and trade information are not available for A. megalommatus.
conservationActions: There   are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It   occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of   Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). Research is needed on the biology, population trends, and use/trade information for this species.

rationale: Sparidentex belayewi is abundant in markets in Pakistan, together with Sparidentex hasta. There is limited information available at present regarding population status, life history characteristics and habitat requirements. Additionally, this species is pending correct taxonomic designation. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little information is available on the biology of this species.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: There is little population information for this species.
range: Sparidentex belayewi is currently known only from Iraq, Iran, and Pakistan (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010). There are no records from the western Persian Gulf (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013).
useTrade: Use and trade information for Sparidentex belayewi in the Persian Gulf is unknown, however, it is very abundant in the markets of the Indus River estuary of Pakistan. Experimental aquaculture for this species, in addition to S. hasta, is occurring in Iran (F. Kaymaram and Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013).
conservationActions: There   are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It   occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database   on Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014).

rationale: Lithognathus olivieri is endemic to Namibia. This species is an important commercial fish in Namibia and there are data indicating declines from fishing. There are no available data at present on its population status, limited information on its life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements. There is ongoing taxonomic work being done on Lithognathus. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The maximum recorded length for this species is 25.6 cm SL (Penrith and Penrith 1969). There is little known about the biology of this species and further research is required. <span class="gs_ctc">
threats: Declines from fishing pose a threat to this species and the lack of life history and population information for L. oliveri will make fisheries management challenging.
population: Capture production in Namibia peaked in 1995 with 195 tonnes, there was a decrease in 1996 with six tonnes and an increase in landings in 1997 with 136 tonnes and 116 tonnes in 1999. From 2000 to 2007 landings were from zero to 56 tonnes.
range: Lithognathus olivieri is endemic to Namibia (Penrith and Penrith 1969).
useTrade: Lithognathus olivieri is an important game fish (Namibian Fishing Industry, http://www.nfi.com, accessed 2009, 2013).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species; however, the range of this species overlaps with marine protected areas throughout its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed March 2014).

rationale: Spicara nigricauda is widespread along the coast of West Africa from 50 to 100 m depths.  Despite the limited information on its population status, life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements, Spicara nigricauda is of minor commercial importance and is presently not undergoing significant population declines.  This species is currently not at a high risk of extinction in the near future and is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend research on its biology and population status.
habitat: This species is found over the continental shelf (Schneider 1990) and grows to 20 cm TL or more (Edwards et al. 2001).
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: There is limited population information available for this species.
range: Spicara nigricauda is distributed in the Eastern Central Atlantic and is known from Ghana to Angola, including the offshore islands (Eschmeyer 2012, Edwards et al. 2001) from 50 m to 100 m depth (Schneider 1990).
useTrade: Spicara nigricauda is of minor commercial importance. Small individuals are taken by net and larger ones by hook. This species is mainly caught from January to April (Edwards et al. 2001).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). Additional information about the biology, population trends and harvest levels are needed for this species.

rationale: Spicara melanurus is widespread along the coast of West Africa. It is a dominant component of the artisanal fishery in Cape Verde and is a minor component of the industrial fishery. Spicara melanurus inhabits the continental shelf but there is limited information on its life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements. There are no data indicating population declines in its distributional range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern. We recommend research on its biology and population status.
habitat:
Spicara melanurus is found over the continental shelf and is usually found at the depths of 100 m to 250 m (Reiner 1996). The maximum recorded size for this species is 32.8 cm TL and its weight-length relationship in Cape Verde is W=0.0713TL2.4915 based upon 1,569 specimens with lengths varying from 18.2 and 32.8 cm and weight varying from 87 to 425 g (Oliveira et al. 2014) .

Spicara melanurus presents multiple spawns practically throughout the year in Cape Verde. These fish are diandric protogynous hermaphrodites. Smaller and larger individuals are mostly males (Carneiro et al. 2014) .
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. Potential declines from fishing may pose a threat to this species, as it is gaining importance in fisheries due to population declines of more valuable species.
population: Population trends for Spicara melanurus are unknown. However, this species has gained importance in artisanal fisheries in the recent years as catches of Decapterus macarellus, an important species in Cape Verde, have declined.
range: Spicara melanurus is distributed in the eastern Atlantic from Senegal and the Cape Verde Islands. Records from Angola (Carpenter in prep.) and Madeira (Wirtz et al. 2008) need confirmation. This species usually occurs between depths of 100 m and 250 m (Reiner 1996).
useTrade: Spicara melanurus is one of the dominant species of the artisanal fishery in Cape Verde and constitutes about half of the total catch (along with one other species), but it is of minor importance in the industrial fishery (Stobberup and Erzini 2006).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). Additional information about the biology, population trends and harvest levels of this species is needed.

rationale: Spirica martinicus is only known from Martinique Island. It is known only from the holotype. Information about the biology, population status, and harvest levels are not available at present. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is limited information available on the biology of this species.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: There is limited information available on the population status of this species. It is known only from the holotype (Eschmeyer 2011).
range: Spicara martinicus is known only from Martinique Island (Cuvier and Valenciennes 1830).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). There is a need for further research on the biology, population status, and harvest levels of this species.

rationale: Typhlops exiguus is known only from the type locality in Belgaum in the Western Ghats of Karnataka. This species is known only from historic records. This species is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitat requirements and ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known about threats to this species.
population: Typhlops exiguus is known only from Belgaum, Karnataka.. It has not been recorded since it was originally described, and there is no information regarding its present population status.
range: Typhlops exiguus is known only from the type locality Belgaum, Karnataka, India.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: Typhlops exiguus is known only from the type locality in Belgaum, in India's Western Ghats, and no recent sightings have been reported. Research is needed to rediscover this species in order to establish its current distribution, life history, ecology and the existence of any threats.

rationale: Only four specimens are known from an imprecise locality with no further information on the species. Hence it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of Cnemaspis boiei.
threats: Nothing is known about the threats to this species.
population: The four type specimens in BMNH (with no associated locality data) are the only ones known of this species.
range: There is no information regarding the distribution of this species. The type locality is marked as "India" (Gray 1842).
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: The taxonomic validity of the species and distribution need to be established.

rationale: Uropeltis broughami is listed as Data Deficient because it is only known from two historical records and there is no information on population size and trends, ecology and potential threats that may affect this species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known about the general threats to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of Uropeltis broughami.
range: Uropeltis broughami is endemic to the Western Ghats, India and is known from the Sirumalai Hills and Palni Hills in Tamil Nadu (Wall 1923, Smith 1943). There are no recent sighting records of this species. The distribution given in Smith (1943) erroneously includes the Nilgiris.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Uropeltis broughami is known only from two locations in the Palni and Sirumalai hills, Tamil Nadu that are not in the protected area network, however, they are in the reserve forests. As this species has not been reported in the recent past, there is a need to establish its existence and distribution.

rationale: Uropeltis beddomii is known only from type locality based on specimen collected in mid 19th century and has not been reported since its type description in 1862. There is no information on population, habitat and ecology or threats to this species. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known about the general threats to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of Uropeltis beddomii.
range: Uropeltis beddomii is endemic to the Western Ghats, India and is known only from the type locality in the Anaimalai Hills in Tamil Nadu (Wall 1923, Smith 1943). There are no recent sighting records of this species.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Uropeltis beddomii is known only from a single location in the Anaimalai hills, Tamil Nadu that may or may not presently be in the protected area network. As this species has not been reported in the recent past, there is an urgent need to establish its existence and distribution, and also initiate actions to conserve this rare and endemic species.

rationale: Oligodon macrurus has been assessed as Data Deficient, as there is little confirmed information on this species and its distribution, habitat and potential threats are not known. More research is needed on this species before a more accurate assessment can be carried out.
habitat: There is no information on the natural history of this species.
threats: There is no information on major threats to this species, as no recent surveys have been conducted in this area.
population: No population status information is currently available for this species, which is known only from historical records at two localities.
range: This species is known only from Viet Nam, where it occurs in a restricted area between Khanh Hoa and Ninh Thuan Provinces. Based on the coastal location of the known localities, it is presumed to occur below 200 m asl (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2011).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are currently known for this species, and neither of the known sites occurs within protected areas. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species, and more information is needed on this species' population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Rhinophis fergusonianus has been assessed as Data Deficient, as it is only known from the type specimen collected in the Cardamom Hills of southern India. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species.
habitat: There is no information on habitats and ecology for this species.
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: Rhinophis fergusonianus is endemic to India and is only known from the type specimen collected in the Cardamom Hills near Trivandrum in Kerala (Smith 1943).
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed to establish its current distribution, as it is only known from one specimen.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while it is known from only a small number of localities, it may be more widespread and is not expected to be subject to major threats.
habitat: This is a ground-dwelling, diurnal species, but no information about its habitat preferences is known.
threats: The sites where this species has been found are on flat plateaus that may be at risk from development. However, threats from this activity are likely to be localized.
population: Arnold (1986) reported collecting 20 specimens in one day at one locality, suggesting that it is at least locally common, but no other information is available.
range: This species has only been found in northwest Yemen, where it is known from fewer than five localities. It is found above 2,000 m asl. Its range extends 26 km northwest of Sa'ada, close to the border with Saudi Arabia, and it is expected also to occur in this country. Its range will extend further south to the area around Mazbah, if Pristurus mazbah is found to be conspecific.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, which is not known to occur in protected areas. Further research into its ecology, population size and distribution is required. Taxonomic study is required to verify whether Pristurus mazbah is synonymous with this species.

rationale: Agamodon arabicus has been assessed as Data Deficient, as it has only been recorded once in over a hundred years, and virtually nothing is known of its habitat preferences, susceptibility to threats, or population status.
habitat: This species has been recorded in cultivated land, where it was fossorial (Obst and Wranik 1998), but nothing else is known of its ecology.
threats: Nothing is known of threats to this species, however it has been recorded in cultivated land and so appears not to be at risk from small-scale agriculture of the form practiced in Yemen.
population: There is no population information available for this fossorial species. It has only been recorded once in the previous 100 years (Obst and Wrank 1998).
range: This species is endemic to Yemen, where it has been recorded from five localities in a restricted area of the southwest. No elevational information is available, but its known sites are in lowlands.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is required into the population status, distribution, habitat preferences, and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that none of the locality data available for this species is considered to be reliable, and its distribution is consequently completely unknown. Pending taxonomic research to identify populations conspecific with the holotype with certainty, nothing can be said of its population status, distribution, natural history, or any threats.
habitat: The species is fossorial and presumably lays eggs like other members of  its genus. No information on habitat and ecology is available.
threats: It is not known if this species is being impacted upon by any major threats.
population: Sharma (2003) described this species as being rare in India, but its occurrence in this country requires confirmation. Consequently nothing is known of this species' population status.
range: This species has been reported from Assam and Haridwar in northeastern India (Smith 1943), and presumably also occurs in intervening Nepal. There is considerable confusion over the geographic distribution of this species. Günther's (1864) type locality of Penang in Peninsular (West) Malaysia is thought to be an error (Smith 1943) and has led to numerous reports of this species occurring in Malaysia and Indonesia (e.g. McDiarmid et al. 1999). Its geographic range is therefore unresolved. There have been no recent surveys within its range in India, and its occurrence in this country needs further validation based on systematic surveys in the reported historic range (P. Mohapatra and C. Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2019). The true identity and distribution of this species are therefore completely unknown.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: Taxonomic study is needed to compare specimens that have been referred to this species from India, Malaysia, and Indonesia to clarify species boundaries and their geographic distributions. Research is needed to obtain information on this snake's population status, natural history and exposure to threats. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Typhlops hypsobothrius has been assessed as Data Deficient because it is only known from two syntypes with the collection locations unavailable. Without further distributional information, it is not possible to assess this species under a different category. The habitat in Sumatra is heavily degraded due to logging and conversion to oil palm plantations and therefore it is recommended that further research is carried out for a more accurate assessment to be made.
habitat: Without knowledge of the locations of the syntypes, it is not possible to determine where the species inhabits.
threats: No information available.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Sumatra, Indonesia, and is known only from two syntypes (David and Vogel 1996).
useTrade: There is no information available on use or trade in this species, but other blindsnakes are not in use.
conservationActions: No information available. Further research into biology and ecology, abundance, threats, and habitat status of this species should be carried out.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from a small number of historical records, and there is consequently no recent information on its distribution within Taiwan, its population status, or its exposure or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: This fossorial snake is presumed to feed on the eggs and young of insects and other small invertebrates (Zhao 2006). Due to the absence of recent records, nothing is known of its habitat requirements.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Zhao (2006) mentioned that experts in Taiwan have never found this species in the wild, and the only historical records date from the 1930s. There is therefore no available population information.
range: This species inhabits Taiwan (Wallach and Pauwels 2004), where it is known from Kuraru (Kueitzuchiano), Hengchun (Koshun), Twannaryo, and Pingtung (McDiarmid et al. 1999).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, although it has been recorded from protected areas. Research is needed to relocate this snake and obtain data on its population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Helcogrammoides antarcticus is only known from a few specimens collected in Antarctica. Nothing is known about H. antarcticus distribution, population, habitat, or ecology. Climate change impacts may be important threats H. antarcticus in this region. Therefore, H. antarcticus is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat preference for Helcogrammoides antarcticus is unknown.
threats: It is not known if there are any threats to Helcogrammoides antarcticus. Climate change impacts may be important in this region.
population: There is no population information available for Helcogrammoides antarcticus and is only known a few specimens (Williams pers.comm. 2010).
range: Helcogrammoides antarcticus is known only from the type locality, Paradise Bay, Antarctic Peninsula (Williams and Springer 2001).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for Helcogrammoides antarcticus.
conservationActions: Helcogrammoides antarcticus is not known to occur in any marine protected areas.

rationale: The species has been assessed as Data Deficient, due to a lack of information regarding species' population trends, or direct threats to this species.
habitat: There is no information available on the species ecology.
threats: No information available on the threats to the species.
population: There is no information available on the species population.
range: The species is known from Hongshuihe River in southeastern China (Guangxi Province) only (Zhang et al. 2000).
useTrade: No information on use and trade is available.
conservationActions: Research is needed for taxonomy, distribution, and population trends.

rationale: This species is extinct. Fossil remains indicate that it went extinct within the last 2,000 years, and historical reports suggest that it may have survived into the late 1700s or even later (Novak 1999).
habitat: There is an indication that this was a burrowing form of pika (Nowak 1999).
threats: Over-hunting for food, and predation and competition from introduced mammals, may have contributed to its demise (Nowak 1999).
population: There is anecdotal information that the Sardinian Pika may have been a  burrowing form of pika that was capable of reaching a high density  (Nowak 1999). Some believe that a small population persisted in the  central mountains of Sardinia until relatively recently, but there is no  evidence to support this (G. Amori pers. comm. 2006).
range: The Sardinian Pika was part of an anagenetic lineage (including Prolagus figaro) that occupied Mediterranean islands since the earliest Late Pliocene to the Holocene. Within this lineage, the Sardinian Pika gradually increased in body mass to an estimated 504-525 g (Moncunill-Soll et al. 2016). Contemporary fossil evidence of the Sardinian Pika has been found on Corsica (France), Sardinia (Italy), and adjacent small Mediterranean islands (Angelone et al. 2008, Angelone and Cermak 2015). Skeletal remains indicate that it was still present on Corsica and Sardinia within the last 2,000 years, and F. Cetti's 1774 report of "giant rats whose burrows are so abundant that one might think the surface of the soil has been turned over by pigs" on the islet of Tavolara may refer to this species (Nowak 1999). It is thus possible that the species survived until the late 1700s or even later, although this has not been conclusively proven. The Sardinian Pika is also known from earlier fossil material found on the mainland of Italy (Nowak 1999).

rationale: This species is only known from the holotype and 12 additional specimens. Very little is known about its biology, abundance or threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is known to occur at a depth range of 17 - 30m (Peter Wirtz pers. comm. 2005). No other habitat or ecology information is available for this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population data available for this species, since it is only from the holotype and 12 additional specimens.
range: This species is found in southern Western Sahara (Morocco) to northern Mauritania (Bath and Wirtz 1992).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for Spaniblennius riodourensis, although it occurs in Banc D'Arguin National Park in Mauritania.

rationale: This species is restricted to the Gulf of California although it is locally abundant with no well-documented major threats and is therefore considered Least Concern.  However, because of its shallow depth distribution and potential for impacts from coastal development and pollution, further research is needed to monitor this species.
habitat: This species occurs in shallow water up to 3m depth.  It is a tube dweller (M. Craig pers.comm. 2011).
threats: It is a shallow water species and therefore could be impacted by coastal development and pollution.  However, there is no current evidence that this constitutes a major threat for this species.
population: This species is common and locally abundant (M. Craig pers.comm. 2011).
range: This species is endemic to the Gulf of California, limited to Mulegé to Cabo San Lucas along the Baja Peninsula and between Isla San Pedro Nolasco and Isla San Ignacio de Farallon along the Mexican continental mainland (Rosenblatt and McCosker 1988).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Acanthemblemaria hastingsi, but it may occur in protected areas.

rationale: This species is only known from the holotype and therefore is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is known only from one specimen, but it is probably a shallow water species (Peter Wirtz pers. comm 2005).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. However, it is a shallow water species and therefore could be impacted by coastal development and pollution.
population: There is no population data available for this species, because it is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known only from the holotype that was collected from Goree, in Senegal.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for Spaniblennius clandestinus.

rationale: This species is only known from the type series and a few additional collections and little is known about threats to this species. We therefore list it as Data Deficient. However, it apparently has a very limited distribution and its very shallow habitat and known habitat in bays indicate that it could be significantly impacted by coastal development and pollution.  We strongly recommend that research be carried out to determine the status of this species in the wild.
habitat: This species is described as occurring in very shallow water (Halpern and Floeter 2008).
threats: It is a shallow water species and therefore could be impacted by coastal development and pollution. It also is a tube dwelling blenny and these typically prefer clear water.
population: There is no population data available for this species.  There are specimens at the Museum Natioonal d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris (2 lots with 1 and 6 specimens).
range: In the eastern Atlantic the species is currently known only from the Bay of Victoria, Cameroon and Bahia de Isabel, Fernando Poo (now called Bioko Island), Equatorial Guinea.  It is only known from the type series and a few collections.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Microlipophrys bauchotae.

rationale: This deep-living, cryptic species is only known from one specimen collected from a single locality. It was captured amongst red coralline algae and large brown algae. Little in general is known on the true extent of its distribution, population or ecology. Therefore, it is considered Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal species was collected at 68 m depth over small red coralline algae and some large brown algae (Fraser 1970).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is only known from a single specimen.
range: This species is only known from a single locality at 68 m depth northwest of Isla Tortuga off Venezuela in the Caribbean Sea (Fraser 1970). Due to its cryptic behavior and deep depth, the full extent of its distribution may not yet be realized.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Additional research is needed into the taxonomy, distribution, natural history and threats to this species.

rationale: This deep-living species is known only from one locality and few specimens. Its estimated EOO is 453 km<sup>2</sup> and its AOO is 367 km<sup>2</sup>, which meet the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2. However, very little is known on its population, habitat and complete distribution. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a bathydemersal species. Little additional information is available on its habitat and ecology.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from only a few specimens.
range: This species is known only from the type locality at Arrowsmith Bank off the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 453 km<sup>2</sup> (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 75+ m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 367 km<sup>2 </sup>(calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to a 75+ m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures. It may be protected by nature of its deep water habitat. Further research is needed into the distribution, habitats and ecology and possible threats to this species.

rationale: This species is known from only five specimens captured from three localities. It has been collected while in association with sponges, but little else is known. Its AOO is less than 4,085 km<sup>2</sup>. Given the paucity of information on its habitat, population, threats, and that it has a possibly somewhat restricted range, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known about the natural history of this species, although it is reported to be associated with sponges.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from a few specimens.
range: This western Atlantic species is  known only from a restricted area off Jamaica, Navassa Island, and Haiti (Gulf of Gonave) (Thacker 2001, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 163,698 km<sup>2</sup> (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 20-50 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 4,085 km<sup>2</sup> (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 20-50 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO). However, this AOO calculation is likely an overestimate since it is restricted to sponge habitat.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: The type locality is within a protected area. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Additional research is needed into its distribution, natural history and threats.

rationale: Corydoras steindachneri é conhecida apenas da localidade-tipo, no município de Paranaguá, Paraná. Não há informações suficientes sobre os limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia da espécie, o que impossibilita identificar ameaças à população. Portanto, Corydoras steindachneri foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Corydoras steindachneri, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido à ausência de dados sobre a mesma.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Corydoras steindachneri é conhecida apenas da localidade-tipo, no município de Paranaguá, Paraná, Brasil (Reis 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos a respeito dos limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Corydoras steindachneri.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Chasmocranus truncatorostris é conhecida apenas de um exemplar de sua localidade-tipo, município de Corupá (ex-Colônia Hansa), bacia do rio Itapocu, Santa Catarina. Entretanto, existem dúvidas com relação à taxonomia e precisão da localidade. Há um outro registro não confirmado da espécie na bacia do rio Itajaí-Açu. A incerteza taxonômica e dúvidas em relação à distribuição geográfica da espécie não permitem identificar possíveis ameaças que coloquem a sua população em risco. Portanto, Chasmocranus truncatorostris foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Chasmocranus truncatorostris, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Chasmocranus truncatorostris é conhecida apenas de sua localidade-tipo na bacia do rio Itapocu, município de Corupá (ex-Colônia Hansa), próxima a Joinville, Santa Catarina, Brasil (Bockmann e Guazzelli 2003). No entanto, há dúvidas com relação à taxonomia e precisão da localidade. Há um outro registro não confirmado da espécie na bacia do rio Itajaí-Açu.
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comércio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. Provavelmente ocorra no Parque Nacional da Serra do Itajaí. Existe a necessidade de estudos para delimitar a distribuição geográfica de Chasmocranus truncatorostris, bem como sua taxonomia, ecologia, entre outros.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Trichomycterus nigricans é endêmica do Brasil, e a localidade tipo é duvidosa, pois na descrição original de 1832 é mencionada como procedente das vizinhanças do município do Rio de Janeiro, e em sua redescrição, de 1846 é citada como proveniente do estado de Santa Catarina. O material tipo não foi designado na descrição original. Com base em evidências circunstanciais, foi proposto recentemente que um exemplar procedente de Santa Catarina fosse o tipo. Uma vez que existem conflitos a respeito da procedência exata da espécie, não é possível determinar possíveis ameaças. Dessa forma, Trichomycterus nigricans foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação disponível sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: A principal ameaça à Trichomycterus nigricans tanto no Rio de Janeiro quanto em Santa Catarina é a urbanização intensa, porém não se sabe ao certo qual o efeito da urbanização sobre a espécie.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Trichomycterus nigricans é endêmica do Brasil, e a localidade tipo é duvidosa, pois na descrição original (Valenciennes 1832) é mencionada como procedente das vizinhanças do município do Rio de Janeiro, e em sua redescrição (Cuvier e Valenciennes 1846) é citada como proveniente do estado de Santa Catarina (de Pinna e Wosiacki 2003). O material tipo não foi designado na descrição original. Com base em evidências circunstanciais, foi proposto recentemente que um exemplar procedente de Santa Catarina fosse o tipo.
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. São necessários estudos a respeito dos limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Trichomycterus nigricans.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Hyphessobrycon latus é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida somente do holótipo, coletada em Fortaleza, Ceará. A espécie não tem sido identificada em nenhuma coleção científica e existem dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica. Portanto, foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Hyphessobrycon latus, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica.
population: Hyphessobrycon latus é conhecida somente do holótipo. A espécie não tem sido identificada em nenhuma coleção científica, pois provavelmente trata-se de uma outra espécie (F.R. Carvalho com. pess. 2013).
range: Hyphessobrycon latus é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida somente do holótipo, coletada em Fortaleza, Ceará (Lima et al. 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. Estudos a fim de esclarecer a validade taxonômica de Hyphessobrycon latus estão sendo realizados por H.A. Britski e F.R.Carvalho.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Bryconamericus megalepis é conhecida somente do material-tipo, coletado em Fortaleza, Ceará, Brasil. A espécie não tem sido identificada em nenhuma coleção científica e existem dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica. Portanto, foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia de Bryconamericus megalepis.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Bryconamericus megalepis, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica (Grupo de Avaliação 2013).
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Bryconamericus megalepis é endêmica do Brasil e conhecida somente do material-tipo, coletado em Fortaleza, estado de Ceará (Fowler 1941).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos de sistemática/taxonomia a fim de se eliminar as dúvidas quanto à validade de Bryconamericus megalepis.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Pseudotatia parva é conhecida de somente um registro no médio São Francisco, em Juazeiro, no estado da Bahia. Parece ser uma espécie rara, entretanto, esse fato pode ocorrer por conta de problemas taxonômicos. Como não é possível delimitar a distribuição ou ameaças que afetem a espécie, Pseudotatia parva foi listada como Dados Insuficientes (DD). São necessários estudos sobre a taxonomia, distribuição e biologia da espécie.
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie. Pseudotatia parva atinge comprimento padrão máximo de 4,6 cm (Ferraris Jr. 2003).
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Pseudotatia parva, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica.
population: Parece ser uma espécie rara, entretanto, esse fato pode ocorrer por conta de problemas taxonômicos (R.E. Reis com. pess. 2011).
range: Pseudotatia parva é conhecida de somente um registro no médio São Francisco, em Juazeiro, no estado da Bahia (Ferraris Jr. 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação.São necessários estudos a respeito da taxonomia e revisão nas coleções (pode estar registrado como Tatia sp.), além de estudos sobre os limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Pseudotatia parva.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: De acordo com a descrição original, Rhamdella exsudans apresenta como localidade tipo aparentemente “Rio de Janeiro”. A espécie é conhecida somente da série tipo, composta de dois exemplares. Além de incertezas da validade da espécie e seu posicionamento taxonômico (Bockmann e Miquelarena 2008), a ausência de dados não permite a avaliação do estado de conservação de sua população. Portanto, a espécie foi listada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie. Apresenta comprimento total máximo de 8,9cm (Bockmann and Guazzelli 2003).
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Rhamdella exsudans, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica e à incerteza sobre sua distribuição.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Rhamdella exsudans é endêmica do Brasil e conhecida somente da série tipo, composta de dois exemplares. A localidade tipo da espécie é imprecisa, relatada apenas como Rio de Janeiro (Bockmann e Guazzelli 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos a respeito da taxonomia, limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Rhamdella exsudans.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: De acordo com a descrição original, Pimelodella rudolphi apresenta como localidade “Mercado de São Paulo”. Outras referências bibliográficas listam a espécie no Estado de São Paulo, porém não vinculados a registros de coleta além da série-tipo (13 exemplares). Outros registros de coleta não foram encontrados nas bases de dados verificadas. Assim, não há dados suficientes que permitam assinalar a área de distribuição desta espécie que foi listada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Pimelodella rudolphi, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica.
population: A população é de origem autóctone e de ocorrência nativa (Langeani et al. 2007), no entanto, não há informação disponível sobre a biologia populacional da espécie ou dados populacionais.
range: Pimelodella rudolphi é endemica do Brasil e apresenta distribuição no Estado de São Paulo (Oyakawa e Menezes 2011, Oyakawa et al. 2009, Langeani et al. 2007, Bockmann e Guazzelli 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos a respeito da taxonomia, limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Pimelodella rudolphi.

rationale: Hyphessobrycon iheringi é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida somente do holótipo, coletada em Fortaleza, Ceará. A espécie não tem sido identificada em nenhuma coleção científica e existem dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica, podendo ser sinônimo de Serrapinnus piaba. Portanto, foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Hyphessobrycon iheringi, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido às dúvidas quanto à sua validade taxonômica.
population: Hyphessobrycon iheringi é conhecida somente do holótipo. A espécie não tem sido identificada em nenhuma coleção científica, pois provavelmente trata-se de outra espécie (F.R. Carvalho com. pess. 2013).
range: Hyphessobrycon iheringi é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida somente do holótipo, coletado em Fortaleza, Ceará (Lima et al. 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. Estudos a fim de esclarecer a validade taxonômica de Hyphessobrycon iheringi estão sendo realizados por H.A. Britski e F.R.Carvalho.

rationale: Hypostomus brevicauda é conhecida apenas do material-tipo, de localidade imprecisa (“Bahia”). Os limites taxonômicos e de distribuição da espécie são desconhecidos e necessitam de investigação, por isso H. brevicauda foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Hypostomus brevicauda, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido à ausência de dados sobre a mesma.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Hypostomus brevicauda é conhecida apenas do material-tipo, cuja procedência é imprecisa, relatada apenas como Bahia, Brasil (Weber 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos a respeito dos limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Hypostomus brevicauda.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Hypostomus wuchereri é conhecida apenas do material-tipo, com localidade-tipo imprecisa “Bahia”, Brasil. Os limites taxonômicos e de distribuição da espécie são desconhecidos e necessitam de investigação, por isso H. wuchereri foi listada na categoria Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Hypostomus wuchereri apresenta comprimento padrão máximo de 20 cm (Weber 2003).
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Hypostomus wuchereri, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido à ausência de dados sobre a mesma.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Hypostomus wuchereri é conhecida somente do material tipo, de localidade-tipo imprecisa, registrada como Bahia, Brasil (Weber 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não há nenhum programa de conservação dessa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. Angela M. Zanata está fazendo a revisão das espécies de Hypostomus da Bahia. Também são necessários estudos a respeito dos limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Hypostomus wuchereri.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: This species is only known from a few specimens collected during a single sample in 1978 from Xishuangbanna, Yunnan, China. No other information is available and this species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No information is available.
threats: Without greater information on the species ecology and distribution, little can be said of the threats to the species.
population: Known from a few specimens collected during a single sample in 1960.
range: Known from a few specimens collected during a single survey in 1978 from Xishuangbanna, Yunnan, China (Kottelat and Chu 1998).
useTrade: No information available.
conservationActions: Further information is required on the species distribution and ecology.

rationale: The species is apparently only known from the type specimens and is considered Data Deficient.
habitat: No information available on the species; congeneric species are found mainly in slow flowing and muddy rivers, swamps, lakes, and anthropogenic habitats such as ponds and rice fields.
threats: Without better information of the species distribution and ecology, nothing can be inferred of the threats to the species.
population: No information available.
range: The species is known only from Thua Luu, Hué Province, Viet Nam.
useTrade: No information.
conservationActions: Confirmation of the taxonomic identity of the species is required, as well as information on its current distribution and ecology.

rationale: This deep-living species is widely distributed and uncommonly observed due to its deep depth range. It occurs over soft bottom. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species occurs over deep soft bottom. Little additional information is available due to its deep depth range.
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: There are 28 nominal records in Fishnet2, with up to two individuals in a single lot.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from  North Carolina south along the U.S. coast into the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys north to Louisiana and at least one record off Campeche, Mexico (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is known from four specimens collected from four localities in the 1940s and 60s. It has a known depth range of 22-36 m and occurs over soft bottoms. There are no major threats known to affect it. It is listed as Data Deficient as it is currently known only from few specimens, which were collected in poor condition, and it may be synonymous with the more widespread species, C. guineensis.
habitat: This is a demersal species that occurs over soft bottoms. Two specimens were collected in trawls and one discovered in the stomach of a shark Carcharhinus milberti (McCosker 1998).
threats: There are no major threats known.
population: This species is known from four specimens collected from four localities in 1940, 1943, 1963 and 1964 (McCosker 1998).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic along the U.S. coast from southern North Carolina to southeastern Florida (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its depth range is 22-36 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures. It is not know if any subpopulations are present within protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as no reliable  information is available at present. More research is needed  on the provenance and taxonomy of this species.
habitat: The habitat of this species is unknown as locality records are unreliable.
threats: No information is available on threats to this species.
population: No information on this snake's population status is available, as it is known from a very small number of specimens with unreliable locality data, and has not been recorded since its original description.
range: The species is only known from two specimens found in Indonesia, where it was described in 1893 and has not since been confirmed. One specimen was mentioned as being from Cibodas, although this specimen cannot be relocated. Another specimen was identified as coming from  Sumatra (V. Wallach pers comm.), but this too requires confirmation. Due to the uncertainty surrounding both this species' taxonomy and its provenance, its distribution needs to be verified (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. August 2011).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Research is needed to rediscover this species and determine its taxonomy, distribution, natural history, population status, and exposure and sensitivity to any threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient on the basis that it is known only from historical records, and there is no information on its distribution, population, natural history or threats.
habitat: Nothing specific is known of this snake's natural history. Blind snakes are oviparous and fossorial, and the diet probably consists of arthropods and worms (Das 2010).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data available on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is apparently endemic to southern Viet Nam, where it may be known only from the type locality Giadinh (Nguyen et al. 2009, Uetz et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place for this species. Research is needed into its taxonomy (it may be a synonym of  T. diardii) as well as its distribution, and population size and trends.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient, as it is known from a single specimen and has not been collected for more than a century.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: In the century since the species was described there has been significant development in linear infrastructure (roads and railroads) but much of this area remains forested. Nothing is known of any impacts on this species.
population: This species is known from a single specimen. Targeted surveys have been conducted to search for this and similar species without success (A. Das pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is known from a single specimen, collected from a disputed border region between Himachal Pradesh (India) and Xizang (= Tibet) (China) (Wall 1922, David et al. 2011, Green et al. 2010). There is no information available on elevation.
useTrade: There is no trade in this species.
conservationActions: Further efforts are needed to rediscover this species. It is unknown whether the species is present in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its distribution, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: Little is known about its habitat and ecology. It may be a forest dependent species, although this requires confirmation.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The population status is not known.
range: The type locality for this species is in Java, Indonesia, although this is now thought to be incorrect and the distribution is therefore unclear. This species has been listed as a species from Sulawesi, even the original label of the type mentioned as Java (fide Fritz, 2019). However, this species has never been recorded from Sulawesi or Java.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. Additional studies are needed to better determine the distribution, natural history and possible threats to this snake.

rationale: O. praefrontalis is listed as Data Deficient as there is not enough information available to assess it in a different category. Research is urgently needed to determine the existence of the species in Weh Island.
habitat: Nothing is known about its habitat and ecology.
threats: There is no information about threats to this species.
population: Nothing is known about its population.
range: At present, it has only been recorded from Weh Island, Aceh, in the north of Sumatra, Indonesia.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: Survey work  in the  Weh Island to determine the existence of this species is urgently needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known from only one area and there is no information on population size and trends as well as its habitats and ecology and potential threats. Research is needed to better establish its distribution and population status.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species are not known. It possibly occurs in lowland forests and probably feeds on reptile eggs and small lizards as for other species within the genus.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There are no data available on population size and trends for this species. It is uncommon.
range: This species is known from several specimens from the Padang area in Sumatra, Indonesia.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: The area where the species has been collected from is not protected. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Further research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trends.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient on the basis that it is known from a single historical specimen, and as such there is no information on its population status, distribution, natural history, or its exposure and sensitivity to threats.
habitat: Nothing is known of this species' natural history, although it is presumably terrestrial in forested areas. Species of Oligodon are oviparous and nocturnal, and feed on small vertebrates.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. Habitat loss through deforestation may threaten this species. Human pressures at the type locality are unknown, but include industrial-scale logging, slash-and-burn agriculture and smallholder farming, road-building and urban development are all leading to deforestation in Viet Nam.
population: This species is known only from two historical specimens, one of which is very small (P. David pers. comm. 2011) and so no population data is available.
range: This snake is apparently endemic to Viet Nam. It is known from only two historic specimens (Leviton 1953, 1960), from Bao Loc and B'Lao, Lam Dang Province (Leviton 1953, Nguyen et al. 2009).
useTrade: As this species is known from only one specimen, it has never been reported in trade and no use for it is known.
conservationActions: The area where this species has been described from is not under protection. No conservation measures exist for this species. Further research is needed to better establish its distribution and population size and trends.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as nothing is known about this snake's habitat preferences and consequently its exposure or susceptibility to any threats, and there is no available information on its population status or distribution.
habitat: No ecological data is available for this species, which was described based on a museum specimen.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, as nothing is known of its natural history.
population: No population data are available for this recently-described species, which is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is presently known only from the type locality, Nha Trang, Khanh Hoa Province, South Viet Nam  (David et al. 2008).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place for this species, and it is not known from any protected areas. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species in the wild, and obtain data on its distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known from only one specimen and there is no information about its population, habitat and ecology, and threats.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology for this species.
threats: The area where this species has been reported from is under pressure  from mining and logging activities. However, it is not known it these threats are affecting this species.
population: There is no population information for this species as it is known from a single specimen.
range: The species is only known from Tanjung, a name which may refer to a village in either East or South Kalimantan or in the west of Melawi Watershed, Sokan River, also in Kalimantan (Indonesian Borneo).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: This species is not known to occur in protected areas. Further research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trends.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that nothing is known of this species' true distributional extent, population status, natural history or threats.
habitat: The known localities are characterized by open habitats (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2011), but the particular habitat preferences of this snake are unknown. Nothing is known of this species' natural history,  although it is presumably terrestrial.
threats: Historical forest destruction around Ho Chi Minh City has been extensive, however the impacts of this activity on this snake are unknown as records from this area are historical and the snake's habitat preferences are unclear. As no precise locality data is available for Cambodia, it is unclear whether this snake is exposed to any threatening processes in this part of its range.
population: No population data is available for this species, which has rarely been recorded, even in areas where surveys have reported numerous specimens of other Oligodon species (B. Stuart, T. Neang and Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2011).
range: This snake is known from southern Viet Nam, where records exist for Dong Nai Province, Bien Hoa and the District of Ho Chi Minh City, and from Cambodia, where no locality data are available.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are in place for this species. Further research is required to establish the limits of this snake's distribution, clarify its natural history and population status, and to determine its exposure and sensitivity to threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is no recent information on this species, and nothing is known about its distribution, population status, natural history or threats.
habitat: No information is available on this species' habitats and ecology. It is expected to live near water.
threats: No information on threats to this snake is available.
population: Very few specimens of this species are known. No recent information is available on population trends.
range: Rhabdophis chrysargoides is poorly known and restricted to Java (Iskandar & Colijn 2001), where it was collected from Ujung Kulon in West Java in 1993 (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2011). The only other known specimens indicate only "Java" as the collection locality (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2012), making this snake's true distribution on the island unclear.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas. Surveys are needed to relocate this species and obtain information on its distribution, population status, natural history, exposure and response to threats.

rationale: The true distribution of Eviota herrei is not known; the only confirmed records are from Samoa. Further research is required to determine the true distribution of this species, and taxonomic clarification is required for the specimens nominally reported as this species outside of Samoa. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little information regarding this species' habitat and ecological requirements. Species in this genus are short-lived, reach sexual maturity in a matter of weeks and release a large number of larvae. The maximum recorded length for this species is 1.34 cm SL (Lachner and Karnella 1980).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: The species appears in collections in small numbers.
range: This species was described from Samoa (Jordan and Seale 1906). Other records throughout the Indo-Pacific may be another species. This species is found in depths ranging from 0 to 6 m (Fricke et al. 2011).
useTrade: It is unlikely that this species is utilised.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for E. herrei.

rationale: This demersal species is found in coastal waters off Peru. It is only known from a few specimens, and little information is known regarding its population, habitat, ecology, and potential threats. It may be a synonym of S. sechurae, however this is unclear at present. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Sphoeroides andersonianus is a demersal species found off the tropical marine coast of Peru. There are no other habitat/ecological data available for this species, as it is only known from a few specimens. This species is likely a synonym of S. sechurae (Walker Jr. and Bussing 1996)

The genus Sphoeroides was found to be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There have been no confirmed population declines in S. andersonianus.
population: Specimens of S. andersonianus are uncommon in museum collections, and are represented by collections of the type material (FishNet2 searched 9 May 2012).
range: Sphoeroides andersonianus is found in the eastern Pacific, off the coast of Peru. There is no depth information for this species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are two major marine protected areas in Peru, Paracas and Manglares de Tumbes, covering over 3,300 km<sup>2  </sup>in area. However, it is unknown if this species is found in either of these designated protected sites. There is a need for more research into the biology, range, and population of this species.

rationale: This species is known in the southwestern Pacific from southeastern  Australia. An additional specimen has been collected from Vanuatu, and this species may be more wide-ranging than current sampling indicates. This species has been collected at depths of up to 10 metres. Potential threats are unknown, and there is a need for research concerning the current  population and status of this species, as well as its precise  distribution, habitat and ecology. There are no known species-specific threats, and it may be somewhat widely distributed. It is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
There is very little information concerning the habitats or ecology of this species as several of the type specimens were collected from deceased individuals washed up on shores (Hardy 1983).

Tetraodontidae
Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: The potential threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is little species-specific population information for T. andersonae. It is represented by at least 14 lots in museum collections (FishNet2 database searched March 2013).
range: Torquigener andersonae is known in the southwest Pacific from southeastern Australia. It is specifically known from Sydney to Brisbane. An additional specimen has been collected from Vanuatu (FishNet2 database searched June 12 2014). The type specimens were described based on dead individuals washed up on shore (Hardy 1983). This species is known from depths ranging from zero to 10 metres.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. There are a number of marine protected areas in New South Wales that overlap with the distribution of this species.

rationale: Canthigaster investigatoris is a rare species known from two syntypes collected off the Andaman Islands in 1910 at depths exceeding 100 m. Based on the limited information available on its population status and life history characteristics, it is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend further research on its population status and general biology.
habitat:
Canthigaster investigatoris is a demersal species. There is little species-specific habitat information available for this species.

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. investigatoris available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
There have been no confirmed population declines in C. investigatoris. However, because of its affinity with coral reefs and seagrass beds, we infer that C. investigatoris may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.

As of 2008, fifteen percent of the world’s coral reefs were considered under imminent threat of being “Effectively Lost” (with 90% of the corals lost and unlikely to recover soon), with regions in East Africa, South and South-east Asia, and the wider Caribbean being the most highly threatened (Wilkinson et al. 2008)

Of 704 zooxanthellate reef-building coral species which were assessed by using the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List Criteria, 32.8% are in categories with elevated risk of extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).
population:
Canthigaster investigatoris is a rare, deep-water species (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). This species is known from two syntypes collected in 1910 off the Andaman Islands in the Indian Ocean (Allen and Randall 1977).

Specimens of C. investigatoris are rare in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012).
range: Canthigaster investigatoris is known from the Andaman Islands and appears to have a limited local distribution (Allen and Randall 1977). It has been collected at 100-160 m depth (Allen and Randall 1977).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. investigatoris.
