rationale: This species is only known from type specimens collected in the 1830s from the HMS Beagle survey. The taxonomic validity of this species is questionable. There is no information available concerning the population, habitats, and ecology of this species. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
There is no available ecological information.

Tetraodontidae
Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough, scaleless skin often covered with small spicules, beak-like dental place divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single short dorsal fin, a single shore anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or injured, are and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, or liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: This species is only known from specimens collected in the 1830s by the Beagle survey. The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain.
range: Tetraodon implutus is known only from the Cocos Islands in the Indian Ocean (Eschmeyer 2012).
useTrade: There is no known information on its use since it is only known from specimens collected in the 1830s.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Lagocephalus cheesemanii is currently undergoing taxonomic revision by K. Matsuura. Revisions have not yet been accepted by the scientific community, and pending publication of this revision there is uncertainty regarding the geographic range of this species. As currently accepted, this species is restricted to eastern Australia and New Zealand. However, if L. gloveri is accepted into the synonymy of L. cheesemanii the geographic range and threats to this species will be substantially increased. Lagocephalus cheesemanii is likely distributed from the Andaman sea east to Indonesia, north to southern Japan, including the Yellow and Bohai seas, and can be found at depths ranging from zero to 100 metres. It may be common in parts of its range. Adults inhabit the continental shelf over sandy or muddy bottoms, and juveniles can be found in estuaries. This species is likely a popular food fish in China, Taiwan and Japan. There is little species-specific population information available. This species is non-toxic and safe for consumption as processed and fresh fish product. It appears to be landed in large quantities in parts of its range, but does not appear to be particularly valuable. Based on population trends seen in other species of commercially important pufferfishes it is inferred that this species may be undergoing population declines in parts of its range. It is also likely to be impacted by coastal habitat degradation, particularly near estuaries and river mouths. Suspected population declines from exploitation and habitat degradation are not currently quantifiable due to lack of reliable data. Additionally, the geographic range of this species is somewhat unclear. Therefore, L. cheesemanii is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Lagocephalus cheesemanii is a tropical species found at depths ranging from 0-100 m. Adults inhabit the continental shelf where they are found over sandy or muddy bottoms. Juveniles can be found in estuaries (Matsuura and Liu pers comm. 2011). Lagocephalus cheesemanii feeds on molluscs, crustaceans and fishes. It is most similar to L. spadiceus and L. guentheri in appearance (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Pufferfish fishery
Lagocephalus cheesemanni is impacted by pufferfish fisheries in parts of its range. In Japan, Pufferfish landings have declined since the early 1990s. Concern about the fishery centers on the most valuable and preferred species, Takifugu rubripes, which, as of 2010, was considered depleted in Japan. Landings of T. rubripes in Japan had declined to 5% of annual landings in 1987. Landings of "other pufferfish", a category which includes L. cheeesemanii (as L. gloveri) were maximized after the decline in T. rubripes landings. These "other pufferfish" have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. Declines in landings have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012).

Fishery-dependent data from China showed declines in catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) from 2001 to 2003, however this data may represent several species of this genus. In the Zhoushan Islands L. gloveri contributed about 15% of the total salted/dried tetraodontiform fish products found in markets. In northern Taiwan, L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) accounted for 80% of the tetraodontiform fish capture volume (uncited/unpublished data).

Habitat degradation
Furthermore, habitat degradation is occurring in many coastal areas within this species' range, particularly near river mouths (J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). In the semi-enclosed regions of the North Bohai and Yellow Seas, large amounts of industrial and municipal effluents containing heavy metals, particularly arsenic, have been implicated in the deterioration of coastal environments (Luo et al. 2010). Heavy metals have also been implicated in the degradation of the heavily populated and industrialized Pearl River delta region in southern China (Cheung et al. 2003). In the Gulf of Thailand, coastal habitat degradation has resulted from pollution, primarily from untreated municipal and industrial waste water, as well as a rapid decrease in mangrove forests, coral reefs, and fisheries resources (Cheevaporn and Menasveta 2003).
population:
Lagacephalus cheesemanii is common and can be locally abundant (K. Matsuura and L. Jing pers. comm. 2011). It is common in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011) and in the east China Sea (M. Liu and J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). Lagocephalus cheesemanii (often identified as as L. gloveri) is a component of the pufferfish trade in east Asia, where it trades under the name sabafugu. It has also been associated with the name "kuro-sabafugu".

In Japan Pufferfish landings have declined since the early 1990s. Landings of "other pufferfish", a category which includes L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri), were maximized after the decline T. rubripes landings. These "other pufferfish" have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. Declines in pufferfish have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012). The percent contribution of L. cheesemanii to the category "other pufferfish" is unknown.

Fishery-dependent data from China showed declines in catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of L. cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) from 2001 to 2003, however these data may represent several species of this genus. The catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) was: 0.88 t/day/boat in 2001, 1.13 t/day/boat in 2002, and 0.72 t/day/boat in 2003 (unpublished data).

Although there is currently no reliable species-specific information concerning the population status of this species and population trends could not be quantified, it is inferred that this species undergoing localized declines in parts of its range where it is harvested commercially.

Specimens of L. gloveri, which may represent L. cheesemanii, are common in museum collections. This species is represented by at least 104 lots in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 30 April 2012).
range: Lagocephalus cheesemanii is originally known known from New Zealand, however it currently undergoing taxonomic revision. Lagocephalus gloveri is likely a synonym of this species (Matsuura 2011, K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014), and is known from the Andaman Sea east to Indonesia, north to southern Japan (Shizuoka Prefecture,West Pacific) and also on the coasts of the South China Sea, East China Sea, Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea (M. Liu and L. Jing pers. comm. 2011, Su and Li 2002, K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Therefore it is likely that the range of L. cheesemanii includes that of L. gloveri, however this is not currently resolved. It has been recorded at depths ranging from one to 100 m.
useTrade: Lagocephalus cheesemanii (as L. gloveri) is widely utilized in the dry fish market through much of east Asia (Chen et al. 2003). This species and L. spadiceus are considered non-toxic, and are approved for use in Taiwan for the dry fish market (Wu et al. 2008). Catch statistics for this species and L. spadiceus are lumped together as "sabafugu" in Japan (Kawata 2012). In Japan, the muscle, skin, and male gonad are consumed (Noguchi and Arakawa 2008).
conservationActions: This species range may overlap marine protected areas.

rationale: Sphoeroides nitidus is likely a synonym of Lagocephalus lagocephalus. It was described from the southwest Pacific near New Zealand, from the Auckland and Tauranga Harbors, and is known from three specimens. Sphoeroides nitidus is assessed as Data Deficient due to it being known from few specimens, a lack of basic biological information, and possible taxonomic uncertainty.
habitat:
This is a demersal, sub-tropical species which has been collected by trawl. There is no other population information available.

The genus Sphoeroides was found to be paraphyletic, and it is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. However, both harbors where this species are known from are fairly developed.
population: There is no population information available for this species as it is only known from three specimens.
range: This species is known from the southwest Pacific: only from New Zealand in Auckland and Tauranga Harbors (Eschmeyer 2012). There is no depth information for this species. Its taxonomic validity is questionable. This species may be a synonym of Lagocephalus lagocephalus (Mastuura pers. comm. 2011)
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this fish.

rationale: There is very little information on the distribution of A. leopardus. Its taxonomy is uncertain and the references pertaining to the species are unsubstantiated. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend research on its population status, specific habitat requirements and life history characteristics.
habitat:
There is no species-specific habitat and ecology information available for A. leopardus.

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species. 

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads,  and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats for A. leopardus.
population: There is no species-specific population information available for A. leopardus.
range: The origin of the name Arothron leopardus is unclear; it appears to be based on a specimen collected from Madras, India, by Francis Day in the late 1878. This specimen is currently housed in the Australian Museum under the name Tetrodon leopardus (Ferraris et al. 2000). It is likely a synonym of Arothron stellatus (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species. It is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. leopardus. Its distribution overlaps with marine reserves in parts of its range (World Database of Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: Javichthys kailolae is known from the Bali Strait, Indonesia and off Batangas, Philippines, although further deep-water sampling may expand its range. It is a benthopelagic species which has been collected at depths ranging from 62 to 68 metres. There is limited information available on its population status, life history characteristics and general biology. There are no known species-specific threats to J. kailolae. It is a relatively deep-water species which has been collected from two widely separated localities, and is likely to be undersampled. Therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Javichthys kailolae is benthopelagic species. It was collected at depths ranging from 62 to 85 m depth off the southern coast of Java (Hardy 1985). 

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: There are no major threats known to this species.
population: Javichthys kailolae is infrequently collected, and may be rare. It is primarily known from the original species description of 12 specimens (Hardy 1985). Nine additional specimens have been collected off the coast of Batangas, Philippines. Specimens of J. kailolae are uncommon in museum collections Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2010-04-30). There are no additional specimens known to have been collected since 1966.
range: Javichthys kailolae is known from the Indian Ocean from along the Serpent Bank, in the Bali Strait, in eastern Java, Indonesia. Specimens have also been collected from the Philippines, off the Batangas (FishNet2 searched April 27 2012). This species is known from depths ranging from 62 to 68 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because there are no data on the species since its description.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: No specimen of this species is known to exist (Das et al. 2019).
range: This species is known only from the vague type locality “Mirzapore?" (possibly in Uttar Pradesh, India), considered doubtful by the describing author himself (Jerdon 1853).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution, population size and trends and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Cnemaspis australis is known only from an imprecise type locality and only from the holotype. The single known specimen has not been exhaustively compared with other Indian congeners and both the validity of the taxon and its actual distribution needs further investigation. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of this species. The type locality details does not clearly indicate whether the species has been collected from the plains or the hilly regions of Tirunelveli.
threats: The threats to the species are not known.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of Cnemaspis australis except that it is known only by the holotype (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).
range: Cnemaspis australis is endemic to southern India. It is known only from the type locality, Tirunelveli in Tamil Nadu (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).  Species boundaries need to be critically re-evaluated in the light of recent taxonomic changes. The range and area of the species are unknown as it is only known from the type specimen.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Taxonomic validation of this species is recommended. Establishing its presence, distribution and population status is recommended.

rationale: Cnemaspis monticola is known only from the type series. The three known specimens have not been exhaustively compared with other Indian congeners and both the validity of the taxon and its actual distribution and ecology need further investigation.  It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known about the general threats to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of Cnemaspis monticola except that it is known only by the holotype and paratypes from the same locality (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).
range: Cnemaspis monticola is endemic to India and is known only from the type locality Wynaad, Waynaad district, Kerala, India (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).  Species boundaries need to be critically re-evaluated in the light of recent taxonomic changes.  The range and area of occupancy of the species are unknown as it is only known from the type specimens. It has been found at 749 m asl.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Taxonomic validation of this species is recommended. Establishing its presence, distribution and population status is recommended.

rationale: This deep-living species is potentially widely distributed, but rarely recorded. Current research indicates that subpopulations from the Atlantic and Indian Oceans are cryptic species. Due to this taxonomic uncertainty and the very limited information available on its ecology, population, and complete distribution, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits deep tropical waters between 60-366 m depth.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: There is limited population information available for this species. There are currently only 14 specimens known in museum collections which is likely to due its natural rarity (K. Tighe pers. comm. 2011).
range: Chlopsis dentatus has been recorded in the western Atlantic from Bermuda, the northern Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from northwestern Cuba, and in the Caribbean Sea from Quintana Roo (Mexico), Colombia (Cartagena to La Guajira), Guadeloupe, Dominica, and Barbados (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It has a depth range of 60-366 m. Records in the Indo-Pacific from Kenya, Mozambique, and Indonesia may represent a cryptic species. Its estimated EOO in the Gulf of Mexico is 55,308 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 50-200 m bathymetric layer). Its estimated AOO in the Gulf of Mexico is 37,164 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 50-200 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Gymnothorax austrinus is only known from the holotype in Victoria, Australia. There is no population information available for this species as it is only known from one specimen collected in 1884. Threats to this species are unknown.  However, it is not known if this species is currently in existence and there are no known conservation measures in place to protect this species. More research is needed on this species concerning its existence, full range, population, ecology, and possible threats. Until then, Gymnothorax austrinus is classified as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little known about this species.  However, it was collected in a bottom trawl and is therefore presumed to be a demersal species.  Also, its preferred climate is presumably temperate (Böhlke and McCosker 2001).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no population data available for this species as it was only recently described from a museum specimen collected in 1884.
range: Gymnothorax austrinus is only known from one specimen, collected from Half Moon Bay, Victoria, Australia. The depth of capture is unknown (Bölke and McCosker 2001).
useTrade: This species is not utilized for trade.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species.  More research on species validity and population and range are needed for this species.

rationale: Gymnothorax philippinus is found in the western Pacific from the Ryukyu Islands, Okinawa, and the Philippines. There are no population data available for this species as it is only known from a few specimens. This species is probably a synonym of G. pseudothyrsoideus. There are no imposing threats to this species nor is it utilized for trade. There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of Gymnothorax philippinus, however, it is necessary to do more research concerning its full range, population status, ecology, biology, and possible threats. It is currently listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a demersal species found in tropical marine waters. However, data are lacking on the specific habitat, feeding ecology, and depth distribution of this species.
threats: There are no major threats known to this species.
population: There are no population data available for this species as it is only known from a few specimens.
range: Gymnothorax philippinus is known from the Western Pacific Ocean, specifically from Luzon (Philippines) and from Kagoshima and Okinawa (Japan) (Smith 2012). There are no depth data available for this species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of Gymnothorax philippinus, however, it is necessary to do more research concerning its full range, population status, ecology, biology, and possible threats.

rationale: Gymnothorax pikei is known from Réunion, Mauritius (western Mascarenes), and Papua New Guinea. It is considered uncommon, and little information is available on its biology, ecology, and potential threats. There are no known threats to the species nor is it utilized for trade. There are no conservation measures in place for this species. However, there is a need for more research to understand the biology and population status of this species, as well potential threats. It is currently listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a deep water demersal species found in tropical waters. However, there is no other information on this species' specific habitat type.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: This species is uncommon (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
range: Gymnothorax pikei is known from Réunion and Mauritius (Mascarenes), and Papua New Guinea (Smith 2012). It is found at 30 to 40 m in depth.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. However there is a need for more research in understanding the biology and population status of this species, as well as potential threats.

rationale: Gymnothorax randalli is known from two widely separate localities: the island of Lombok in south-central Indonesia, and the Gulf of Aqaba in the Red Sea. However, it probably occurs continuously across the northern Indian Ocean to southern Indonesia. It is currently known only from four specimens, three type series from Lombok and the single specimen from Gulf of Aqaba. There is very limited information available on this species' life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend research on its biology and ecology and monitoring of its population status.
habitat: There is currently no information available on the habitat or method of capture of the specimens examined (Smith and Bohlke 1997).
threats: There are no known threats to Gymnothorax randalli.
population: Gymnothorax randalli is currently known only from four specimens, three type series from Lombok and the single specimen from Gulf of Aqaba. This species is thought to be uncommon throughout its range, however, further research on its population size and trends is recommended.
range: Gymnothorax randalli is known from two widely separate localities: the island of Lombok in south-central Indonesia and the Red Sea (Smith and Böhlke 1997, Bogorodsky et al. 2014). It probably occurs continuously across the northern Indian Ocean to southern Indonesia (Smith and Böhlke 1997). The depth range of G. randalli is most probably up to 22 m (Bogorodsky et al. 2014).
useTrade: Specimens from Lombok were obtained from a fishermen. This species may be a component of artisanal fisheries in parts of its range.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of Gymnothorax randalli.

rationale: Gymnothorax sagmacephalus is known only from the holotype, found in Tokyo Bay, Japan. Little is known about its biology, ecology, or potential threats which suggests that future research will be necessary. It is listed as Data Deficient until more is known about this species, particularly the full extent of its distribution and population status.
habitat: This is a demersal species found in a temperate habitat. Further research is needed considering there is no other information currently available concerning this species habitat and ecology.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. However, it may be impacted by the heavy development and industry in Tokyo Bay.
population: Gymnothorax sagmacephalus is only known from the holotype described in 1997. More information regarding population size and trends is necessary.
range: Gymnothorax sagmacephalus was described from a single specimen collected in Tokyo Bay (Böhlke 1997). More recently, it has been reported from southern Taiwan (Loh et al. 2014, Ho et al. 2015). Further research is needed to clarify its complete distribution and depth preferences.
useTrade: This species is not utilized for trade.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of Gymnothorax sagmacephalus.

rationale: Gymnothorax shaoi is known only from its recent description in 2007 from Taiwan, and relatively few individuals have been collected. Little is known regarding its biology, ecology, or potential threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little information about the habitat and biology of this species as it is has only recently been discovered in 2007, therefore, more research is needed on its life history, habitat, and biology.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. Taiwan is a heavily industrialized island, and Gymnothorax shaoi may suffer from habitat loss as a result.
population: There are no population data available for this species, as it is only recently discovered and currently known from a handful of specimens described in 2007 (Chen and Loh 2007). Further research is needed regarding population size and trends.
range: Gymnothorax shaoi is currently only known from the type locality in southeastern Taiwan, where it was described from in 2007 (Chen and Loh 2007). A recent report from the Marquesas, French Polynesia (Delrieu-Trottin et al. 2015) requires confirmation. There is no depth information available for this species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized for trade.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for the protection of Gymnothorax shaoi.

rationale: Gymnothorax sokotrensis is only known from the holotype, found off Socotra Island. There is very little known about this species, as it is only known from one specimen collected in the late 1960s. There is a need for more research on its existence, habitat, population, and possible threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat/ecology of this species. Further research is needed on the habitat and ecology of Gymnothorax sokotrensis.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no population data available for this species as it is only known from holotype described in 1968.
range: Gymnothorax sokotrensis is only known from the type locality off Socotra Island, Yemen (Smith et al. 2008). There is no depth information available for this species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There is very little known about this species, as it is only known from one specimen collected in the 1960s.  There is a need for more research on habitat, population, and possible threats.

rationale: Gymnothorax vagrans is known only from the unique holotype with a stated locality of South America that is likely to be incorrect. There is virtually nothing known about this species' population, life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is very limited information available on this species' life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements. Gymnothorax woodwardi is thought to be a demersal species that resides in tropical waters.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: Gymnothorax vagrans is known only from the unique holotype, which is in poor condition and cannot be identified as any known species of moray.
range: Gymnothorax vagrans was described in 1917 from a single specimen with a stated locality of South America; however, this is probably incorrect and therefore the distribution is unknown (Böhlke and Smith 2002, Smith 2012). There is no depth information available for this species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized for trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. There is need for research concerning this species distribution, population, habitat/ecology, possible threats, and existence. Gymnothorax woodwardi's theorized range could potentially overlap with marine protected areas.

rationale: Gymnothorax ypsilon is known throughout the western and central Pacific from southern Japan, Ryukyu Islands, New Zealand, and the Hawaiian Islands. It is restricted to deeper waters and is found between 120 and 185 m depth. There are only a handful of specimens known for this species. This species is not utilized, nor does it have any major threats. Its range overlaps several marine protected areas. It is listed as Least Concern. There is however a need for more research concerning the full range of this species, ecology, population, and the possibility of threats.
habitat: This is a benthic species found in subtropical marine environments. However, there is no other information available for its habitat type, ecology, or life history.
threats: There are no major threats known to this species.
population: Due to its depth range, there are only a handful of specimens currently known of this species. Future research on population size and trends is needed.
range: Gymnothorax ypsilon is known from scattered localities in the Pacific Ocean: Ryukyu Islands (Japan), Hawaiian Islands (USA) and Kermadec Ridge (New Zealand). It is found between 110 and 185 m depth (Stewart and McCosker 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized for trade.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for the protection for Gymnothorax ypsilon, however, parts of its range overlap with marine protected areas.

rationale: Scuticaria okinawae is found in scattered locations in the Indo-Pacific from Mauritius, Hawaii, Tahiti, in the Ryukyu Islands (Japan). More research is needed to confirm its distribution.  It is found at depths from 0-10 m.  Threats to this species are unknown, however, it is likely impacted by coastal development and habitat degradation in parts of its range.  Its range overlaps several marine protected areas, especially the several new reserves established in the Hawaii'an archipelago.  More information is needed regarding its geographic distribution, biology, ecology and the impact of potential threats. It is listed as Least Concern
habitat: This is a demersal species found in shallow (0-10 m) benthic communities of tropical marine environments.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. However, it is probably impacted by coastal development and habitat degradation in parts of its range.
population: This species is relatively uncommon throughout its range (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
range: This species is known from scattered localities in the Indo-West Pacific, including: Mauritius, Ryukyu Islands (southern Japan), Hawaii, and the Society Islands (French Polynesia). It is found at depths from 0-10 m. More research is needed to confirm its distribution and depth range.
useTrade: This species is not utilized for trade.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of Scuticaria okinawae. However, its range overlaps several marine protected areas, especially the several new reserves established in the Hawaiin archipelago. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full distribution, population, and habitat.

rationale: Myroconger compressus is distributed in the eastern Atlantic and is known from Cape Verde Islands, Senegal, Gulf of Guinea and St. Helena. There is no known depth information available for this species. There is limited information available on this species' population status because it is known only from a few specimens. There is very limited information available on this species' life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements; it is therefore listed as Data Deficient with a recommendation for research on its biology and ecology and monitoring of its population status.
habitat: There is very limited information available on this species' life history characteristics and specific habitat requirements.
threats: It is not known if there are any threats to this species.
population: There is limited information available on this species' population status because it is currently known only from a few specimens (K. Tighe pers. comm. 2011).
range: Myroconger compressus is distributed in the eastern Atlantic and is known from Cape Verde Islands, Senegal, Gulf of Guinea and St. Helena. There is no known depth information available for this species.
useTrade: This species is not used in commercial fishery, although it is caught incidentally for food; specimens from Senegal and Gulf of Guinea have been collected from fish markets (K. Tighe pers. comm. 2011).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species.  There is a need for more information about this species' habitat, population and any possible threats.

rationale: This deep-living, cryptic and extremely small species has been only recorded from three localities in the Bahamas. It has been collected from steep slopes with coral and rock. Based on the limited information available on the extent of its distribution, ecology and population, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The holotypes and paratypes were collected from a steep slope with medium-sized coral heads and rocky outcrops. It is one of the smallest vertebrate species ever found with a maximum recorded size of 1.4 cm SL (Briggs 1969).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species was described from ten specimens collected in relatively deep waters off West Plana Cay (Briggs 1969).
range: This species is known only from a few localities in the Bahamas, including the Plana Cays, Great Inagua, and Acklins Island. Due to its cryptic behavior, the full extent of its distribution may not yet be realized (M. Craig pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures. Additional research is needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is currently known only from two localities and few specimens. Its currently known estimated EOO is 18,457 km2 and its AOO is 99 km2, which meets the thresholds for Vulnerable under B1 and Endangered under B2. It has been collected from a relatively deep reef wall. This species is potentially highly-valued in the aquarium trade and its rarity may predispose it to overexploitation. It is very likely consumed in possibly high frequency by the invasive lionfish, which has been documented to drive steep population declines in reef fishes. Little in general is known on this restricted range species and the impact of these potentially serious threats, therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed on the possible impact of the invasive lionfish.
habitat: There is little information on this species as it is only known from two localities and few specimens. The type specimens were collected at 20 m depth from a reef wall (Victor and Randall 2010). The single specimen observed off Little Cayman was positioned upside-down amongst a group of Gramma loreto over a spur and groove reef formation. It appears to be highly site-attached with limited mobility (Lohr et al. 2014).
threats: There are no known major threats. It could be highly desirable in the aquarium trade if a market were to develop; two specimens were sold in 2011 for a price of $4,500 USD each. It is very likely consumed by the invasive lionfish due to its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). The lionfish occurs throughout its range in very high densities. To date, at least two Grammatidae spp. have been documented to frequently occur in the diet: Gramma melacara and G. loreto (Morris and Akins 2009, Bejarano et al. 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This is a recently described species with no information on population size or abundance. It is generally considered to be rare in comparison to other co-occurring Gramma species.
range: This species has been recorded in the western Atlantic off southern Cuba near the city of Trinidad and off Little Cayman Island (Victor and Randall 2010, Lohr et al. 2014). It has been recorded at 18 and 20 m depth. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 18,457 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 20-50 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 99 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 20-50 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. There is a need for further research on the biology, population, possible threats and full range of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient due both to doubt concerning whether the presumably extinct Palauan lizard is conspecific with Hypsilurus godeffroyi, and whether that Palauan agamid (provisionally considered to belong to H. godeffroyi) is itself extinct. No confirmed records of this species have been taken since 1867, and nothing is known of its distribution (including whether or not this is genuinely a Palauan species), population status, natural history or exposure to threats.
habitat: All other known species of the genus Hypsilurus are arboreal. Nothing further is known about the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: Extensive searches have been conducted on Palau in recent times and have failed to record any surviving populations of this large agamid. Although it is considered likely that the Palauan agamid is now extinct, It is not known what the causes of any decline were, nor whether, if a population survives, what threats it may be exposed to.
population: This species is known only from two specimens collected in 1867, and possibly from subfossil bones collected from an agamid of a similar size found in deposits on Palau (Bauer and Watkins-Colwell 2001). Anecdotal evidence indicates that an agamid lizard may have survived on Palau until at least the 1940s. A. Bauer (pers. comm. 2012) reports an account from a skilled amateur herpetologist who collected an agamid in Palau during the Second World War, although it is unknown from which island this record was taken. More recent, extensive surveys on Palau have turned up no evidence of surviving agamid lizards, however Hypsilurus species are elusive and the existence of an extant population (while unlikely) cannot be ruled out (A. Allison pers. comm. 2012).
range: This species is considered to be, or have been, endemic to Palau (having been collected on "Pelew"). There is however some uncertainty as to the whether the species was ever present on these islands, due to confusion over the provenance of the original collecting locality, and possibly this is due to a mislabeling of the only two specimens (see Bauer and Watkins-Colwell 2001). An agamid lizard of the same size is however known from subfossil deposits to have occurred on the Palauan island Ngeaur (Crombie and Pregill 1999).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is or was used.
conservationActions: Further research is needed to determine if this species is or was a Palauan endemic and is therefore likely to be globally extinct, or whether it is distributed elsewhere and has been extirpated from Palau. Extensive surveys already conducted have failed to record surviving agamid lizards on Palau.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species is known from only four specimens collected over a period of over a century, it has not been recorded since 1971, its distribution is uncertain, and there is no information on its population status, natural history or threats. Recent surveys have failed to record it on either Erromango or Aneityum and it is unknown to local people near the presumed collecting locality on the former island. It is consequently unclear whether this site has been misidentified, whether this is an extremely rare species, or whether it is genuinely extinct.
habitat: The 1971 record is of a specimen collected from inside a tent in a lumber camp (Cranbrook 1985). Nothing further is known about the habitat and ecology of the species, although Perochirus species are arboreal and other species have been found in coconut palms and arboreal ferns in a breadfruit tree (Brown 1976).
threats: Threats to this species, and the cause of its possible extinction, are unknown. Erromango is one of Vanuatu's major centres of logging operations, however, there is no information on this species' ecological requirements or sensitivity to disturbance. Invasive species have been implicated in declines and local extinction in the related species Perochirus ateles.
population: This species has only been collected on three occasions: in 1859 or 1860, in 1971, and reportedly between these dates in 1937 (Boulenger 1885, Cranbrook 1985). It has not been reported since 1971, and was not found in a week-long 2004 survey conducted close to the presumed site of the only named locality (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2013). The species does not appear to be familiar to local people and it is thought that the gecko may be extinct (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2011).
range:
This species is known only from four specimens. Two have the unspecific type locality "Erromango, New Hebrides" [=Vanuatu] (Boulenger 1885), and a third a century later is from Nuangkau lumber camp on the same island (Cranbrook 1985). This site appears to be close to Ipota in eastern Erromango, based on the map of the 1971 survey that recorded it (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2013); however, a 2004 survey of this area did not rediscover the species and local people did not recognize a description of the gecko (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2013).
A single record exists for Aneityum, the southernmost island of Vanuatu (Cranbrook 1985); however, while the collection date is given as 1937, it was not reported from this island by Medway and Marshall (1975), and it has not been collected here since then (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2013). Its presence on this island must therefore be considered uncertain (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2013).
useTrade: This species is not used or in trade.
conservationActions: Surveys during 2004 failed to locate any specimens (A. Hamilton pers. comm. 2011). There is a need for additional surveys of Erromango Island to confirm the continued survival of this species and, if found, to determine its distribution, population status, natural history and its exposure and sensitivity to any threats.

rationale: Acutotyphlops solomonis has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is known from Bougainville island in the Solomon islands and the south-west of Milne Bay Province in Papua New Guinea. It does not occur in any protected areas. Further research into this species' distribution, population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: Very little is known about the natural history of this fossorial species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. It is potentially threatened by predation by pigs and general development.
population: There is little population information available for this species. It is known only from a single specimen in mainland New Guinea.
range: This species occurs in the northern Solomon island of Bougainville and in Alotau in Milne Bay Province, Papua New Guinea (McCoy 2006). It has been recorded from sea level to 915 m asl.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in protected areas. Further research into this species distribution, population status, habitat and threats is recommended.

rationale: This species is poorly known due to its similarity to Mugil curema. It appears to be uncommon throughout its large range where it occurs over shallow soft bottom. It is not targeted, but is likely taken in mullet fisheries. Considering its wide distribution and lack of major threat, fisheries are not likely impacting its overall global population. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to conduct further research on its ecology and population trend.
habitat: Specimens from Margarita Island were collected over sandy and muddy substrates. Little other information is known about its ecology (Harrison et al. 2007). Size has been recorded up to 25.8 cm SL.
threats: It is not a target species, but may be caught with other mullets within its range. Because of the difficulties in identifying this species, and the limited information on population abundance, it is unclear if and to what extent fisheries may be impacting this species.
population: There is very little population information. It appears to be uncommon from Florida to Venezuela.
range: This species has been recorded in the western Atlantic from Cape Canaveral, Florida south into the upper Florida Keys and Florida Bay, and in the Caribbean from the Dominican Republic (Puerto Plata) through the Antilles to Colombia (La Guajira) (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is easily confused with M. curema (Harrison et al. 2007). It has now also been confirmed off Brazil from Para to Bahia (Menezes et al. 2015). There is at least one record off Tuxpan, Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico that requires verification.
useTrade: This species is not purposefully targeted. However, it may be taken in fisheries directed at Mugil curema, to which it is very similar.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species.

rationale: Heteroconger tricia was described on the basis of two specimens collected off Flores, Indonesia via trawl. It is listed as Data Deficient until more is known concerning its full distribution, population, habitats and ecology, and possible threats.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no population data available for this species, as it is currently only known from two specimens (Castle and Randall 1999).
range: This species known from two specimens collected at two localities off Flores, Indonesia, via trawl. There is no depth distribution available for this species (Castle and Randall 1999), but it is presumably a shallow-water species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full range, population, habitats and ecology, and threats.

rationale: This species is known only to the Philippines. There is no depth information. There are no population data available for this species as it is only  known from a handful of specimens and the holotype is no longer  available and presumed destroyed. There are no major threats known to affect this species, however there  is very little information on habitat, ecology, depth range, and other  factors contributing to understanding of threat magnitude. The range may overlap marine protected areas in  the Philippines. Because there is so little information concerning this species' full range, depth, population, habitats and ecology, and magnitude of threats, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no habitat and ecology information available for this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no population data available for this species as it is only known from a handful of specimens and the holotype is no longer available and presumed destroyed.
range: This species is known only to the Philippines (Herre 1923, Herre 1953, Smith 1989). There is no depth information.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for the protection of this species. However, the range may overlap marine protected areas in the Philippines.

rationale: Hemerhinus opici is known only from three specimens collected from Congo, Ghana and Senegal. This species is known only from the holotype, paratype, and an additional specimen from Ghana. While there are no species-specific threats to H. opici, its current known distribution is in a region of high habitat disturbance and pollution. Until there is more known about this species' range, population, habitat/ecology, and magnitude of possible threats, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a demersal species.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: Hemerorhinus opici is known only from the holotype, paratype and an additional specimen from Ghana.
range: Hemerhinus opici is known only from three specimens collected from Congo, Ghana and Senegal (Bauchot et al. 1993).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This deep-living species is widely distributed and uncommonly observed. Little is known on its habitat preferences due to its deep depth range, however, it is unlikely that it is being impacted by any major threat processes. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Little is known on the habitat preferences of this benthopelagic species due to its deep depth range.
threats: Due to its deep depth range, there are not likely to be any major threats.
population: There are 63 nominal records in Fishnet2, with up to three individuals in a single lot.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from the Bahamas and throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea (Smith et al. 1981).
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is currently only known from Saya de Malha Bank in the western India Ocean. There is no population information available for this species, as it is only known from a handful of specimens. Threats to this species are currently unknown, and there are no conservation measures in place. Because of the lack of data on this species' full range, population, habitats and ecology, and possible threats, Ariosoma ophidiophthalmus is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species as it is only known from the type specimens.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species, as it is only known from a few specimens.
range: This species is only known from Saya de Malha Bank in the western India Ocean. It is found from 110-115 m depth (Karmovskaya 1992).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species.

rationale: This deep-living species is known only from five very widely-spaced localities. It is likely to occur elsewhere, but its deep depth range is not often sampled. It occurs over soft bottom. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs over deep soft bottom habitat; little else is known.
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is currently known from five widely dispersed adult specimens.
range: This species has been recorded in the western Atlantic from Grand Bahama Island, Mexico (Cozumel), southwest of Curacao off Venezuela, and off Brazil from Cabo Frio and Rio Grande do Sul (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its depth range is 100-420 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place.

rationale: This species is found in the eastern Atlantic from Mauritania to St. Helena, and St. Paul's Rocks. The depth distribution of this species is unknown and there are no population data available for this species. There are very  few records available in collections and most do not date after the  1970s. This species is listed as Data Deficient until more is known about its full distribution, depth habitat, population, habitat/ecology and possible threats.
habitat: The habitat of this species is unknown.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no population data available for this species. There are very few records available in collections and most do not date after the 1970s.
range: This species is found in the eastern Atlantic from Mauritania, St. Helena, Ascension Island and St. Paul's Rocks. It has also been reported from India, but this specimen has not been verified. A sole depth record exists at 15 metres.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species.

rationale: This species is known only from its type locality at 22°35'S, 166°16'E of the southwestern coast of New Caledonia. Type specimens were collected at a depth of 50 m. There are no population data available for this species as it is only known from a handful of type specimens. This species is not utilized and while there are no species-specific threats to Bathycongrus trilineatus, it is well within the range of trawl fishing, especially shrimp trawls. There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species and as its range is not fully known, it is unknown if it is found in any protected areas. More research is needed concerning this species' range, population, habitat, ecology, and magnitude of threats. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information concerning this species' habitat/ecology, as it was described from leptocephali larvae stored in a museum collections from surveys off of New Caledonia.
threats: While there are no species-specific threats to Bathycongrus trilineatus, it is well within the range of trawl fishing, especially that of shrimp trawls.
population: There are no population data available for this species as it is only known from a handful of type specimens.
range: This species is known only from its type-locality at 22°35'S, 166°16'E of the southwestern coast of New Caledonia. Type specimens were collected at a depth of 50 m (Castle 1995, Castle and Smith 1999).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full range, population, habitats and ecology, and threats.

rationale: This species is found in the northwestern Pacific near Japan and the Korean peninsula. Currently, there is no population data available for this species, but it is considered to be rare. There are no major threats known to affect this species, but it may be impacted by heavy trawl fishing in the area. It is listed as Least Concern, with a need for more information concerning its taxonomy, depth, habitats and ecology, possible threats and their possible magnitude.
habitat: This is a demersal species that lives in marine and estuarine environments over soft-bottoms, to an unknown depth.
threats: There are no major threats known to affect this species. However, if it is restricted to shallower depths it may be subject to removal and habitat loss from the heavy trawl fishing in the area.
population: There are no population data available for this species, and it is considered to be rare and non-abundant.
range: This species is found from Sagami Bay south to Hakata Bay, northern Kyushu (Japan) and the southern Korean Peninsula (Mochioka et al. 2012). Depth information is unknown.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species' range overlaps some marine protected areas on both the Korean and Japanese regions of distribution. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full range, population, habitats and ecology, and threats.

rationale: Bascanichthys inopinatus is currently known only from a few specimens collected off Puerto Rico over sandy bottom between zero to 40 m depth in the 1960s and 70s. Due to the lack of data available regarding the ecology and full extent of its range, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known about the habitat or ecology of this species. It has been collected from sandy bottom. The maximum size is 81 cm (McCosker 2002).
threats: There are no species-specific threats known for B. inopinatus; however, since this species occurs at shallow depths, it may be subject to coastal pollution.
population: This species is known only from a few specimens (Accessed through Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 22 April 2013).
range: Bascanichthys inopinatus is known only from three specimens captured from two localities off Puerto Rico: Puerto Yabucoa and Crashboat Basin, Aguadilla (Academy of Natural Sciences and Florida Museum of Natural History - Accessed through Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2, 22 April 2013). Its depth range is zero to 40 m (McCosker 2002).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place. The known range of this species may overlap with marine protected areas off Puerto Rico (IUCN and UNEP 2013).

rationale: This species is known only from leptocephalus larvae collected in the Red Sea. It is listed as Data Deficient until more is known about its full distribution, population, habitats and ecology, and possible threats.
habitat: There is no information available concerning this species' habitats and ecology, as it is only known from its larvae.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no population data available for this species as it is only described from leptocephalus larvae.
range: This species is found in the Red Sea around the Kamaran Islands. It is known to depths of 522 m (Castle 1997).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full range, population, habitats and ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this snake is known from a very small number of historical specimens, it has not been collected since 1946, and nothing is known of its natural history or any threats.
habitat: Little is known of this species' natural history. It is fossorial and, in common with other thread snakes, is presumed to feed on ant larvae (Egan 2007).
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: Fewer than five specimens are known, the most recent collected in 1946. These fossorial snakes are very difficult to find and for non-specialists to recognize, and so it is not clear whether this reflects genuine rarity.
range: This species is known from southwestern Yemen at Khawbar and ad Dhali, the latter about 75 miles from Aden (Schätti and Desvoignes 1999). The two known sites are very close to one another. There is a need for further sampling to better determine the species' distribution range.
useTrade: There is no trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this little-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from the type series and has not been recorded for over 35 years. Nothing is known of its true distribution, its population status or its natural history.
habitat: Little is known about the natural history of this species. It is presumably nocturnal and feeds on lizards. It is believed to be oviparous (Egan 2007).
threats: No immediate threats have been identified to this species, although it is thought to have a rather limited distribution.
population: This species is only known from the three specimens in the type series (Leviton 1977).
range: This species is known only from a locality in the southeastern Asir Mountains of Saudi Arabia (Egan 2007) at 2,000 m asl. (Leviton 1977), and from one at sea level in the Tihama coastal plain (Leviton 1977). It is likely to occur in the Yemen borderlands (Leviton 1977), however surveys have not been conducted in this area as they are politically difficult to undertake (S. Busais pers. comm. February 2012).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to relocate this species and to establish whether it also occurs in neighbouring areas of Yemen, as well as to conduct research into its population status, natural history and threats. Taxonomic research is required on Lytorhynchus specimens from surrounding areas to establish their identity in case this species has been overlooked in more recent collections.

rationale: This snake is listed as Data Deficient as it is known from a single specimen, it has not been recorded since 1932, and nothing is known of its distribution, population status, biology or threats.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitat or biology of this snake. It may be nocturnal (Egan 2007), however other Rynchocalamus species have been found in the daytime (R. Sindaco pers. comm. February 2012) so this is unclear.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, and as its type locality is uncertain any human pressures on the site are likewise unknown.
population: This snake is known only from a single specimen. Although it is a conspicuously-coloured snake, it has not been recorded since 1932.
range: This snake is known only from a single specimen collected at an indeterminate locality near Aden, Yemen in 1932 (Schmidt, 1933). There are no more recent records (Egan 2007).
useTrade: This species is not traded.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution (the provenance of the type specimen is vague), abundance, natural history, and threats to this little-known species. Reexamination of the type specimen is recommended to establish the validity of this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient due to uncertainty about its taxonomic validity and the absence of information regarding its distribution, population status, natural history and threats.
habitat: There appears to be no information available on the habitats and ecology of this little-known species, which was described based on a museum specimen.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, described in 1978 and with an unknown collection date.
range: This poorly known species has been recorded from a single locality, Khasawiyah near Jizan in southwestern Saudi Arabia. Two published records from central Saudi Arabia (al-Sadoon 1988) are unreliable (Scähatti and Gasperetti 1994).
useTrade: There is no use or trade known for this species.
conservationActions: Further research is needed into the distribution, habitat, ecology and possible threats to this species. Taxonomic reexamination of the holotype is required to confirm its identity as a valid species. It is not known if the species occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from one specimen and there is no information available on its population size and trends, habitat, and threats. Research is needed to better determine the taxonomic status of this species, as well as its distribution, and population size and trends.
habitat: No ecological information is available for this species, although it is presumed to resemble D. pictus in making use of a wide range of native and artificial habitats, including secondary forest and rice fields (Lazell 2002). There is a report of an individual from the island possibly attributable to this species that was found on a road (Lazell 2002), however its identity cannot be verified.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species. To the extent that this species shares the broad adaptability of D. pictus, Lazell (2002) suggests that "it should not be habitat or resource limited" on Shek Kwu Chau.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is only known from one specimen. In recent years, there have been surveys in the island and no specimens have been found.
range: This snake is presumed endemic to the small island of Shek Kwu Chau in the South China Sea (Lazell 2002), a Chinese territory that forms part of the Islands District of Hong Kong.
useTrade: There is no information on use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place, although Shek Kwu Chau has been proposed as a site of special scientific interest (Lazell 2002). Research is needed to determine if this is a valid species. Efforts are needed to relocate this species, in order to obtain information on its distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is known only from a single specimen from an imprecise locality in Yunnan, China.
habitat: No ecological data is available for this species.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: Known from the type specimen only.
range: This snake is known from its type locality in 'Yunnan', China (Zhao and Adler 1993). No more precise locality data is available, and it is not mapped here.
useTrade: There is no information on use and trade in this snake.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. There is a need for further surveys in Yunnan to locate additional specimens of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from historical records, its validity is uncertain, and there is no information on its distribution, population status, natural history or threats.
habitat: No information is available on this species' habitat requirements.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population of this species, which is known only from historical records.
range: This lizard is known only from historical records from Kursi bei Aden in Yemen, and from one poorly-preserved historical specimen from Massawa, now in Eritrea (Bauer et al. 1995, Schätti and Desvoignes 1999).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known whether this species occurs in any protected areas. Research is needed to rediscover this species and to determine its validity, as well as to obtain data on its distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its taxonomic status, extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat or ecology of this species. The island is a low-lying coral atoll with some sandy patches.
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown, although the island is small and very remote.
population: There is a single known specimen, collected in 1964. It is unknown whether any further herpetological surveys have been carried out on Sarso Island.
range: This snake appears to be endemic to Sarso Island, within the Farasan Archipelago, Saudi Arabia.
useTrade: It is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There is a need for dedicated research into the distribution, habitat and ecology and threats to this species. It is not believed to occur in any protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient as it is known from a single historical specimen without a specific type locality, and nothing is known of its distribution, population status, natural history or threats.
habitat: There appears to be no information available on the habitat of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from the type specimen.
range: It is known only from the type specimen with the nonspecific type locality of 'Yemen'.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There is a need for dedicated surveys to rediscover this enigmatic species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from historical specimens, no recent surveys have been carried out on Cocos Island, and there is no information on this species' ecological requirements or exposure to threats.
habitat: No notes are associated with specimens, and so no ecological information is available.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: Nothing is known about the population of this species.
range: This snake is endemic to Cocos Island, an Indonesian territory off the coast of Sumatra. It was described based on five specimens, two from Simeulue and three from Cocos Island, north of Simeulue. The specimens from Simeulue are considered as Calamaria modesta, so only the three specimens from Cocos Island are assigned to this species.Up to the present there is no new collection performed from the Cocos island.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: Cocos Island has no conservation area. It is not known if the island is well populated or not.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient as the species has only been recently rediscovered, the true extent of its range on Taveuni is not known, and its population status, exposure and sensitivity to threats are likewise unknown.
habitat: This is a fossorial species, but its habitat requirements are unknown.
threats: Taveuni is free of mongoose and rats at present, and if these are introduced they may represent a threat. It is unknown whether other threats exist to this species.
population: This species was previously thought to be extinct, but is now known from a few recently-collected specimens (Morrison 2003).
range: This species is endemic to Taveuni Island, Fiji. Recent specimens are known only from the single locality of Vuna. It has not been recorded at any additional localities. It is found at elevations of around sea level to 1,250 m asl. Taveuni Island has an area of 441 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: Further surveys are needed for this elusive species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Oligolepis dasi is only known from two specimens collected from the south Andaman Islands. More information on this species' population, habitat, ecology and the impact of any threats is also needed. This species is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This marine species is extremely data poor and there is no information available on its life history and ecology.
threats: Given the overall paucity of data for this species, it is not possible to assess threats imposed upon it.
population: There is no population information for this species currently available.
range: Oligolepis dasi is poorly known, only recorded from 2 specimens in the south Andaman Islands, India (Kapoor et al. 2002).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Zebrias keralensis is known only from a few localities in the northeastern Indian Ocean. Limited information is available regarding its distribution, population size or trends, habitats or potential threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Information on the habitat and ecology of this species is unavailable.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: Population information is limited for this species as it is known from few specimens.
range: Zebrias keralensis is known from limited records: Pakistan and two localities along the western coast of India (Joglekar 1976, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, FishNet2 accessed on 14/08/2019). It has been reported from 5 to 18 m depth (FishNet2 accessed on 14/08/2019).
useTrade: Use and trade information for this species is not available.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The habitat and ecology for this snake is not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is endemic to the Nicobar Islands of India,. It has been recorded from the indistinct type locality of “Camorta in the Nicobars”. The altitudinal limit is unclear.
useTrade: There is not any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Much further information is needed on the taxonomy (including collection of fresh specimens), distribution (fixing the type locality), natural history, population and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen collected over 160 years ago from an imprecise locality, and nothing is known of its true distribution, population status, natural history or any threats.
habitat: This snake is oviparous. It was reportedly collected at an elevation of 2,100 m in Darjeeling (Das et al. 1998, Wallach et al. 2014). Nothing is known about the habitat at the type locality, which was identified imprecisely. Darjeeling itself is a major city, in which tourist activities are expanding, but there are some areas of good forest - suspected to be the natural habitat of this snake - in the vicinity.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species, which was described from an imprecise area over 160 years ago.
population: The holotype is lost, and this species has never been rediscovered. Several surveys have been conducted in Darjeeling, but no targeted searches for this species have been undertaken.
range: This species is known from a vague locality "India (near Darjeeling, West Bengal)" (Blyth 1854).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Surveys of the Darjeeling Hills are recommended in an effort to rediscover this species, and no further conservation measures can be proposed unless it is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its distribution, extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
