habitat: This little-known species is likely a terrestrial snake, but nothing additional is known about the natural history.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from the historical holotype.
range: This species is endemic to the Nicobar Islands of India, where it has been recorded from ‘Nancowry haven on Camorta' (Stoliczka 1870), although this appears to be an unconfirmed locality.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. Much further information is needed on the distribution, natural history, population and threats for this poorly-known snake.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has rarely been mentioned in the literature, and nothing is known of its distribution, population status, ecology or any threats.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat needs and natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of this species. The type locality has not been surveyed for this snake.
range: This species is known from eastern India, where it has a type locality in West Bengal (Darjeeling Hills) (Uetz et al. 2019); sight records from Sikkim (Chettri and Bhupathy 2007) need to be verified. This species appears to have rarely been mentioned in literature other than in checklists and its distribution is consequently unclear.
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Taxonomic research is needed, including the discovery of more material from the type locality to compare with reports elsewhere. It is not known if there are any populations within protected areas.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen collected in 1873 from an indeterminate locality thought to be in northern India. Both proposed localities are under heavy pressure, but it is uncertain either whether the species is more widespread or whether it genuinely occurs or occurred in either locality.
habitat: Nothing appears to be known of the ecology of this species, which seems not to have been reported since its original description from an indeterminate locality in India.
threats: Ambala has heavily urbanized and forested tracts have been converted for agriculture since this species was described. Kulu Valley under pressure from tourism and road construction and related development activities. Nonetheless nothing is known of its true distribution or whether it occurs or occurred in either locality.
population: The holotype, collected in 1873, remains the only known specimen (Constable 1949).
range: This species was probably collected in North India, likely from Ambala (Haryana) or the Kulu Valley (Himachal Pradesh).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species' range is unclear and it is unknown whether it occurs in protected areas, although there are none in either of the localities proposed as the likely type locality. Research is needed to rediscover it and clarify its distribution, including comparisons with any Indotyphlops material collected from the Ambala or Kulu Valley areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because there are no data on population size and trends, ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: This species' habitat is not known, but species in the genus usually occur in rocky outcrops. The species has been reported to occur at an elevation of about 3000 m asl (Baig et al. 2012).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to India (Ladakh, Kashmir, Haridwar, and upper Simla) (Stolickza 1871, Boulenger 1885, Baig et al. 2012). In Simla, it occurs at an elevation of 3,000 m. The type locality in Haridwar is questionable as it is in a lower elevation area, which does not correspond to the rest of its distribution.
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It has not been recorded in protected areas. Research is needed to better determine its distribution, population size and trends and the threats that may be affecting it. Taxonomic studies are also needed to distinguish this species from the more widely distributed Laudakia tuberculata.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from two specimens from a single locality, and nothing is known of its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: There is no data on the ecology of this species. The fort is on a hillock, surrounded by cultivated trees and cut grass (Duda and Sahi 1978).
threats: Any threats are unknown. The type locality is a tourist site.
population: There is no information on the population of this species, which may only be known from the type and one additional specimen (Agarwal et al. 2018).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Reasi Fort (Bhimba Fort), Reasi District, Jammu and Kashmir (Agarwal et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed into the taxonomy, distribution, ecology and population status of this species, and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single confirmed specimen collected nearly 150 years ago, and while records of an apparently related (and potentially conspecific) gecko elsewhere suggest it may be more widespread nothing is known of its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: Specimens referred to by Agarwal (2014) as cf. lawderanus were found both on stones and on the ground (Agarwal et al. 2014). Nothing is reported of the ecology of the type specimen.
threats: There is no information on any threats, and this species' range is unclear.
population: There is only one specimen from the type locality, which represents the only confirmed record of this species, and the identity of records elsewhere is in need of clarification (Agarwal et al. 2014).
range: There is only one confirmed locality of this species sensu stricto: Almora, Kumaon, eastern Uttarakhand, India. Records west of the type locality in Himachal Pradesh (C. Murthy pers. comm. 2019) and from Jammu and Kashmir may represent undescribed species, and are reported as cf. lawderanus by Agarwal et al. (2018).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Research is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of records away from the type locality, and to clarify the species' distribution, ecology, population status and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen which is doubtfully distinct from a widespread relative, and if valid it is possible that it may have been unrecorded as a result of taxonomic confusion.
habitat: Goalpura lies along the banks of the Brahmaputra River, but nothing else is known of its ecology.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is only known from a single specimen that exhibits overlapping characters with a widespread relative.
range: This species is only known from a single specimen from Goalpara, Assam, India.
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Taxonomic research needed to clarify this species validity, and if valid to determine whether other records exist that may have been confused with Takydromus sexlineatus.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that nothing is known of its population status, ecology or any threats and taxonomic research is needed to clarify its distribution.
habitat: These are sandy islands, but nothing is known of the lizard's ecology.
threats: There is no information on any possible threats.
population: Two specimens are known from the Nicobars. Although it seems widely distributed on Andamans, there are no data.
range: This species is known from the Andaman Islands, with records from South, Middle and North Andaman and Ritchie's Archipelago ( Sivaperuman and Venkataraman 2018). Records from islands other than South Andaman, and from records reported from the Nicobar Islands (Great Nicobar, from Campbell Bay [1966], and Little Nicobar [1994] - K. Deuti pers. comm. 2019) may require verification to clarify their identity, although the differences between the holotype and the Nicobar specimens were regarded as "understandable" by Das (1997).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There is a record from Campbell Bay National Park. Taxonomic research is needed, along with clarification of its distribution, population status, ecology and any threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is only known from the type series collected in the 19th century from an unknown locality in Ecuador. Given the uncertainty about the provenance of the type specimen and the lack of subsequent records, nothing is known about the potential range, threats, population status, or protected area status of this species. Taxonomic research is needed to revalidate the taxonomic status of the species.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species are unknown.
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown.
population: No population information is available for this species, which is apparently known only from the original collection in the 19th century.
range: This lizard was reported from "Ecuador" by Boulenger (1890). No additional locality information is available.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Taxonomic revision and a review of material in collections is needed to determine whether any further examples of this taxon exist and to clarify the status of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, population status, ecological requirements, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality Perico, in the Cajamarca region of Peru (Peters and Orejas-Miranda 1970).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to obtain additional material and to clarify this species' full distribution, natural history, and the identity and impact of any threats.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient because of continuing uncertainty concerning the distribution, natural history and potential threats to this species.
habitat: Nothing is known of its ecology as there is no information on the specific island where it was taken and the Nicobar Islands vary in their natural vegetation cover.
threats: Any threats unknown.
population: This species is known from one specimen, and it has not been recorded for more than a century.
range: This species is known only from the type with the nonspecific locality "Nicobar Islands" (Harikrishnan and Vasudevan 2019).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to rediscover this species and identify the type locality.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is only known from the type series, and no information is available on its distribution, population status, natural history or any threats.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this species are unknown.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: There is no information on the population of this species. The type series contains four specimens (Wallach and Boundy 2005).
range: This snake is known from Oyo State in the Western Region of Nigeria,  where it is known from the vicinity of Ibadan University Zoological  Garden (7º23'N, 3º54'E), ca. 150 m asl. (Wallach and Boundy 2005).
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. Research is needed to relocate this species and to obtain information on its distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from only two specimens, which may not in fact be conspecific, it has not been recorded for more than 50 years, and nothing is known of its true distribution, natural history, or its exposure or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: Species of this genus are small fossorial species that feed mainly on termites and insect larvae. One of the two known specimens was collected from the stomach of a coral snake (Micrurus mipartitus), and its natural habitat is entirely unknown.
threats: There is no information on this species' ecology or the true extent of its distribution, and it is therefore unknown whether it is subject to any threats.
population: This species is known only from the two specimens in the type description, having been described in 1964.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia, where it has been found highly disjunctly from two Andean localities: Florencia (on the east versant of Cordillera Oriental) and in Sonsón (on the east versant of Cordillera Central) (Pinto et al. 2010).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Surveys are needed to rediscover this species, which has not been recorded since its original description, and to obtain information on its ecology and any threats. The two known localities are highly disjunct and biogeographically unlikely to represent a single species (J.C. Arredondo pers. comm. 2013), and taxonomic work is required to determine whether they are in fact conspecific.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from two specimens collected in the early 20th Century and there has been little effort to try and rediscover it. Although the known localities are in an area that has been subject to extensive clearance of the natural habitat for urban development and associated activities, it is unknown to what degree this species is reliant on natural habitats, or whether it is more widespread. It may therefore be at risk or possibly extinct, if it is restricted to the Guyaquil area, or it may be more widespread and adaptable and so subject to no major threats across its range.
habitat: The habitat is unknown.
threats: Most of the natural habitat in the vicinity of Guayaquil has been destroyed for industrial development, urban expansion, cattle ranching and agriculture (rice, fruits and vegetables). As nothing is known of this species' ecological tolerances or broader distribution, it is unknown whether these represent major threats.
population: This species is known only from the type specimens collected in the early 20th century and no further records have been obtained. However, there has been little effort to relocate the species in the vicinity of Guayaquil. If this species still occurs in the Guayaquil area, the population of this species is likely to be small, as the area harbors one of the biggest cities in Ecuador, it is heavily influenced by human activities and most natural habitats have been destroyed or altered (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016).
range: Trilepida guayaquilensis is known from two specimens collected in Guayaquil, Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016). Recorded at 4 m asl.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown if the species occurs in a protected area. One protected area, Manglares Churute Ecological Reserve, is located near the range of this species. Surveys are needed in remaining habitats in Guayaquil to attempt to relocate the species. Also, unidentified Trilepida specimens in collections should be examined to determine if any pertain to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because nothing is known about this species, including the type locality. As the only known specimen was lost during the Second World War, obtaining new data or verifying the identity of any future 'rediscovery' will be very difficult.
habitat: No data are available on this lizard's ecology.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species..
population: Nothing is known about the population status of this species, which is known only from the holotype. The holotype appears to have been destroyed during the Second World War (Gans 1987).
range: This species was described based on one specimen from "Lagos, Sierra Leone" and has not been found in any other country (Gans 1987). This locality is questionable and no similar specimens have been identified from Sierra Leone; moreover no locality with the name Lagos is known in this country (Gans 1987). Morphologically the holotype resembled western West African species, suggesting that the "Lagos" in question is not the Nigerian megalopolis (Gans 1987).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: No conservation measures can be applied to this species unless it is rediscovered. In the absence of a known type locality, it is not possible to suggest research that can realistically be undertaken to relocate this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, because while it is very poorly-known the species has been recorded from a large area of presumably suitable habitat with no apparent threats.
habitat: No habitat information for this fossorial species is currently available (Pauwels and Vande Weghe 2008). It is unclear whether this is a forest dependent species.
threats: The threats are not well-known, is seems probable that there are no threats to the species in the remote area of Gabon that it has been recorded from (L. Chirio pers comm. 2019).
population: This species is known only from the type specimen.
range: This species is only known from a single specimen collected about 50 km southwest of Lambaréné, which is located on the boundary between the provinces of Moyen-Ogooué and Ogooué- Maritime. Because of the river access routes from Lambaréné, this species would only occur within  the province of Middle Ogooué. This species is listed as endemic to Gabon (Pauwels and Vande Weghe 2008).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It occurs in Bas Ogooué, a Ramsar Site (Wetland of International Importance) (Vande Weghe et al. 2016). Additional research is needed into the natural history of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that it is only known with certainty from the original description.
habitat: No data are available on its ecology, although it is reported to occur in ant hills (Gans 1987).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of this species because it is known only from three localities. Gans (1987) reports only six specimens, none of which appear to have been collected after 1881.
range: This species is known from Akropong, Christians Village and Somanya Krobo, all in the same region of southwestern Ghana (Gans 1987). A single specimen with the locality data "Sierra Leone" is "presumably an error" (Gans 1987). Recorded from sea level up to 500 m.
useTrade: This species is not known to be used or traded.
conservationActions: Research is required to rediscover this species and clarify its distribution, population status, natural history and threats, because it is only known from the description and one doubtful locality.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient.on the basis that this species is known only from its type description, based on a museum specimen, and has not been collected since 1963. There is consequently no information on its distribution, population status, natural history or any threats.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this species, which was described based on a museum specimen.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known only from the holotype collected in 1963.
range: This species is only known from the type locality Wenchi, "about 60 mi north and slightly east" of Kumasi in <span class="page_assessment_classScheme_content">Ghana (Gans 1987).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to rediscover this species, and if relocated to obtain data on its distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since the early 19th century, and extensive searches have failed to locate this species.
habitat: There is no information on this species other than it being terrestrial. Similar species are crepuscular predators found in undergrowth.
threats: The causes of extinction are believed to be habitat loss, colonization by people of Tonga, along with associated predators such as dogs, pigs and rats.
population: This species is considered to be extinct.
range: This species was endemic to Tonga.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures needed for this extinct species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecological preferences, although its requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and this species likewise presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, and there have been no subsequent records of it since its discovery, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, "Buala am Uam, Neu Kamerun".   Frétey (2007) recently located the type locality in Bouala,  at 998 m asl, in Central African Republic.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: Its taxonomic validity needs to be reassessed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecological preferences, although its requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and it likewise presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, and there have been no subsequent records of it since its discovery, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, "Buala am Uam, Neu Kamerun". Frétey (2007) recently located the type locality in Bouala,  at 998 m asl, in Central African Republic.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: Its taxonomic validity needs to be reassessed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecological preferences, although its requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and it likewise presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, and there have been no subsequent records of it since its discovery, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, "Buala am Uam, Neu Kamerun".   Frétey (2007) recently located the type locality in Bouala, at 998 m asl, Central African Republic.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: Its taxonomic validity needs to be reassessed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is only known from two specimens collected over a century ago, and the type locality is not known, not even the country of origin is certain.
habitat: There is no information known about the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: There is no information known about threats to this species.
population: It is only known from two syntypes collected over a century ago.
range: The type locality is recorded as "South Africa", however, there is significant doubt regards the origin of the only two syntypes of this species, and somewhere in Southeast Asia may be more plausible.
conservationActions: The taxonomic validity of this species needs to be determined.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements as well as on continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.
habitat: No information available on the species' habitat and ecology.
threats: No major threats are known for this species.
population: No population status information is currently available for this species.
range: Rhinella alata's distribution is poorly documented; the type locality is in Panama but the population currently allocated to this name is in Venezuela north of the Orinoco River, possibly also in northern Colombia (Frost, 2007).
conservationActions: No conservation measures are known for this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information available on this species' habitat and ecology.
threats: No major threats are known for this species.
population: No population status information is currently available for this species.
range: Hyloxalus maculosus is only known from "Puyo, between Turingia and theatre, 950 m, Provincia Pastaza, Ecuador" (Frost, 2007).
conservationActions: No conservation measures are known for this species.

rationale: The species is only known from a very restricted area. There are no records since 1980s despite two surveys. The species might be extinct. Assessed as Critically Endangered (CR); further surveys are urgently required to determine whether the species persists.
habitat: Only females have been found. Unknown, habitats may be similar to M. aurascens, including forest, scrub and roosts in underground sites.
threats: Unknown, destruction of roost sites might be threat to the population.
population: Population size unknown, the species is known only from five sites, probably of records from nursery colonies (no male individuals have yet been recorded). There are no proved records since 1980s. There have been 2 surveys, although effort was only three days in one case, a second survey in 2003 specifically for this bat did not find the species (K. Tsytsulina pers. comm. 2008) - it might be extinct. Only thirty specimens are in museum collections.
range: Rare species, endemic of the basin of the Sevan Lake, Armenia (ca. 4000 sq. km, above 1800 m a.s.l.).
conservationActions: Poorly known species with very restricted range and which requires legal protection and a conservation management plan. Research on status, ecology, threats and conservation measures is needed. Public awareness campaigns may also be valuable.

rationale: This species is found in a restricted range (area of occupancy is <2,000 km²); there are recent records from European Turkey but these were very difficult to collect (involved years of collecting effort). It is known from more than 15 sites and its range is fragmented. The vast majority of potential habitat has converted to agriculture, and the remaining areas are severely fragmented and probably subject to ongoing decline. Consequently it qualifies for Vulnerable (VU B2ab(iii)). More data and a reassessment in a few years are required.
habitat: It inhabits scrub and semi-open habitats with trees or bushes such as orchards, vineyards, hedgerows in arable land, and river banks. Although it is found in some extensively managed agricultural habitats, it is absent from intensively farmed areas. It is more terrestrial than other dormice, and its diet consists for the most part of seeds.
threats:
The range of this species is in decline. In European Turkey, most of its habitat has been transformed by agriculture. In spite of intensive searches the species has not been found over the last five years. It is clear that the range is shrinking.

It is very difficult to determine what is happening with the range because it is the exact habitat preferences are not known. It has been declining since the Pleistocene. Only 50 animals are known in collections. The region in European Turkey and Bulgaria is intensively cultivated, with very little natural habitat remaining.
population:
Little is known about this restricted-range species. In Turkish Thrace there are only definite records from a small number of sites. Until recently, despite intensive searches, the species was not found at all for at least 5 years (SW Asia workshop 2005). Very recently (within the last three years) there were several specimens collected, but this species remains very difficult to find and collect (B. Krystufek pers. comm. 2007).

Throughout its distribution the vast majority of suitable habitat has been converted to intensive agriculture, and the species' range is severely fragmented and subject to ongoing losses (SW Asia workshop 2005).
range:
Endemic to the Mediterranean region. The mouse-tailed dormouse is found in Bulgaria and Turkey (both European and Asian Turkey). It may also occur in eastern Greece. It is mainly a lowland species.

This species is found in southeast Bulgaria through Thrace (Kurtonur and Ozkan, 1990) and western Turkey (Storch, 1978). The exact limits are unknown in western Anatolia, where the species is presently known from only three separate localities. The species was first described as a fossil species in 1937, and was only described as an extant species in the late 1940s. Subfossil information from southern Turkey and Israel indicated a larger range over the last few thousand years. The last published records in Bulgaria are from 1985.
conservationActions: It is listed on Appendices II and III of the Bern Convention. Surveys are needed to determine if and where the species can still be found, and sites where the species is found should be strictly protected. This species is not found in any protected areas.

rationale: Foa madagascariensis has been assessed as Data Deficient. This species is only known from two specimens which have since been lost. There is doubt regarding the validity of this species.
habitat: Foa madagascariensis has been collected at a depth range of five to six m in coastal waters.
threats: It is unknown whether Foa madagascariensis is being impacted by any major threat processes.
population: Foa madagascarensis is only known from two specimens.
range: Foa madagascariensis is only known from the type locality, Saradrano, Tulear, Madagascar.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, however it may be found in at least one of the five marine protected areas around Madagascar.  Further research on the taxonomy of this species is required with further collections being made at the type locality (O. Gon pers. comm. 2009).

rationale: Thamnaconus melanoproctes has been assessed as Data Deficient. The species is known from very few specimens, and shows a wide, but very disjunct range and there are taxonomic issues: it may be a synonym of Thamnaconus multilineatus. This taxonomic issue must be rectified and further research into this species is needed in order to determine if this species is being impacted by any major threats before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: The Blackvent Filefish, Thamnaconus melanoproctes, is a demersal species that has a depth range of 30–200 m.
threats: It is unknown if Thamnaconus melanoproctes is being impacted by any major threats, however it may be taken as by-catch like its ecologically similar congener Thamnaconus fajardoi which is taken incidentally by bottom trawls (FAO 1984). Current fishing methods in the Arabian Sea have resulted in overexploitation of coastal resources, and this is mostly due to large fishing vessels that fish illegally near the coast (NOAA 2004).
population: There is no population information available for Thamnaconus melanoproctes.
range: Thamnaconus melanoproctes is found from the Gulf of Oman to Western Australia (Matsuura pers. comm. 2009).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Thamnaconus melanoproctes.

Further research into the distribution, habitat, population numbers of this species is needed in order to determine if this species is being impacted by any major threat process.

rationale: Balistes rotundatus has been assessed as Least Concern. This wide-ranging species is not known to face any major threats. Further research on the ecology and threats faced by this species could clarify if it is in fact a component of coastal fisheries.
habitat: Balistes rotundatus is a pelagic, coastal species. Species from the family Balistidae can occur from the coastline to a depth of 100 m and feed on bottom invertebrates (FAO 2001). Further information is needed on the specific ecological requirements of this species.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threat is impacting this species, however, the Balistidae family are highly valued as food in many handline fisheries, and also taken as by-catch in commercial trawls (FAO 2001).
population: There is no population information available for Balistes rotundatus.
range: Balistes rotundatus is an Indo-West Pacific triggerfish reported from India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Japan and the Marshall Islands and Cook Islands.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Balistes rotundatus, however it may be found to occur in a number of marine protected areas.

Further research is needed on the threats, ecology and distribution of this species.

rationale: Cynoglossus maccullochi has been assessed as Data Deficient. This species is currently only known from a single locality. Due to difficulties in identifying the cynoglossid species, it may in fact have a broader range and may also be taken as by-catch in the cynoglossid fisheries. Further research on the distribution, taxonomy and population trends of this species is needed before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: The type specimen was a trawl specimen (G. R. Allen pers. comm. 2009). Nothing further is known on the biology or ecology of this species. Cynoglossids are difficult to identify due to the similarity between species (J. G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2009).
threats: It is unknown if Cynoglossus maccullochi is being impacted by any major threats. This species may occasionally be taken as by-catch by trawlers operating within its range (J. G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2009).
population: There is no population information available for Cynoglossus maccullochi.
range: Cynoglossus maccullochi is known from the holotype (type locality Hummocky Island, north of Curtis Island) on the east coast of Australia off Queensland. This species is likely to have a wider distribution however due to difficulties in identifying this species the distribution is uncertain (J. G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2009).
useTrade: Cynoglossus maccullochi may be harvested in Cynoglossidae fisheries, individual statistics for species' of this family are not available.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Cynoglossus maccullochi.

Further research is needed on the taxonomy and distribution of this species.

rationale: Oneirodes epithales has been assessed as Data Deficient, as it has only been described from a single specimen collected in the northwest Atlantic Ocean. It is unknown whether threats are acting on this species and further research is needed before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be made.
habitat: Oneirodes epithales is a deep water species. The only known specimen was caught at a depth of 1,829 m.
threats: It is not known whether Oneirodes epithales is being impacted by any major threat processes.
population: There is currently no population information available for Oneirodes epithales.
range: A single specimen of Oneirodes epithales was found in the northwestern Atlantic, approximately 800 km south of Newfoundland (Orr 1991).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Oneirodes epithales.

Due to the lack of information available for this species, research should be conducted on its distribution, ecology and potential threats.

rationale: This species is known from only five individuals, and little is known about its distribution, population status, habitat requirements, or threats. Kazuko's False Moray, Chlopsis kazuko, has been assessed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: This species is thought to be found on sand and coralline-rubble substrata as the holotype was taken with sand by a dredge at 95 m. However, the habitat requirements and ecology of this species are unclear.
threats: It is unknown if there are any major threats to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Only five individuals are known.
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Tropical Pacific. However, it is only known from five individuals, and no additional records have been made since 1988 (Lavenberg 1988). This species distribution may range from the tip of Baja California and from Jalisco, Mexico to Costa Rica. However, its currently known distribution is very disjunct and is represented by the locations of the only known individuals (Lavenberg 1988). These include the holotype from Boca de la Trinidad, Gulf of California; and 3 pelagic leptocephali: 1 from Arroyo de San Luis, Gulf of California; 1 from Costa Rica, and 1 from near Malpelo Island, Colombia.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures for this species. This species is poorly known, and more research is needed on this species distribution, population status, habitat requirements and threats.

rationale: Xestochilus nebulosus has been assessed as Least Concern, due to its large distribution in the Indo-Pacific.  This species is not thought to be undergoing a population decline, and appears to have very generalist habitat preferences.
habitat: Xestochilus nebulosus is a demersal species found in tropical waters.  It is a benthopelagic species, found at a depth range of 2–42 m.  As with many members of the family Ophichthidae, there is little known about its habitat or ecology (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2008).  These species are sand and mud-burrowers, and do not seem to be limited to a small geographic area.  Their rarity in collections is mostly a result of the difficulty in sampling them.  Many species in the family are widely distributed, and none seem to occupy a unique habitat (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2008).
threats: It is unlikely that Xestochilus nebulosus is being impacted by any major threat processes.
population: There is no population information available for Xestochilus nebulosus.
range: Xestochilus nebulosus is an Indo-Pacific snake eel, reported from Mozambique, the Seychelles, Israel, India, the Marquesas Islands, Indonesia, Palau, and the Marshall Islands.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place, or needed, for Xestochilus nebulosus.  However, the distribution of this species may coincide with a number of designated marine protected areas, including several around the Seychelles.

rationale: Cabillus macrophthalmus has been assessed as Data Deficient.  This species is known from only a few specimens collected in Indonesia.  Further research is needed on its distribution, abundance and potential threats before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be made.
habitat: Cabillus macrophthalmus is a demersal goby.  The type specimen was collected from a dredge trawl over a coral bottom at a depth range of 120-400 m; very few gobies are collected in this depth range.  The only known specimen was 30 mm, however its congener, Cabillus atripelvicus, is known to reach a size of 41 mm.
threats: It is unknown whether Cabillus macrophthalmus is being impacted by any major threat processes, however most gobiids are of no commercial or recreational importance (Larson and Murdy 2001).
population: There is no population information available for Cabillus macrophthalmus.
range: Cabillus macrophthalmus is known from only one specimen collected at Djampeah Island, Indonesia (the type locality) (Randall et al. 2007).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Cabillus macrophthalmus. Further research is needed on its distribution, abundance, ecology and potential threats.

rationale: Thamnaconus fijiensis has been assessed as Data Deficient. This species is only known from three specimens and there is therefore very little information avilable for this species. Thamnaconus fijiensis is thought to be rare and before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made further research is needed.
habitat: Thamnaconus fijiensis is a demersal species that has been collected at a depth range of 130 to 210 m although its true depth range is yet to be determined.
threats: It is unknown whether Thamnaconus fijiensis is being impacted by any major threats.
population: Thamnaconus fijiensis is reported to be rare (Matsuura 1999).
range: The rare filefish Thamnaconus fijiensis, is only known from three specimens collected from Fiji, New Caledonia and Kii Peninsula, Japan.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Thamnaconus fijiensis.

Further research is needed on the biology, ecology, population numbers, potential threat processes, and distribution of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Other than it being a burrowing snake, there is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is probably known only from the lost holotype.
range: This species is endemic to southwestern Iran where it is known only from the type locality of "Maidan Mihaftan, 30 miles east of Schustar in southwest Persia".
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place; it is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, reproduction and ecology of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There currently appears to be no information available on the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
population: This species is known only from the holotype and paratype.
range: This species is known only from the Philippines, where the indistinct collection details of the type series, only 'Philippines' is recorded, means that the range remains very poorly known (Brown and Alcala 1980).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, reproduction and ecology of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements. The species is only known from the holotype and no precise data is available on where it was collected.
habitat: There appears to be little, if anything, known about the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: This poorly known snake might be endemic to the Philippines, as it is known only from the 1846 holotype labelled "Manlia, Philippines" (Ota 2000). It is possible that the species was not collected from the Philippines, but was brought to the country and mistakenly tagged as collected in Manila.
conservationActions: Studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, ecology, and possible threats to this poorly-known species.

rationale: This species is only known from two specimens, both collected in 1917. The area in which it was found is protected, and does not seem to have changed much over the past century (there is a mix of agricultural areas and forest).  Further research is needed on the ecology, abundance, range, and conservation status of this species.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this little-known snake.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. The area of Luzon where the species was collected is a mix of forest and agricultural areas, and has probably not changed much over the past 100 years.
population: This species is known only from two old 1917 specimens.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippine Islands, where it is known only from Luzon, with a single specimen collected at Balbalan and another at Kalinga, both collected in 1917. There is a record from Mindoro, although this may be in error. The specimens on Luzon were collected at around 850 m asl.
conservationActions: The area in which the species was found is protected within Balbalasang-Balbalan National Park. Further research is needed on the distribution, ecology, abundance, threats, and conservation status of this poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: While little is known about the species natural history, it is likely to be found in loose soil and leaf litter within wooded habitats. It is not known if the species can persist in modified habitats.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information on the abundance of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines, where it has been recorded from the islands of Negros, Marinduque, Bohol, Camotes, Luzon, Mindanao and Mindoro (McDiarmid et al. 1999).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, general ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There are no details of the species ecological needs.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It appears to be known only from the holotype specimen.
range: This very poorly known species is known only from the indefinite locality of "Filipinas", and is probably from Luzon Isand in the Philippines (Taylor 1922, McDiarmid et al. 1999). It is not mapped here owing to the uncertainty of its range.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Taylor (1963), does not provide any details on the habitat and ecology for either of the two known specimens. It is not known if it can persist in degraded habitats.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from the type series.
range: This species is known only from two specimens collected at circa 1,980 m asl in mountains near Banaue, Mountain Province, northern Luzon Island, the Philippines (Taylor 1963).
conservationActions: It is possible that the species might occur in the nearby Balbalasang-Balbalan protected area, however, this requires confirmation. General field studies are needed into the distribution, ecological requirements and potential threats to this poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The natural history of this species is poorly known, but it is likely to be associated with forest or similar wooded habitats.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. If it is associated with forest habitats, then deforestation through logging and conversion of land to alternative uses are probable threats.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: This poorly known species is endemic to the Philippines, where it is known only from the type locality of "Tarabucan, four miles southeast of spur of Sigarag Mountains, Matuguinao Municipality, extreme northern Western Samar".
conservationActions: The species is within the proposed Samar Island Natural Park. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats to this poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There appears to be little recorded about the habitat from which this species was collected. Other members of this genus usually require reasonably intact forest, and are somewhat fossorial in nature.
threats: The threats to this species are poorly-known, but as it seems likely to be a forest obligate, ongoing deforestation on Mindanao (e.g., for conversion of land to banana and pineapple plantations) appears to be a threat to the species (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).
population: This snake is known only from the type specimen.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines where it is known only from the type locality of Malalag, Kibwalan, Davao del Sur in South Cotabato, Mindanao Island Island. The location of the type locality appears to be unclear and the species is not mapped here.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. There is a need to conserve any remaining areas of suitable forest close to the type locality of the species. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, general ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: Although little is known about the natural history of this species, the holotype was collected in a shrub, approximately two metres from the ground in the evening (Ota and Ross 1994). The habitat from which it was collected is unclear from the species description.
threats: There is currently no data available on the major threats to the species.
population: The species is recently-described, and may only be known from the two animals in the type series.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines, where it is collected only from the northern part of the Cordillera Central (Barrio  Cabatacan, Lasam, Cagayan Province and Butiqui, Mountain Province) on Luzon Island (Ota and Ross 1994). It appears to be a lowland species.
conservationActions: The species may potentially occur in the Balbalasang-balbalan protected area, as this is close to the area of specimen collection. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, natural history and possible threats to this snake.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species is known only from two specimens collected from Balbalan, in Mountain Province, Luzon Island, the Philippines in the 1920s. No recent data is available for the species.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species is poorly-known, with little information other than it is known only from high elevations in the mountains of northern Luzon. The species was collected within the vicinity of Balbalan, which seems to be an agricultural area, but with forest nearby.
threats: The major threats to the species are not known. If it persists in agricultural areas, chemical pollution may pose a threat to the species.
population: There are currently no details available on the abundance of this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Balbalan, in Mountain Province, Luzon Island, the Philippines. Two specimens were collected at 950 m asl in the 1920s. Earlier reports from Catanduanes Island are likely to be in error (R. Brown pers. comm. 2007).
conservationActions: The species was collected within the Balbalasang-Balbalan protected area. Further research is needed on the ecology, abundance, range, and conservation status of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species has not been recorded since the 1940s, and is only known from three specimens (two localities). There is likely continued decline in the species habitat extent and quality. However, further research is needed before assessing the threat status of this species.
habitat: There currently appears to be no information available on the natural history of this species.
threats: Habitat loss due to deforestation is likely to be the threat for this species.
population: There are currently no details available on the abundance of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the island of Palawan in the Philippines, where it was collected in the Thumb Peak and Brooke's Point area in the 1920s and 1940s (three specimens in two localities). It was collected at around 300 m asl.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats to this poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The species was collected during an excavation for a church and during the ploughing of a field (Brown and Alcala 1980). No further details about the natural history of this species are available.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are currently no details available on the abundance of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines, where it is known only from two specimens collected in Baguio in the mountains of norther Luzon during the early 1900's (Brown and Alcala 1980).  It was collected at about 900 m asl.
conservationActions: The species was not collected in a protected area, and it is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats to this poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: Nothing is known about the natural history of this species. Other members of the genus are small burrowing species, usually associated with forest habitats.
threats: There is extensive, often illgegal, logging underway in the Sulu Archipelago. Much of this timber is transported to Malaysia and Mindanao.
population: This species is known only from holotype.
range: This poorly known snake has only been recorded from an indistinct locality in the Sulu Archipelago of the Philippines. It may have been collected on the island of Sulu. The maps shows the possible range of this species including the islands of Sibutu, Bongao, Sanga-sanga, and the small island between Tawi-Tawi and Jolo.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measure in place for this species, and it is not known if it is present in any protected areas. There is an urgent need to conserve remaining areas of forest within the Sulu Archipelago. Field studies are needed to determine the range, habitat requirements and threats to this species.

rationale: Agama bocourti has been assessed as Data Deficient due to the lack of population and accurate distribution data available, and uncertainty about any threats to the species. Further research is therefore needed before a more accurate assessment of the conservation status of A. bocourti can be carried out.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species.
threats: This species is found within a range that is experiencing habitat loss  and degradation due to agricultural expansion, overgrazing, and possible  logging activity, however, the impact of these threats on the species is not known.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species was originally reported from Gambia and southern Senegal and in "Mélacorée" which may refer to a locality in Guinea (Rochebrune 1884).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research and monitoring of the population, distribution, biology and ecology, habitat status, and threats to this species should be carried out.

rationale: Nothing is known about the range, habitat or population of this species so it has to be listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information available. Other species of Pseudoacontias have been found in forest leaf litter; however, as no species in this genus is known from more than one specimen (Glaw and Vences 2007) it is difficult to draw conclusions about this lizard's ecological requirements on that basis alone.
threats: There is no information available.
population: There is no information available.
range: This species is endemic to Madagascar (Glaw and Vences 2007). The precise locality is unknown, but all other known species in the genus have been found in the north of the island (Glaw and Vences 2007). The type collection was made over 120 years ago.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There is no information available on whether this species occurs in areas subject to conservation management. Surveys are needed to try and rediscover this species and obtain information on its distribution, population status, ecological requirements and exposure to threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that very little is known about this species' distribution, population status, ecology or threats. All collections are historical and there is no indication of the habitat in which the specimens were collected. It is possible that this species was confined to lowland humid forest and with forest clearance it has disappeared.
habitat: The habitat for this species is not known. It is probably a burrowing species and, based on the apparent habitat preferences of other Paracontias skinks, may have been found either in lowland humid forest or in more sandy areas.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. It is possible that it may have been impacted by forest clearance for agriculture and through logging, but there is no information on its sensitivity to these processes.
population: There is no available information on the population of this species. All collected specimens are historical and the species has not been recorded by any recent expedition (M. Vences pers. comm. January 2011), although neither of the small islands where this lizard has been recorded have been subject to recent, intensive surveys (M. Vences pers. comm. May 2011).
range: This species is endemic to northern Madagascar where it is known from the islands of Nosy Mitsio and Nosy Mamoko (Andreone et al. 2003) off the northwest coast. Extensive surveys of Nosy Be, a larger island 70 km from Nosy Mistio, have never recorded this species. It may also occur in Marojejy in northeast Madagascar (Glaw and Vences 2007). The skink's extent of occurrence, based on the combined area of these three sites, is 626 km².
useTrade: This species is not traded or used.
conservationActions: The presence of species has yet to be confirmed in any protected areas, and it is not clear whether this lizard is in need of protection or, conversely, whether it still exists. Targeted surveys are needed to relocate this species, to confirm whether it is found in Marojejy or other mainland sites, and to obtain information on its population status, ecological requirements, exposure to and sensitivity to threats.

rationale: The species is known from only three specimens, from at least two localities, and has not been seen since 1939. There is no information on its biology, ecology or habitat, nor on the current status or extent of the population and what threats the species might be facing. The lack of recent records may reflect inadequate search efforts or methods. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is presumed to be fossorial. Nothing is known of the species' habitat, biology or ecology.
threats: There is no data on threats to this species. It is potentially at risk to forest clearance leading to removal of habitat or soil desiccation and to competition from the recently introduced Ramphotyphlops braminus.
population: Nothing is known of population size or trends. May have suffered a population decline and/or reduction in extent through the removal of natural forest cover.
range: This species is endemic to Province des Iles, New Caledonia. It has been recorded only from Lifou and Maré islands. It is known from only three specimens. Only one of the three specimens has a named locality i.e. the village of Netché, on Maré. Although this village is close (<500 m) to the coast and backed by slopes with closed littoral forest, it is the place where Sarasin and Roux stayed during their expedition and there is no clear indication that it is exactly where the specimen was collected (Roux 1913). It occurs at elevations of up to 150 m. The extent of occurrence is approximately 1,848 km² (estimated from the area of  the islands), and the area of occupancy is estimated to be <1,848 km².
conservationActions: This species is protected in Province Sud under Code de l'environnement de la Province Sud (Délibération No. 25-2009/APS, 20 March 2009) but not protected in Province Nord under Code de l'environnement de la Province Nord (Délibération No. 306-2008/APN, 24 October 2008). It is not present in any reserves and there is no specific conservation management for this species.

rationale: Only very few specimens exist and some experts think that this species is conspecific with B. albus. There is no information on its ecology, although it is suspected to be terrestrial. The major threats to this species are unknown. This species is therefore listed as Data Defficient.
habitat: Nothing has been documented about the habitat and ecology of this species. It is probably terrestrial due to it being in the same genus as B. albus.
threats: The major threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available on the abundance of this species.
range: This species was reported to occur in Ansus, Yapen, Indonesia. However, the specimen from that region was destroyed during World War II, so no verification can be made. Two other specimens were reported to be from Ceram. However, it was not possible to distinguish these specimens from B. albus (Murphy 2007).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures specific for this species. Considerable research on all aspects of this species is needed.

rationale: This species is known only from the type specimen of uncertain locality and it is hence listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No information is available.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Only known from a single specimen.
range:
This species is only known from the type specimen. The locality listed from "Indian Ocean".

It is thought to be found along the coasts of the Philippines, south to the Arafura Sea and the Australian-New Guinean continental shelf (Heatwole 1999). It is thought that the records of H. inornatus from Philippines might in fact be H. ornatus and H. lamberti see (Rasmussen 1989). According to A. Rasmussen (pers. comm. 2008) the only known record of H. inornatus is the type specimen, hence no countries or other geographic units are coded.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

No sea snake species is currently listed by CITES (the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora).

rationale: This species is only known from a few specimens and it appears to have a relatively restricted range in New Caledonia. Its is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat type is unknown  (Rasmussen and Ineich 2000). Captured at 62 m from a trawl.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Only known from three specimens. Probably naturally rare.
range: This species was described from the Chesterfield Reef in New Caledonian waters (Rasmussen and Ineich 2000).
conservationActions:
There are no species specific conservation measures for this species. The location where it occurs is extremely remote.

No sea snake species is currently listed by CITES (the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora).

rationale: Known from a single specimen from an uncertain locality and is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No information is available.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species. It is only known from one specimen.
range: Known from a single specimen from an uncertain locality in the "north Indian Ocean", Malayan archipelago. The precise range is unknown (David and Ineich 1999). This species may be a synonym of H. nigrocinctus (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2009).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures for this species.

rationale: Typhlops filiformis has been assessed as Data Deficient, because its type locality and extent of distribution are not known. Further, the taxonomic status of this species is not entirely certain, as it may be a synonym of T. porrectus. Research on the taxonomy, population, distribution and habitat of this species is recommended before a more accurate assessment can be carried out.
habitat: There is no information available on this species' habitat or ecology, as distributional information is unknown.
threats: It is not known if any threats are affecting this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: The exact location of the type of this species is unknown, but is presumed to be India (Khan 1999).
conservationActions: Further research on the taxonomy, distribution and habitat of this species is recommended to determine its taxonomic status and assess whether it is threatened.

rationale: Amphiglossus elongatus has been assessed as Data Deficient. The exact distribution and habitat preferences of this species are not known, and therefore the type and level of threats it may be facing are not known. Further research is needed to determine the distribution, ecology, and habitat of this species before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be made.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this species are unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no population data available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to northern Madagascar. It is found in the  Ambilobe Region which has an area of less than 10,000 km². Within this region, the species is  estimated to occur over an area of around 7,900 km². Museum specimens  have also been collected on the volcanic island of Nosy Be (area of 300  km²). However, a survey carried out between 1991 and 2001 failed to find  this species on the island, and it may have been missed in recent surveys because it is difficult to sample and most survey work has focused on the Lokobe reserve, where it may not be present (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. July 2011).
useTrade: The species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: It is likely that this species occurs in protected areas. Further research is needed into the taxonomy, threats, population status, ecology, and population trends of this species.

rationale: Typhlops domerguei has been assessed as Data Deficient due to the lack of population, distribution and habitat data available and uncertainty about any threats to the species. Further research is therefore needed before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be carried out.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this burrowing species, probably due to its secretive lifestyle.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known from southeastern Madagascar. Its type locality is Ranomafana.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, however, it is probably found within Ranomafana protected area. Further research into the distribution, population, biology and ecology, habitat status, and threats to this species should be carried out.

rationale: Typhlops reuteri has been assessed as Data Deficient due to the lack of population, distribution and habitat data available and uncertainty about the impacts of threats. Its distribution may also be larger than is currently known, as it is thought to also occur on the mainland of Madagascar. Further research is therefore needed before a more accurate assessment of the conservation status of T. reuteri can be carried out.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species, probably due to the cryptic nature of the members of this genus; however, this species probably occurs in humid forests.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats. Tourism has grown rapidly on Nosy Be, however, it is not known what impact this is having on the abundance of this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species has been found on Nosy Be, a small volcanic island off the northern coast of Madagascar. The area of this island is approximately 300 km². However, C. Raxworthy (pers. comm.) states that this species probably also occurs in the Sambirano region of mainland Madagascar.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, however, it may occur in the Lokobe Reserve. Further research into the distribution, population, biology and ecology, habitat preferences, and threats to this species should be carried out.

rationale: Lygodactylus blanci has been assessed as Vulnerable under criterion D2 because it is found in only one location, with a highly restricted distribution. Quarrying, human disturbance, and climate change are regarded as future threats to this species. More research into this species is required because if future threats occur, significant population declines may occur.
habitat: This species was found in a very rocky area, and the summit region of Mount Ibity is largely treeless with some bushes.
threats: At present there is no imminent threat to the summit region of Mount Ibity, however, quarrying and deforestation of the last dry forests on the mountain slopes is ongoing, and may pose a threat to the summit region in the future. Shifting climatic conditions due to climate change may also impact upon this species, especially considering its extremely restricted distribution.
population: This species was rediscovered in February 2008 at its type locality. Three unsuccessful searches had already taken place, indicting that this species is rare (M. Vences pers. comm.).
range: This species is only known from the type locality of Mount Ibity, Antananarivo Province, Madagascar. This species appears to be limited to the summit regions of Mount Ibity, and does not occur on the slopes below the summit. The area in which this species is distributed is less than 100 km²<sup></sup>.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into the population, distribution, biology and ecology, habitat status, and threats to this species should be carried out.

rationale: Currently there is insufficient information on this species abundance, distribution and threats. There are only three records, and there is also a degree of taxonomic uncertainty with the Lake Albert sub-population. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient. It has also been categorized as Data Deficient for eastern and north eastern Africa.
habitat: This species is found in running and standing waters. It breeds in the flood season.
threats: No information available.
population: No information available.
range:
This species is known from Sudan and Uganda.

Eastern Africa: It is present in Lake Albert and the upper Nile.

Northeast Africa: It is recorded around Khartoum and in the jebel Aulia reservoir.
useTrade: This species is harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: No information available. More research is needed into this species taxonomy, population numbers and range, biology and ecology, habitat status and threats, as well as monitoring of population trends.

rationale: Very little is known about this species. More information is needed on the species distribution and threats before an assessment can be made.
habitat: No information available.
threats: No information available.
population: No information available.
range: This species is known from the White Nile basin in Sudan and Ethiopia.
conservationActions: No information available.

rationale: There is limited information on population status or threats for this species, but the known distribution suggests that this species does not currently meet threatened criteria, and has therefore been assessed as Least Concern. For the regional assessments it has been categorised as Data Deficient for both east and northeast Africa.
habitat: No information available.
threats: No information available.
population: No information.
range:
This species is found in Somalia and Kenya.

Eastern Africa: It is present in the lower reaches of the Athi and Tana River systems.

Northeast Africa: It is found in Juba (Wabishebelle-Benadir), Somalia
conservationActions: No information available. More research is needed into this species population numbers and range, biology and ecology, habitat status and threats, as well as monitoring of population trends.

rationale: This species is known only from two specimens collected four decades ago. There is no information available on the population status of the species, its habitat preferences or major threats. The species is a priority for further survey work, especially given the potential threats to this species from ENSO/climate change events within its potentially restricted distribution and shallow-water tidepool habitat. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat of this species is unknown, but the original specimens were collected from a tidepool.
threats: It is unknown whether there are any major threats to this species. Recent El Niño events (1982-1983 and 1997-1998) had strong effects on tidepool and shallow subtidal species at the Galápagos. For example, the abundant shallow-water chaenopsid, Acanthemblemaria castroi, had largely disappeared following the most recent El Niño. McCosker et al. (2003) considered the possibility that Cottoclinus canops might be a naturally-occurring casualty of a recent El Niño event.
population: This species is known only from two specimens collected in 1964. In January 2002, a collecting trip surveyed tidepools contiguous with the type locality. Although the original pool sampled in 1962 could not be accessed, surveyors were able to sample two pools within a kilometer of that site, and both pools were devoid of large fish (McCosker et al. 2003).
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Pacific, and is known only from Isla Española in the Galapagos Islands (McCosker et al. 2003).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, its likely distribution falls within the Galápagos Islands National Park and UNESCO World Heritage Site.

rationale: This species is known from only two collections, and little is known about its distribution, population, habitat requirements, or threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is poorly known. It is a benthic species that presumably inhabits rocky shores.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: This species is only known from two specimens.
range: This species is only known from two collections. The first is the holotype collected in 1939 of unknown provenance, and given as "somewhere between Golfo de Nicoya, Costa Rica and 30 miles south of Cabo Corrientes, Jalisco, Mexico" (Briggs 1951). The second is from Isla Negrito, Costa Rica (USNM 369258), from 1968. The species is most probably known only from Costa Rica.
conservationActions: It is not known whether this species occurs in any protected areas. There is a need for survey work to determine the precise distribution range and population status of this species.

rationale: This species is only known from one specimen collected from Jalisco, Mexico. Little is known about its distribution, population, habitat requirements, or threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is poorly known. The only known specimen of this demersal species was collected from a depth of 55 m off the Jalisco coast.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: No population information is available for this species.
range: This species is only known from the holotype collected near Jalisco, Mexico.
conservationActions: There are no known specific conservation measures for this species.
