conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. Research is need to clarify the validity of this species and establish its likely place of origin.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species was described from an uncertain type locality and has never subsequently been recorded. As such there is no information on its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: No confirmed information on the ecological requirements of this species is available. Largen and Spawls (2010) suggest that it may be a montane grassland species found at approximately 3,000 m asl. Its reproductive mode is unknown.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which is known from only a single specimen (Largen and Spawls 2006). There are not thought to have been any subsequent collections of Panaspis species from the area of the presumed type locality (T. Colston pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species was described from the locality "Dabarif" in Ethiopia (Largen and Spawls 2006). No site of this name is known to exist in this country; Largen and Spawls (2006) associate it with Dabarik (also spelled Debarek), and Largen and Spawls (2010) indicate that it is "almost certainly" in the vicinity of Lake Tana.
useTrade: There is no information on any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. It is not known if this species occurs within protected areas. Additional research is needed into the taxonomy, distribution range, habitat requirements and threats to this species.

rationale: As this species is only known from the holotype, and has not been collected since 1941, no information is available on its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats, and it is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There appears to be no information on the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the abundance of this species. De Witte's original description is based on a single specimen (de Witte 1941).
range: This poorly-known species appears only to have been recorded from Rwanda, where it has was taken from the Rwankeri region at an elevation of 2,200 m asl. (de Witte 1941). It is not included in a more recent field guide to the reptiles of this region (Spawls et al. 2002).
useTrade: There appears to be no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species was described in a report on the herpetofauna found during a survey of Albert National Park (de Witte 1941). Nothing else is known about it and it has not been recorded since its original description, and no research or conservation can be proposed unless the species is rediscovered and information obtained on its distribution, ecological requirements or any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has not been recorded since its original description 80 years ago, and while anthropogenic pressures are ongoing in the area where it was found nothing is known of its true distribution or ecological requirements and so it is unknown whether it is at any risk.
habitat: Nothing is known about the life history of this species (Spawls et al. 2002), although its collection localities suggest an affinity with marshy areas. Other species of Meizodon are, however, generally found in dry habitats (S. Spawls pers. comm. 2014). It is presumably otherwise similar to the other snakes of this genus, i.e. terrestrial, diurnal and oviparous (Spawls et al. 2002).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist. The Tana delta is under agricultural pressure for rice, sugarcane and other crops, but nothing is known about  this snake's ecological requirements and so sensitivity to threats from agriculture and settlement. This is an area of internecine tribal warfare, making development and agriculture difficult and preventing surveys to rediscover this species (W. Branch and S. Spawls pers. comm. 2014).
population: This species has not been recorded since the two specimens in the original description were collected in 1934 (Spawls et al. 2002).
range: This species is endemic to Kenya, where it is presumably widespread in the Tana River delta region but is so far known only from the villages of Kau and Golbanti (Spawls et al. 2002). It may occur in the marshy regions south of Witu, or further upriver (Spawls et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is not known to be used or traded, as it is known from only two historical specimens.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas The Tana River delta is a designated RAMSAR site, however, this has not prevented arrangements to develop the area for agriculture. Surveys are needed in an effort to rediscover this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from two specimens collected nearly 40 years apart, the most recent more than 60 years ago,  and, as it was described based on museum specimens, nothing is known of its ecology, population status, or its exposure or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: Both the holotype described by Broadley (1994) and the additional specimen assigned to this species by Crochet et al. (2008) are museum records, and nothing is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: Only two specimens are known, one collected in 1927 and one in 1966 (Crochet et al. 2008)
range: This species is known from two localities in the same region of the Blue Nile Valley, Sudan (Crochet et al. 2008). The type locality lies around 30 km north of Sennar (Crochet et al. 2008, Broadley 1994)
useTrade: There is presumed to be no use or trade in this species, which is known only from two historical records.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: This species is only known from a single specimen collected in the Gambia before 1937. Nothing else is known about its range, population and threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: There is no information on the population of this species, which has not been recorded with certainty since its original description (pre-1937).
range: This species was described from McCarthy Island in the Gambia before 1937, and has not definitively been recorded since (Trape and Mané 2006). Records of "M. macrorhyncha" from Ghana may represent this species (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. July 2012).
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and clarify its distribution, population status, natural history, and its exposure and sensitivity to any threats. Taxonomic research is required to clarify the appropriate assignment of "M. macrorhyncha" complex specimens from Ghana, which may be referable to this species.

rationale: This species is only known from an unspecified locality in the original description from 1898, and is therefore is listed as Data Deficient as no information is available on its distribution, population status, natural history or threats.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this species.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: No population information is available, as this species is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known only from one specimen from the unspecific locality "Liberia" (Roux-Estève 1974).
useTrade: There is no information on use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Further research into its distribution, population and habitat status of, and threats to, the species is required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from only two localities and nothing is known of its true distribution, population status, ecological requirements or its exposure to any threats.
habitat: The species was collected in sand in Geriban (Lanza and Carfi 1966). There is no other information on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the population status of this skink.
range: This species is known only from Somalia, where records exist for Hafun (Bari region) in the north and Geriban (Mudug region) in central Somalia (Lanza and Carfi 1966, Lanza 1990).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen collected before 1863 from an indeterminate locality in Bahia, Brazil, and nothing else is known of its distribution, natural history, population status or any threats.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species, as both its ecology and distribution are unknown.
population: This species is known from a single 19th Century specimen (Myers 2011).
range: This species is known only from a specimen reportedly collected in "Bahia" in Brazil prior to 1863 (Myers 2011). It is not clear whether this refers to the present state of Bahia or the city São Salvador do Baía de Todos os Santos (presently known as Salvador, but historically as Bahia) (Myers 2011). The species could consequently have been collected anywhere within an 800 km radius of Salvador (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2018). The type locality has not been verified, but Myers (2011) investigated the possibility that it may be in error and concluded that there is presently "no good reason" for doubting this species' provenance, while allowing that future research is needed to either confirm or falsify the Brazilian type locality. Costa and Bérnils (2018) accept the Bahia locality in the current list of reptiles of Brazil.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species, which is known from a single historical specimen.
conservationActions: Research, including more extensive comparisons with Old World species than was possible for Myers (2011), is needed to clarify the relationships of this species and to determine its distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient since it has only been described in 2010, and there is still very little information on its distribution, status, threats and ecological requirements. However, should future work indicate that it is a forest specialist (a habitat which is under significant human pressure) with a restricted distribution, this species may qualify to be reassessed in a Threatened category.
habitat: Nothing is known about the natural history of this species. The habitat type is unknown, but it might be found in moist rainforest (J. Penner pers. comm. June 2012). It is suspected to breed in water by larval development based on reproduction in congeners.
threats: The type locality is next to the road leading to open-cast mining concessions on Nimba that was mined from the 1960s to the 1990s; mining remains a potential threat due to continued interest in the area's resources. Pressure on the forest at lower elevations on Mount Nimba is ongoing due to the expansion of agricultural activities.
population: It is known only from the holotype, collected in 1969 (Rödel et al. 2010). The fact that it was the only individual of its species present in a collection of hundreds of Phrynobatrachus specimens collected at Mount Nimba suggests that it may be a rare or cryptic species (Rödel et al. 2010). Its cryptic nature is further supported by the lack of records despite many general and targeted surveys at the type locality, and surveys on the Guinea and Cote d'Ivoire sides of the mountain since the 1940s to the present (L. Sandberger pers. comm. July 2016). As it was found in mid-altitude it may be present at other similar sites that have not yet been surveyed, however further studies are required (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. March 2017). Its population trend is unknown.
range: This species is only known from the type locality on Mount Nimba, at 700 m Asl, in northeastern Liberia (Rödel et al. 2010). It is likely that it may occur more widely, in nearby Ivory Coast and Guinea (Rödel et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions

No conservation actions are currently known for this species. 


Research Needed

More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient because it is only known from a specimen collected in 1928 and was only recognized as being specifically distinct in 2012. There is no population or habitat information to identify the degree to which the species is exposed to threats, if at all. Land use conversion on the island where the species was collected may or may not represent a threat because some congeneric species can tolerate heavily-disturbed habitats.
habitat: The habitat of this species is unknown. Species of American Mabuyinae are ovoviviparous, but no specific information is available about reproduction in this species (Hedges and Conn 2012).
threats: It is assumed that, in common with most Caribbean islands, black rats have been introduced to Great Corn Island. These, together with other introduced mammals, are thought to represent the greatest potential threat to this species (Hedges and Conn 2012).
population: The population status is unknown because the species is known only from the holotype, which was collected in 1928 (Hedges and Conn 2012).
range: This speciesis known from a single specimen collected on Great Corn Island, in the Caribbean Sea around 50 km off the coast of Nicaragua (Hedges and Conn 2012). It may occur on the nearby Little Corn Island, but this is uncertain (Hedges and Conn 2012). The presence of unusual individuals belonging to the Marisora brachypoda species complex in eastern Nicaragua which share some characters with M. magnacornae may indicate that this species occurs on the Central American mainland, or these may be attributable to other species (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: Research is needed to determine its relationships to mainland species of Marisora, and to clarify its population status, natural history, and the existence and nature of any threats (Hedges and Conn 2012). If found to be at risk, captive breeding programs may be required (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the species remains very poorly-known. It may be more widespread than is currently recognised, however, additional surveys are needed to validate this.
habitat: Little is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not well known.
population: This is a very poorly-known species that is more common on plateau areas (Broadley et al. 2004).
range: This species has been recorded in western Angola (a single specimen at 'Congulu') and the Upemba National Park in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Broadley et al. 2004, Marques et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It has been recorded in the Upemba National Park of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Broadley et al. 2004). Additional research is needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as while this is a little known species, the area where it has been recorded is heavily modified. Surveys are needed to determine whether the species is still extant, however, this research is currently restricted by the outbreak of the disease Ebola within the known distribution.
habitat: There is little information available on the natural history of this skink.
threats: The threats to this poorly-known species are not well-known. However, the area in which this species was collected has been heavily modified through logging, agriculture and urbanisation, There is no natural habitat remaining within the site.
population: It is presumably currently known from the holotype. It has not been recorded since the 1930, although there do not appear to have been dedicated surveys for this species.
range: This species appears to have only been recorded to date from 'Lubero (west of Beni, west of Mount Ruwenzori)' in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Broadley 1998). It was collected at close to 1,100 m asl.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. More details are needed about the distribution, natural history and threats to the species, however, the area in which this species was recorded has limited research access due problems with the Ebola disease outbreak.

rationale: This deep-living species is widely distributed and locally abundant where it occurs over soft bottom. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This deep-living species occurs over muddy soft bottoms between 76-183 m (Collette 2002). Little additional information is available on its habitats or ecology. This species, like all members of the subfamily Thalassophryninae, has a highly developed venom apparatus (Collette 1966). Maximum size attained is 6.3 cm SL (Collette 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: Collette (1966) examined at least 42 specimens in the original description. This species can be locally abundant; there are 31 nominal records in Fishnet2, with up to 103 individuals in a single lot.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic in the Caribbean Sea from Bocas del Toro, Panama to Aruba (Collette 2002, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: This venomous species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This small, demersal species is rarely recorded, but is relatively widely distributed. It inhabits shallow muddy bottoms. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits shallow mud bottoms.
threats: There are no known major threats. The area where most specimens have been collected (off the mouth of the Orinoco River, eastern Venezuela) is a large oil extraction zone.
population: This species is rarely recorded, but may be locally common near the mouth of the Orinoco River, Venezuela.
range: Citharichthys minutus is distributed in the western Atlantic along the Central and South American coast from San Blas, Panama to Venezuela and Trinidad (Cervigon 1996, Saavedra-Diaz et al. 2000, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It occurs from 0-3 m depth (Saavedra-Diaz et al. 2000) and up to 20 m based on collection records off eastern Venezuela (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its estimated EOO is 757,043 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 0-20 m bathymetric layer). Its estimated AOO is 58,070 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 0-20 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: Due to its small size, this species is not likely targeted, but potentially occurs as bycatch.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Trawling has been banned in all of Venezuela since early 2009 (J.M. Posada pers. comm. 2013).

rationale: This species is only known from a few collections off Nicaragua and the province of Colon, Panama. It possibly occurs in other estuaries and shallow bays within this area, however, further surveys are required. Threats are not well-known, but its habitat is suffering declines due to expansion of the Panama Canal as well as general degradation in the system. Given the uncertainties on its full distribution, which is potentially relatively restricted (AOO is less than 6,000 km2), and unknown affects of habitat degradation, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Atherinella beani is a coastal species found in estuaries and shallow bays (Chernoff 2002). Little in general is known about its habitat or ecology. The maximum standard length is 8.2 cm (Chernoff 1986, 2002).
threats: The possible threats to this little-known species require further study. Habitat degradation is likely occurring in the Panama Canal Zone.
population: Population information for Atherinella beani is limited as it is known from only four collections. It rarely occurs on species lists in studies conducted in this region - whether this reflects rarity of this species or taxonomic difficulties in identifying this species is unknown. Two collections in Nicaragua (University of Florida collections) yielded 87 A. beani, which could indicate local abundance.
range: Atherinella beani is only known in the western Atlantic from estuaries between Laguna de Perlas, Nicaragua south to the Panama Canal Zone (Colon Province) (Chernoff 2002, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is known from only two collections from the province of Colon, Panama (Chernoff 2002), and two collections from Nicaragua (1960 Rio San Juan at San Juan del Sur, Rivas Providence and Estuary of Poneloya, 18 km W of Leon). It may also occur in other locations in Central America. Its estimated EOO is 128,923 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 0-10 m bathymetric layer). Its estimated AOO is 5,233 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 0-10 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for Atherinella beani.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This uncommon benthopelagic species is widely distributed and occurs over soft bottom on the continental shelf. No  major threats  are known, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species occurs over soft bottom on the shallow continental shelf from 18-61 m. Its maximum size is 15.3 cm total length.
threats: No major threats are known,   but it may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries off South America.
population: Ophidion guianense is uncommon. Between 1958-1969, 20 specimens were deposited in museum collections (Accessed through the FishNet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 19-09-2012).
range: Ophidion guianense is distributed in the western Atlantic from the Saba Bank along the Antilles to Venezuela and east to Suriname from 18-61 m. It may have a wider distribution that extends westward into the southern Caribbean Sea (Lea and Robins 2003).
useTrade: Ophidion guianense is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is widely distributed and occurs in coastal waters over soft bottom. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits coastal waters over mostly soft bottom between 0-55 m depth. Little else regarding its habitat and ecology is known. It attains a maximum size of 66 cm SL (Collette 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats. Its occurrence as bycatch in shrimp trawls is unknown.
population: <span class="st">Little is known regarding its population status. There are 16 nominal records in Fishnet2, with up to 11 individuals in a single lot.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from Belize to Brazil (just north of the Amazon River) (Collette 2002, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Saurida caribbaea is widely distributed, common and locally abundant where it occurs over soft bottom most often in offshore waters on the continental shelf. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species occurs in offshore areas over soft bottom on the continental shelf and slope; occasionally in shallow inshore waters. Its maximum size is 15 cm TL, but common to 10 cm (McEachran and Fechhelm 1998).
threats: There do not appear to be any substantial threats to this species. It could potentially be affected by its occurrence as shrimp trawl by-catch in parts of its range.
population: This species is common and locally abundant; there are 118 nominal records in Fishnet2, with up to 42 individuals in a single lot. It is a common lizardfish in Brazilian waters (Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from North Carolina south along the U.S., the northern Bahamas and north-central Cuba, throughout the Gulf of Mexico except Cuba, in the Caribbean from Jamaica, Puerto Rico to Saba Atoll, and along the Central and South American coast from Mexico to Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Anderson et al. 1966, Claro et al. 2001, Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). The depth range is 10-460 m.
useTrade: Saurida caribbaea is of no interest to fisheries (Russell 2002).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This deep-living species is widely distributed where it occurs over the continental shelf and slope. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Lophiodes reticulatus prefers water temperatures between 12 and 19 degrees Celsius. It is mostly found on the continental slope, but is sometimes found on the outer continental shelf (Ross and Caruso 1984, Caruso 2002, Caruso et al. 2007). It is a voracious predator that feeds on fishes, crustaceans and birds, sometimes as large as themselves (Smith 1997). Females are thought to deliver eggs in a veil. Little else is known on its biology. Its maximum length is 30 cm SL, but common to 15 cm SL (Caruso 2002).
threats: <span>It occurs occasionally as bycatch when trawling at appropriate depths (Caruso 2002), however, this does not represent a major threat.
population: Lophiodes reticulatus is an infrequently encountered species that is widespread in deep waters over the outer continental shelf and upper continental slope in all tropical and temperate seas (Caruso et al. 2007).
range: Lophiodes reticulatus is distributed in the western Atlantic from North Carolina south along the U.S. coast, throughout the Gulf of Mexico except for northwestern Cuba, in the Caribbean from Puerto Rico to Tobago, and along the Central and South American coast from Mexico to Suriname (Smith 1997, Caruso 2002). Its depth range is 64-820 m (Uyeno et al. 1983).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Ophidion grayi is a common and widespread benthopelagic species that occurs on soft bottom over the continental shelf. There are no known major threats, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Ophidion grayi is benthopelagic with a maximum size of 30 cm TL that is found in shallow, coastal waters (Robins and Ray 1986, Nielsen et al. 1999). One ripe female at 155 mm SL was recorded in March; O. grayi off Texas spawn in March and April (Retzer 1991). Off southeastern Florida it is in breeding condition in January and February. In a study conducted off the coast of Texas by Retzer (1991), 33% of O. grayi were collected during the day.
threats: No major threats are known for Ophidion grayi, but it may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries.
population: Ophidion grayi is common (R. Robins pers. comm. 2013). Between 1935-1993, 274 specimens were deposited in museum collections (Accessed through the FishNet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 19-09-2012).
range: Ophidion grayi is distributed in the western Atlantic from South Carolina south along the U.S. coast, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys north along the Gulf coast to the Texas/Mexico border (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its depth range is 10-60 m (Robins and Ray 1986, Nielsen et al. 1999, Nielsen and Robins 2002).
useTrade: Ophidion grayi is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, demersal species occurs on the shallower continental shelf over soft bottom. There are no known major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species occurs on the continental shelf over soft bottom in water temperatures of 17<sup>o</sup>C or greater. It reaches a maximum size of 10 cm, but it most commonly attains sizes of 5 to 8 cm standard length (Munroe 2002). Off the southeast U.S., it spawns during winter months and the pelagic eggs and larvae develop offshore (Leslie and Stewart 1986, Hare and Govoni 2005).
threats: Due to its small size, it is of no interest to fisheries, but it may be taken as bycatch in demersal shrimp trawl fisheries. There are no known major threats.
population: Little is known on the population of this species. There are 96 nominal records in Fishnet2 with up to 32 specimens per lot.
range: Etropus cyclosquamus is distributed in the western Atlantic from Cape Hatteras, North Carolina south along the U.S. coast to Cape Canaveral, Florida, and in the Gulf of Mexico from Fort Myers, Florida along the Gulf coast to Mississippi (Munroe 2002); it has also been reported west to Corpus Christi, Texas (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015). It is rare or absent off southern Florida. It is most abundant between 10-30 m depth (Leslie and Stewart 1986, Munroe 2002).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. It is not known if populations occur in protected areas.

rationale: Prionotus murielae is known only from a single specimen collected at Cay Sal Bank, Bahamas. More research is needed regarding its distribution, population status, ecology, and potential threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only size and depth record for this species is a single individual of 20 cm found at 11 m (Miller and Richards 1991).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: Little is known regarding the population status of this species, as it is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known only from the holotype collected at Cay Sal Bank, Bahamas (Richards and Miller 2002). The record reported from Mexico is incorrect (B. Eschmeyer pers. comm. 2012), but the type locality seems correct.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Assuming that it breeds in a similar manner to other Leptopelis species, it lays its eggs in a nest buried in mud near water, into which the larvae emerge and develop.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. Despite recent herpetological surveys within the expected range of this species, no specimens have been collected since the type specimen.
range: This species is known only from its type locality at 1,000 m asl in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), near the Semliki Sector of Virunga National Park at the Mamudioma River (a tributary of the Djuma River), on the new road to Watalinga. It may have a more extensive distribution in the lowland rainforests of DRC (E. Greenbaum pers comm May 2012).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: This species presumably occurs in Virunga National Park, but no effective conservation is currently in practice in this region due to rebel activities (A. Plumtre pers comm June 2012). Research is required into the distribution and population status of this species, as well as into its' ecology and threats.

rationale: This species is known only from illustrations from the type material from Ningpo, China. There are no recent illustrations since the original description. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information available on this species' biology or habitat preferences. There are no illustrations, nor recent descriptions (J.H. Choat pers comm. 2009).
threats:
There are no major threats known for this species.

Parrotfishes show varying degrees of habitat preference and utilization of coral reef habitats, with some species spending the majority of their life stages on coral reefs, while others primarily utilize seagrass beds, mangroves, algal beds, and /or rocky reefs. Although the majority of the parrotfishes occur in mixed habitat (primarily inhabiting seagrass beds, mangroves, and rocky reefs) approximately 78% of these mixed habitat species are experiencing greater than 30% loss of coral reef area and habitat quality across their distributions. Of those species that occur exclusively in coral reef habitat, more than 80% are experiencing a greater than 30% of coral reef loss and degradation across their distributions. However, more research is needed to understand the long-term effects of habitat loss and degradation on these species populations.   Widespread coral reef loss and declining habitat conditions are particularly worrying for species that depend on live coral reefs for food and shelter especially as studies have shown that protection of pristine habitats facilitate the persistence of adult populations in species that have spatially separated adult and juvenile habitats. Furthermore, coral reef loss and declining habitat conditions are particularly worrying for some corallivorous excavating parrotfishes that play major roles in reef dynamics and sedimentation (Comeros-Raynal et al. 2012).
population: There is no population information available for this species. It is known only from the type material from Ningpo, a set of rocky islands just south of Shanghai.
range: This species is endemic to temperate China (Parenti and Randall 2000).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Palaeopropithecus ingens is one of the last survivors of the large-bodied extinct lemurs of Madagascar.  It is known only from subfossil remains on Madagascar, where radiocarbon dating from southwestern Madagascar suggests that it survived until ~1500 CE. When, in the late 1600s, Etienne de Flacourt interviewed local Malagasy people in the region of Tolagnaro (Fort Dauphin), southeastern Madagascar, he found that his informants believed this to be still alive. Locally known as the “tretretretre”, the animal was said to have a short, round head, human-like face and ears, monkey-like hands and feet with elongated digits, frizzy hair, and a short tail. Folklorists recorded stories of an “ogre” with peculiar sloth-like behavioural characteristics into the late 1800s.
habitat:
Palaeopropithecus was morphologically strongly convergent on extant arboreal sloths, hence the name "sloth lemur."  It lived in a wide variety of forested habitats, and while its postcranial adaptations reveal tree-slothlike (highly suspensory, arboreal) behaviour, it is also known to have descended to the ground, where it sometimes fell victim to crocodiles.  The Family to which it belongs (i.e., the Palaeopropithecidae) is closely related to the Family Indriidae.  However, unlike living indriids, Palaeopropithecus was not able to leap, and would have moved in a four-footed suspensory manner in trees, and in a sprawling manner on the ground, grabbing onto ground vegetation and slowly moving forward, as do tree sloths when they descend to the ground.  It is believed to have been highly folivorous.

Palaeopropithecus ingens lived in the subarid forests of southern and southwestern Madagascar (spiny thicket and succulent woodland).  P. maximus lived in the sub-humid forests of the central highlands and in the dry deciduous forests of the extreme north.  P. kelyus is known from the lowland western dry forests in the Mahajanga region (northwest) and at the Beanka reserve just north of the tsingy of Bemaraha (near the west coast).
threats: The reasons for the extinction are not known, although multiple hypotheses have been proposed. These are reviewed, for example, in Burney et al. (2004), Goodman and Jungers (2014), Douglass et al. (2019) and Godfrey et al. (2019).
population: This species is Extinct. Relict populations may have survived until after 1500 CE (Godfrey and Jungers 2003, Burney et al. 2004).
range: The genus Palaeopropithecus is known from subfossil remains on Madagascar from the extreme south to the extreme north and through the central highlands.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are needed.

rationale: The Jamaican Monkey is assessed as Extinct. It is known exclusively from subfossil specimens discovered at several localities in Jamaica. Its disappearance date is uncertain. Sir Hans Sloane (1707–1725) mentioned the presence of monkeys on the north coast of Jamaica, but thought they had come from Africa. One recent estimate based on radiocarbon dated fossils suggests that Xenothrix became extinct ~900 bp (1100 CE), possibly at a time when Jamaica was first occupied by humans (Cooke et al. 2018).
habitat: Xenothrix mcgregori is known only as a fossil taxon. It was most probably a frugivore. Several features of the known limb skeleton suggest a slow quadrupedal locomotor style that has no evident counterpart among extant platyrrhines, but was possibly somewhat convergent on sloths (MacPhee and Fleagle 1991).
threats: The reasons for the extinction of this species are not known.
population: This species is now Extinct. There are no observations of the monkey in life and all dated fossils are considerably older than 1500 CE.
range: The type site of the Jamaican Monkey is Long Mile Cave on the island’s north coast (Williams and Koopman 1952). Additional cranial and postcranial material attributed to Xenothrix has also been recovered from caves in southern Jamaica, suggesting an islandwide distribution (MacPhee and Fleagle 1991, MacPhee and Horovitz 2004).
conservationActions: No conservation actions are required for this Extinct species.

rationale: Cynisca senegalensis has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is known only from a single specimen without ecological information and has not been reported since 1973.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this species. Amphisbaenids are fossorial. Niokolo-Koba National Park is characterized by Guinean savanna, although this large national park encompasses all habitat types found in this climatic zone (UNESCO 2012). There is no information on the specific habitat where this species was collected.
threats: Niokolo-Koba National Park was added to the list of Endangered World Heritage Sites in 2007, largely on the basis that the park is at risk from increased drying of wetland habitats following dam construction outside the park boundary, as well as encroachment by invasive plants and bush fires (UNESCO 2012). It is not known whether these processes threaten this species, whether it occurs outside the park or, if so, whether it is exposed to any threats elsewhere in its range.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, collected in 1973 (Gans 1987).
range: This species is only known from an indeterminate type locality in Parc Niokolo-Koba (known internationally as Niokolo-Koba National Park), in eastern Senegal (Gans 1987).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Niokolo-Koba National Park is listed by UNESCO as both a Biosphere Reserve and a World Heritage Site. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and, if successful, to obtain data on its distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: This snake is known only from two specimens from 1941 and 1954, and despite recent survey in the Nimba region, no further specimens have been found. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this fossorial species, and its habitat requirements are unknown.
threats: It is unknown whether threats exist to this species, which is only known from two records, either or both of which are potentially erroneous.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known from only two specimens collected in 1941 and 1954.
range: This snake is known from Harbel in Liberia and from Nzo, at 500 m elevation in the Guinean portion of Mount Nimba, close to the border with Côte d'Ivoire and Liberia (Roux-Esteve 1974). It is known only from two specimens, and despite recent survey in the Nimba region, no further specimens have been found. The possibility exists that both localities are incorrect (W.R. Branch, M.-O. Rödel and J. Penner pers.comms. 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Further research is required to rediscover this species and to establish information on its distribution, population and habitat status, and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic status as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species, although like other members of the genus, it presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. There have been no recent records, probably due to lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the St. Louis Plain on the western shore of Lake Tanganyika in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Given this lack of specificity, attempts to map its distribution can only be approximate at this stage.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research is required on the taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitat, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: No information is available on its habitat and ecology, although it is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: There is no information available on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Arebi (Uelé), Ituri, in north-eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It is not known to occur in any protected areas. Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the identity of this taxon.  More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing taxonomic uncertainty and the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information available regarding its habitat or ecology, although it presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: There is no information on major threats to this species.
population: Its population status is unknown. There are no recent records of this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Murugaragara, near Mosso, Rutana, in south-eastern Burundi, at 1,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. Research is needed on the taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitat, ecology, use and possible threats to the species.

rationale: This species is known only from type locality and is listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat or ecology. It presumably breeds by direct development, like other members of the genus.
threats: There is no information on the threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known with certainty only from the type locality, Accra, in Ghana. Animals found in the Togo-Volta Highlands of Ghana could possibly belong to this species, or to Arthroleptis brevipes. Alternatively, A. zimmeri could prove to be the correct name for a widespread savannah species of Arthroleptis.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: There is no information on conservation measures for this species. It is not known from any protected areas. Research is required on the taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitat, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic status as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecological preferences, although it presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. There have been no recent records, probably due lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Mwana, at 1,650 m asl, near Mwenga, in southern Kivu (Sud-Kivu Province), eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research is required on the taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitat, ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity and lack of information on distribution, ecology, life history and threats.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecological requirements. It presumably has a free-living, aquatic larval stage like other members of the genus. Amiet (2012) reported a record of a call from a species that could not be identified, that could possibly belong to this species.
threats: There is no information on specific threats to this species, although the only area from which it has been found is now a large city.
population: If it is a valid species, it is possibly extinct following the very extensive habitat destruction that has taken place around the city of Douala (Amiet 2009). There have been no records since its discovery, despite extensive herpetological work in the area.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Bonamandune, near the city of Douala in Cameroon. Its elevational range is unknown. It is possible that it is not a valid species.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
This species has not been found in the wild for some time, therefore research into its population and distribution is required. Its taxonomic validity has also been questioned, so research in this area is required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecological requirements of this species, which presumably breeds in water by larval development.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Its population status is not known.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Bibundi, Cameroon, although this form cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas. There are continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, so research is required in this area.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, uncertain provenance, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It presumably breeds in waterbodies and has a larval development breeding strategy.

useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas. Research is needed on its taxonomic status, as well as to locate this species in the wild and assess its distribution, population status, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although there have been relatively few records, it has a relatively wide distribution and has a presumed large population.

threats: There is no information on threats to this species, though it occurs in an area of low human impact, and it is unlikely to be threatened.

range: This very poorly known species ranges from northwestern Angola to southern Democratic Republic of Congo to east-central Zambia. It appears to occur at moderately high elevations. It distribution is very poorly known, and the maps should be regarded as preliminary. There do not appear to be any recent records, presumably due to lack of herpetological work within its range.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. There is no information for the habitats and ecology of the species, therefore this area would benefit from some research.

population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Ukami, supposedly in the Uluguru Mountains in eastern Tanzania. However, this locality appears to be in the Udzungwa Mountains, so there is considerable doubt as to where the type specimen comes from. No distribution map is provided. This name cannot be linked to any known species in the wild, and is probably a synonym of something else.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. There are continuing doubts as to this species' taxonomic validity and research into this is needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic status, extent of occurrence and ecological requirements.
habitat: It presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which is known from a single specimen.
range: This species is only known from Mount Teye at 1,800 m asl on Mount Ruwenzori, in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
useTrade: There in no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: This species was found in Virunga National Park. Research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats to this species. There are also continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements (Chou et al. 2007).
habitat: The habitat preferences of this species are unknown. However, it presumably breeds by larval development in temporary waterbodies.
threats: The threats to this taxon are not known.
population: The population is not known.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Gbarnga, and from Mount Coffee, Liberia.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if this taxon occurs in any protected areas. Research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats to this species. There are also continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.

rationale: This species is known only known from the type locality, and is listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its status and ecological requirements, and continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecological requirements of this species, although assuming that it breeds in a similar manner to other Leptopelis species, it lays its eggs in a nest buried in mud near water, into which the larvae emerge and develop.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. There have been no recent records, presumably because of the lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from its type locality, Nyonga, in Upemba National Park, Shaba Province, in south-eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Upemba National Park is the only protected area from which this species is currently known. Further research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology, threats, and use and trade of this species. There is continuing doubt as to the taxonomic validity of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species' habitat and ecological preferences are not known, although they are presumably similar to other members of the genus, and it likewise probably also breeds in water by larval development.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. There are no recent records, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Mauda (Uele), in north-eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. When mapping its range this can only be done approximately, owing to a lack of specificity regarding the type locality.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded in any protected areas. Further research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology, threats, and use and trade of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Nothing is known about this species' preferred habitat. However if it is like other members of the genus it probably requires water to breed and develops via a larval stage.
threats: There is no recent information.
population: It is apparently a very common species, although there have been no recent records, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from Upemba National Park, and nearby areas, in south-eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Upemba National Park is the only protected area from which it is currently known. Further research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology, threats, and use and trade of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Its habitat and ecological preferences are not well known, but are presumably similar to other members of the genus, and this species probably likewise breeds in water.
threats: There is no information available on threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species. There have been no recent records.
range: This species is known only from the non-specific type locality of "Congo" (Ahl 1923), which is presumably in Democratic Republic of Congo. Because of the lack of explicit locality data, it is not possible currently to map its range.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Its taxonomic validity needs to be reassessed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecological preferences, although its requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and it likewise presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, and there have been no subsequent records of it since its discovery, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Buta, in north-central Democratic Republic of Congo.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research is needed on the distribution and population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Its habitat and ecological requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and it probably also breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, and there have been no subsequent records of it since its discovery, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from its type locality at Yambata in northern Democratic Republic of Congo. Records from Cameroon are in error and refer to Phrynobatrachus accraensis. The location of the type locality is not absolutely clear, so attempts to map its distribution must be considered as approximate.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research is needed on the distribution and population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species' habitat and ecological requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and it likewise presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There are no recent records from either country, presumably due to lack of herpetological work within its range, although recent collections of frogs from southern Guinea might refer to P. brongersmai (Rödel pers. comm.).
range: This species is known only from its type locality, Lambarene, Ogowe, in west-central Gabon, and (on the assumption that Phrynobatrachus brongersmai is a synonym of this species), from Grand Cape Mount in western Liberia.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: The taxonomic status of both this species and P. brongersmai needs to be re-examined.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species most likely has similar habitat and ecological requirements to those of most other members of the genus, and presumably also breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. There do not appear to be any recent records, presumably due to taxonomic confusion, and due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Buddu Forest, in southern Uganda along the western shore of Lake Victoria. The location of the site is not absolutely clear, so attempts to map its distribution should be considered as approximate. It has also been reported from Mount Kenya, but this requires confirmation.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Further research is required to resolve its taxonomy.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It probably has similar habitat and ecological requirements to those of most other members of the genus, and presumably also breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, and there have been no subsequent records of it since its discovery, presumably due to a lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Fort Crampel, in the Central African Republic.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Its taxonomic validity needs to be reassessed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the fact it is only known from type locality, and the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat or ecology. Although it presumably breeds by larval development, as with other congeners.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is only known from its type locality, 12 km north of Bamako, in Mali. Its taxonomy remains unresolved, but if it turns out to belong to this genus it is likely to be a dry savanna species and is expected to be more widespread  (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016). Its EOO is 9 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions 
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Research Needed
Further research is required on population status, ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because known only from a single specimen of very uncertain provenance, and there continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of any information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: If this is a valid species, it presumably occurs in or near water where is most likely breeds by larval development.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the unspecified type locality in Eritrea. It is known only from two old specimens, one of which survives. It is possibly closely related to (or even synonymous with) Pelophylax ridibundus. It is also possible that the species is not even native to Eritrea (Pelophylax ridibundus having been introduced widely elsewhere in the world), and the specimens were perhaps not even collected in that country, but the amphibian fauna of Eritrea is too poorly known for these issues to be resolved at present. Given the current state of knowledge, it is not possible to map this species' range.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: More research is needed to determine whether or not it is a valid species and to improve understanding of its distribution and population status.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is widespread and very common at least in parts of its range.
habitat: This species has often been found beneath stones and rocks, but is also sometimes encountered in tree holes or under bark (Loveridge 1947). The recent record from Djibouti was found in a coastal situation, beneath flotsam on a fossil reef (Nistri and Vanni 2014). Its broad habitat preferences appear not to be recorded.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: An early series taken by a single collector included 21 individuals (Loveridge 1947). Mazuch (2013) reports that it is "very common" in the foothills of the Goolis Mountains, and T. Mazuch (pers. comm. 2019) notes that it is among the most common members of this genus in Somaliland. It is thought likely to be rare in or absent from the highlands of the Haud and the Omo Mountains (Parker 1942).
range: This species appeared until recently to be endemic to Somalia, where it has been recorded from regions throughout the country north of the Juba River (Lanza 1990) and has a wide distribution in the north of the country (Mazuch 2013). A northern range extension to a coastal area close to Obock in Djibouti represents the first confirmed record outside Somalia (Nistri and Vanni 2014). It has been recorded between 50 and around 960 m asl (Loveridge 1947). A historical record from Nairobi has had its identity confirmed, but may represent an introduction (Loveridge 1947). It is not known, if so, whether the introduction was successful, as no population appears to have been confirmed in Kenya and the species is not included in a field guide to this region (Spawls et al. 2002).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from the holotype collected over a century ago from a single, imprecise locality, and nothing is known of its true distribution, natural history or any threats.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat in which this species was collected. The collecting locality is somewhat imprecise, and it is therefore not possible to characterize the habitat at this locality although it is in a dry area.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from a single specimen.
range: This species is known only from a single example collected in 1893 from the upper reaches of the Ganale River, probably somewhere to the east of Kebre Mengist, Ethiopia (Largen and Spawls 2010). A second reported specimen, from the Ogaden region, is in bad condition and may be a misidentified Hemidactylus smithi (Largen and Spawls 2010). The elevational range is not known.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species occurs in any protected areas. Further field surveys are needed to learn more about this little-known gecko.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen collected more than 70 years ago, and nothing is known of its true distribution, ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species was described based on a single specimen (Scortecci 1948), and this remains the only known record (Šmíd et al. 2019).
range: This species is known only from Gelib, Middle Juba Province, in southwest Somalia (Lanza 1990).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because it remains little-known, with the exception of a few localities along a narrow band. There is currently insufficient information on the distribution, ecology and possible threats to this species.
habitat: Nothing is reported about the ecology of this species as redescribed by Mahony (2011).
threats: The possible threats to this species remain poorly-known.
population: There are few details on the abundance or population trends for this species.
range: This species is known with certainty from three localities along a stretch of the Indus River Valley in Pakistan (Mahony 2011). The known localities lie along a line around 76 km long (Mahony 2011). Records exist from Kashmor town or its administrative region, Bhanar, and Ural, all in Sindh District (Mahony 2011).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known whether populations of this gecko are present in any protected areas. Additional general studies are suggested into the distribution, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from four specimens from two localities, and does not appear to have been reported since it was described more than 85 years ago.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species was described based on four specimens (Parker 1932). It does not appear to have been collected since (Lanza 1990).
range: This species is known from two localities in northern Somalia: Sol Haud (at 930 m asl) and the Nogal Valley (at 570 m asl) (Parker 1932, Lanza 1990).
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its, natural history, threats and conservation status
habitat: The habitat and natural history of this species is not well-known. Annobon is largely lowland tropical forest, however, it is not known if this gecko was collected from this forest habitat.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. It is possible that there are no threats, however, this needs to be confirmed.
population: This species is known only from the type series collected in the 19th century.
range: This species is known only from Annobon Island of Equatorial Guinea, in the Gulf of Guinea.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The island of Annobon is a Ramsar Site. New surveys are needed to better determine the distribution, natural history, threats and conservation status of this very poorly-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from very few specimens and there is no information on its ecology or any threats, and while it may be somewhat widespread its distribution has been the source of uncertainty due to confusion with Hemidactylus robustus.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species. Fewer than 10 specimens are known from collections (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species has been reported from Central Somalia, and from the Middle Juba and Mogadishu regions of southern Somalia (Lanza 1990). A record from Zanzibar represents Hemidactylus parkeri, a junior synonym of H. robustus, and no records of H. puccioni are known from Kenya (from which a previously reported record is now considered to represent H. robustus) or Tanzania (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no information on any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. Taxonomic research is required to clarify the relationship between this species and Hemidactylus turcicus.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from three localities and very few specimens, and nothing is known of its natural history or any threats.
habitat: This species appears to be terrestrial (Parker 1942) and has been found beneath rocks (Parker 1932). It is probably nocturnal (Parker 1942).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species. The type series consists of five specimens collected at two localities (Parker 1932); no data is available for records from the third locality.
range: This species is known only from three localities in northeastern Somalia: Gedò (Bari region), and unnamed sites in the Sanaag and Nogal regions (Lanza 1990). It has been recorded from 810 m asl (Parker 1932).
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species' exact provenance, distribution, population status and ecology are completely unknown. The general area from which it was described is now entirely converted to agricultural land. If this species is a localized habitat specialist it may no longer exist, however, this region has not been subject to recent herpetological surveys and it closely resembles (and may be conspecific with) a disturbance-tolerant species known to persist in modified areas.
habitat: There is no natural history information available for this species. No natural vegetation survives in Chimbo, which is entirely agricultural land given over to fruit plantations. It is unknown whether this arboreal lizard could persist in these plantation habitats, or whether it is or was more widespread.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by a major threat. The entire area from which it was originally described no longer contains any native vegetation except for possibly small remnants, and the area has not been subject to recent herpetological surveys. As this lizard's ecology is wholly unknown, it is not clear whether it is able to persist in modified habitats. It has been proposed that it may be a junior synonym of Anolis tropidogaster (Peters 1967), a disturbance-tolerant species, and so it might be adapted to persist in disturbed areas.
population: This species was described based on "several specimens from Chimbo" (Boulenger 1898).
range: The only information regarding this species' distribution is that it is found in western Ecuador, with the type locality given as the canton of Chimbo in the province of Bolivar, Ecuador. More precise locality information is not available.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into the taxonomy, population status, distribution, habitat preferences, and threats to this species needs to be carried out.

rationale: This recently described species is assessed as Data Deficient due to unresolved taxonomic problems related to it. In fact, not even the type locality can be exactly retraced. There are several unpublished results suggesting that it might be a synonym of O. eregliensis or O. germenicus.
habitat: No habitat data are available.
threats: No threat data are available.
population: No population data are available for this taxon.
range: Turkey: the species might have been described from Büyück Menders drainage in western Anatolia, but the exact type locality is unknown.

rationale: This uncommon, benthopelagic species occurs on soft bottom on the continental shelf. No major threats are known, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species occurs occurs over soft bottom between 7-66 m depth on the continental shelf (Robins et al. 2012). All Lepophidium are oviparous and pelagic larvae are documented for a number of species. It has a maximum size of 16.4 cm SL.
threats: Lepophidium collettei likely occurs as bycatch in trawl fisheries, however, until quantifiable catch data is available, the extent of such a threat cannot be determined. No major threats are known for this species.
population: Lepophidium collettei is uncommon (Robins et al. 2012). At least 16 specimens have been deposited in museum collections between the years 1963-1975 (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2012-11-12).
range: Lepophidium collettei is distributed in the western Atlantic from 7-66 m depth along the South American coast from the Gulf of Paria, Venezuela to the mouth of the Amazon River (Robins et al. 2012).
useTrade: There is no evidence that Lepophidium collettei is utilized. Species of the Ophidiidae family are considered good eating in South America, and are targeted by recreational hook and line fishermen. They are also of some importance commercially, especially in Venezuela. Lepophidium spp. are occasionally harvested as bycatch of the shrimp trawling fishery on the northern coast of South America where they are marketed as "perla" (Cervigon et al. 1992, Nielsen 2002).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This common, deep-living, benthopelagic species is widely distributed and occurs over soft bottom on the continental shelf to slope. No major threats are known, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species occurs over soft bottom on the middle continental shelf and upper slope (Robins et al. 2012). Details on the life history of L. cultratum are limited. All Lepophidium are oviparous and pelagic larvae are documented for a number of species. It has a maximum size of 30.8 cm SL.
threats: Lepophidium cultratum occurs as bycatch in trawl fisheries, however, until quantifiable catch data is available, the extent of such a threat cannot be determined. No major threats are known for this species.
population: Lepophidium cultratum is a common, widespread species that may be locally abundant off Panama. At least 111 specimens have been deposited in museum collections between the years 1957-1983 (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2012-11-12). Previous to the description of Lepophidium cultratum many workers applied the name Lepophidium profundorum to the undescribed species (R. Robins pers. comm. 2013). A trawl survey completed in 2003 in the Gulf of Morrosquillo, Colombia on the bycatch of shrimp trawlers reported L. profundorum composing about 4.65% of the total catch (Herazo et al. 2006). It is likely that these data are attributable to L. cultratum.
range: Lepophidium cultratum is distributed in the western Atlantic from 91-329 m depth along the Central and South American coast from eastern Honduras to French Guiana (Robins et al. 2012).
