useTrade: There is some evidence that Lepophidium cultratum is utilized. Species of the Ophidiidae family are considered good eating in South America, and are targeted by recreational hook and line fishermen. They are also of some importance commercially, especially in Venezuela. Lepophidium spp. are occasionally harvested as bycatch of the shrimp trawling fishery on the northern coast of South America where it is marketed as "perla" (Cervigon et al. 1992, Nielsen 2002). Previous to the description of Lepophidium cultratum many workers applied the name Lepophidium profundorum to the undescribed species (R. Robins pers. comm. 2013).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This deep-living, benthopelagic species is widely distributed and occurs over soft bottom on the continental shelf to slope. No major threats are known, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species occurs over soft bottom on the middle continental shelf and upper slope from 101-261 m depth (Robins et al. 2012). Details on the life history of L. robustum are limited. All Lepophidium are oviparous and pelagic larvae are documented for a number of species (Fahay 1992, Richards 2006). It has a maximum size of 23 cm SL.
threats: Lepophidium robustum may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries, however, until quantifiable catch data is available, the extent of such a threat cannot be determined. No major threats are known for this species.
population: Lepophidium robustum is uncommonly recorded. At least 9 specimens have been deposited in museum collections that were captured between the years 1962-1969 (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2012-11-12).
range: Lepophidium robustum is distributed in the western Atlantic from 101-261 m depth along the southern Caribbean Sea from western Panama to north of Trinidad (Robins et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This deep-living, benthopelagic species is widely distributed and occurs over soft bottom on the continental shelf to slope. No major threats are known, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This benthopelagic species occurs from 173-348 m depth over soft bottom on the lower continental shelf and upper slope (Robins et al. 2012). Details on the life history of L. zophochir are limited, however all Lepophidium are oviparous and pelagic larvae are documented for a number of species. It has a maximum size of 24.3 cm SL.
threats: Lepophidium zophochir may occur as bycatch in trawl fisheries, however, until quantifiable catch data is available, the extent of such a threat cannot be determined. No major threats are known for this species.
population: This is a relatively commonly occurring species. At least 68 specimens have been deposited in museum collections that were captured between the years 1957-1983 (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2012-11-12).
range: Lepophidium zophochir is distributed in the western Atlantic from 173-348 m depth along the South American coast from Barranquilla, Colombia to the Guianas (Robins et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This deep-dwelling species is rarely recorded, but has a wide distribution and occurs over soft bottom. There are no known major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This deep-dwelling species occurs over soft bottom (Munroe 2002). Little is known on its habitat and ecology.
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is rarely recorded (Munroe 2002).
range: This species has been recorded in the western Atlantic off Caribbean Nicaragua in the southern San Andreas Archipelago and from La Guajira Peninsula, Colombia to west of Nueva Esparta Island off Venezuela (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its depth range is 115-200 m (Munroe 2002).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while poorly-known, this species is widespread in Somalia.
habitat: This is a fossorial species, and is thought to be associated with relatively humid soils given its distribution (Parker 1942). No other data are available on its ecology. T. Mazuch (pers. comm. 2019) reports having seen a photograph of this species on social media, which was of an animal found in coastal southern Somalia beneath a shipping container.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is "not uncommon" (Parker 1942), although in contrast Gans and Pandit (1965) report that it is very uncommon in collections.
range: This species is known from the south-central coast of Somalia (where it is widespread - Gans and Pandit 1965) (Gans 2005). The subspecies Agamadon anguliceps immaculatus is known only from Afghedud in the Mudug region and a site in Galgadud "7 km NW of the Rugno Well" (Lanza 1990), both in central Somalia. Gans (2005) includes eastern Ethiopia in the species' distribution, presumably based on a record from Ethiopia with no associated locality data (Gans 1960), but the species is not included in a recent field guide to the reptiles of Ethiopia (Largen and Spawls 2010).
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is very poorly known and records so far exist only from a restricted area of southern Somalia.
habitat: This is a burrowing species that, based on its coastal distribution and its absence from more arid northern Somalia, is thought to prefer relatively humid soils (Parker 1942). No other ecological data are available. Specimens have been collected within metres of the related, but morphologically distinct, Agamodon anguliceps (Gans and Pandit 1965).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is "not uncommon" (Parker 1942). It has nonetheless rarely been reported in the literature and few specimens are known: Gans and Pandit (1965) conducted the only review to date of this species, reporting that only three specimens had previously been reported in the literature and providing data for 12 specimens.
range: This species is endemic to coastal southern Somalia, with records from the Mogadishu and Middle Shebelli regions (Lanza 1990).
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. Further research is needed to obtain more specimens, to clarify the distribution and natural history of this species and to determine whether any threats exist.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this poorly-known species has not been recorded for over 50 years and there is essentially no information on its distribution, ecological requirements, or its exposure or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: Nothing is known about this species' habitat requirements (Spawls et al. 2002). Animals are likely associated with sandy areas containing termite mounds. It is expected to be similar to other worm lizards, i.e. fossorial, oviparous with a single egg laid in a clutch, and to feed on small invertebrates (likely termites) (Spawls et al. 2002).
threats: It is unknown whether patterns of land use change are impacting this species' habitat, as nothing is known of its ecological tolerances (Spawls et al. 2002), but it is not thought likely to be threatened by any other process (Spawls et al. 2002).
population: A. b. barkeri is known only from the holotype. The A. b. newalae type series contains eight specimens, the most recent collected in 1962 (the year of the subspecies' description) (Gans 2005).
range: This species is endemic to southeastern Tanzania (Spawls et al. 2002). Both of the recognized subspecies are known only from their respective types (Gans 2005): A. b. barkeri from a single specimen collected in Mbembkuru, Lindi District, and A. b. newalae from the Makonde Plateau (Spawls et al. 2002). It may be more widespread than these records suggest (Spawls et al. 2002). It is found possibly around 800 to 1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Additional surveys are needed to rediscover this species and better understand the range, habitat and ecology and any possible threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a small number of records in poorly-known areas of Somalia, it may not have been recorded for more than 50 years, and nothing is known of its full distribution, population status, ecology or any threats.
habitat: There is no information on the ecological requirements of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species. Gans (2005) lists two known specimens for the nominate form and three for Ancylocranium somalicum parkeri; the latter have accession dates in 1958. Gans and Pandit (1965) mention in passing that a drowned specimen of this species was found in a pool south of Mogadishu, but these authors do not discuss this record.
range: This worm lizard is a near-endemic to coastal southern Somalia, where it has been recorded from a number of localities from the mouth of the Giuba (=Jubba) River to Eggi (Gans 2005, Lanza 1990). The subspecies Ancylocranium somalicum parkeri - treated as a full species without comment by Gans (2005) - is restricted to the Haud in northern Somalia, where it is known from three specimens at elevations of 2,100-2,300 ft (640-700 m asl) (Gans 2005).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that almost nothing is known of this species, which is known from a small number of records from Sudan and South Sudan and appears not to have been reported since 1994.
habitat: There is no information on the ecological requirements of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: This species is known only from a small number of localities on the east bank of the Blue Nile, close to Suki, Singa and Sennar in southeastern Sudan (Broadley 1994, Loveridge 1955), from Wadi Medani in east-central Sudan (Broadley 1994), and from a series reported from Torit in modern South Sudan (Loveridge 1955).
useTrade: There is almost certainly no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species that this species is known from four specimens from a single locality and appears not to have been recorded since its original description.
habitat: No ecological information is available for this species. The type locality is a mountain oasis (Lanza 1978).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This is a rare species (Schätti et al. 2009). Lanza (1978) report that it was then known from four specimens, two of which were new records from the same general area; it is not known to have been recorded since (S. Spawls pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is only known from Galgalo Oasis in northwest Somalia (Puntland) (Lanza 1990, Schätti et al. 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. Research is needed to obtain more material of this species and clarify its distribution, population status, ecological requirements and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species is poorly-known, it has an extent of occurrence greater than 30,000 km<sup>2</sup> in an arid area of northeastern Somalia where human population density is generally low.
habitat: There is no information on the ecological requirements of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, but members of this genus are generally common in Somalia (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019)..
range: This species is known only from the Sanaag, Bari and Nogal regions of northeastern Somalia (Lanza 1990), from the Sol Haud to the coastal zone (Parker1942). Most records are from between 600 and 1,000 m asl, but there is at least one record from as low as 6 m asl (Parker 1942).
useTrade: There is no information on any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is only known from two specimens, collected at least 50 years apart, and it has not been recorded for over 60 years.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is known from only two specimens, the most recent with a catalogue number indicating a 1954 collection date (Largen and Rasmussen 1993).
range: This species known only from the highlands of northwest Somalia (Woroqi Galbeed region - Lanza 1990), where it was described from Wagga in the Goolis Mountains between 900 and 1,250 m asl (Boulenger 1906). The only other locality record available is a specimen from Hargeisha mentioned by Largen and Rasmussen (1993) and Broadley and Wallach (2007), also in this region of the country. The species is presumed to occur in Ethiopia, but no records yet exist (Largen and Rasmussen 1993).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to obtain more material and clarify its occurrence in Ethiopia, as well as to clarify its ecology and determine whether it is subject to major threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single 19th century specimen from an unspecific locality in Sudan, and nothing is known of its true distribution, ecology or any threats.
habitat: No ecological data is available for this snake, although all thread snakes are fossorial. This may be one of the smallest known snakes, however it is not clear that the known specimen was an adult (Adalsteinsson et al. 2009).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, which was destroyed in a fire in 1978 (Broadley and Wallach 2007, Adalsteinsson et al. 2009).
range: This species was described from "White Nile, central Africa", indicating a distribution in modern Sudan (Broadley and Wallach 2007), but no other information is available.
useTrade: There is presumably no use of or trade in this species, which is known from a single specimen.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. More information is needed on this species' population, habitat requirements, and ecology,.

rationale: Hypsilurus bruijnii has been assessed as Data Deficient because it is only known from one, imprecise locality in Indonesian New Guinea, and nothing is known of its true distribution, ecological requirements, or its exposure and sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: This species is presumably found within rainforest, in common with other members of the genus, but no habitat or elevational nformation is associated with the known, imprecise locality.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: The species is only known from the type locality "Arfak Mountains", West Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. It is apparently only known from this locality; records from elsewhere need verification following taxonomic changes (Manthey and Denzer 2006). Its precise range within the Arfak Mountains (the highlands of the Vogelkop Peninsula) is unclear, and the mapped distribution is therefore approximate.
useTrade: There is presumably no use or trade in this species, which is known only from its type description.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known whether it occurs in any protected areas. Further research on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and its exposure and sensitivity to any threats is recommended.

rationale: Varanus telenesetes has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is currently known only from a single specimen reportedly from Rossel island in Milne Bay Province, Papua New Guinea. This locality is doubtful, and the species' true distribution is therefore wholly unknown. Further research on this species taxonomy, population status, ecological requirements and any threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: This species is thought to be an arboreal monitor inhabiting moist forests, but because of the uncertainty surrounding this species' idemtity and true distribution its habitat requirements are unknown.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is subject to any major threats, as nothing is known of its true distribution or ecological requirements.
population: Targeted surveys revealed that villagers were unaware of any prasinus-like monitors on Rossel Island (G. Shea pers. comm. 2014). The only known specimen was collected in the 1900s, and as the collector sampled widely in eastern New Guinea it is very possible that this species was collected elsewhere and that the locality data is incorrect (G. Shea pers. comm. 2014).
range: This species is endemic to Papua  New Guinea and known only from Rossel Island, Milne Bay Province (Böhme 2003). The island has an area of 262 km².
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species, which is known from a single specimen collected over a century ago. Most monitor lizards, however, are collected to some degree for the international pet trade.
conservationActions: This species is listed under Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES)<span lang="EN-GB">. This species is not known to occur in any protected areas. Further research into the taxonomy of this species is recommended; if it proves to be valid, research will be needed to locate a wild population and determine its distribution, population status, natural history and exposure and sensitivity to any threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species is poorly-known, it seems to occur widely on Seram - which retains a relatively large area of contiguous, good forest - and has a global extent of occurrence of nearly 60,000 km<sup>2</sup>, and recent observations suggest it exhibits some degree of tolerance of habitat modification
habitat: Very little is known about this species (Murphy 2007). Remains of earthworms in stomach contents indicate that this species is not aquatic (J. Murphy, pers. comm. 2009). No specific information exists on the types of habitats the species occurs in. Stubbs (pers. comm. 2019) reports finding it in a rural garden in Seram, beneath a rice sack in a coconut plantation.
threats: Any major threats to this species are unknown. Seram is being deforested but it is unclear whether this is having any impact on this species, and large continuous tracts of good forest remain. The main drivers are palm oil plantations and industrial-scale logging.
population: There is little information available on the abundance of this species. This species is considered uncommon in museum collections and is therefore it is considered to be scarce in the wild.
range: Following Murphy et al. (2012) this species is restricted to Seram and Ambon in Maluku Province, Indonesia. Historical records exist from a number of satellites of Seram (Kopstein 1926); a 19th century record from the Banda Islands needs confirmation (Murphy et al. 2012). A museum specimen from Pulau Bisa is "very similar to this species" (Murphy et al. 2012). These authors discuss historical confusion regarding records of this species from other islands (ranging from Sumatra to New Guinea), which appear to represent misidentifications of morphologically similar species or erroneous localities.
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is possible that it is present within some protected areas, although this requires confirmation. It probably occurs in Manusela National Park in Seram, which is presently effective due to its size and inaccessibility, although there is some logging (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Dendrelaphis lorentzi has been assessed as Least Concern. It has a large distribution in New Guinea, and while it is poorly known it is not believed to be affected by any major threats.
habitat: The exact habitat preferences of this species are unknown. From its collection localities it seems to be riverine, however, it is possible that this is a result of collection bias as both surveys and local settlements are concentrated around rivers (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015).
threats: It seems unlikely that any major threat is impacting this species, as it appears to be widespread and there are large tracts of largely intact natural habitat within its range.
population: This rarely-encountered species is known only from a few specimens (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015). As individual records have been reported from widely scattered localities in northwest (Salawati), northeast (Huon Peninsula) and extreme eastern (Normanby), it may be widespread but uncommon and under-recorded (van Rooijen et al. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to the island of New Guinea. In Papua New Guinea, it is known from the Western Province, at Balimo on the Aramia River, at Tabubil in the upper reaches of the Fly River, and at Gusiko on the Huon Peninsula as well as from Morobe Province. In Papua Province (Indonesia), it is known from the Lorentz and Mimika Rivers (O'Shea 1996), and from Salawati island (van Rooijen et al. 2015). A photographic record exists from Normanby Island (van Rooijen et al. 2015). Unconfirmed records exist from a number of other localities across both Indonesian Papua and Papua New Guinea (M. O'Shea unpubl. data), suggesting that this species may be widespread across the island but uncommonly encountered (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015, van Rooijen et al. 2015). This species is found between sea level and 1,000 m above sea level.
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place, or needed, for this species. This species may occur in protected areas in New Guinea, although this requires confirmation. Further research is required into the taxonomy of this species once more material from northern New Guinea is obtained.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as although this species has been recorded over a wide range and good forest remains in Seram and much of New Guinea, it is known from few specimens and nothing is known with certainty about the habitat requirements, especially in the context of possible threats on islands that have undergone or are projected to undergo substantial habitat modification - particularly Halmahera.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species, however, it is known that species of this genus are usually found in association with freshwater, within rainforest, open or cultivated country, or even towns (O'Shea 1996).
threats: This species is may be threatened on Halmahera by extensive clear-cutting of forest habitat. Although rates of forest loss on Halmahera have been relatively low until recently (ranging from 5.8-10% between 2000 and 2018 based on data from Global Forest Watch), industrial-scale housing developments are underway and the island exhibits signs of forthcoming industrial-scale oil palm plantations (Hughes 2018). Data for 2015 suggests an increase in deforestation rates of 252% compared with previous years (Hughes 2018). Forest cover is declining on both Morotai (8% of forest with 30% canopy cover between 2000 and 2014 - BirdLife International 2019 derived from Hansen 2013) and Ternate (4.8% between 2000 and 2018 based on Global Forest Watch data). Threats on Seram and New Guinea are likely to be less severe, but this species is known from too few specimens to determine where the majority of the population occurs and the reasons for its apparent rarity over such a wide area are not well-understood.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known from a small number of specimens over a very wide area.
range: This species occurs on the eastern Indonesian islands of Seram, Ambon and Halmahera in Maluku Province. In Indonesian New Guinea it has been found on Salawati island and in several localities in West Papua Province and on Biak and Numfor island (Malnate and Underwood 1988) and Wapoga area in Papua Province (Richards et al. 2000). This species is found up to a maximum altitude of 500 m above sea level.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known whether this species is present in any protected areas. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Toxicocalamus misimae has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is known only from Misima Island in Milne Bay Province, Papua New Guinea and is therefore restricted in its range. It is likely to inhabit lowland rainforest which is under increasing threat from deforestation and conversion. It does not occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species, however, it is probably found within lowland rainforest. It is likely to be a diurnal species, semi-fossorial and feeds on earthworms. It may be oviparous.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. Misima Island is the most populated island in the Louisiade Archipelago and areas of remaining forest are threatened by conversion and urban expansion. The region has previously been mined, however, this is no longer a threat. The restricted range of this species may present a threat, as it is more vulnerable to stochastic events. The loss of these forests could impact heavily on the endemic species found in this region (Shearman and Bryan 2011).
population: It is known only from three specimens.
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea, and known from Misima Island in the Louisiade Archipelago in Milne Bay Province. The  range map encompasses the entire island, however, its occurrence throughout Misima has not been confirmed (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015). It has also tentatively been recorded in Mekeo in Central Province but this needs verification as it seems likely to be a misidentification (O'Shea 1996). It ranges from 100 to 350 m asl.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Conservation measures are required to reduce the rate of habitat loss due to urban expansion, such as the establishment of protected areas. Further research on this species population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Ramphotyphlops similis has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is only known from its one location in West Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. It is not known if there are any threats to this species.
habitat: Little is known about the natural history of this fossorial species.
threats: The threats to this species are not well known.
population: It is known only from a few specimens.
range: This species is endemic to Indonesian New Guinea and is known only from Manokwari on the Doberai Peninsula in West Papua Province (McDiarmid et al. 1999). It is found at <100 m asl.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas. Further research into this species' population status, habitat and threats is recommended.

rationale: Leptostomias longibarba is subtropical to tropical North Atlantic and area 34 and N47, excluding the Gulf of Guinea. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: There is no habitat information for this species. Reports of the subfamily Melanostomiinae show some species, especially females, undergo diel vertical migrations and that their diets consist mainly of other mesopelagic fishes.
threats: There do not appear to be any threats towards this species, although further study is needed to verify this.
population: There are six records of this specimen in four geocodes. The lot with the largest specimens taken in one haul was two, taken off the coast of Louisiana (Fishnet2 2012). In a separate study conducted in 2001 off around the seamounts of the Azores archipelago reported that the percentage of total catch for  L. longibarba was 0.00004 (Melo and Menezes 2002).
range: Leptostomias longibarba is found in the eastern Atlantic between Ireland and the Azores, as well as from the Canary Islands to South Africa. However, it is not recorded in the Gulf of Guinea. In the western Atlantic, it is found off of Bermuda (Gibbs and Barnett 1990).
useTrade: This species is not utilized in trade.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because this species has not been recorded since 1890.
habitat: Unknown.
threats: It has been suggested that an important factor in the decline of hare-wallabies has been the alteration of grassland habitat through trampling and grazing by sheep and cattle. The removal of aboriginal Australians from large areas by European settlers may also have contributed to loss of hare-wallabies by resulting in the removal of regular winter burning regimes and increasing the likelihood of devastating lightening-caused fires in summer months.
population: It is presumed to be extinct. Little is known about this species. Krefft (1866) found it to be common in the 1850s on the plains around the junction of the Murray and Darling Rivers.
range: The Eastern Hare-wallaby formerly occurred in central New South Wales, north-western Victoria and eastern South Australia. Subfossil data extends the range into southern Queensland (Burbidge et al. 2009). Specimens in the National Museums, Liverpool, and the Natural History Museum, London, from the 1840s labelled ‘South Australia’ and ‘Interior of New south Wales’ do not have accurate collecting localities (C. Fisher pers. comm.).
conservationActions: The species is extinct.

rationale: The Nullarbor Dwarf Bettong was described very recently (McNamara 1997). It is known only from subfossil material, but is considered to have been extant at European settlement, e.g. Baynes (1987 as ‘unnamed potoroid’) placed it in the modern mammal fauna of the Nullarbor Plain. It has never been reported alive (Boscacci et al. 1987).
habitat: There is no information about its habitat or ecology.
threats: The species is extinct.
population: Only known from recent subfossils (McNamara 1997). The species is thought to have persisted after European settlement.
range: The Nullarbor Dwarf Bettong is known only from the Nullarbor and adjacent Hampton and Mallee bioregions (Burbidge et al. 2009)
conservationActions: All Bettongia spp. are listed on CITES Appendix I.
yearLastSeen: There is no record of it ever having been seen.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence and population status – it is known from only two specimens. It has not been seen since 1990, but surveys appropriate to the species (which seems to have very specific habitat requirements) have not been conducted. The habitat is still largely intact, but dogs may be a threat if they are in the area.
habitat: Very little is known about the natural history of Menzies' Echymipera. It is suspected to be restricted to a specific habitat type that has not been well surveyed, possibly the gallery forests along the Fly-Strickland river drainage.
threats: Threats to Menzies' Echymipera are not known. It could be restricted to a specific habitat type. Predation by feral dogs may be a threat to the species.
population: Menzies' Echymipera is known from only two (possibly three) specimens. It appears to be a naturally rare species.
range: This species is known only from two fairly recent specimens collected at two localities in the Fly-Strickland river drainage of Papua New Guinea. There is a third, unconfirmed record from Mount Menawi. If accepted, this would extend both the range and the elevation of the species. Elevation range is sea level up to 1,000 m asl.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed to determine the range, natural history, and possible threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing problems with its taxonomy as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: There is little information available on the natural history of this poorly known bat.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from the holotype.
range: This poorly known species has only been recorded at the type locality of 'between Semian and Wogara, Belegaz Valley, Ethiopia'.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further research is needed into the systematic status, distribution, natural history and possible threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, threats, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on habitat and ecology, although this species should have similar habits to other medium-sized species in the genus, being a frugivore from Andean mature forests (see Handley 1976).
threats: Threats for this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species.
range: The species is known from northern Venezuela and northern to central Andes of Colombia (Simmons 2005, Velazco and Gardner 2009). In its most restricted sense, it does not include P. aquilus, which occurs in southeastern Panama (Velazco and Gardner 2009).
conservationActions: Further studies are needed into the distribution, habitat, ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct), as it has not been recorded since the nineteenth century despite some surveys within its range, and it is quite a colourful and large bat. It may have been the target of hunting and may now be possibly extinct. There is one unconfirmed record of a bone from this species from 1992.
habitat: There is little information available about the ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. This species is a potential target for hunting, and this may have resulted in the species' decline, but this has not been confirmed. Large-scale sugarcane plantation development on the Aru Islands threatens 92% of the primary tropical forest, which could be a devastating loss of habitat for this species (Obidzinski et al. 2015).
population: This species has not been collected since the nineteenth century. The complete absence of twentieth-century records for P. aruensis is concerning, and expeditions to the Aru Islands sponsored by the Western Australian Museum in the early 1990s did not encounter it. However, a single toothless jaw from a kitchen midden collected by P.A. Woolley at Namara on the island of Kobroor in October/November 1992 probably represents this species (field number NA/36, unregistered lot at CSIRO) (K. Helgen pers. comm.). It is a very large and colourful bat and so hence it is potentially a target of concerted hunting. It could possibly be extinct.
range: This species is apparently restricted to the Aru Islands, Indonesia (Simmons 2005).
conservationActions:
There are no conservation measures in place for this species. A proposed protected area (Pulau Kobroor) is within the general area where the species was found. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats of this species.
It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, threats, status and ecological requirements. However, due to the extent of the species occupancy being quite small (the Kei Islands are only 1,440 km²), and continued habitat degradation due to slash and burn agriculture, this may qualify the species in a threatened category in the near future.
habitat: Nothing is known of the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. Habitat degradation probably threatens the species, as slash and burn agriculture is common on the Kei Islands.
population: The abundance, population size and trends for this species are not known.
range: This species occurs on Kei Islands in Indonesia.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, reproduction, ecology and threats of this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its presumed wide distribution, apparent tolerance to habitat disturbance and relative abundance at known sites in Viet Nam. An extensive study through its distributional range is required for a proper confirmation,
habitat: Nothing is known about habitat preferences that is unequivocally attributable to this species (Smith et al. 2008).
threats: There are no major threats although the species may be affected by hunting in some parts of its range (C. Francis pers. comm).
population: As currently defined this is a common bat throughout much of its range (Bates et al. 2008).
range: This species occurs in Yunnan, China (Smith et al. 2008), extending to Myanmar (Akanti, Upper Chindwin), northern Thailand, and northern Viet Nam (Simmons 2005). It can be expected in northern Lao PDR, but this has not been confirmed. Although H. grandis is considered distinct from H. larvatus the geographical range is not clearly understood and it is impossible to draw a range separate from that of larvatus with any degree of confidence.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, and ecology of this species.

rationale: Kai Horseshoe Bat is assessed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its status, ecological requirements, and threats. The current population status of this species is unknown, yet there are large scale habitat changes occurring in its known range, which could lead to population declines.
habitat: Presumably this is a cave roosting species.
threats: There have been large-scale habitat changes within its range, but the impact of these on the species has not been recorded.
population: The population abundance is not known.
range: This insular species has been recorded on the Indonesian islands of Lombok, Sumbawa, Komodo, Wetar, Ambon, Batjan, Goreng, Ternate, Bacan, Manawoka, and the Kai Islands (Flannery 1995). It has also been recorded from the island of Timor (Timor-Leste and Indonesia).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Protection of important roosting sites and foraging areas is needed. Further studies are necessary into the taxonomic status, distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient as there is no new information regarding this species since its first description in 1844 based on a single specimen. Its taxonomic status is highly doubtful.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitat or ecology of this species (Molur et al. 2002). It might be a cave roosting species, but this needs to be confirmed.
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown (Molur et al. 2002).
population: It is known only from the holotype collected in 1844.
range: This species is endemic to India. It is presently known only from the type locality, Chaibassa in Jharkhand (Molur et al. 2002), at an elevation of 300 m. Recent surveys by Y.P. Sinha did not yield any new records of this species from the type locality (Molur et al. 2002).
conservationActions: Very little is known about this species, hence surveys, ecological studies and habitat evaluation are recommended (Molur et al. 2002).

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient because there is no information on the population status, habitats, ecology or threats to this species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species (G. Csorba pers. comm).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown (G. Csorba pers. comm).
population: The status of the population is unknown (G. Csorba pers. comm).
range: This species is known only from Siantan Island (Anamba Islands) and North Natuna Islands in Indonesia.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, habitat, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, as it occurs in a number of protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: This species is poorly known. All previous information for C. brevicauda applies to C. sowelli (Pineda pers. comm.).
threats: There are no known threats throughout its range.
population: In a rapid assessment in Alta Verapaz, Guatemala, C. sowelli was the most abundant species.
range: This species is known from San Luis Potosi (Mexico) south to west Panama (Simmons 2005).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is found in protected areas. Research actions are required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is only known from its holotype specimen and in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity. The taxonomic uncertainty and the detectability challenges prevents concluding the species as extinct. The Nendö Tube-nosed Bat may be indistinguishable from populations of Nyctimene major elsewhere in the Solomon Islands (Helgen et al. 2009). There is also an absence of any information on its extent of occurrence, status, and ecological requirements (though the species would almost certainly qualify as threatened if it is a valid species). Research is needed to resolve the taxonomic uncertainty and to confirm, if possible, the existence of the species.
habitat: There is no information available regarding the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: Disturbance by humans may have led to the extinction of this species (Mickleburgh et al. 1992). The island of Nendö has been extensively logged in the past, and renewed logging has commenced and is proposed for additional areas of the island which could potentially be a threat to the species if still extant (T. Leary pers. comm.).
population: The Nendö Tube-nosed Bat is known from a single specimen, and may now be extinct (Flannery 1995, Parnaby et al. 2017) if a taxonomically valid species (Helgen et al. 2009). Extensive surveys in the 1980s and 1990s (Flannery 1995, Leary and Aujare 1994) and more recent surveys between 2014 and 2018 (T. Leary pers. comm,) failed to find any Nyctimene species on Nendö Island. The majority of this survey effort has concentrated on the lowland coastal zone and has targeted primary and secondary lowland rainforest and gardens, although there has also been some mist-netting away from the coast and in mangrove habitats (T. Leary pers. comm.). This survey effort is by no means exhaustive, and much of this survey effort has been at a similar time of year (T. Leary pers. comm.). This is important because even a slight difference in season and habitats sampled can change the detectability of other Nyctimene. For example, N. major in New Britain and Bougainville, were captured in large numbers seasonally, feeding on beach front fruiting trees, whilst no captures were made just 200 m inland in forest areas (S. Hamilton pers. comm.).
range: The Nendö tube-nosed bat is known only from the holotype - a single female specimen sent to the Australian Museum by Rev. Actaeon Forrest in July 1892 along with other specimens of bats and fish but the locality was not recorded, other than Santa Cruz Group (Parnaby et al. 2017). Flannery (1995) suggested that the specimen was from Santa Cruz (Nendö) Island and certainly from within the Santa Cruz Island Group. Mickleburgh et al. (1992) erroneously report that it was last seen on Nendö in 1907, however there is no evidence to suggest this. Several subsequent biological expeditions in the 1980s and 1990s and between 2014 to 2018 to the region have failed to confirm this species (Flannery 1995, T. Leary pers. comm.).
useTrade: The species is unlikely to be hunted or traded due to its comparatively small size. On Nendö Island, the main bat species targeted by hunters is the much larger (420 – 550 g) Pacific Flying Fox Pteropus tonganus (T. Leary pers. comm.).
conservationActions: Research is needed to resolve taxonomic uncertainty and to confirm, if possible, the existence of this species on Nendö Island.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient given unresolved questions regarding the validity of the species and in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: There is no information regarding the habitat other than the site descriptions of the specimens collected by Emmons and Kinbag (2001). Nothing is known of the ecology of this species.
threats: It is not known whether this species faces any threats.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: The precise distribution of the Demonic Tube-nosed Bat is unknown, and  there may be confusion with other species in the genus. It appears to be  endemic to the island of New Ireland in the Bismarck Archipelago, Papua  New Guinea. The type locality of this species is Ralum, New Ireland (3  degrees 31' S, 152 degrees 22' E). The species might extend through the  Bismarcks, perhaps the north coast islands of Papua New Guinea, and  possibly even the east Papuan Islands (relevant museum samples from  these regions need to be investigated, K. Helgen pers. comm.). Little is  known about the altitudinal distribution of the species, but Emmons and  Kinbag (2001) assign specimens collected on southern New Ireland in the  Weitin River valley (165 and 260 m asl) and the lower Hans Meyer Range  (1200 m asl) to this species.
useTrade: The species is unlikely to be hunted or traded given its small size, though animals opportunistically encountered may be killed for food.
conservationActions: The distribution of this species is uncertain, as is the taxonomic status. Studies are needed into the ecology, biology, and threats to it.

rationale: This bat is now listed as Extinct because the species is only known from a single skull found in 1972 and extensive surveys have failed to locate it since. The incomplete skull was originally considered to be a sub-fossil until a re-examination indicated that it was likely deposited 50-100 years ago (Duncan et al. 1999).
habitat: Nothing is known about this species' preferred habitats since the only known specimen (an incomplete skull) was collected from a ledge in a cave that may have been an owl roost (Duncan et al. 1999).
threats: The reasons for its decline and eventual extinction are unclear. However, it is possible that this species was predated by introduced owls and rats.
population: The incomplete skull this species is known from was originally considered to be a sub-fossil until a re-examination indicated that it was likely deposited 50–100 years ago (Duncan et al. 1999).
range: This species was thought to be endemic to Lord Howe Island, New South Wales, Australia.
conservationActions: Introduced owls have now been eradicated from Lord Howe Island and programmes to eradicate rats are underway (Duncan et al. 1999). However, extensive surveys for this species have not located any remaining animals (Duncan et al. 1999).

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient since it has only recently been described, and there is still very little information on its extent of occurrence, status, threats and ecological requirements.
habitat: This small bat is mainly insectivorous. It may be associated with Giant Armadillo burrows (Davalos pers. comm.)
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: It is rare (Simmons et al. 2002).
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Peru, Loreto Department, southeast bank of Río Gálvez, village of Nuevo San Juan (5°17'30"S, 73°9'50"W, 150 m asl; Simmons et al. 2002, Simmons 2005).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: The holotype was not found in a protected area but we know nothing more. Further research on this species is needed.

rationale: The species is listed as Near Threatened because it is in significant decline (but at a rate of almost 25% over three generations (15 years; Pacifici et al. 2013) due to human population density on the island and habitat conversion, although the species occurs in a small range. Almost qualifies as threatened under criterion A2c.
habitat: This species is poorly known. It is insectivorous; a few fecal pellets from a single bat have been examined; they contained only beetles. Activity is probably crepuscular, as evidenced by a few observations. Usually roosting on the foliage of large trees (Silva-Taboada 1979). It seems to be associated to woodland patches (Mancina et al. 2007).
threats: As usually reported for other Caribbean bats, severe weather (e.g., hurricanes) can be a major threat to local populations. Also human population density in the island and habitat conversion.
population: Rare and uncommon in collections. The highest number of individuals recorded rooting has been three, in two occasions; otherwise, it is always found as a single individual (Silva-Taboada 1979). It is a widespread species, but it is rarely found (Mancina et al. 2007).
range: Lasiurus pfeifferi only occurs in Cuba (Simmons, 2005). This species was previously include under the species L. borealis, but is clearly recognized as distinct by most recent authors (Baird et al. 2015).
conservationActions: Research actions are needed to improve our knowledge on this widespread but rare species. It is found in protected areas in Cuba.

rationale: The species is confirmed as Near Threatened because it is in significant decline (at a suspected rate of about 25% over three generations (15 years; Pacifici et al. 2013) due to human population density on the island and reduction of habitat quality, being that the species occurs in less than 20 localities. Almost qualifies as threatened under criterion A2c.
habitat: This species is poorly known. It is insectivorous (Silva-Taboada 1979). During the day it roost in small groups under human buildings and light posts (C. Mancina, pers. comm.). A female with two embryos was recorded in May, nothing else is known about its reproduction (Silva-Taboada 1979). All the known records come from the four western provinces of Cuba (Mancina et al. 2007). These bats fly slowly among the vegetation, when darkness is complete (Silva-Taboada 1979).
threats: Its restricted distribution suggests some degree of habitat specialization or past extinction from part of its original distribution. Changes in habitat or roost suitability can make its populations vulnerable to extinction. Severe weather (hurricanes) are a potential disturbance to island populations. However, specific or immediate threats to this species are unknown.
population: This is an endemic and uncommon species, although it is locally common in some localities of the Pinar del Río province and Havana City (Mancina et al. 2007). In general, it is poorly known (Mancina pers. comm.)
range: Nycticeius cubanus is a species endemic to Cuba (Simmons 2005). It has been collected only in the western half of the island (Mancina et al. 2007).
conservationActions: Research actions are needed, as few details on the biology of the species are known. It is found in protected areas (Mancina pers. comm.).

rationale: There have been exhaustive surveys of Réunion and this species has not been recorded for nearly 140 years. However, there is not enough information to determine its taxonomic status, as the holotype is badly damaged and other possible specimens cannot be reliably assigned to this species. If the taxonomic status of this species is confirmed, then the species may qualify for a higher threat category and may well be extinct.
habitat: The natural history of this species is not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species was considered to be relatively common in the early 19th Century on La Réunion; however, it was not recorded in the 20th century or 21st century (Cheke and Dahl 1981).
range: This holotype was described from two specimens from La Réunion and one of these was designated as the lectotype but is now in very poor condition (Goodman et al. 2005). In Madagascar, it is known only from a single specimen collected in 1868, at Sarodrano, near Toliara in the south (Goodman et al. 2005). The identity of the Madagascar specimen cannot be confirmed due to absence of reliable material from La Réunion. The area near Sarodrano has been relatively well surveyed recently, but no new specimens were obtained (Goodman et al. 2005).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place.

rationale: This is a recently described species and very little is known. This species is listed as Data Deficient in view of absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Little is known of the habitat or ecology of this species, but it is probably similar to other members of the genus.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This is a recently described species and very little is known.
range: This species is known only in Venezuela and Bolivia (Sánchez-Hernández et al. 2005). Its geographic distribution between these points is unknown. Experts consider that this species needs revision to clarify its distribution and ecology.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: Areas where this species has been collected in Bolivia are in protected areas. A review of the taxonomy is required.

rationale: The species is confirmed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There is little information on the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: This species is endemic to Grand Comore island in the Comoros.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: There is no information on the habitats and ecology.
threats: There are no known threats throughout its range.
population: This is an uncommon species (Barquez pers. comm.). Only six specimens have been collected (Barquez pers. comm.).
range: This species occurs in Venezuela, Trinidad, Guyana, Suriname, Brazil, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Paraguay and northern Argentina (Simmons 2005).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: Research actions are required for this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, presence at several protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: Not many studies, although it seems to occur in a wide variety of habitats (Eger 2008). It occurs up to 1,800 m (Reid 2009, Solari et al. 2013). Found in lowland humid forests, deciduous forests and pine-oak, as well as pastures and even urban areas (Eisenberg 1989, Jung and Kalko 2011). These bats are known to forage in open areas above the forest canopy or in open landscapes (Jung et al. 2014).
threats: There are no major threats throughout its range.
population: It seems to be a common species through its geographic distribution (S. Solari, pers. comm). It is not very common in Mexico, although a recent study suggest them as very active at a northern locality (González-Terrazas et al. 2016).
range: This species is present from Jalisco and Yucatán (Mexico) south to eastern Ecuador and Peru, western Brazil, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname, and Trinidad, western Bolivia, Paraguay, and northeastern Argentina (Simmons 2005). Paraguay distribution adjusted according to Eger (2008). New record from northwestern Mexico extends the geographic range of the species (González-Terrazas et al. 2016). Not found in Costa Rica (B. Rodriguez, pers. comm). This is the restricted definition of the species after the validation of P. davisoni by Gregorin and Chiquito (2010).
conservationActions: Because of its large geographic distribution, this bat is found within several protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because it is likely in significant decline, but probably at a rate of less than but close to 30% over the past three generations (with a generation length of six years), because of widespread habitat loss and degradation throughout much of its range. This species is close to qualifying for Vulnerable based on A2c.
habitat: Very little is known about this species. It does not eat fruit (Solari pers. comm.). The generation length is six years (Pacifici et al. 2013).
threats: Habitat conversion to agriculture is the primary threat.
population: It is rare and known from approximately 10 individuals (Solari pers. comm.). It is expected to decline in response to increasing human habitat destruction.
range: This species occurs in northwest Peru and southwest Ecuador (Simmons 2005).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It occurs in a few protected areas in northern Peru.

rationale: This bat is assessed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, threats, ecology, and population status.
habitat: There is little information available about the ecology and habitat preferences of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: This species is found on Java, Madura, Lombok, Sumbawa, Moyo, Alor, Wetar, Seralu, Timor (including Timor-Leste), Semau, Roti, and Savu Islands in Indonesia (Simmons 2005).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, natural history and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There is little information about the natural history of this bat, in part because it has often been confused with Neoromicia nana.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Little information is available on the population abundance or size of this species.
range: This East African species has been recorded from Djibouti, southern Somalia, southern Sudan, northeastern Uganda, Kenya and northern Tanzania. It may be more widely distributed (Peterson 1987, Simmons 2005).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. There is a need for studies into the distribution, abundance, natural history and possible threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species has been recorded from a wide variety of habitats. It has been reported from both lowland and montane tropical moist forest, dry and moist savanna, and similar wooded areas. They appear to be particularly common in localities with some banana plants (Skinner and Chimimba 2005). The rolled up, terminal, leaves of these plants are frequently used as roosting sites, although the species has also been recorded in roofs and in thatch of rural huts (Skinner and Smithers 1990; Taylor 2000). Animals usually roost singly or as small colonies of two to six individuals (Skinner and Chimimba 2005).
threats: There appear to be no major threats to this widespread and seemingly adaptable species.
population: Probably not uncommon in suitable habitats (Happold 1987).
range: This bat is widely distributed throughout most of sub-Saharan Africa. It ranges from Senegal in the west, through West and Central Africa, to Eritrea, Ethiopia and Somalia in the east; from here it is found southwards to southeastern South Africa. The species has been recorded from Madagascar, where it has only been reported from the Kirindy CFPF forest in western Madagascar, and from Zombitse (Rasolozaka 1994). Bates et al. (2006), recommend that the identity of the specimens from Madagascar need to be reviewed. It appears to be absent, or largely absent, from northern Kenya, Namibia, southern Botswana, western Zimbabwe, northern Mozambique, Lesotho and much of South Africa. It is possible that the species ranges more widely in these areas than is currently known, and further field studies are needed to investigate the distribution of the species.
conservationActions: In view of the species wide range it is likely that it is present in many protected areas. Further research is needed into the taxonomy of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity. It is known only from a single type specimen from Samoa, which may have been mislabeled or misidentified; little else is known about the specimen.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: There is no information about threats to this species.
population: It is known only from the holotype.
range: There is a lot of doubt surrounding the distribution of this species. It is only known from the type specimen, which may be incorrectly labeled (Koopman 1984). It was purportedly collected in Samoa, but this has not been confirmed. Another alternative is that the specimen was a vagrant to Samoa.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures pertaining to this species. However, if there is a way to test the taxonomic validity or geographic origins of the specimen this could be very useful (Helgen et al. 2009).

rationale: Findley's Myotis is listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is ca. 900 km² and all individuals occur in fewer than five locations. A continuing decline is inferred and there are several threats (urban development, livestock farming, wood-cutting and introduction of non-native species) than can affect the extent and quality of its habitat and therefore increase the susceptibility of populations to stochastic events.
habitat: This species is poorly known. It is insectivorous (Nowak 1999, Ceballos 2014), but the details of their diet are unknown. All the specimens collected during a field trip in 1976 were captured in mist nets set over small trickling pools in arroyos on the Islas Tres Marias. If this species behaves similar to other species in the genus (high-flight insectivores, roosting on caves or hollows, preying on insects around forests), it can be inferred that its habitat must be natural forest cover with enough structures available for day roosts.
threats: Islas Marias is being used as a Federal Prison and there are several problems with the introduction of alien species (black rats; Wilson 2001). Urban development, livestock farming, wood-cutting and introduction of non-native species might be reducing natural forest cover (Arizmendi and Marquez-Valdelamar 2000). Although a direct relationship between these threats and reduction of populations has not been found, they can increase suceptibility of population to stochastic events such as hurricanes.
population: There is no information on population size or trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic of Mexico, only occurs in Tres Marías Islands, with records on coastal Nayarit (Simmons 2005, Ceballos and Oliva 2005, Ceballos 2014).
conservationActions: The species occurs in a protected area, Islas Marias (Reserve of the Biosphere).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, threats, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on habitat and ecology.
threats: Threats are unknown for this species.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species.
range: This species occurs in southeastern Brazil, Paraguay, and northeastern Argentina (Simmons 2005).
conservationActions: Further studies are needed into the distribution, habitat, ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, and indeed if it genuinely came from Australia (potentially the specimen was mislabelled). No living specimen has been since discovered. Data Deficient better describes the situation rather than Extinct.
habitat: The natural history of this species is not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only with certainty from the type specimen.
range: The type is the only known specimen  and was collected in the nineteenth century reportedly from Sydney, New South Wales, Australia.

rationale: This species is confirmed as Data Deficient, as it is only known from two specimens from 1910 in the Irodo River Valley and has not been recorded since. Further extensive surveys are needed for this species, as well as knowledge on its distribution, biology, ecology, and any threats affecting it.
habitat: There is nothing known about the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from two specimens and has not been recorded since 1910. There was a team in 2003 that surveyed this area, but did not find this species.
range: This species is known only from two specimens caught in northern Madagascar near Analamera in the Irodo River Valley in 1910 (Petersen et al. 1995) and has not be found in recent surveys of northern and western Madagascar (Goodman et al. 2005, Robinson et al. 2006).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, natural history and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as it is known only from the damaged holotype. If this bat is a valid species it is nearly certain that the population has either suffered a catastrophic decline or is already extinct.
habitat: The ecology and habitat preferences of this species are not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: Myotis oreias is known only from the type locality, Singapore. This species is known only from the damaged holotype, re-described by Francis and Hill (1998), who noted that the type locality is questionable.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, natural history and threats to this species.

rationale: Confirmed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There appears to be little information available on the natural history of this species. Lunde et al. (2001) recorded three specimens (allocated toG. egeria) collected in dense secondary tropical lowland forest and along a forest road.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known from very few specimens.
range: This little known African bat has currently only been recorded from three localities. The type locality is Bibundi in the Western Province of Cameroon (Thomas 1913); three individuals (as G. cf. egeria) were collected from Dzanga-Sangha Special Dense Forest Reserve in the Central African Republic (Lunde et al. 2001); the species indicated as being present in western Uganda by Koopman (1993), although further details are needed of the collection site in this country.
conservationActions: It has been recorded from the Dzanga-Sangha Special Dense Forest Reserve in the Central African Republic (Lunde et al. 2001), and may be present in additional protected areas. Further field surveys are needed to better determine the distribution, natural history and possible threats to this little known bat.

rationale: Confirmed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There appears to be little habitat or ecological information available for this species. It may be an inhabitant of coastal forest.
threats: The threats to this species are unclear. If it is associated with coastal forest habitats, it is likely to be threatened by extraction of wood and conversion of land to agricultural use.
population: This species is known only from the type collection.
range: This little known African bat has only been recorded from the type locality of 'Galole Road, 8.5 km north of Garsen, Coast Province, Kenya'.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species is present in any protected areas. There is a need for additional field surveys to better understand the distribution, natural history and possible threats to this little known species.

rationale: The species is widespread and abundant and there is no evidence of population decline. Consequently it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
This species forages over open woodland, pasture and wetlands, and often feeds at lights in rural areas, towns and cities. It roosts in rock crevices, occasionally in fissures in buildings or under bark, rarely in underground habitats. Found mainly in uplands and mountains in North Africa, foraging over water and prairies, roosting in crevices of rocks, trees and buildings. Occurs around cliffs and in rocky areas and deep valleys in the Canaries.

Nothing is known about the migratory behaviour of this bat (Hutterer et al. 2005). Migration is suspected in Europe but the longest movement recorded is 250 km.
threats: No major threats are known.
population: In the western part of its range it generally occurs at low densities and is restricted by its habitat requirements, but it is abundant in some European areas bordering the Mediterranean. Summer maternity colonies usually number 20-70 females. In the Canary Islands it is the commonest bat species. In the eastern part of its range population size and trends are not known (Molur et al. 2002).
range: Savi's Pipistrelle (Pipistrellus savii) has a wide range in the Palaearctic (and marginally in Indomalaya), extending from southern Europe and north Africa (Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, the Canary Islands of La Palma, Tenerife, La Gomera, Gran Canaria, and El Hierro, and the Cape Verde Islands of Santiago and San Vicente) through the Middle East and the Caucasus to Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Afghanistan and northern India (Horácek and Benda 2004, Wilson and Reeder 2005). During the last 30 years, this species' range has been expanding northward in Central Europe (Paunović et al. 2015, Uhrin et al. 2015). From 2008 to date, Savi's Pipistrelle has been confirmed in Slovakia and Czech Republic (Reiter et al. 2010, Jahelkovà et al. 2014). Late studies also stated the occurrence of this bat in Romania, where it may have been present and only recently detected due to an increase in bat survey efforts in the region (Uhrin et al. 2015). It occurs from sea level to 3,000 m.
conservationActions: It is protected by national legislation in some range states. There are also international legal obligations for its  protection through the Bonn Convention (Eurobats) and Bern Convention in parts of its range where these apply. It is included in Annex IV of EU Habitats and Species Directive. It occurs in protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient since it has only recently been recognised as a distinct species, and there is still very little information on its extent of occurrence, status, threats and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is little information available on the natural history of this poorly known bat.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is currently little information on the abundance of this species. Specimens were collected by Goodman (2007) from Anjouan in 2007.
range: This little known species is endemic to the island of Anjouan in the Comoros Islands.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the natural history and possible threats to this little known species.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct because it has not been found in its only known range, or nearby, much after the original collection in 1874 (specific date uncertain) despite extensive surveys.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitat requirements of this species.
threats: It is possible that the species declined and eventually became extinct because of its vulnerability to habitat loss (Conder 2008).
population: This species is known only from the holotype. It was reported as being plentiful at the close of the 19<sup>th</sup> century (Conder 2008).
range: This species is known only from a single specimen (collected in 1874) from the Percy Islands, Queensland, Australia, and subsequent non-specimen records of a colony (L. Hall pers. comm.). It is not known from which island the specimen originally came. Despite more survey effort recently, the species has not been found on the Percy Islands.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES. Despite extensive surveys so far, further field studies on the Percy Islands and other islands in the region are needed to determine if any remnant populations of this species persist (L. Hall pers. comm.). There is also a need to try to find skeletal remains near old camps, in order to confirm the locality of this specimen (L. Hall pers. comm.). Additional taxonomic work is needed to resolve the status of this species.

rationale: Confirmed as Data Deficient in view of continuing problems with its taxonomy, and lack of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: The natural history of this species is poorly known. It is currently unclear whether the holotype was collected in savanna or tropical moist forest (Freeman 1981), however, it appears to have been reported to roost in tree hollows (Lang and Chapin 1917).
threats: The threats to this species are currently unknown.
population: It is known only from the holotype.
range: This little known species was collected from "Niangara, northeastern Belgian Congo" (Democratic Republic of the Congo near the border with Sudan) (Allen et al. 1917, Lang and Chapin 1917).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this little known bat.

rationale: This bat is assessed as Data Deficient as it has not been recorded since 1907 and there is no information on the range, population, ecology and threats to this species.
habitat: Nothing is known of the ecology of this species, but it is probably similar to other Mormopterus species.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: The population status and trend are unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality in Soekaranda, Deli, northern Sumatra, Indonesia, below 250 m asl. It has not been recorded again since its description in 1907.
conservationActions: It is doubtful that the type locality is in a protected area. Survey work is required to determine the range, population status, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since prior to 1874, and extensive surveys over the years have failed to locate this species.
habitat: There are no records available concerning the natural history of this species.
threats: The specific causes of the extinction of Pteropus pilosus are unknown. Hunting for food by local people may have been a contributing factor as well as the degradation of native forest habitat (Wiles et al. 1997).
population: It is known from only two specimens collected prior to 1874.
range: This species was endemic to Palau.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Appendix I of CITES.

rationale: Pteropus subniger is considered Extinct. The last authentic record of this species on Mauritius was in 1859, but it is believed to have died out between 1864 and 1873. On Réunion, no new records appeared after 1862 and it seems probable that it became extinct in the 1860s.
habitat: It roosted in hollow trees and sometimes amongst rocks.
