population: The population abundance of this species is not known.
range: This poorly-known species has been recorded from the islands of Bougainville and Buka in Papua New Guinea, and from Choiseul Island in the Solomon Islands. The elevational range of the species is unknown.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, habitat, ecology, and threats to this species. There is also some doubt as to whether or not it is distinct from M. rufescens, and further taxonomic research is a priority.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information about its population status, ecological requirements, and threats to the species. The habitat on Rossel Island (< 300 km<sup>2</sup>) is still in relatively good shape, however, this species does not appear to have been recorded since 1960. A survey of Rossel Island to determine the population status of this species should be a high priority.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: There is no recent information about threats pertaining specifically to this species. Rossel Island is still mostly forested and is unlikely to be under severe threat of habitat destruction (F. Kraus pers. comm.). The village of Cheme is quite large and its footprint is probably serious within the surrounding area. The higher elevations of Mt. Rossel are considered taboo by local inhabitants, and the habitat is particularly secure here (Rossel reaches a maximum elevation of 839 m asl, and the species has been recorded as high as 700 m asl) (F. Kraus pers. comm.). Introduced murids would have the potential to compete with this species.
population: There is no information about the population of this species.
range: Rossel Island Melomys is known only from specimens collected from Rossel Island (Papua New Guinea). The holotype and four more specimens were collected by the fifth Archbold Expedition in October 1956 (Flannery 1995, Musser and Carleton 2005). Specimens were collected at elevations ranging from 50 to 700 m asl (Flannery 1995). Four additional specimens were colleted by H.F. Osborne in 1960 (VertNet 2015). Other Milne Bay Islands have been well-surveyed without locating this species, thus it is likely to be endemic to Rossel (Flannery 1995).
conservationActions: It is unknown whether or not Rossel Island Melomys occurs within protected areas. A survey of Rossel Island to determine the population status of this species should be a high priority.

rationale: Listed as Endangered as it has a restricted distribution with an extent of occurrence of less than 570 km², and can be considered a single location as virtually the entire island is being logged. There is continuing decline in habitat extent and quality due to deforestation. The species does occur in secondary habitats and if it is found to be more tolerant of disturbance may need to be downlisted to Vulnerable D2.
habitat: The natural history of this species is not well known. It presumably occurs in tropical moist forest. It is not known if the species can adapt to secondary or degraded forest.
threats: The islands from which the species has been recorded are being logged. It is potentially threatened by competition with the non-indigenous Rattus rattus.
population: It is possibly a common species.
range: This poorly-known species is endemic to the Kai Besar in the Moluccan Islands of Indonesia (extent of occurrence less than 570 km²). A record from the island of Kai Taam may also refer to this species. The species has an elevation range of sea level to 500 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: It is not known if it is present in any protected areas. Further studies into the taxonomy, distribution, natural history, and threats to this species are needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is not clear what the true range of this species is or was. If the range could be clarified, it would very likely be listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: The natural history of this species is not known.
threats: Ugi is a relatively small Island (44 km<sup>2</sup>) and logging is going ahead there at present (T. Lavery pers. comm).
population: It is known only from the holotype. Nothing is known about the population and abundance.
range: This species is known from a single holotype from the Solomon Islands. Lavery (2013) determined that Ugi Island (44 km2) is the correct type locality of this species and not Florida Island (= Nggela Sule a land-bridge extension) as previously thought. A preliminary survey on Ugi Island failed to detect the species (Lavery 2013). A large Solomys has been recorded from Makira, but was never collected (seen in 1996 by R. James but eaten by a dog) and therefore the species could also be present on this island too.
conservationActions: Surveys of Ugi Island are needed to ascertain whether the species is still extant, as well as thorough surveys of neighboring islands (T. Lavery pers. comm.).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it is seldom recorded and known from only a few locations, it is likely more widespread than these records suggest, it does not appear to have any major threats (occurring in karst habitat), and it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category. More survey work, however, is needed to confirm its distribution and population status.
habitat: There appears to be little known about the habitat use, other than the specimens were collected from lowland hill forest on limestone karst and also in higher elevation forest on the slopes of Mt. Bosavi. They are considered to be terrestrial and are likely to be nocturnal (Musser et al. 2008).
threats: There are unlikely to be any major threats to the species. It may have a restricted range.
population: The species may be more common than previously thought. The type series consisted of four females. Tanya Leary collected a pregnant female and a subadult male.
range: This species is endemic to the island of New Guinea (Papua New Guinea only), where it is known from the type locality close to Sturt Island Camp on the lower Fly River. It was collected by Tanya Leary on the Darai Plateau, and is known now from the slopes of north-western Bosavi (collection in the Bernice P. Bishop Museum, Hawaii). It has been collected from sea level to 1,400 m asl.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution and population status of the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species is known only from the holotype collected in 1938, and there is no recent information on its population status. It has a restricted distribution, with the total area of the island of 2,406 km². There has been extensive forest loss on Peleng, but it is not known whether this species might be able to adapt to disturbed habitats as with the closely related R. hoffmanni.
habitat: There is little information available for this species, the type specimen was collected in coastal plains on Peleng. Its closest relative is R. hoffmanni, suggesting that it may be found in all habitats on the island.
threats: There has been extensive habitat loss on Peleng due to logging, which will certainly have led to a decline in this species if it is confined to forest habitats.
population: Represented only by the holotype collected in 1938. There is no information on current poulation status.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Kepulauan Banggai, Pulau Peleng (1°23'S, 123°14'E) in Indonesia (Musser and Carleton 2005). There is no reason why the species could not occur all over the island, but there has been limited survey work on Peleng. The area of the island is 2,406 km².
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. There is an urgent need for further survey on Peleng to determine the population status of this species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) because its extent of occurrence is less than 100 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. This species is known only from a tiny island. There have been six recent collecting efforts that have failed to locate this species, so it may be possibly extinct. Its extent of occurrence and area of occupancy meet the criteria for CR B1 and B2. Even if it extends to adjacent islands within the island group, it would still qualify under CR B1 and possibly B2.
habitat: Nothing has been recorded about the natural history of this species. It presumably occurs in tropical moist forest.
threats: This species is threatened by deforestation. It is susceptible to changes in its habitat since it is known from a small island system.
population: There is no information available on population abundance of this species. According to Fisher and Blomberg (2011), the last sighting of Emma's Giant Rat was in 1946. Recent collecting efforts have not located this animal.
range: This species is known only from the holotype collected from Owi Island in the Paidaido Islands east of Supiori-Biak, Papua Province, Indonesia. It is probably a small island endemic.
useTrade: Emma's Giant Rat is not utilized.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species is present in any protected areas. Further field studies are urgently needed to locate any remaining populations and also to study the natural history of this little-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its threats and conservation status. This species is very likely to be restricted to the Weyland range, which is geographically distinct. Exhaustive surveys were carried out in the 1930s and it was not found elsewhere. However, surveys have not been carried out since then. Further knowledge about threats could result in a threatened listing.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species is not known, but it presumably lives in montane forest.
threats: There are no major threats known, however, there has been an increase in degraded montane forest as logging roads expand, but very little montane forest loss evident in Papua between 2000-2012 (Margono et al. 2014).
population: It is known only from the type series of four animals.
range: This species is known only from the type series collected on Mount Kunupi in the Weyland Range, Papua Province, Indonesia, by Georg Stein in 1931. It is possibly restricted to the Weyland Range (Flannery 1995). It was collected between 1,400 and 1,800 m asl.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further surveys of the original collection site are needed to gather more information about this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There appears to be no information available on the natural history of this taxon.
threats: The threats to this taxon are not known.
population: There is no information available on the population abundance of this species.
range: This taxon is known only from the indistinct locality of Dharfur, Sudan. No additional details appear to be available. No distribution map is provided
conservationActions: It is not known if it is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed to determine if Gerbillus burtoni is a valid species, and where it is distributed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, threats, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is little information available for this species. The type locality is in dry hilly country.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, however, there has been land degradation in Somalia (Omuto et al. 2011), with an increase in population dependent on pastoral and agropastoral livelihoods and there has also been a decline in rainfall (Pricope et al. 2013).
population: There is no information available on the population abundance of this species.
range: This poorly known species has only been recorded from type locality, Burao, in northern Somalia.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, reproduction and ecology of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is little information available on this species. Presumably, it is found in arid areas.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available on the population abundance of this species.
range: The distribution of Gerbillus agag is very unclear. Populations of Gerbillus agag have been reported from Mali, Nigeria, and Niger to Chad, Sudan and Kenya (Musser and Carleton 2005); however, because of considerable taxonomic confusion, it is uncertain as to which of these populations should be allocated to Gerbillus agag. The type locality is Agageh Wells, Kordofan, Sudan (not mapped here).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Additional studies are needed to determine if Gerbillus agag is a valid species, and where it is distributed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: The ecological requirements of this taxon are unclear, however, populations reported to be this species have been recorded from irrigated agricultural land and dry grassland with compacted soils.
threats: The threats to this taxon are not known, however, there is ongoing drought and desertification across Sudan (Elagib and Elhag 2011).
population: There is no information available on the population abundance or trends for this species.
range: This poorly-known taxon has been reported from a number of localities in Sudan, however, because of considerable taxonomic confusion it is uncertain as to which of these records refer to Gerbillus muriculus. Only the approximate type locality of '80 miles (129 km) northeast of El Fasher, Madu, Darfur, Sudan' is mapped here.
conservationActions: It is not known if it is present in any protected areas. Additional studies are needed to determine if Gerbillus muriculus is a valid species, and to better understand where the species is distributed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is little information available on this species. Presumably, it is found in arid areas.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, however, there has been land degradation in Somalia (Omuto et al. 2011) and an increase in population density in pastoral and agropastoral livelihoods and a decline in rainfall (Pricope et al. 2013).
population: There is no information available on the population abundance of this species.
range: This species is known only from the unspecified type locality and a few additional records in northern Somalia, including Berbera, Bulhar and Burao. This species ranges from sea level to at least 1,000 m asl (Burao).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and has not been recorded for more than 40 years.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is known only from the holotype (Roux-Estève 1974).
range: This species has only been recorded from Las Anod in northern Somalia, at an elevation of 2,400 feet (approximately 727 m) asl (Roux-Estève 1974). It is still known only from the type locality (T. Mazuch pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species, which is known only from the holotype.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: Echis hughesi has been assessed as Data Deficient because it is only known from its type locality and could possibly be synonymous with E. pyramidum. Further taxonomic and ecological research is therefore needed before a more accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no information on the ecological requirements of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threat process.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is only known from its type locality in far northern Somalia, near Meledin in northern Migiurtinia (=Bari) (McDiarmid et al. 1999).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into the taxonomy, population, distribution, ecology, and any threats to this species should be carried out.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it is seldom recorded, it has a relatively wide distribution, has a presumed overall large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is a small, fossorial snake. Little additional information on the natural history is available for this species.
threats: There may not be any threats to this species as it is known from a large protected area.
population: The population trends and abundance for this species are not well-knwon.
range: This little known species has been recorded from the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where it is only known with certainty from the Lake Tumba region.. The type locality is Irebu, in Bandundu Province, northeast Democratic Republic of the Congo. It was found at about 300 m asl.
useTrade: There is no use of this species.
conservationActions: It has been recorded from the Lake Tumba Transboundary National Park. Further surveys are needed for this species.

rationale: Hypsilurus ornatus has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is currently only known from one locality in the Southern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species; related species are to a greater or lesser degree arboreal and generally associated with rainforest.
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown; although this is an isolated area, it is unknown where on Mt. Bosavi this species was collected, what habitat exists at this locality, and what pressures may exist to this locality.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is only known from the holotype with an unknown collection date.
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea and is known only from Mount Bosavi in Southern Highlands Province (Manthey and Denzer 2006).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species is not known to occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Hypsilurus tenuicephalus has been assessed as Data Deficient. Nothing is known about its distribution, population status, habitats, or threats, and research into this is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist, as its distribution and natural history are entirely unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known from only one specimen.
range: The distribution of this species is unclear, as it is known only from one individual imported for commerce. This individual was reportedly collected in the highlands of Western Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea (Manthey and Denzer 2006).
useTrade: This species is only known from one individual male collected for the pet trade. It does not appear to have been recorded since either in trade or in the wild.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known whether this species occurs in any protected areas. No research can be proposed without a better idea of where this species occurs.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species is only known from its type specimen. Research is needed on the distribution, habitat and ecology of this species before a conservation assessment for the species can be made.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this skink; based on the holotype, it may be one of the smallest skinks known (Uetz et al. 2018).
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being affected by any major threats.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is only known from the type specimen, which was found in the southern Nuba Mountains of Sudan (Werner 1914, Meiri et al. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is to rediscover this species and clarify its distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Gehyra interstitialis has been assessed as Data Deficient, as it is known from a single locality and there is no information on its distribution, population status or natural history. Further research on this species' taxonomy is required.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. Species of this genus tend to be arboreal and found in forest habitats, but are frequently tolerant of modified areas such as rural gardens and urban areas.
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown, although many related species adapt well to habitat modification.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species was described from a specimen from the Kamoro area in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea (Rosler et al. 2005); nothing is known of its full distribution (P. Oliver. pers. comm. 2014)
useTrade: There is no trade or use information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed to clarify whether this taxon is a valid species and, if so, to obtain further material to determine its distribution, population status, natural history and threats is required.

rationale: Gehyra leopoldi has been assessed as Data Deficient, as nothing is known of its ecological requirements, population status or any threats. Further research on this species' taxonomy is required.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. Species of this genus tend to be arboreal and found in forest habitats and modified areas such as rural gardens and urban areas.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Indonesian New Guinea and is only known from Manoi and Sorong in northwest Vogelkop (Brongersma 1930, Rosler et al. 2005).
useTrade: There is no trade or use information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species is likely to occur in two protected areas, the Klamono Nature Recreation Park and the Sorong Nature Recreation Park in Indonesian New Guinea. Further research on this species' taxonomy, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Considered as a single taxon, this species complex occurs widely across New Guinea and so is unlikely to be subject to more than localized threats, despite little information on its population status or ecology. It is consequently provisionally listed as Least Concern. Taxonomic research is needed to clarify longstanding, complicated taxonomic problems among New Guinean Gehyra and to clarify species limits in this group.
habitat: There is no specific habitat information available for this species. Species of this genus tend to be arboreal and found in forest habitats and modified areas such as rural gardens and urban areas.
threats: No major threats to this species are known.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: Medium sized Gehyra occur across New Guinea. There are three names available for these taxa (G. interstialis, G. lampei and G. papuana) that have been applied to specimens from New Guinea. Recent genetic data indicates that an additional species from Palau is also part of this complex (Gehyra brevipalmata; Heinicke et al. 2011). More work is required to resolve how many species are involved, their distributions are, and which names are applicable. Pending resolution of this issue this account applies the name Gehyra papuana to this entire species complex, which has a widespread distribution across the New Guinea mainland.
useTrade: There is no trade or use information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research on the taxonomy of this species complex is required to clarify species limits in and the distributions of component taxa.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this an extremely rarely-recorded gecko whose ecological requirements are unknown, and although it has been recorded from disturbed areas in recent surveys and appears to be more widespread than previously recognized, the reasons for this rarity are not well-understood.
habitat: This gecko has been collected from under the loose bark of tamarind trees (Darevsky 1964, Auffenberg 1980). A recent specimen was found on an abandoned shed at the edge of a village in a coastal area, but this species is very rare and its ecology is almost unknown (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019). It may be confined to intertidal areas, as is the case for some other species in the genus (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist. There appear to be records from somewhat disturbed areas but reasons for extreme rarity unknown. Tourist infrastructure development has recently been proposed for both Komodo and Rinca, but any impact this activity may have on this gecko is unknown.
population: This species is extremely rare, and known from very few specimens, although it was apparently relatively abundant on Komodo when surveyed by Auffenberg (1980). Three or four specimens were collected in surveys over around five years (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019). The ecological requirements of this species are too poorly-known to permit targeted surveys, and it is possible that this rarity reflects a lack of extensive surveys in the intertidal zone which it has been suggested this species may favour (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to the Lesser Sunda Islands in Indonesia, with published records from the islands of Komodo and Rinca (Darevsky 1964). It has recently been recorded on the eastern island Alor (S. Reilly unpubl. data, confirmed by A. Stubbs). It is likely to occur on Flores and other intervening islands, but taxonomic work is needed to confirm species boundaries (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species presumably occurs in Komodo National Park, but no recent records although when first recorded here it was relatively abundant (Auffenberg 1980). More surveys, both in Komodo and in the rest of the Lesser Sundas, including work to clarify its ecology, and more taxonomic research are needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has only been reported once in the last 90 years, and nothing of the locality or habitat of the Sumbawa record has been recorded. The species' distribution, population status and natural history on both islands from which it has been recorded are consequently unknown, and nothing is known of any threats.
habitat: There appears to be little information available on the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species. Both Sumbawa and Lombok contain both heavily degraded areas and areas of intact natural vegetation, but nothing is known of the localities where the species was recorded on either island or of its ecological requirements.
population: This species is known from indeterminate localities on both Lombok, from which it has not been recorded since the 1929 description, and Sumbawa. Only one specimen is known from the latter island, and not many from Lombok (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species was until recently thought to be endemic to the island of Lombok, in the Lesser Sunda Islands of Indonesia. It has recently been recorded from eastern Sumbawa, but the exact locality was not recorded (S. Reilly and A. Stubbs unpubl. data)
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species may occur in Rinjani National Park on Lombok. Further surveys are needed to clarify this species' distribution, ecological requirements, population status and any threats.

rationale: Carlia aramia has been assessed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is widespread in New Guinea and, while poorly-known, is likely to be able to tolerate habitat modification and not subject to major threats.
habitat: There is no species-specific habitat information available, but all members of New Guinea's Carlia radiation are associated with open habitats, and often thrive in areas of disturbance and regrowth.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species.
population: This is a well-collected species (A. Allison pers. comm. 2014).
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea (but is known from close to the Indonesian border and presumably ranges into this country) and is known from the Bamu to the Morehead Rivers, and the upper reaches of the Fly River in Western Province (Zug 2004). It ranges from sea level to mid-elevations of the Fly drainage; the highest known elevation is around 500 m based on locality records (A. Allison and G. Shea pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no trade in or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species occurs in one protected area, the Tonda Wildlife Managment Area in Papua New Guinea. Further research on this species' ecology is required.

rationale: Cryptoblepharus furvus has been assessed as Least Concern on the basis that, while it is only known from its type locality on Normanby Island (which has an area of 915 km2), it is thought unlikely to be subject to major threats on this island and may be more widespread than presently known.
habitat: The ecology of this species is unknown, however, it is described as a littoral skink (Horner 2007)
threats: Specific threats to this species are unknown. Normanby is a fairly large island and access is difficult, so there is not presently any major pressure from development (Parker pers. comm. 2014). This species may be able to adapt to at least localized disturbance.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Cryptoblepharus forms are often common and in many cases commensal with humans (Horner 2007). It is not known whether this is true of this species; however, the type series consists of 16 specimens all collected from the vicinity of Guleguleu Village on a single day in 1988 (Horner 1988) and so it seems likely to tolerate some level of disturbance.
range: This species is only known from the vicinity of Guleguleu Village on the mid-eastern coast of Normanby Island. This island is in the D'Entrecasteaux Island group in Milne Bay Province, Papua New Guinea (Horner 2007). As a coastal species known from one island in a small archipelago, it is possible it will be found on additional islands in this group (Parker and M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Emoia ahli has been assessed as Data Deficient, as it appears to be only known from its type locality in northwest Papua New Guinea. Further research on this species population, distribution, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. Species of this genus tend to inhabit the surface, herbaceous, and low-shrub strata of forests (Brown and Marshall 1953).
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known from a single specimen.
range: This species is only known from its type locality in the upper Sepik drainage area in the north-western Western and south-western West Sepik Provinces, Papua New   Guinea (Brown 1991).
useTrade: There is no trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Surveys are needed to obtain new material of this very poorly-known species and clarify its ecological requirements, population status and any threats.

rationale: Emoia coggeri has been assessed as Data Deficient, as it appears to be only known from its type locality in Papua New Guinea. Further research on this species' population status, distribution, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. The holotype is a gravid female containing two eggs (Brown 1991), collected in November.
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known only from a series of 29 specimens taken in 1963 (Brown 1991). This area has not been resurveyed, as it is accessible only by boat, but the number of specimens taken suggests that it was locally abundant at this locality when collected.
range: This species is only known from Singorakai in the north of the Huon Penninsula, Morobe and Madang Province, Papua New Guinea (Brown 1991). It may occur further along the coast in this area, but is likely to be genuinely restricted to this coastal strip (G. Shea pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species is not known to occur within protected areas. Further research on the population status, distribution, habitats, and threats to the species is required.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that recent records exist from an island where disturbance is limited and it is known elsewhere from islands which retain good forest. It is consequently thought unlikely to be subject to major threats, but more research is needed to confirm this and to clarify its ecological requirements and distribution.
habitat: The known localities contain lowland forest. It is unknown whether it is terrestrial or arboreal.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist. Enggano appears to consist largely of intact forest away from the coast, but it was affected by the 2004 tsunami (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Good forest remains on Simeleue (M. Kamsi pers. comm. 2019). If it is arboreal it may be sensitive to deforestation. Nothing is known of the status of the subpopulation on Java, but as it occurs on multiple islands where natural forest remains and may be more widespread it is probably subject to no widespread threats (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
population: Other than specimens from Enggano housed in the LIPI collection (A. Riyanto pers. comm. 2019), all records of this species appear to be historical (pre-1915).
range: This species occurs in the Mentawai Islands (Sipora, Simalue and Nias, and the type locality Enggano) and western Java, both in Indonesia (Brongersma 1942). It presumably occurs on the Sumatran mainland of Sumatra, although this requires confirmation. Recent records exist only for Enggano; other records are historical, and while it may be widespread on other islands in the Mentawai Archipelago recent surveys are lacking. These include very old records from Panimbang District in west Java close to the sea represented by specimens and paintings in the early 1820s; these latter are "definitely this species" (Brongersma 1942). Could be widespread on other islands in the Mentawais, but these are unsurveyed.
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are protected areas on islands within this species' range, and traditional restrictions on removing timber from Enggano have limited disturbance on this island. Distributional studies, including surveys of poorly-known islands, are recommended, and data is needed on the ecology of this species.

rationale: Papuascincus phaeodes has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is currently only known from the Sepik Basin region in northwest Papua New Guinea. The threats to this species are unknown and it is not known to occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species.
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type specimens and nothing is known about their distribution or ecology other than they are from New Guinea, probably the Sepik Basin in northwest Papua New Guinea.
useTrade: There is no trade or use information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research on this species' distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Prasinohaema parkeri has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is currently only known from one locality in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. There are no likely threats within the area where this species was collected. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. Prasinohaema are arboreal species and so will be reliant on some degree of forest cover (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species known only from Utakwa River in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea (Smith 1937).
useTrade: There is no trade or use information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Sphenomorphus meyeri has been assessed as Least Concern due to its large distribution in New Guinea and Aru island in the Moluccas. It is unlikely that there are any major threats to this species and is likely to occur in several protected areas. Further research into this species' population status and threats is recommended.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species other than it was observed in lowland rainforest.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species. The lowland rainforest habitat in which this species was observed is under increasing threat from deforestation (Shearman and Bryan 2011).
population: This species is locally abundant in Western Province, Papua New Guinea (G. Shea. pers. comm. 2014).
range: This species has a patchy distribution across New Guinea. It is known from Batanta and Gagie or Gebe Island (the record is uncertain of which island this species was recorded on) the northern area of West Papua Province. It has been recorded in the Tamarau Mountains, Jayapura region, the Mimika river, and central mountain range of Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. It has also been recorded on Aru island in the Molucca island group. In Papua New Guinea it is found in the Torricelli Mountains in West Sepik Province and in Western, Southern Higlands, Gulf, Chimbu and Central Province. It occurs at elevations between 0 – 1,100 m asl (Goldberg et al. 2009; G. Shea. pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species is likely to occur in several protected areas in New Guinea. Further research on this species' population status and threats is recommended.

rationale: Sphenomorphus mimikanus has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is currently only known from the Mimika River in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. It does not occur in any protected areas but potentially occurs in a wider area which has not been surveyed. The threats to this species are unknown and further research on this species' distribution, population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: This species has been recorded on alluvial flood plains (A. Allison. pers. comm. 2014).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is relatively common where collected (A. Allison pers. comm. 2014)
range: This species is only known only from the lowlands around Mimika River in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea (Boulenger 1914; G. Shea. pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species does not occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species distribution, population status and threats is recommended.

rationale: Sphenomorphus rufus has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is currently only known from Wokam Island in the Aru Island group, Indonesian Moluccas. It does not occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species' population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown, the Aru islands have been heavily deforested (G. Shea pers. comm. 2014).
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Indonesian Moluccas and only known from Wokam Island in the Aru Island group (Loveridge 1948)
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species does not occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species' population status, habitats and threats is recommended. The taxonomy of this species also needs research.

rationale: Sphenomorphus wollastoni has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is currently only known from one location in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. It does not occur in any protected areas. Further research on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Indonesian New Guinea. It is known only from Mimika River in Kamoro area, Papua Province (Boulenger 1914).
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species does not occur in protected areas. Further research on this species' distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Dendrelaphis papuensis has been assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that it is known only from historical specimens with an unclear distribution in the Trobriand Islands, and while no pressures on these islands are presently known nothing is known of this snake's ecological requirements and recent fieldwork has not been conducted. Research is recommended to rediscover this species and clarify its natural history.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this species are unknown.
threats: No threats to natural habitat on the Trobriand Islands are known at present, however, nothing is known of this species' ecology following the recent taxonomic revision and it unknown whether any threats are ongoing or likely to arise in the near future (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015).
population: There is no population information available for this species, which appears to be known only from the types.
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea. Its distribution is unclear due to the taxonomically confused history of this species and the lack of precise locality information for the syntypes, which were collected from the Trobriand Islands (van Rooijen et al. 2015). The species was probably collected from Kiriwina Island, the largest of the Trobriands (van Rooijen et al. 2015). It has been reported from eastern New Guinea (McDowell 1984), but van Rooijen et al. (2015) found no evidence of a mainland population. These authors "conservatively" consider the species endemic to the Trobriand Islands.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Fieldwork is recommended to rediscover this species and clarify its distribution on the Trobriand Islands, its natural history, and the existence of any threats (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015).

rationale: Cyclindrophis aruensis has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is currently only known from Damar island and the Aru Islands in Maluku Province, Indonesia. Further research on this species' population status, habitats and threats is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. It is likely to be semi-fossorial, and presumably found in damp habitat, possibly including disturbed/trash areas. The prey might be blind snakes.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. It might be predated by pigs, and deforestation may also be a threat. Future development in the Aru Islands may represent a threat.
population: It is known from very few specimens.
range: This species is found in the Aru Islands and Damar in Maluku Province, Indonesia (Smith and Sidik 1998). It possibly is a lowland species, although this needs to be verified.
useTrade: This species is not known to be used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this very-poorly known species has limited natural history information, and the threats are poorly known.
habitat: It is a poorly known, small terrestrial snake. Smith and Sidik (1998) did not report any natural history information in the description of this species. It is presumed to be nocturnal, fossorial and viviparous, as with other members of this genus.
threats: The threats to this species are not well-known, although the Tanimbar Islands have been heavily deforested with ongoing forest loss.
population: It seems to be only known from a few specimens, nothing is known about  the population trend.
range: This species has only been recorded from Yamdena Island, in the Tanimbar Islands of Indonesia (Smith and Sidik 1998).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas. Additional research is needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this little-known species.

rationale: Toxicocalamus buegersi has been assessed as Least Concern. There appear to be no significant threats to the species or its presumed lowland forest habitat, however, further research is recommended to clarify its distribution, population status, ecological requirements and any threats. It is only known from two mountain ranges in northwest Papua New Guinea.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species, however, this region is characterized by lowland rainforest. It is believed to be diurnal, semi-fossorial and to feed on earthworms or similar prey. It is presumed to be oviparous.
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown, however, lowland forest within its range seems to be relatively intact and there is not expected to be any commercial interest or local use of this snake.
population: This species is known from only a few specimens.
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea and known from the Torricelli Mountains in Sandaun Province and the Prince Alexander Mountains and Wewak in East Sepik Province (O’Shea 1996). It is found at elevations up to 200 m asl.
useTrade: There is no trade in or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It may be present in the Tenkile protected area. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitats and threats is recommended.

rationale: Toxicocalamus grandis has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is known only from one locality in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea and has not been recorded for over a century. Nothing is known about its true distribution, population status, ecology, or any threats.
habitat: There is no natural history information available for this species. It may be semi-fossorial, preying on worms and similar prey, in common with other members of the genus.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. It may be potentially threatened by habitat degradation resulting from possible future mining activities in the area, although this needs further research.
population: This snake is known only from a single specimen collected in 1912.
range: This species is known only from one specimen collected from the Setekwa River in Papua Province, and may be endemic to Indonesian New Guinea (Kraus 2009).
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. The type locality is within the Lorentz National Park World Heritage Site in Indonesian New Guinea. Research is needed to obtain additional material in order to better-understand its distribution, population status, ecological requirements and any threats.

rationale: Leiopython biakensis has been assessed as Vulnerable under criterion D2. It has a range restricted to a single island, and is subject to the pet trade, which may represent a significant threat to the limited population.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. It is likely to inhabit lowland forested and riparian areas, in common with other species of Leiopython.
threats: As this species is restricted to the island of Biak and its population status is unknown, exploitation for the pet trade may pose a significant threat to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known from very few specimens most of which were collected around the Biak military base during the Dutch colonial period.
range: This species is endemic to Indonesian New Guinea and known only from the island of Biak (Schleip 2008). It is known from only a few specimens mostly in the south of the island, which has an area of less than 2,000 km2. It can be found at low altitudes.
useTrade: Natusch and Lyons (2012) noted the trade of this species from Biak in Indonesian New Guinea and reported that two individuals were recorded at wildlife traders between September 2010 - April 2011. This species is listed under CITES but does not have protected status in Indonesia. There is no quota for this species.
conservationActions:
This species is listed under Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This species is not protected by Indonesian New Guinea law (Natusch and Lyons 2012). 

It is not known if it is present in any protected areas. Fieldwork on the island is required to obtain recent material and establish its population status, ecological requirements, threats, and the scale and sustainability of any harvesting for trade.

rationale: Leiopython huonensis has been assessed as Data Deficient. While it is not thought that major threats operate in this area and it may range more widely, it has not been collected since 1964 and too little is known of its natural history to confirm that it is at no risk.
habitat: This species is known only from museum material, and no habitat information is available for this species. It may be present in lowland tropical moist forest.
threats: There are not suspected to be any threats to this species, but this requires verification as nothing is known with any certainty of its habitat requirements or its true distribution.
population: It appears to be known from relatively few specimens: Schleip (2008) reported 15 specimens, none with reported collection dates later than 1964. It is possible that unreported specimens not available to Schleip (2008) have been collected and identified as Leiopython albertsii (M. Auliya pers. comm. 2018).
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea, where it is known from close to sea level around Finschhafen and from an area about 16 km west of Lae on the southern coast of the Huon Peninsula. One specimen was found east of the Ramu River at Dumpu in the Morobe Province. Its western range limit is unclear (M. Shea pers. comm. 2018). As the Huon Peninsula is not a known area of endemism in snakes (Macdowell 1984) it may be more widespread than presently known, but any records from elsewhere require verification. This species was found at elevations between sea level and 152 m asl (Schleip 2008).
useTrade: There is no trade or use of this species.
conservationActions: This species is listed under Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This species has protected status in Papua New Guinea (Natusch and Lyons 2012). It is not known from any protected areas. Further research on this species' population status, habitats and any threats is recommended.

rationale: Ramphotyphlops flaviventer has been assessed as Least Concern. It is unlikely to be affected by any significant threats.
habitat: There appears to be no natural history information available for this fossorial species.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is found in West Papua Province, Indonesia, where it is limited to the islands of Batanta and Salawati; and the Doberai and Onin Peninsulas. It can be found from sea level to 550 m asl. It is also present in the west Maluka Islands of Indonesia.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it is present in any protected areas.

rationale: This species has been assessed as Least Concern. It is known from the northern Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait islands in Australia and southwestern Papua New Guinea. While the species is very poorly-known due to its occurrence in a remote area, there are unlikely to be any significant threats.
habitat: There is no certain natural history information for this fossorial species.
threats: There appear not to be any threats to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species, due to a lack of surveys in the remote areas where it is found (G. Shea pers. comm. June 2017).
range: This species occurs in Australia in the northeast of the Cape York Peninsula and the eastern islands of the Torres Strait (Badu, Mabuyag, Mua, Dauan, Erub and Mer) in Queensland (Lavery et al. 2012). It is has also been recorded in the lower Fly River and Mata in Western Province, Papua New Guinea (O’Shea 1996, Wilson and Swan 2003, Lavery et al. 2012). It is found in low-lying areas, below 50 m asl.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It may occurs in the Tonda Wildlife Management Area in Papua New Guinea and in reserves in the northern Cape York Peninsula. Further research into this species population status and natural history is recommended.

rationale: Ramphotyphlops multilineatus has been assessed as Least Concern. It has a wide distribution in Indonesian New Guinea. It is unlikely to be affected by any significant threats.
habitat: Little is known about the habitat or ecology of this fossorial species.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species.
population: It appears to be known from few specimens.
range: This species occurs in Indonesian New Guinea and has been recorded on the Kei islands in Maluku Province, Vogelkop Peninsula, Lake Jamur and Salawati island in West Papua Province and Taritatu river (formerly the Idenberg river) in Papua Province (O’Shea 1996). Elevation is not known.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it is present in any protected areas. Further research into this species' population status and threats is recommended.

rationale: Ramphotyphlops supranasalis has been assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that, while no threats have been identified, the species is apparently endemic to Salawati Island and is presently known from only two specimens.
habitat: There appears to be no natural history information available on this fossorial species.
threats: There are not thought to be major pressures to natural habitat on Salawati, but nothing is known about this species' ecology. Additionally, as an island endemic it may be sensitive to any future development, for instance if oil or gas were discovered (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015).
population: It is known only from two specimens.
range: This species is endemic to Indonesian New Guinea and is known only from Salawati island in West Papua Province (O’Shea 1996). It is known from only low elevations.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further research on this species distribution, population status, habitat and threats is recommended.

rationale: Gerrhopilus inornatus has been assessed as Least Concern, as although it is very poorly-known it is unlikely to be affected by any significant threats and specimens are known from across a moderately wide area of southeastern Papua New Guinea.
habitat: The natural history of this fossorial species is very poorly known.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species, however, this needs additional research.
population: It appears to be known only from a few specimens.
range: This species is endemic to Papua New Guinea and occurs on the Huon Peninsula in Morobe Province and throughout the Papuan Peninsula in Central, Oro and Milne Bay Provinces. It has been recorded at elevations between 580 – 2,000 m asl (O’Shea 1996).
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas. Further research into this species population status, habitat and threats is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen apparently collected within the vicinity of Ibague, but there is no information on its true distribution, ecological requirements or any threats to which it may be exposed.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species, which was described based on a museum specimen. Ibague itself is a small city; the precise locality where the species was collected is unclear, and there is therefore no information on the habitat at this site.
threats: There is insufficient information on the locality where this species was collected to identify any threats. It may have been collected somewhere in the vicinity of Ibague, however, the possibility also exists that it was collected elsewhere and transported to the city (J. Velasco pers. comm. 2013).
population: This species still appears to be known only from the holotype, a juvenile female (Williams 1975).
range: There is only one known specimen of the species, reportedly from Ibague, Department of Tolima, Colombia.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species, which is known from a single specimen.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Research is needed to rediscover this species and clarify its taxonomic status.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it has not been seen since the 1960s and, although the known localities lie within a protected area, nothing is known about the species' natural history, distributional extent, population size or trends, or any threats.
habitat: There are no ecological notes associated with the known specimens (Williams 1982).
threats: The area where the species occurs has been inaccessible for at least 50 years, and any threats are unknown.
population: The species is known only from museum specimens collected in the 1960s from two localities. The area where the species was found was subsequently subject to extended social conflict; as of 2013 no herpetologist has returned to resurvey the area.
range: This species is known from two localities on the eastern versant of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Department of Cesar or Magdalena, Colombia, at elevations at or above 2,000 m asl (Williams 1982).
useTrade: This species is presumably not subject to any use or trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. The area where the species was found is within the Parque Nacional Natural Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. Research is needed on the distribution, population, and natural history of the species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although its distribution is limited to a single mountain summit, the species occupies a remote, uninhabited, inaccessible area on the summit of a tepui where there are no threats other than possibly climate change. The entire range of the species is within a protected area. Revisiting the area to confirm the population status of the species, which has not been recorded since the the early 20th century would be helpful to confirm the status of the species.
habitat: There is no habitat information for the species. It was recorded from a tepui, which may have humid forest, shrublands, or rocky areas.
threats: Although the range of the species has not been visited recently, the remoteness of a tepui summit suggests that the only potential threat is climate change. The tepui is nearly completely inaccessible.
population: This species is only from the original description, based on specimens collected in the early 20th century. Herpetologists have not returned to the area. The tepui region where the species was collected is remote and with no threats, suggesting that the population trend is unlikely to be significantly declining.
range: Arthrosaura tyleri is known only from its type locality, Mount Duida in southern Venezuela, where it was collected at 1,700 m (Hoogmoed and Avila-Pires 1992).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in Duida-Marahuaca National Park. Revisiting the area to confirm the population status of the species would be helpful to confirm the status of the species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although its distribution is limited, the species occupies a remote, uninhabited, inaccessible area on the summit of a tepui where there are no threats other than possibly climate change. The entire range of the species is within a protected area. The area needs to be revisited to determine the current population status of the species.
habitat: This species occurs on a tepui where the habitat can be montane forest, shrubland, or rocky areas. Which of these habitats is inhabited by this species is unknown.
threats: Although the range of the species has not been visited recently, the remoteness of a tepui summit suggests that the only potential threat is climate change. The tepui is nearly completely inaccessible.
population: This species is only known from two specimens that form the type series, collected in 1985. The species is known from a remote tepui from which no additional information has been published. Although there has not been additional sightings, the remoteness of the tepui and lack of threats suggests that the population may be stable.
range: Cercosaura nigroventris is endemic of Venezuela, and is known only from its type locality in Cerro Guanay, Bolivar state. The species has been collected at 1,650 m asl (Gorzula and Señaris 1998).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in Cerro Guanay Natural Monument. The area needs to be revisited to determine the current population status of the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from a 19th Century specimen with no precise locality data, and therefore nothing is known of its distribution, population status, natural history or its exposure to any threats.
habitat: The habitat for this species is unknown.
threats: The threats to this species cannot be determined without knowing where the species was collected.
population: There are no population data for this species, which has not been recorded since the 19th century from an unknown locality.
range: Werner (1894) reports "Ecuador" as type locality. The species has never been rediscovered and nothing is known of its true distribution.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Taxonomic work is needed to understand this species' relationships with related taxa, including searching European natural history museums for additional specimens. No survey work can be proposed without better information on its distribution.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species - which is of unclear validity - is known from a single specimen from an imprecise locality in the Colombian Andes, and nothing is known of its ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species. The natural vegetation in this area is forest.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species, or on its ability to tolerate disturbance.
population: This species is known only from the holotype (Prado 1944).
range: This species is endemic to Colombia. It is known only from its type locality, given only as "Andes" in the original description (Prado 1944) and associated with the Department of Antioquía, northwestern Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009, Passos et al. 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is underway into the taxonomy of this species, and if it is recognized as a valid species further research will be needed to determine its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is no published information on the ecology of this species, although Atractus species are fossorial. Much of the valley where this species has been found in Colombia has been converted to sugar cultivation and cattle grazing (W. Bolivar pers. comm. 2013)
threats: Deforestation for sugar cultivation and cattle ranching are likely to represent the major threats to this species in Colombia, however, essentially nothing is known of its ecology or the extent to which it requires intact forest habitat. Cultivation has been ongoing for a long time in this area, and most records of this species postdate disturbance, although it is not known whether any records have been taken from cultivated land.
population: This species is known from a small number of records in Colombia: only 10 specimens were reported by Passos et al. (2009), only one of which was collected in the last 10 years (C. Arredondo pers. comm. 2013).
range: This snake occurs in Colombia, where it is found in the departments of Cauca and Valle del Cauca (Passos et al. 2009); it is likely to occur along the Valle del Cauca between these sites. The type locality given by Uetz and Hallerman (2012) is "Hoya de Cuenca, Prov. Azuay, Ecuador", which lies on the Pacific versant of the Ecuadorian Andes. Passos et al. (2009) did not list Ecuador localities for the specimens they examined.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to determine whether cultivation and ranching activities pose a threat to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from museum specimens more than 60 years old and nothing is known of its ecology or population status. Human activities are ongoing within its known range, however, without information on this species' true distribution or ecological tolerances it is unknown whether these threaten its survival.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this presumably fossorial snake, which is known only from historical museum records.
threats: Deforestation for cattle ranching, and for coffee and small-scale coca cultivation, is ongoing within the species' historical range, but there is no information on its ecology and it is therefore unknown whether these activities represent threats to this species.
population: All known specimens are from museum collections and are at least 60 years old, and there is no information on the species' current population status.
range: This species is known from several localities in the Department of Antioquia and the Valle de Cauca, western Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009). It is believed to be endemic to the Cordillera Occidental; although voucher specimens exist from the northern Cordillera Central, these are presumed to be in error (C. Arredondo pers. comm. 2013). Recent surveys have not recorded the species from the Valle de Cauca, at the southern limit of the known range (C. Arredondo pers. comm 2013).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Tatama Natural National Park lies within this snake's range, but there are no records from protected areas. No targeted searches have been conducted to rediscover this species, which has not been seen for over 60 years, and efforts to rediscover it are needed before its conservation requirements can be determined.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and  threats for this species are too poorly known to allow it to be placed  in another category.
habitat: All species in the genus are semi-fossorial. Little else is known about the habitat of this species.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is known from a single specimen.
range: This species is known only from its type locality (Chita) in the Department of Boyacá, Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009, Passos et al. 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Conservation needs include better information on the species' distribution, abundance, life history, population trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: This is a semi-fossorial snake; little is known about its habitat requirements.
threats: Habitat requirements are not well known, so the nature and degree of threats are uncertain.
population: Population status is poorly known; this species is represented by a small number of specimens.
range: This species is known from five localities in the departments of Boyacá and Norte de Santander, Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Conservation needs include better information on the species' distribution, abundance, life history, population trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: Specific habitat information for this semi-fossorial snake is unknown.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is known from a single specimen from the type locality and from one additional locality.
range: This species is known from the type locality in the municipality of Ocaña, Department of Norte de Santander, Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009). It is also known from the Cesar Department in Colombia (ICN-R Reptile Collection).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: This species is not known to occur in any protected areas. Better information is needed on current distribution, abundance, trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: This species is cryptic and possibly nocturnal. It is found in litter and loose soil.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats.
population: This species is only known from type locality.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia. It is known only from its type locality, Loma Linda, Departmento de Meta.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Conservation needs include better information on the species' distribution, abundance, life history, population trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen of unknown provenance, although it resembles - and was formerly confused with - a species known from northern South America.
habitat: Nothing is known of the ecology of this species.
threats: The threats are unknown.
population: This species is known from the juvenile holotype (Natera-Mumaw 2015)..
range: The holotype is from an unknown locality; following the removal of Epictia amazonica from synonymy (Natera-Mumaw 2015), this appears to be the only known record. Hahn (1979) restricted the type locality to northern Amazonia, but this was based on his association of this species with Leptotyphlops amazonicus, now recognized as a distinct species. It is not considered to occur in Venezuela pending resolution of its geographic distribution (Natera-Mumaw 2015). Cisneros-Heredia (2008) found that reports of "E. signata" from Amazonian most likely represented E. amazonica records taken in Venezuela, however, D. Cisneros-Heredia (pers. comm. 2020) notes that there are unidentified specimens from the Andean foothills of Ecuador that are probably distinct from E. amazonica. It is consequently possible that these may correspond to true E. signata.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Research is needed to clarify this species' identity and determine whether any known records of Epictia in collections are conspecific with the holotype. Pending the rediscovery of this snake no research or conservation measures can be recommended.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from only two specimens, both collected more than a century ago, from a single locality, and nothing is known of its true distribution or of its natural history or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: Spawls et al. (2002) indicate that "there would appear to be no shortage of suitable habitat for this species" at the known locality, but do not detail the habitat type. Ujiji itself is a town. It is presumed to fossorial, diurnal, and to feed on invertebrates, in common with other worm lizards (Spawls et al. 2002).
threats: If this species' range is genuinely confined to the area of the type locality, it may be at risk from varied human activities including settlement, agricultural development, and direct and indirect impacts of industry (Spawls et al. 2002). In the absence of information about both its distribution and its ecology, however, it is not possible to determine whether these represent major threats.
population: This species has not been recorded for over a century (Spawls et al. 2002), in part because no one has recently surveyed the area. It was described based on two specimens (Gans 2005).
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of Ujiji, on Lake Tangyanika in Tanzania's Kigoma Region (Spawls et al. 2002).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. This species is not known from any protected areas at present. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and, if located, to obtain data on its distribution, ecological requirements, and sensitivity to potential threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance natural history of and any threats of this species are too poorly known to allow it to be placed in another category.
