habitat: This species' habitat requirements are unknown. Members of this genus are small fossorial species that feed on earthworms and insect larvae.
threats: Although large areas of natural habitat in Cundinamarca have been lost or degraded from conversion to agriculture, it is unknown whether this represents a significant threat.
population: This rare species is known from only four localities (Dixon and Kofron 1984).
range: The distribution of this species has been a matter of some confusion. This account follows the species concept applied by the describing authors, in which Liotyphlops argaleus is known from four localities in Cundinamarca and Santander Provinces, Colombia. This species was described from 'La Selva' in Colombia (Dixon and Kofron 1984). These authors associate this name with a locality within the Rio Magdalena Basin in Cundinamarca Department, but as there are six localities named 'La Selva' in Colombia (and three within this basin) they caution that the true identity of the type locality may never be known (Dixon and Kofron 1984). Further records exist from Santo Cruz Zoo, 16 km WSW of Bogota at an elevation of 166 m asl. and from Paine, both in Cundinamarca, and from San Vicente de Chucuri in Santander Department (Dunn 1944, Dixon and Kofron 1984).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Conservation needs include better information on the species' distribution, abundance, life history, population trend, and threats.

rationale: This species is only known from the type collection made in 1896. No further information is available on its provenance, ecology and threats. The species is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is nothing known about the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is only known from the type specimen collected in 1896 (Meiri et al. 2018).
range: This enigmatic species of lizard is known only from the type locality of “Nyika Plateau” in “Nyasaland” (= Malawi). Some authorities believe that it may have been collected at Livingstonia (D. Pietersen pers. comm.).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The only known specimen was supposedly collected in the Nyika National Park. Surveys are required to collect additional specimens and to gain further understanding about this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this poorly-known species is known from only two specimens, one of which is from an indeterminate locality, and essentially nothing is known of its distribution, ecological requirements, or its exposure and sensitivity to threats.
habitat: Nothing is known about this fossorial species' natural history, but it is presumed to occur in soft soils (Spawls et al. 2002). The species' habitat preferences are unclear at present; Manga Forest includes both lowland forest and grassland (Doggart et al. 1999); most forest is mature, but there are some open and disturbed forest areas (Doggart et al. 1999) and it is unknown where this species was recorded. It is likely to be diurnal; Spawls et al. (2002) indicate that it presumably lays eggs, however, viviparity has since been confirmed for a related species, Melanoseps emmrichi (Rödder et al. 2009).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist. Doggart et al. (1999) reported that timber extraction had largely ceased in Manga Forest Reserve, although there was some peripheral encroachment by fire.
population: This species is known from "very few" specimens (Spawls et al. 2002), only one of which is recent. Of two historical specimens collected over a century ago, one is now understood to be referable to Melanoseps pygmaeus and the other has been lost (Broadley et al. 2006).
range: This species is only known with certainty from the Manga Forest Reserve. There are historical records from poorly-defined sites in northeastern Tanzania, including "Maasailand" (identified as the Maasai Steppe by Broadley et al. 2006). Manga Forest ranges from 100 to at least 1,100 m asl in elevation.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The only recent record of this species is from the Manga Forest Reserve. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and obtain information on its distribution, population status, natural history and its exposure and sensitivity to any threats. Museum searches are required to recover the lost specimen and clarify its generic assignment.

rationale: This species is known from a single locality record collected in 1928. Its distribution, ecological requirements and any threats are unknown. The species is consequently listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only locality record of this species is from the coast region near Lumbo, Mozambique. The species' habitat is essentially unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, because its distribution and ecology are not understood. The area where the holotype was collected is a highly transformed urban residential environment.
population: This species has not been recorded since its description in 1928.
range: This species is known only from the type series from a single, vaguely described locality near Lumbo, Nampula Province, Mozambique (Barbour and Loveridge 1928), therefore its distribution is unknown.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures in place and the species is not found in any protected areas. Given that its distribution is essentially unknown and it has not been recorded since the type description in 1928, efforts to rediscover this species are needed to obtain data on its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The natural history of this species is poorly-known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: While the holotype has been lost, there are some specimens in museums. However, no information appears to be available on the species abundance or population trends.
range: This poorly-known skink has only been recorded from the type locality of 'base of Pic de Santa Isabel, Fernando Po' (= Pico de Basile, Bioko, Equatorial Guinea). The elevation of collection remains unclear.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if populations of this species are present in any protected areas, although Pico de Basile is now a National Park. There is a need to undertake new field surveys to locate populations of this skink, and to better understand the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, natural history and threats to the species.

rationale: There is only one locality record of this species, and so its distribution is unknown. The potential threats to the species and its habitat are not known, as there is no information on its ecology. The species is therefore considered Data Deficient.
habitat: The known specimen was collected from the margin of the Púnguè River between Lamego and Muda near the N6 (national road; Broadley and Wallach 1997).
threats: Púnguè River flats are used for agriculture, which could be a threat to this species. However, the distribution of the species is not known so the threats cannot be established or estimated.
population: This species is known only from the holotype. No information on the population status is available.
range: This species is known only from a single specimen collected approximately halfway between Muda and Lamego, adjacent to the Púnguè (Pungwe) River in Mozambique (Broadley and Wallach 1997). Any broader distribution is unknown.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Further records of this species are needed in order to estimate its distribution, to clarify its population status and ecology, and determine whether it is subject to major threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has not been recorded since its original description, and nothing is known about its natural history or any threats. Dar es Salaam is a well-surveyed area, and the failure of surveys to record this species for 50 years may suggest either that it is extinct or that it is simply an aberrant specimen of a better-known species.
habitat: There is no information on this species' natural history or habitat requirements. Dar es Salaam is a major urban centre. It is presumed to be diurnal, and most species of Lygodactylus are arboreal in trees (Spawls et al. 2002).
threats: Nothing is known about threats to this species. Spawls et al. (2002), while noting that data is insufficient to determine its conservation status, opine that it is probably threatened and may be extinct based on the absence of records since its description. It was described in 1964, as the capital of the newly-independent Tanzania was developing into a major regional economic centre, and it is therefore possible that general urban development is or was a threat.
population: This species is known from a single specimen (Spawls et al. 2002).
range: This species has only been recorded from Dar es Salaam in Tanzania (Spawls et al. 2002). Regular observations in this well-surveyed area have not recorded this species since its original description (Spawls et al. 2002).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required, and no conservation or research can be proposed unless this lizard is rediscovered. It is not clear whether it is a valid species.

rationale:
This Red List Assessment (RLA) is for the species and does not include analyses of subspecies or genetic lines. According to the Red List Guidelines (IUCN 2019), this assessment focuses primarily on free-living (wild) subpopulations that are larger than Minimum Viable Population (MVP) size (150 mature animals), and finds a genuine increasing change in the past five years and since the most recent Red List assessment (Olech 2008); so that the species no longer qualifies for threatened status (Critically Endangered, Endangered, or Vulnerable) under Red List Criteria A-E per below (IUCN 2019). In 2019, there were only eight subpopulations greater than MVP that included 2,518 mature animals, with no subpopulation including greater than 500 mature animals; thus making this species nearly qualify for Vulnerable C2a(i). Additional consideration of free-living subpopulations that are less than MVP, indicates that this species warrants Near Threatened status in light of its dependence on ongoing conservation programmes to persist beyond the next five years, a very limited number of viable free-living subpopulations (eight), and a large number of small isolated free-living subpopulations less than MVP (39). While the number of conservation herds and individuals in subpopulations managed for species conservation and ecological restoration is increasing, all free-living mature individuals occur within active management programmes which, if ceased, would result in the species qualifying for a threatened status. The species is not currently in decline but the overall free-living population size of wild mature individuals could decline or suffer extreme fluctuation if current protections are reduced or removed. This is a conservation dependent species and several exacerbating factors described below are anticipated to continue across the current and next generation unless there are substantial multi-national adjustments in management of free-living European Bison. 

  1. Population viability. There are very few viable subpopulations (only eight out of 47 free-living subpopulations are greater than MVP). Most free-living bison subpopulations are very small (e.g. ~34% < 25 mature animals, ~51% <50 mature individuals, and ~83% include less than MVP of 150 mature animals), indicating that natural selection dynamics are not operating adequately. Quantitative population viability analyses of the eight free-living populations greater than MVP have not been completed.
  2. Genetics. Mean expected heterozygosity, calculated on the basis of microsatellite data, has been estimated as 0.29 (29%) for the Lowland line and 0.35 (35%) for the Lowland-Caucasian line (Tokarska unpublished). This low genetic variability negatively influences effective population size (Ne). For example, the largest subpopulation is the Polish part of the Białowieża Forest (462 mature animals), yet the effective population size is calculated as less than 30 (Tokarska et al. 2009). Based on the extremely limited number of founder animals, this tremendous disparity between subpopulation number of mature animals and Ne can be reliably inferred for other free-ranging subpopulations.
  3. Fragmentation. Approximately 77% of 43 free living subpopulations for which information is available are functionally isolated by distance or an impermeable barrier. Approximately 30% of free-living subpopulations are isolated by an impermeable barrier (man-made or natural) from the nearest neighbour subpopulation. For subpopulations not isolated by a natural or man-made barrier, 60% are at least 60 km from the nearest-neighbour subpopulation (range 60–530 km). It can be expected that subpopulations at a greater distance from a nearest neighbour are much less likely to see successful natural dispersal or exchange of cows (and their genetics) between subpopulations across multiple generations, thus we can infer further genetic drift of inherently low genetic diversity to be amplified through long-term isolation.
  4. Supplemental feeding and selective culling. The majority of free-living European Bison subpopulations were restored into forest habitats, which often do not provide sufficient food resources year round for this large herbivore. Supplemental feeding occurs at all eight subpopulations greater than MVP, and is reported for 34 out 46 free living subpopulations for which information is available. Selective culling is reported for six out of eight subpopulations greater than MVP. While supplemental feeding and selective culling are well-intentioned to manage subpopulation distribution and abundance to protect bison from poaching and to reduce conflicts with surrounding land uses, there is concern that long-term reliance on these management techniques could lead to unintended consequences, including unsustainable expense, reduced subpopulation viability, and disruption of the species evolved natural life history.
  5. Conservation dependence. Free-living European Bison are a conservation dependent species. Though the total mature population size for the eight subpopulations greater than MVP has been increasing for the past generation, there have also been recent incidents of local extinction of other subpopulations (see WWF 2019). While the species is not currently in decline, the abundance of wild mature individuals could be reduced if there are significant perturbations such as a major disease outbreak, or current management regimes are negatively changed or removed. Such major perturbations have occurred previously leading to the species changing from Vulnerable to Endangered status in Red List Assessments conducted in 1996 and 2000. Progress in recovery of the European Bison through large-scale ecological restoration projects will depend on significant changes in its legal status and management as wildlife by governments, harmonisation of policies and activities among agencies at multiple levels, cooperation with environmental organisations, and public tolerance and support of free-living bison managed as wildlife on large landscapes. Cooperation and coordination are particularly important where different nations and organisations have separate management jurisdiction for adjacent land areas within an ecosystem unit in which ecological restoration of bison is possible.

Red List Criterion A – Population Size Reduction. Not applicable. Over three generations (36 years, 1983–2019), the number of free-living mature animals in subpopulations greater than MVP has increased from several hundred to over 2,500.

Red List Criterion B – Geographic Range. Not applicable. The minimum-maximum AOO of the eight subpopulations >MVP is 13,236-22,100 km², and exceeds the Criteria B threshold of 2,000 km². The EOO for these eight subpopulations is 544,401 km², and exceeds the criterion B threshold of 20,000 km². Although the species is fragmented per B2(a), the species is not undergoing continuing decline per B2(b) or extreme fluctuations per B2(c).

Red List Criterion C – Small Population Size and Decline. Not applicable. In 2019, only 2,518 mature individuals occurred in eight isolated wild free-living subpopulations greater than MVP, and no subpopulation was greater than 500 mature animals, thus making this species nearly qualify for Vulnerable under criterion C2a(i).

Red List Criterion D – Very Small or Restricted Population. Not applicable. Subpopulations are widely distributed across portions of the historic range, and exceed criteria D1 threshold of 1,000 total mature individuals.

Red List Criterion E – Quantitative Analysis. Not applicable. Quantitative population viability analyses of the eight free-living subpopulations greater than MVP have not been completed.
habitat: The majority of European Bison subpopulations were (re)introduced to forest habitats (Kerley et al. 2012). However, patterns of habitat use strongly vary between different population and are strongly shaped by habitat structure (forest cover) and management actions (Hofman-Kamińska et al. 2018). Preference towards open habitats such as meadows, river valleys, abandoned farmland, forest gaps and clearing is observed (Kuemmerle et al. 2011, Kowalczyk et al. 2019, Zielke et al. 2019). European Bison are mixed feeders or browsers (Gębczyńska et al. 1991; Kowalczyk et al. 2011, 2019; Bocherens et al. 2015, Merceron et al. 2015), which continuously adjust their diet with seasonal availability of easily digestible non-grass vegetation (Kowalczyk et al. 2019). In winter, bison foraging ecology can be strongly influenced by supplementary feeding (Kowalczyk et al. 2011). Non-fed populations usually utilise open habitats and agriculture areas. Farm crops depredation is compensated in some countries. European bison are not territorial and their spatial organisation and population density are influenced by habitat quality and food abundance (Kerley et al. 2020). Home ranges of bison covers from several dozen to two hundred km2, in relation to habitat structure and seasonal migrations (Kowalczyk and Plumb 2020). Home range sizes of mixed groups are influenced by the distribution and availability of forage resources, while home range of mature males is more related to reproductive behaviour and activity than food-related factors. In many populations seasonal migrations are observed, driven by supplementary feeding or access to food resources out of forest habitats, or having altitudinal character to avoid harsh winter conditions (Kowalczyk et al. 2013, Perzanowski et al. 2012).  Dispersal by male bison has occured up to several hundred km (Krasińska and Krasiński 2013). Dispersal by mixed groups is beginning to be observed in expanding populations, as the result of density-dependent intra-specific competition (Kowalczyk et al. 2013, Krasińska et al. 2014).  The European Bison exhibits a well-developed and dynamic social organisation (Krasińska et al. 2014). Mixed groups of up to 20 individuals generally, including adult cows, 2–3-year-old sub-adults and calves are the basic social units. Males remain solitary or form bachelor groups of two to eight animals. The size and composition of mixed groups are dynamic and change seasonally, being the largest during rut and winter aggregations (Krasińska and Krasiński 2013). Daily activity is typical of large ruminants and includes foraging bouts (up to five hours) alternating with resting bouts (up to four hours) devoted primarily to rumination (Caboń-Raczyńska et al. 1987).
threats:
Genetics
Contemporary genetic variability of European Bison is relatively low, being an effect of population bottleneck due to species extirpation in the wild in the early 20th century and subsequent restoration from limited number of captive survivors. The entire contemporary species population derives from only 12 individual genotypes (Pucek et al. 2004, Wójcik et al. 2009, Tokarska et al. 2011). Mean expected heterozygosity, calculated on the basis of microsatellite data, has been estimated as 0.29 (29%) for the Lowland line and 0.35 (35%) for the Lowland-Caucasian line (Tokarska, unpublished). This low genetic variability negatively influences effective population size (Ne). For example, the largest subpopulation is the Polish part of the Białowieża Forest (462 mature animals), yet the effective population size is likely less than 30 (Tokarska et al. 2009). Based on the extremely limited number of founder animals, this tremendous disparity between subpopulation number of mature animals and Ne can be reliably inferred for other free-ranging subpopulations.

Fragmentation and small population size
Approximately 77% of free-living subpopulations for which information is available are functionally isolated and fragmented from nearest neighbour populations by distance or barriers (man-made or natural). There are only eight subpopulations that exceed MVP, and ~34% of all free-living subpopulations include 25 or fewer mature animals, ~51% include 50 or fewer mature individuals, and ~83% of the populations include less than MVP. Given the small size of most free-living subpopulations, those at a greater distance from a nearest neighbour are much less likely to see successful natural dispersal or exchange of cows (and their genetics) between subpopulations across multiple generations, and thus we can infer further genetic drift of inherently low genetic diversity to be amplified through long-term isolation.

Refugee Species
When restoration into the wild began in 1952, the European Bison was characterised as a forest specialist and thus the species was restored in forest habitats. Increasing scientific evidence demonstrates that the European Bison is also adapted to effective use of open and mixed habitats (Mendoza and Palmqvist 2008, Kerley et al. 2012, Bocherens et al. 2015, Hofman-Kamińska et al. 2019). Recently, the species has been recharacterized as a refugee species, that can no longer access optimal habitat, but is confined to sub-optimal habitats, with consequences of decreased fitness and density, and attendant conservation risks (Kerley et al. 2012). The process of becoming a refugee species likely started after the last glaciation due to increasing human pressure related to human spread and development of Neolithic agriculture, and was reinforced during species restoration (Kerley et al. 2012, Hofman-Kamińska 2019). Confinement of an open-habitat adapted species to forest habitats may act against natural selection pressures, entails supplementary feeding, intensifies management complexity, increases management expense, increases vulnerability to disease and parasites, and may increase risks of human-wildlife conflicts when bison attempt to move out of forests (Hofman-Kamińska and Kowalczyk 2012; Kerley et al. 2012; Kowalczyk et al. 2013; Kołodziej-Sobocińska et al. 2016a, b, c; Samojlik et al. 2019). Contemporary habitat selection indicates the species’ preference for open and wet/open habitats and abandoned fields over the forests, especially coniferous ones (Kuemmerle et al. 2010, 2018, Kowalczyk et al. 2019, Zielke et al. 2019). As a large and potentially conflicting species, European Bison require large spaces of mosaic habitats supporting the populations year round, with lower human densities and agricultural activities, to reduce potential conflicts. Such areas are limited in Europe. Increasing land abandonment in Eastern Europe (Russia and Ukraine) creates potentially suitable conditions for species restoration (Alcantra et al. 2013), however instability of nature conservation in those countries makes these areas risky. Forest introductions are still continuing (e.g. Bad Berleburg, Germany and Augustów Forest, NE Poland), though recent reintroduction in Romania and Bulgaria in suitable remote mountainous areas may lead to subpopulation growth with less conflict.

Disease
Knowledge on health status of European Bison comes from limited number of populations, mainly in Poland. While several diseases are known to occur in European Bison, including blue tongue virus, foot-and-mouth disease, respiratory viruses, and bovine tuberculosis (Larska and Krzysiak 2019), they are not as broadly distributed within or across free-ranging populations as the infectious parasites. Nearly 90 species of parasites in European Bison were identified (Karbowiak et al. 2014a, b), with species richness, prevalence and intensity of infections increasing in multiple populations (Drożdż 1998). It was documented that supplementary feeding and unnatural aggregation of bison in winter at fixed locations lead to increased parasitic load (Radwan et al. 2010, Kerley et al. 2012, Karbowiak et al. 2014b, Kołodziej-Sobocińska et al. 2016b). Adaptive management has proven effective in reducing parasite transmission and risk of diseases (Kołodziej-Sobocińska et al. 2016b).

Culling, hunting, poaching
Paradoxically for a species with low numbers, some free-living subpopulations (including small ones) are subjected to culling to reduce number, regulate sex-age structure or even for commercial hunting purposes. This policy contrasts strongly with the management of other large mammals which have undergone similar population declines as the European Bison and for which populations are now increasing in response to conservation management, such as the rhinoceros or the Cape Mountain Zebra (Emslie 2008, IUCN SSC African Rhino Specialist Group 2008, Hrabar and Kerley 2013). Poaching plays locally important role especially in small populations exposed to high stochasticity. In the 1990s, uncontrolled hunting and poaching in Ukraine during democratic transformation resulted in a strong decline or extirpation of bison herds (WWF 2019).

Policy inconsistency
Though this issue was identified in the 2004 European Bison Status Survey and Conservation Action Plan (Pucek et al. 2004), it still remains an important concern. The European Bison is generally a protected species in the countries where it occurs. It is covered by EU legislation in frame of Council Directive 92/43/EEC on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora, and included in the Annex 2 (animal and plant species of community interest whose conservation requires the designation of special areas of conservation) as priority species, and Annex 4 (animal and plant species of community interest in need of strict protection). However, across the historic range, there are inconsistent national policies regarding management and conservation procedures, that can concede to habitat degradation, population restriction, and selective culling. Following political transformations in Eastern Europe, uncontrolled hunting and poaching in Russia and Ukraine lead to population decline (Pucek et al. 2004, WWF 2019). Such inconsistency not only impacts existing populations, but also limits the possibility of restoration and population expansion. Large areas of abandoned fields in eastern Europe in recent decades (especially in Russia and Ukraine) (Alcantara et al. 2013) may now be suitable for the introduction of the bison, but cannot currently be considered due to insufficient protection.
population:
This assessment adheres to the IUCN Red List Guidelines and utilises IUCN terminology intended for consistency across taxa (IUCN 2019). For this assessment, ‘subpopulation’ does not infer a meta-population. The Red List term ‘wild’ equates to the ‘free-living’ animals as reported in the EBPB, and does not include the EBPB “captivity” or “semi-free living (e.g. large enclosures)” categories. This assessment also refers to the term ‘minimum viable population (MVP)' as an ecological threshold that specifies the smallest number of individuals in a subpopulation capable of persisting at a specific statistical probability level for a predetermined amount of time. This Red List assessment (RLA) uses the occupied grid cell approach to estimate ‘area of occupancy (AOO)’; by counting the number of occupied cells in a uniform grid that covers the entire range of distribution, and then tallying the total area (km²) of all occupied cells; so that AOO = number of occupied cells × area of an individual cell (IUCN 2019). Though the Red List Guidelines recommend using a uniform 2 x 2 km grid for consistency across taxon, we also used a comparative 10 x 10 km grid that better aligns to the spatial scale of the landscape ecology of the European Bison (see Kowalczyk et al. 2013, Kuemmerle et al. 2018, J.A. Hernandez-Blanco pers. comm. 2020, G. Wilson pers. comm. 2020), in order to generate comparative minimum and maximum AOO estimates. The term ‘extent of occurrence (EOO)’ is the calculated minimum convex polygon area size (km²) for a set of subpopulations (IUCN 2019).

In addition to information from the European Bison Pedigree Book, this assessment also considers subpopulation-specific information to assess whether a subpopulation is deemed to contribute to the number of mature individuals considered in a Red List Assessment. A key consideration is whether a free-living subpopulation includes sufficient mature animals to maintain the potential for ecological adaption through the effects of natural selection operating on viable populations. While there is variation in age-class demography between subpopulations, this information is not uniformly monitored or reported to EBPB. As reported in the detailed species monograph by Krasińska and Krasiński (2013), the mature age class generally accounts for approximately 60% of a subpopulation. Thus, for this assessment, the 60% mature age class was applied uniformly to each subpopulation. Taking into account the levels of inbreeding of the European Bison population (described below), Brook et al. (2002) calculated the MVP of a subpopulation as 250 individuals for a 95% probability of subpopulation survival for 100 years; thus yielding a generalized MVP of 150 mature animals (250 * 0.60). Subpopulation size trend (increasing, decreasing, stable) was assessed between 2015–2019 (as reported in the 2016 and 2020 EBPB). The Red List Guidelines prescribe analyses to be conducted for the recent 10 years, or three generations, whichever is longer (IUCN 2019). For this assessment, generation length is calculated as 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction (IUCN 2019), wherein the age of first reproduction is set at 4 years and adult mortality set at 13% (Krasińska and Krasiński 2013), so that generation length = 4+ 1/.13 = 11.7 rounded up to 12 years. Thus, for the analyses herein, three generations equal 36 years. Fragmentation is considered through measurements of distance (km) to nearest neighbour subpopulation and whether there are natural or man-made barriers to dispersal movement between subpopulations. Additional consideration is given to whether subpopulation resources are naturally limited or if the subpopulation otherwise receives supplemental feeding; and whether a subpopulation is subject to selective culling. Belarus has indicated that, while the Nacional’nyjj Park Pripjatskijj is reported to the EBPB as one subpopulation, there are actually two free living herds that are isolated from each other (P. Veligurov pers. comm.); and are reported herein as two distinct subpopulations. Russia has indicated that, while the Kaluzhskije Zaseki Zapovednik plus Nacional’nyjj Park Ugra and the Orlovskoe Poles’e Nacional'nyjj Park are reported to EBPB as two units under separate management, there is natural movement exchange of mature animals between the two management units (J.A Blanco-Hernandez pers. comm.), and so they have been combined into one subpopulation for this assessment. Ukraine has reported that, while the Forest Range “Storozhynetske” (Chernivtsi Region) and the Forest Hunting Range “Beregometske” (Chernivtsi Region) are reported to EPBP as separate management units, there is natural movement exchange of mature animals between the two management units, so they are combined in this assessment. This is also the case for the Ukraine Hunting Range “Zvirivske” (Volyn Region) and the Limited Liability Company “Maidan Myslyvskyi” (Volyn Regioin), so these are also combined into one subpopulation (V. Smagol pers. comm.).

In 2019, only eight free-living subpopulations exceeded MVP (range 166–462 mature animals) with a total of 2,518 mature animals (see Table 1 in Supplementary Information). During the past three generations (36 years, 1983–2019), there was a genuine, observed increase in the abundance of mature free-living European Bison living in subpopulations greater than MVP, from a few hundred to over 2,500 (see Supplementary Information). Between 2015–2019, the average annual growth rate  was 12.3% for these eight subpopulations greater than MVP. For these eight subpopulations, the minimum AOO was 13,236 km² and maximum AOO was 22,100 km2, and EOO was 544,401 km2; (see Supplementary Information).
range: Palaeontological and archaeological findings indicate that the species distribution during the Holocene extended east from France to the Ural and Northern Caucasus, and north from Bulgaria to southern Sweden, not including the Iberian Peninsula (Soubrier et al. 2016, Hofman-Kamińska et al. 2019). Lowland Bison were distributed across western and eastern Europe (Węcek et al. 2016, Pucek et al. 2004), while the Caucasian Bison occurred only in the northern Caucasus mountains and foothills (Heptner et al. 1966). As a generalist quadruped, the European Bison evolved to utilise open or mixed habitats; and with relatively high mobility in response to environmental drivers, there was likely substantial variation in local abundance and density, including extended absences at local to regional scales while the species was still distributed across the historic range. In short, the European Bison was likely patchily distributed and did not occur everywhere all the time within suitable habitat within its historic range. Extensive forest expansion occurred 12,000–8,000 Before Present (BP) concomitant with reduced open habitats available for large herbivores such as Bison and Aurochs. Humans expanded with the development of Neolithic agriculture (7,000-5,000 years BP) resulting in pressures on bison including hunting and land use conversion to agriculture. The species became absent from most of Europe between 9,500 and 7,000 years BP,  and after this period, recovered or recolonised, probably from east (see Hofman-Kamińska et al. 2019). Since the 16th century, European Bison persisted in the wild only through royal protection. By the 19th century, free-living European Bison were limited to only the Białowieża Forest of northeast Poland and western Belarus, and Caucasus mountains (Pucek et al. 2004). By the early 20th century, the species was increasingly imperilled in the wild, with the Lowland Bison becoming Extinct in the Wild in 1919, and the Caucasian Bison Extinct in the Wild by 1927 (Pucek et al. 2004).
useTrade: In general, free-living European bison are not subject to extensive trade and use. All free-living subpopulations exist at locations where management emphasis is primarily on protection of the species; with some locations utilizing supplemental feeding and selective culling to manage local distribution and abundance in order to mitigate potential poaching and conflicts with surrounding land uses.
conservationActions:
Population Viability
While the European Bison is no longer threatened by extinction, most free-living subpopulations are small and isolated. Small, isolated subpopulations are at risk from random catastrophic events, and also lose genetic diversity more quickly than large subpopulations through the process of genetic drift, which in turn can decrease the viability of populations through an accumulation of inbreeding and loss of adaptive capacity. To mitigate the loss of genetic diversity in these isolated subpopulations, bison population viability analyses have suggested increasing subpopulation size where possible, and otherwise restoring effective gene flow among subpopulations and managing under a meta-population framework, where gene flow can be restored either through the restoration of natural movements between populations or through the translocation of animals (or gametes) among populations (Daleszczyk and Bunevich 2009, Hartway et al. 2019).

Conservation planning
In 2004, the IUCN-SSC-BSG published a report entitled “European Bison Status Survey and Conservation Action Plan” (CAP, Pucek et al. 2004). With the free-living population growing from 1,848 in 2003 to 6,244 in 2019, it is clearly time for undertaking a new collaborative multi-stakeholder conservation planning process to produce an update to the 2004 CAP that includes a long-term conservation action plan with a very strong scientific basis and actionable consensus. Key issues needing to be examined include climate and environmental change, science advances and needs, increased interest in restoration programs involving large mammals, meta-population dynamics, conservation genetics (including the prevailing emphasis on separation of the Lowland (B. b. bonasus) and Caucasian (Bison bonasus bonasus x B. b. caucasicus) genetic lines amongst free-living subpopulations), disease ecology, habitat availability and shifting land use practices, restoration and translocation priorities, human dimensions, integrated in situ and ex situ management, and European Union and variable national and legal and policy status. The IUCN-SSC-BSG is formally partnering with the IUCN-SSC-Conservation Planning Specialist Group and multiple European wildlife conservation organisations to undertake collaborative conservation planning to produce an updated IUCN CAP that will serve as an innovative, efficient and effective milestone for its potential to empower new initiatives and result in better alignment of multi-national conservation strategies and actions.

Science needs
There is a critical need to enhance levels of collaborative and comparative science. Enhancing the effectiveness and sustainability of restoration activities should include testing of alternative hypotheses about landscape ecology, analysing habitat availability and suitability for optimal restoration designs, and comparative analyses of population viability and potential meta-population management strategies (see Daleszczyk and Bunevich 2009, Hartway et al. 2020, Kerley et al 2012, 2020). Comparative analyses of the effects of selective culling and supplemental feeding will be important for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of local conservation management. Also needed are comparative analyses of bison ecology across the historic range (e.g. population ecology, metapopulation macrophysiology, foraging ecology, competition with sympatric wild ungulates, ecological cascades, ethology, etc.), comprehensive disease and parasitology monitoring, and innovative social science that addresses the human dimensions of bison recovery.

Adaptive Management
Achieving the full ecological recovery of the European Bison conservation will require collaboration of researchers, managers, and policymakers to develop and implement science-based adaptive management (Kerley and Knight 2010). There is a need to institutionalise evidence-based capacity to learn and adjust management as needed to restore bison to optimal habitats that secure the needs of the species throughout the year and spacious enough to maintain viable populations (Samojlik et al. 2019). It is very important to adaptively manage for an effective and efficient balance of supplementary feeding and culling with conservation of the full extent of the species naturally evolved ecology. Adaptive management can also serve as a framework to restore large heterogeneous landscapes that include forests, meadows and open habitats for both existing and future bison herds, thereby potentially lowering the expense of supplementary feeding when introducing to suitable habitats; to gain and employ improved understanding of the human dimensions of bison recovery and thereby enhance active social support that includes financial and habitat commitments; and to strive for effective long-term genetic conservation and population viability by establishing sufficiently large meta-populations that link smaller isolated populations across regional geographic ranges.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct as there is no evidence to suggest that this large species of Cryptoprocta currently survives on Madagascar. It is currently known only from subfossil remains and is believed to have survived at least into the recent geological past.
habitat: Given the size of Cryptoprocta spelea, its massive jaws and large carnassial teeth, it must have been a formidable predator and certainly capable of taking larger prey than the extant C. ferox. Evidence suggests that the two forms of Cryptoprocta might have been separated well enough in size to be able to coexist (Goodman et al. 2004).
threats: The reasons for the disappearance of this species on Madagascar (its entire world range) are unknown.
population: It is extinct.
range: On the basis of current subfossil evidence, Cryptoprocta spelea occurred at a variety of sites from Lakaton’ny Akanga in the far north near Antsiranana, along the western portion of Madagascar, south to numerous sites at the southern end of the island; it is also recorded on the central highlands at Antsirabe (Goodman et al. 2004).
useTrade: There are no uses at present as this species is extinct.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are needed because the species is extinct.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on its distribution, population status, ecology and threats.
habitat: While its actual habitat preference is not known the region of the type locality has tundra and islands of Nothofagus forest. Its breeding ecology is unknown, although it could be presumed to breed by larval development in streams similar to other species in the genus.
threats: The major threats to this species are unknown, but the region is completely inaccessible and uninhabited.
population: Very little is known on the population of this species and the population trend is unknown. Charles Darwin collected the only known specimen of this species in the 1800s.
range: This species is known only from the type locality: Inchy Island in southern Chile. Confusion over the precise location of the type locality has hampered efforts to rediscover this species. Records of this species from elsewhere in Chile and in Argentina now refer to other species (see taxonomic note), so its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 65 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The area where it is thought to have been collected might be protected in Laguna San Rafael National Park. 

Research Needed
Research on the taxonomy status, population and distribution, ecology and threats for this species is required.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient, because it is only known from two locations and there is nothing known about its population, habitat requirements, or the threats faced by the species.
habitat: Habitats for this species are unknown.
threats: No information is available on possible threats to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the populations of this species.
range: This species is known from two localities in eastern Iran, Kavir-e-Namk, Kashmar, and Kavir-e-Lout, Bandan.
useTrade: The use and trade information is unknown.
conservationActions: The conservation actions informations for this species are unknown.

rationale: This species is endemic to the Gulf of Mexico and known from few specimens captured from two Mexican reef systems: Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz, Mexico. It has not yet been observed in its habitat, but was captured in shallow waters by fishermen using hook and line. Under the assumption that the preferred habitat is coral reef, it has an estimated EOO of 8,409 km<sup>2 </sup>and AOO of 32 km<sup>2</sup>. There have been direct observations of a 17% decline in coral cover off Veracruz over 34 years. Both reef systems are threatened by pollution and coastal development, which are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs. The species may also be susceptible to predation by the invasive Lionfish, which now occurs throughout the entire range of this species. If these assumptions are correct, this species could qualify as Vulnerable under B1 and Endangered under B2. However, this species is known from only a few specimens and there is an ongoing debate on the validity of species within this genus. Consequently, little is known on its life history, complete distribution, population or ecology. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient until further research is conducted.
habitat: This species was recently described from two specimens captured by fishermen fishing with hook and line in shallow waters less than 20 m in depth. It has not yet been studied in its habitat, therefore, nothing is known on its ecology. The sizes of the two specimens collected were 10.4 cm SL and 7.5 cm SL (Tavera and Acero 2013).
threats: This species is likely impacted by loss of coral reef if it is its preferred habitat. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). It is considered endemic to the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems which are threatened by heavy anthropogenic impacts such as accidental fuel spills from the nearby Port of Tuxpan, commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area, and contamination from heavy metals, feces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants out of the Tuxpan River (Ortiz-Lozano 2012, Gandara et al. 2013). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). This uncommon species could easily be targeted by aquarium trade. It also may be easily targeted for predation by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (Green et al. 2012).
population: This species was recently described from two specimens with little known on its population (Tavera and Acero 2013).
range: This species is only known from two specimens captured between Bajo de Tuxpan to Isla Lobos, Veracruz off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico (Tavera and Acero 2013). Its preferred habitat and depth range are not yet well understood. Assuming it prefers coral reef habitat, it has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,409 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a coral reef layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 32 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). Quantified data are not available for the Tuxpan-Lobos Reef System, however, declines are suspected there as well due to increased port activity and pollution from river runoff (Gandara et al. 2013).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano has been designated as a national park since 1992 and a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 2006, however, there is no effective management plan in place. Furthermore, the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There is also a marine protected area around Isla Lobos, with a management plan in press, but there is limited enforcement (T. Camarena-Luhrs pers. comm. 2014). Further research is recommended on the range, habitat, ecology, life history, and population of this species (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2014).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, if this species survives at all, it occurs in a single location defined by the presence of invasive species, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred as a result of predation by exotic mammals. Guadeloupe has multiple satellites where it is possible a remnant population survives, and as one of the largest of the Lesser Antilles it is possible that an undetected population may exist on the mainland, but it is thought likely that if the species survives it will have an area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup>.
habitat: No ecological information exists for this species (Hedges and Conn 2012).
threats: If this species survives it faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose, which has, however, probably already led to its extinction. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012).
population: This species has not been observed in about a century (Hedges and Conn 2012).
range: The species is endemic to Guadeloupe, where the only known named locality is the city of Pointe-à-Pitre, Grande-Terre. No specific locality data are associated with other specimens (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine if the species still exists and the health of any remaining populations (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, if this species survives at all, it occurs in a single location defined by the presence of invasive species, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred as a result of predation by exotic mammals. Guadeloupe has multiple satellites where it is possible a remnant population survives, and as one of the largest of the Lesser Antilles it is possible that an undetected population may exist on the mainland, but it is thought likely that if the species survives it will have an area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup>.
habitat: No ecological information exists for this species (Hedges and Conn 2012). Dark pigmentation on the known specimens is typical of species found in mesic habitats (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015).
threats: This species, if it survives, faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose, which has however probably already led to its extinction. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012). If a remnant population survives, it is likely that it has an extremely restricted distribution, and will be found at a single location defined by a threat from mongoose predation.
population: The species has not been observed in more than a century (Hedges and Conn 2012), having not been collected since 1892. It is known from three specimens (Hedges and Conn 2012).
range: The species is known to have occurred on Guadeloupe, but with no specific locality. It has been assumed that the species was allopatric with Mabuya grandisterrae, known from Grand-Terre, and so by implication likely occurred on Basse-Terre (Hedges and Conn 2012), the part of the island to which the name Guadeloupe referred explicitly when the skinks were collected (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine if the species still exists and the health of any remaining populations (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: This species has not been seen since 1877 despite its historical occurrence on two well-surveyed islands, and may well be extinct. Nevertheless it is tentatively listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that a remnant population may persist, but if so it will have an extent of occurrence below 100 km<sup>2</sup> (and probably an area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup>), any population will presumably be severely fragmented, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred from the continuing presence of invasive mongoose. Targeted surveys are needed to confirm whether the species should indeed be listed as Extinct.
habitat: No ecological information is available for this species. Presumably it was viviparous, in common with other Spondylurus species, but no data on reproduction are available.
threats: Declines and extinctions of mabuyine skinks throughout the Virgin Islands have been blamed on the introduction of mongoose (Hedges and Conn 2012, Perry and Gerber 2006), and several species now survive only on smaller islands where this invasive predator is absent (Hedges and Conn 2012). Predation by other exotic species, including black rats, and urban and agricultural development may also have contributed to the apparent extinction of this species.
population: This species is known from six specimens collected intermittently between 1799 and 1877 (Hedges and Conn 2012). On the assumption that the assignment of specimens "probably from St. Croix" to St. John and St. Thomas is correct (and that the species was therefore endemic to these islands), this skink is apparently now extinct. Considerable subsequent herpetological research on these islands has failed to rediscover it, and the dates of the last records correspond with losses of other Spondylurus species from St. Thomas, and possibly St. John, following the introduction of mongoose (Hedges and Conn 2012). Nevertheless, evidence from elsewhere in the Caribbean indicates that Spondylurus species can persist undetected on large, well-surveyed islands where mongoose are ubiquitous, albeit as very small, restricted-range populations (as is the case for S. fulgidus in Jamaica and S. nitidus in Puerto Rico), or can survive on small offshore islets (as with S. magnacruzae on Green Cay) (Hedges and Conn 2012, S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2013). By analogy with these cases, in which surviving subpopulations are highly fragmented or confined to a single locality, and under ongoing pressure from invasive species, any surviving population is presumed to be both severely fragmented and declining.
range: This species has been recorded from unspecified localities on St. Thomas and St. John, two of the larger US Virgin Islands (Hedges and Conn 2012). It has not been recorded since 1877 despite extensive herpetological survey work in the Virgin Islands (Hedges and Conn 2012). It may once have been more widespread, perhaps occurring in the British Virgin Islands, however since very few herpetological surveys were conducted in this region prior to the 19th Century introduction of mongoose this is impossible to verify (Hedges and Conn 2012). Records "probably from St. Croix" appear to have been assigned an erroneous locality due to confusion with Spondylurus magnacruzae, and these specimens are instead presumed to have come from St. Thomas or St. John by Hedges and Conn (2012). St. Thomas and St. John have a combined land area of 129 km2, however in the absence of locality data for either island the species' historical extent of occurrence cannot be determined. Any surviving population will occur over a much smaller area, as both islands are well-surveyed and possible refuges where this species could have survived overlooked are therefore limited.
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species, which is not known to survive.
conservationActions: This species is likely to be extinct, in which case no conservation measures are applicable. Nevertheless, although considerable herpetological survey work has been undertaken on St Thomas and St John, targeted surveys for this skink are needed on these islands and associated islets following its recognition as a distinct species, in case a remnant population survives (Hedges and Conn 2012). Should the species be rediscovered, research into its population status and threats will be a priority (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: This common, deep-living, benthopelagic species is widely distributed and occurs over soft bottom on the outer continental shelf and upper slope. No major threats are known, therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This deepwater, benthopelagic, oviparous species lives over soft bottom on the lower continental shelf and upper continental slope where it eats mainly crustaceans (Nielsen 1999, Nielsen 2002, Garrido-Linares and Acero 2006, Mincarone et al. 2008, Nielsen et al. 2009). It is possible that it burrows in the sediment to avoid predation (Nielsen 1999). The ocelli (color patterns) of Neobythites spp. may function as camouflage from predators and for social communication between species (Uiblein and Nielsen 2005). It has a maximum size of 14.8 cm SL.
threats: No major threats are known for Neobythites multiocellatus, but it may occur as bycatch in deepwater trawl fisheries.
population: Neobythites multiocellatus is a common species (Nielsen et al. 2009).
range: Neobythites multiocellatus is widely distributed in the western Atlantic from 102-770 m depth from eastern Florida, Cuba, southern Jamaica, northern Dominican Republic to Montserrat, and along the Central and South American coast from Honduras to Isla de Margarita. It is known from at least 69 localities (Nielsen et al. 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species has only been recorded from a single specimen captured in the Caribbean Sea well offshore of Panama in relatively deep waters (100 m). Little is known on its distribution, habitat and ecology. Therefore it is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Minyichthys inusitatus is a very small species with specimens averaging 2.9 cm (Fritszche and Vincent 2002). The single specimen was collected from deep pelagic waters (100-109 m).  Little else is known about the ecology of this species. Other species of Minyichthys tend to feed on planktonic or benthic crustaceans, and males carry the eggs in a brood pouch (Herald and Randall 1972).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is rarely recorded (Kuiter 2009). It was described from a single specimen (Dawson 1983).
range: Minyichthys inusitatus is known only from a juvenile specimen captured in the Caribbean Sea from 100-109 m depth well offshore of Panama, and another possible specimen from northern Argentina (Dawson 1983). It is believed this species is restricted to deep waters based on the fact that there have been very few trawled specimens (Kuiter 2009), as well as the fact that they were not collected during numerous SCUBA surveys within the range of 0-30 m. Therefore, it is presumed that this species occurs in depths greater than 30-40 m, to about 175 m (Dawson 1983).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this fish.

rationale: Syngnathus dawsoni is known from the Lesser Antilles where it occurs in shallow, near-shore waters. The species' habitat and population size are unknown, as are threats. This species is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species has been captured at shallow depths to 7 m, however, little else is known. It has been collected from nearshore bays and reef habitats.
threats: Threats are unknown at this time, however, shallow coastal habitats often face degradation.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates undertaken for this species. Further research is needed to determine population size.
range: Syngnathus dawsoni has been recorded in the western central Atlantic Ocean in the Caribbean Sea from Puerto Rico to St. Lucia and is known to occur only on the east side of the Mona Passage (Fritzsche and Vincent 2002, Taylor and Hellberg 2006). Its depth range is 0-7 m. Its known estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 192,520 km² (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 0-10 m bathymetric layer). Its estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 5,412 km² (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 0-10 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: The species is not known from trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this fish.

rationale: This species is only known from one specimen collected in deep waters off Curacao. There are no known major threats, however, more inoformation is needed regarding life history and current population size. Therefore, Haptoclius dropi is currently listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only known specimen of this species was recently described from a collection performed via manned deep submersible dive, therefore, little is known. The size of the female specimen collected was 2.1 cm SL (Baldwin and Robertson 2013).
threats: There are currently no known major threats to this species.
population: This species was recently described from one specimen. Therefore, population data is limited until further research is conducted (Baldwin and Robertson 2013).
range: This species is known only from one specimen collected in the western Atlantic off Curacao in the southern Caribbean from 157−167 m depth (Baldwin and Robertson 2013).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for Haptoclinus dropi.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is only known from specimens collected in 1975, from an area which has not subsequently been accessible for surveys, and although the known locality is a town that has subsequently been developed for tourism nothing is known of any threats to this species, its ecological requirements, or its broader distribution.
habitat: This species was collected from a house in Kishtwar Town (Duda and Sahi 1978).
threats: Kishtwar is a tourist area, within a region whose natural habitat is pine and fir forest. Nothing is, however ,known of any threats or whether the species is more widespread, and there has been no recent survey effort in Jammu Kashmir.
population: This species was described based on eight specimens taken in May and October 1975 (Duda and Sahdi 1978). There have been no subsequently published records and no other specimens appear to exist.
range: This species is known only from Kishtwar town, Doda district, Jammu, India (Duda and Sahi 1978).
useTrade: Not in use or trade
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas. Research is needed to clarify its present status, distribution, ecology and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are not known and that this species is only known from the type specimen collected in the 19th Century.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: Any threats to this lizard are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species, as it is only known from the 19th Century type specimen.
range: This species is known only from the type locality between Moyobamba and Puerto Balsa, Río Huallaga, eastern Peru (Cope 1876, Williams 1979).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species, which is known from a single specimen.
conservationActions: No conservation measures can be proposed unless this species is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because although the species is known only from the type locality, it is not thought to be subject to major threats.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: No major threats are known for this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, the town Marainiyoc in the Region Junin, at 2,880 m elevation (Köhler 2003).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its distribution, abundance, and population trends should be carried out in order to identify whether any threats are affecting this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because of a lack of any recent records of the species, a problem exacerbated by taxonomic uncertainty about the status of the species and a lack of clarity about both the type locality and the broader distribution of this species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: Any threats are unknown.
population: This species may not have been recorded for more than a century. Of five specimens from Peru examined by Chávez et al. (2018), only the two members of the type series proved to be referable to this species. Similarly, the only Ecuadorian report of this species dates to the 19th Century (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016).
range: Following the work of Chávez et al. (2017) this species is known in Peru only from the vicinity of Moyobamba in San Martin, with an unspecific type locality. It has been reported from the Amazonian slope of the Andes in southern Ecuador, where, but there is doubt about the origin of the only known specimen.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This is one of the most poorly-known reptile species in Peru (P. Venegas pers. comm. 2018). Taxonomic work is needed to clarify the status of this species and whether any material existing in natural history museums correspond to this species. Surveys in the area of the type locality are needed to relocate the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, population trend, and threats are poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, the Andes of Cuzco, Perú. It has been recorded at 2,395 m asl (Peters and Donoso-Barros 1970). There is not enough information to map this species (C. Aguilar and J. Pérez pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its taxonomy, distribution, abundance, and population trends should be carried out in order to identify whether any threats are affecting this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient due to a lack of information about the extent of its distribution, population status, natural history, and protection status. The species is know from a few specimens, the most recent of which date from the mid 1900s. Research is needed to better establish the distribution, threats, life history, and population status of this species.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which has not been recorded since the mid 1900s.
range: This species is known from the Andes of Ecuador and Peru. In Ecuador, the species has been recorded at Puyo (between Mera and Tena) in Pastaza Province. In Peru, it is known from Puntoyacu, the Perené River, and Cerros del Sira (98 259 S, 748 449 W), in Huánuco region; the Aguaytía River and Cordillera Azul in Loreto region; and Ollachea in Puno region, all in Peru. The elevational range is from 1250-1560 m asl (Peters and Donoso-Barros 1970, Kölher and Lehr 2004).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Whether this species occurs in a protected area is unknown. Research is needed to better establish the distribution, threats, life history, and population status of this species.

rationale: There is very little known about this species as it is only known from one specimen. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species are unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This western central Atlantic species is known only from the holotype taken off the island of Aruba in the Caribbean Sea.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is only known from single samples in two locations. There is no population information known about this species therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is reef-associated.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no species specific population information available.
range: This western Atlantic species is only known in the Caribbean Sea from San Blas, Panama and Santa Marta, Colombia in the Aguja Canyon.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: There is little known about this species and it is only known from two specimens. Therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Very little is known about the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: There are no known threats for this species.
population: This species is known from two specimens. This is a very small, deep water species, so it likely escapes most fishing and sampling gear.
range: This western Atlantic species is known only along the Caribbean Colombian coast from Punta Caribana to Cartagena (Smith-Vaniz 2000). Specimens have been taken between 60-72 m depth.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: There is very little known about this species as it is only known from a single specimen. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species is unknown.
threats: There are no known threats for this species.
population: There is no species specific population information available.
range: This western central Atlantic species is known only from a single specimen collected from Cubagua Island (Isla de Cubagua), Venezuela (Robins and Randall 1965). It is not known if this is a restricted range species, or more widely distributed. Records from Mexico and Barbados require verification.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is only known from one location. There is no population information known about this species therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is bathydemersal.
threats: The threats to this species are not well known.
population: There is no species specific population information available.
range: This western Atlantic species is only known from its type locality of Arrowsmith Bank (21°04'N, 86°19'W) located off the Yucatan Peninsula (Mexico) in the Caribbean Sea.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: There is very little known about this species and only from one sample. Therefore is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information known about this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not well known.
population: There is no population information known for this species.
range: This western Atlantic species is known only from Roatan Island, Honduras in the Caribbean Sea (Johnson and Greenfield 1976).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species was described from an erroneous type locality and has never since been recorded. As such both its taxonomic validity and its provenance are unclear, and nothing is known of its ecology, population status or any threats.
habitat: The only known specimens are the ones used for the description by Laurent in 1990 that were collected by Wolfgang K. Weyrauch some time between 1938 and 1962. All known museum records of lizards in the type locality belong to Stenocercus, not Liolaemus (C. Aguilar pers. comm. 2015). There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species. Nothing is known of its reproductive mode (Aguilar et al. 2013).
threats: As this species' true distribution is unknown, nothing is known of any threats.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Fieldwork near the type locality in both 2012 and 2013 failed to record any specimens (Aguilar et al. 2013) and the locality is considered to be in error (C. Aguilar pers. comm. 2016, R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016).
range: This species' type locality is given as Huamachuco, in the Region of La Libertad, Perú (Laurent 1990). This is certainly in error, and the species does not occur here (C. Aguilar pers. comm. 2014, R. Langstroth pers. comm. 2016). The species has not been rediscovered and it is consequently not clear either whether it is valid or what its true distribution may be.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Should future research locate additional specimens referable to this taxon, research is needed to clarify whether it is a valid species and, if so, to determine its true distributional extent, ecological requirements, and exposure to any threats.

rationale: Microlophus heterolepis has been assessed as Data Deficient. In Peru it is known only from the holotype and hence its current distribution is not known. Because of this lack of information it is not known whether M. heterolepis is being impacted by any major threats.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: Due to a lack of distribution and habitat information, it is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats.
population: There is no population information available for this species, which is known only from the holotype.
range: This species has been reported only from the extreme northern Chile and southern Peru (Peters and Donoso-Barros 1970). Although the type locality is from Peru, the species has not been reported in this country since its description (J. Pérez pers. comm. 2014). Recently, its occurrence in Chile has been disputed (Ortiz et al. in press), in which case the species is still known only from the Peruvian type locality.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species, which has not been recorded since its original description.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its taxonomy is needed before any other research, due to the little information currently available.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: There are not known threats for the species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type specimen, which is only known to come from Peru (Peters and Orejas Miranda 1970). There is not enough information to map this species.
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species would benefit from better information on taxonomy, distribution, abundance, population trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another Red List Category.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this species.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from Santo Domingo, Carabaya in the Peruvian Andes, having been recorded at 1,800 m (Boulenger 1904, Schmidt and Walker 1943).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species would benefit from better information on taxonomy, distribution, abundance, population trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, population trend, and threats are poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Lima, Perú (Peters and Orejas-Miranda, 1970). There is insufficient information to map this species (J. Pérez pers comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no information on any use or trade in this species, but it is unlikely to be of any commercial interest.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its taxonomy, distribution, abundance, and population trends should be carried out in order to identify whether any threats are affecting this species.

rationale: Tropidurus arenarius has been assessed as Data Deficient. Its taxonomic status is unclear and hence its current distribution is not known. Because of this lack of information it is not known whether T. arenarius is being impacted by any major threats.
habitat: There is no ecological information available for this species.
threats: Due to a lack of distribution and habitat information, it is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: There are no confirmed records of this species since its description by Tschudi (1845), from Huacho, Lima region, Peru, an area that is frequently sampled (Aguilar et al. 2007; J. Pérez pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
