conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its taxonomy is needed before any other research, due to the little information currently available.

rationale: Amphisbaena polygrammica is only known from the type specimen and it is unclear whether any threats are significantly impacting this species. This species has therefore been assessed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed before a more accurate assessment can be carried out.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecological information available for this species.
threats: The Chanchamayo District is characterized by extensive agriculture, and is well-known for its citrus and coffee production. However, it is unknown if these activities are significantly impacting this species, as nothing is known about its true distribution or ecological tolerances.
population: There are no population data available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the type locality in the district of Chanchamayo, Peru (11°04'S, 75°19'W). There is no information about elevation range range (E. Lehr pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. <span lang="EN-US">Surveys are needed to obtain more material of this species and clarify its distribution, natural history, and sensitivity to agricultural development.

rationale: Atractus paravertebralis has been assessed as Data Deficient due to the lack of population and accurate distribution data available. Further research is needed to assess how this species is affected by habitat change before a more informed assessment on the conservation status of A. paravertebralis can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species, apart from it being fossorial. The region of Madre de Dios is comprised predominantly of low-lying Amazonian rainforest.
threats: Potential threats in the region include habitat degradation due to logging and mining. However, it is not known what impact these threats are having on this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from the area of Baja Tambopata, in the department of Madre de Dios, Peru.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, however, in places its distribution coincides with protected areas, including the Reserva Nacional de Junín. Further research is required into the population, habitat preferences, ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: Atractus pauciscutatus has been assessed as Data Deficient as this species is only known from its type locality. It has not been mentioned in scientific literature since it was first described in 1943. The type locality is in an area where there is a high rate of habitat degradation occurring, however, the impact that this is having on A. pauciscutatus is not yet known. Further research is needed on this species to make a more informed assessment of its conservation status.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species, possibly due to it being a fossorial or semi-fossorial species.
threats: Large areas of Junin are threatened by high rates of habitat loss and degradation, mainly due to logging and conversion of land to agriculture. However, the impact that this is having on this species is currently unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is only known from the type locality, Carpapata, in the upper Chanchamayo Valley, within the Department of Junin, Peru.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is required into the distribution, ecology, habitat preferences, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species is poorly-known, it is known from multiple records in a remote area where no threats are likely to exist.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species, but as it appears to be widespread in a remote area it is presumably not subject to major threats.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: This species is endemic to Afghanistan (Sindaco and Jeremçenko 2008), although within the Hindu Kush it is widespread (Wagner et al. 2016). Most records are from the Hindu Kush although the type locality, steppe to the east of Herat, lies outside this region and it is also known from the mountains of Central Afghanistan. It is likely to occur in intervening areas between the widely-separated known localities in extreme northeastern and northwestern Afghanistan (T. Papenfuss pers. comm. 2016).
useTrade: There is no information in any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are known to be in place and it is unlikely to occur in protected areas, however, it is not thought likely to be in need of particular conservation attention (T. Papenfuss pers. comm. 2016).

rationale: Atrobucca bengalensis is only known from the type locality and two specimens collected from a fish market in Sri Lanka. Information about its population and ecology are very limited. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is only known from fish market specimens therefore nothing is known about their habitat preferences or ecology. The maximum recorded length for this species is 24 cm standard length (Sasaki 1995).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species. Specimens were collected from a fish market and are only known from the type locality (Sasaki 1995).
range: This species is known only from the Indian Ocean, off the east coast of Sri Lanka (Sasaki 1995). The depth information for A. bengalensis is unknown.
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species but the type specimens were collect from a fish market in Sri Lanka (Sasaki 1995).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for A. bengalensis.

rationale: Atrobucca antonbruun occurs in the northern Bay of Bengal to at least 64 m depth. There is a lack of information about the ecology and population trend of this species. This species is difficult to identify and there are no known studies other than the original description by Sasaki 1995. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is found in depths from 26-64 m and the maximum recorded length is 19.7 cm standard length (Sasaki 1995). There is very little additional information available.
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is considered to be rare in India. It is very difficult to identify (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2018).
range: This species is found from the Bay of Bengal, along the east coast of India to Bangladesh and to Myanmar from 26-64 m depth (Sasaki 1995).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for A. antonbruun.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: The details of its habitat and ecology are unknown, and there is no information given in the original description. It is unknown whether it is tolerant of habitat disturbance. The larvae are likely to develop in water.
threats: The major threats to this species are unknown.
population: Its population status and trend are unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Parque Nacional de Las Orquídeas, in the municipality of Urrao, in Antioquia Department, Colombia, from 1,300-1,400 m asl (Rivero and Serna 1995).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is currently known only from a single protected area: Parque Nacional de Las Orquídeas.

Research Needed
Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

rationale:
Global
Acanthopagrus latus was recently divided into five species, in which A. sheim was described from the Persian Gulf. Little is known about this species, though Persian Gulf-specific data of A. latus likely refers to A. arabicus and A. sheim. There are no known species-specific conservation measures for A. sheim in the Persian Gulf. The stock assessment for A. latus (which now refers to A. arabicus and A. sheim) suggests that the stock is exploited sustainably. Therefore, A. sheim is listed as Least Concern, but we recommend further discrimination between A. arabicus and A. sheim to clarify their individual status.

Persian Gulf 

Acanthopagrus sheim was recently described from the Persian Gulf and previously thought to be A. latus. Major threats to this species in the Persian Gulf have not been identified and it is believed to be harvested sustainably. Species specific population information is needed. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Acanthopagrus sheim can attain sizes of 25–30 cm (Iwatsuki 2013). Additional habitat and ecology information for A. sheim in the Persian Gulf is unknown. Acanthopagrus latus was recently divided into five species, in which A. sheim was described from the Persian Gulf. Little is known about this species, though Gulf-specific data of A. latus likely refers to A. arabicus and A. sheim (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2013).
threats: Current threats to this species are unknown.
population: In the past, Acanthopagrus sheim was identified as A. latus and it may still be confused with A. arabicus (Iwatsuki 2013), thus, population information for A. sheim is currently unknown. Acanthopagrus sheim is most abundant in the northern Gulf (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).
range: Acanthopagrus sheim is found throughout the Persian Gulf to western Pakistan (Iwatsuki 2013).
useTrade: Use and trade information for A. sheim in the Persian Gulf is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for Acanthopagrus sheim in the Persian Gulf. The range of this species may overlap with marine protected areas in the Persian Gulf (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014).

rationale: Crenidens macracanthus is only known from two specimens from the Indian Ocean. Additional information regarding population, commercial use, and life history is needed. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Crenidens macracanthus possess unique teeth which are thought to be used for eating algae. The largest specimen of this species is 15 cm SL (Iwatsuki and Maclaine 2013).
threats: Current threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from two specimens (Iwatsuki and Maclaine 2013)
range: Crenidens macracanthus is known from Kurrachi (Karachi), Pakistan and Madras (Chennai), India (Iwatsuki and Maclaine 2013).
useTrade: The sparid congeners of Crenidens are important commercial species in the Middle East (Iwatsuki and Maclaine 2013).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for C. macracanthus.

rationale: Polysteganus mascarenensis is a large-bodied sparid currently known only from three type specimens collected from the Mascarene Islands (Madagascar, Mauritius and Reunion), Indian Ocean. This species is known to occur in deeper waters from 258-305 m. Additional data about the commercial use, habitat and ecology, and population are needed. This species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Polysteganus mascarenesis was collected during the course of a trawl survey of fishes of the Mascarene Islands. The largest of the type specimens is 60 cm (SL). There is limited information available on the habitat requirements and life history of this species (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2011).
threats: Current threats to this species are unknown.
population: Polysteganus mascarenesis is only known from the three type specimens (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2011).
range: Polysteganus mascarenensis is currently known from the Seychelles, Mascarene Plateau and Mascarene Islands (15°23.32'S‒15°41.11' S 61°04.54'E‒61°13.41'E). It is considered to be endemic to the Indian Ocean. The type specimens were collected from a trawl survey at depths from 258–305 m (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2011).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014).

rationale: Rhabdosargus niger is currently only known from Kalimantan, Indonesia. The type specimens were purchased at a fish market in Pusan, Korea where they were frozen and had been imported from Indonesia. The extent of commercial use is currently unknown, and population data are not available. This species is listed at Data Deficient.
habitat: The largest type specimen of this species is 28.9 cm SL (Tanaka and Iwatsuki 2013).
threats: Current threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from type specimens.
range: Rhabdosargus niger is currently only known from southwestern Kalimantan, Indonesia; the exact collection site of the holotype is unknown (Tanaka and Iwatsuki 2013).
useTrade: The type specimens of Rhabdosargus niger were purchased frozen, at a fish market in Pusan, Korea and were imported from Indonesia (Tanaka and Iwatsuki 2013). The extent of commercial use of R. niger is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for this species.

rationale: Stenocercus tricristatus é endêmica do Brasil. Trata-se de uma espécie de descrição antiga  (1851) e conhecida somente de um espécime sem localidade precisa para o estado de Minas Gerais. Pela incerteza da localidade-tipo, por não haver coleta posterior e também não haver qualquer outra informação sobre a espécie, Stenocercus tricristatus foi categorizada como Dados insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informações sobre o habitat desta espécie. O holótipo apresenta comprimento rostro-cloacal de 60 mm, com cauda 1,7 vezes maior que o corpo (Torres-Carvajal 2005).
threats: Com há incerteza sobre sua distribuição, foi descrita há muito tempo e não há informações sobre suas exigências ecológicas, não é possível fazer afirmações sobre ameaçam que pairam sobre a espécie.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Conhecido de apenas um indivíduo.
range: Espécie endêmica do Brasil. Possui apenas um registro de ocorrência, no estado de Minas Gerais (Coleção Herpetológica da Universidade de Brasília, Torres-Carvajal 2007). Sua distribuição real é desconhecida, mas em levantamento realizado pela Universidade de Brasília foi encontrado no município de Pará de Minas, na Serra da Canastra.
useTrade: A espécie não é usada ou comercializada.
conservationActions: Não é conhecida nenhuma ação específica para a conservação da espécie. Provavelmente pode ocorrer no Parque Nacional Serra da Canastra. Faz-se necessário a realização de estudos de levantamento de fauna na região de ocorrência da espécie, população/estrutura, distribuição da mesma.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that nothing is known of this species other than that it was reportedly collected from an unknown locality in Ecuador, and it has not been rediscovered since it was described nearly 70 years ago.
habitat: The ecology of this species is unknown.
threats: The threats are unknown.
population: Nothing is known about the population of this species, which was described from a single specimen from an unknown locality in Ecuador and not recorded since.
range: This species was reported from "Ecuador" by Laurent (1949), and is still known only from the holotype. Nothing else is known about the range of this species.
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No specific conservation measures are in place for this species. Although the species appears to be valid (Cercio et al. 2012) nothing is known of its distribution, and research is needed to identify new material and clarify the species' distribution before further research recommendations can be made. The species is included in CITES Appendix II.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because of the uncertainty about where the species was originally collected (the species is thus unmappable), the lack of any specimens (the type, collected in 1839, has been lost), and the lack of a detailed description. Without this information, there is little hope of learning more about this species.
habitat: The habitat is unknown.
threats: The threats to the species are unknown.
population: The species has not been reported since it was described in 1839. The holotype specimen was subsequently lost from a Paris museum and no other specimens are known. Without the type, it is next to impossible to identify new specimens as belonging to this taxon.
range: This species is only known from a single collection in "Santa Cruz de la Sierra", Bolivia, in the early nineteenth century. Although today "Santa Cruz de la Sierra" is the largest city in Bolivia, the name may have pertained to somewhere else in Bolivia when the specimen was collected.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Without a specimen or a detailed description of the species, it is next to impossible to enact conservation or research actions for the species. Attempts are required to relocate this species.

rationale: This deep-living species is known from four widely disjunct localities and four specimens. It is rarely recorded due to the lack of sampling effort at these depths, therefore, it is likely more widespread. Although poorly known, it is not thought to be impacted by any major threat. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Little is known about the population, habitats and ecology of this species. There are only four known specimens which were taken by shrimp trawl and tumbler dredge. It is relatively deep-living and rarely recorded (Hastings and Findley 2013). Its maximum size is 3.2 cm SL.
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Little is known on the population of this species. It is known from only four specimens taken by shrimp trawl and tumbler dredge. It is relatively deep-living and rarely recorded (Hastings and Findley 2013).
range: This species is only known from four widely separated offshore localities in the western Atlantic: northern edge of Little Bahama Bank, in the Gulf of Mexico north of the Dry Tortugas, in the Caribbean Sea from Tobago Island and La Guajira Peninsula, Colombia. Its depth range is 62-138 m (Hastings and Findley 2013).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because its distribution is uncertain in Peru and therefore its population and threat status cannot be determined.
habitat: Unable to determine the habitat because of uncertain distribution.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is known from its type locality, about 75 miles to the west of Leticia, in the Loreto Province (Myers 1954), in the Peruvian Amazon (Ortega et al. 2012).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trends.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because its exact distribution is unknown and there is no information on population size, trends and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: Tropical feshwater tropical pelagic fish (Froese and Pauly 2013).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species occurs in the Peruvian Amazon (Ortega et al. 2012), likely from northwestern Peru. However, the exact distribution is not known as this species was described based on aquarium specimens.
useTrade: This species is used as ornamental.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient due to uncertainty in its distribution and lack of information on population size and trends and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: Tropical benthopelagic freshwater fish (Froese and Pauly 2013).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is known only from Peru, but its type locality and distribution are unknown (Römer 1997).
useTrade: There is no information on use and trade for this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because its distribution is  uncertain in Peru and therefore its population and threat status cannot  be determined.
habitat: Unable to determine the habitat because of uncertain distribution.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is known from its type locality in a backwater of the Chipiria River and Amaquiria River (Ucayali River drainage), about 120 kilometers south of Pucallpa, Peru (Seegers 1983).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because the locality where the species was originally collected is uncertain.
habitat: Unable to determine the habitat because of uncertain distribution.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is known only from its type locality in Perim, Peru, at 800 m asl. (Regan 1903). However, apparently there are no places in Peru with that name. Therefore, the distribution of this species is uncertain.
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trends.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts on its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements. Surveys are urgently needed and systematic work to evaluate the taxonomic status of the species.
habitat: There is no information on the species' habitat and ecological requirements, although it presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in Huatusco, Veracruz, Mexico, at 1,300 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 121 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records that this species is utilized or traded.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas. It is protected by Mexican law under the "Special Protection" category (Pr). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, threats, and taxonomy.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species is largely unknown but it could have been collected from a forest habitat. The larvae presumably develop in water.
threats: The main threats are principally presumed to include habitat loss given the extensive deforestation of the Chiriquí region.
population: The population status of this species is unknown, and the level of deforestation within the region of collection might have led to its extinction.
range: The type locality of this species is recorded as "Chiriquí", which at the time of description included the Atlantic versant and the Pacific versant of western Panama. Given the unspecified nature of the single locality a map cannot be produced for this species.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Research Needed
Surveys of potentially suitable habitat within the area defined as "Chiriquí" during the initial species description, are urgently required to determine the continued existence of this species, which might now be extinct.

rationale: Hippocampus fisheri is a coastal and shelf seahorse species that is endemic to the Hawaiian Islands. Little is known about the species' population size, or trends in abundance. The species is not exposed to trawling and occurs in relatively deep waters in areas with limited anthropogenic pressures. There are no known threats. Therefore this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Habitat preferences for Hippocampus fisheri are currently unknown.  It has occurred several kilometres off shore and from depths of greater than 100 m (Lourie 2016). The species has been recorded from the stomach contents of yellowfin tuna (Thunnus albacares), trevally (Carangidae), and dolphinfish (Coryphaena spp.) (FishNet2 2016, Lourie 2016). Little is known about feeding, but other seahorses tend to consume crustaceans such as gammarid and caridean shrimps, mysids, amphipods, and copepods (Woods 2002, Kitsos et al. 2008). Their reproductive biology is also unknown, but seahorses in general are ovoviviparous and males brood the young in a pouch prior to giving live birth (Foster and Vincent 2004). They reach a maximum size of 8 cm (Lourie et al. 1999). 
All seahorse species have vital parental care, and many species studied to date have high site fidelity (Perante et al. 2002, Vincent et al. 2005), highly structured social behaviour (Vincent and Sadler 1995), and relatively sparse distributions (Lourie et al. 1999).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Hippocampus fisheri. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Hippocampus fisheri is known from the Hawaiian Islands (Szabo et al. 2011). Specimens from Lord Howe Island, Australia and New Caledonia that were previously tentatively assigned to this species have subsequently been described as Hippocampus jugumus and H. pusillus (Kuiter 2001, Fricke 2004, Lourie et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is no record of this species in trade, but seahorses in general are traded heavily worldwide for use as aquarium pets, curios, and in traditional medicines (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake, if any, are unknown. It may be less susceptible to exploitation and being caught as bycatch, as it inhabits deeper waters than many seahorse species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hippocampus fisheri. The species is listed along with all other seahorses on CITES Appendix II. It is unknown whether the species occurs in any marine protected areas. Bottom trawling has been banned in Hawai'i since 1986.

rationale: Hippocampus jugumus is a poorly known seahorse species that is thought to be endemic to Lord Howe Island, Australia. It is known from two specimens. Little is known about habitats, ecology, threats, or population size and trends in abundance. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Habitats and ecology are poorly known for this species, as it is only known from two specimens. Nothing is known about their feeding, but other members of the genus tend to feed on small crustaceans such as amphipods, gammarid and caridean shrimps, mysids, decapods, and copepods (Woods 2002, Kitsos et al. 2008). It is known to be taken as prey by kingfish Seriola lalandi  (Lourie et al. 2016).  Their reproductive biology is likely similar to other seahorses, which are ovoviviparous. The males brood embryos in a pouch prior to giving live birth (Foster and Vincent 2004).
threats: The threats to this species and its habitat are unknown. It may be caught as bycatch but levels of offtake, if any, are unknown.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Hippocampus jugumus, and the species is known from only two specimens. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Hippocampus jugumus is known only from Lord Howe Island, Australia.  The depth range for this species is unknown because specimens were taken from a beach and the gut of a kingfish (Seriola lalandi) (Kuiter 2001, Lourie et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade, but other seahorses are traded heavily globally for traditional medicines, curios, and aquarium use (Vincent et al. 2011).  Some illegal trade occurs in Australia, but levels are low compared to other regions (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006). This species may be involved but likely at low levels.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hippocampus jugumus. It is listed along with all other seahorses on CITES Appendix II, where trade by the parties must be shown to be sustainable if it is suspected otherwise. The species is also protected along with all other synganthids by the Australian Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999). It's unclear at this time whether the species occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known from a single specimen and its distribution and population status are unknown. Studies to clarify the taxonomic status of the species are needed.
habitat: Because of its morphology it is thought to be a sand-dwelling species (Núñez and Yáñez 1984). Nothing else is known about its ecology.
threats: The general area where the species was reported is threatened by mining activities.
population: The population status is unknown.
range: This species is endemic to Chile. It was described on the basis of one individual and its type locality is unclear (Núñez and Yáñez 1984, Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013a, Troncoso-Palacios 2014) , believed to be located 50-70 km east of San Pedro de Atacama, Antofagasta Region (Núñez and Yáñez 1984, Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013a).
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species was classified as Data Deficient by the Chilean Environmental Ministry (Decreto Supremo 52/2014 MMA). Studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of this species. It is not known whether it occurs in a protected area.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species occurs on a single island with an area of around 215 km<sup>2</sup>, and both major threats from mammal predation and localized competitive exclusion are thought to be ongoing, supported by apparent evidence of decline in urban areas. Nevertheless this species is adaptable and still frequently encountered in natural areas in the western part of San Cristóbal and it is presently unknown whether introduced mammals are significantly affecting the population in natural habitat. Further research into the population status of and threats to this species may suggest that it warrants listing in a threatened category applying criterion B (almost qualifies under B1ab(v)).
habitat: San Cristóbal Island has a range of habitats from evergreen forest to grassy highlands. This species has been found in rocky areas and under bark on trees across the island (Van Denburgh 1912); in artificial situations it colonizes walls and buildings. This species lays eggs in October and November in rocky areas (Fitter et al. 2000).
threats: San Cristóbal is the second most heavily-populated island in the Galápagos, and introduced predators - particularly cats (which have been observed to eat this gecko - D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. obs.), rats and dogs - represent the major threat to this nocturnal species. It appears to have been displaced from the centre of urban areas by the introduced house gecko Lepidodactylus lugubris, although as a larger species than Phyllodactylus darwinii this effect may be less pronounced than in that species. While this is a localized threat, it may be significant if the species is under pressure also in other parts of the island from introduced mammals. No information is available on population trends in natural habitats to determine whether it is declining as a result of predation.
population: It is frequent to uncommon in both natural and inhabited areas in targeted surveys in the western part of the island (D. Cisneros-Heredia unpubl. data), although it is slightly commoner than the sympatric Phyllodactylus darwinii. 39 males and 43 females were reported in 1992 from an inhabited area in the capital (Olmedo and Cayot 1994). In 2009, at most 25 individuals were found in the same areas investigated by the previous study (D. Cisneros-Heredia unpubl. data). In the former P. leeii was rare in the centre of the town, where the introduced Lygodactylus lugubris was present; in the recent study it was entirely absent from the centre (D. Cisneros-Heredia unpubl. data), although L. lugubris appears to occur at no higher abundance now than in the previous study.
range: This species is only known from San Cristóbal Island in the Galápagos (Cope 1889). It appears not to occur in humid highlands on the island (D. Cisneros-Herdia and C. Márquez pers. obs.)<sup></sup>
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in its species.
conservationActions: This species is endemic to Galápagos National Park. Surveys are needed to clarify the population status and sensitivity to threats from mammal predation of this gecko, especially in natural areas of San Cristóbal.

rationale: Enneanectes wilki was described from 12 specimens that were previously identified as Enneanectes boehlkei. Little is known about their life history or current population size. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known on the habitats and ecology of this cryptic species, although it may be similar to that of Enneanectes boehlkei, the species from which it was recently split taxonomically. The maximum known size is 1.7 cm SL (Victor 2013).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species, further research is needed on its habitats and life history.
population: This species was described from 12 specimens that were previously identified as Enneanectes boehlkei, little is known about their population (Victor 2013).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from the southern Lesser Antilles chain (Windward Islands) particularly Dominica, Tobago, and St. Vincent (Victor 2013).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Enneanectes wilki.

rationale: This species is only known from Mauritius, possibly Reunion and was described from southeast India. This species is only known from freshwater habitats that are under a number of threats from anthropogenic impacts. The limited distribution of this species and threatened habitat may qualify G. kokius for placement into a threatened category; however, this species is currently under taxonomic revision and the full distribution is not known. The type specimens from India consist of two species. Given these circumstances, this species is listed as Data Deficient. More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, habitat, and impact of threats.
habitat: There is very little known about this species' habitat but it probably occurs in freshwater (H. Larson pers. comm. 2018). The maximum recorded total length is 13.6 cm (D. Hoese pers. comm. 2018).
threats: This species is sensitive to anthropogenic activities with major threats including habitat loss and eutrophication (Fricke et al. 2009). In Mauritius, this species' habitat is under threat from agriculture, land conversion, pollution and other threats (Turner et al. 2000). Many estuarine, lagoon, and near-shore marine and freshwater habitats in India are also severely degraded (Sandilyan et al. 2010).
population: There is no population information available.
range: This species was described from southeast India and also reported from Mauritius and Reunion (Letourneur et al. 2004, Fricke et al. 2009, H. Larson pers. comm. 2019). Its depth range is 1-10 m (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003). This species has been reported from the St. Lucia estuarine system in South Africa (Vivier et al. 2010) but this may be a different species.
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: The species is listed as Data Deficient due to the lack of precise data on its still presence within its historical range from 1953, exact range (as it could have been erroneously identified and therefore present in other collections), population size and threats.
habitat: There are no data on habitat and ecology for this species.
threats: The only area where the species was once recorded is impacted by habitat degradation and pollution due to cropland, mining, and deforestation. It is unclear if the species is still there and therefore affected by these threats.
population: The species is only known from 7 specimens collected from the type locality in 1953.
range: This species endemic to Bolivia was described in 2001 based on specimens collected in 1953 (7 specimens). It is currently known only from its type locality on a left tributary of the Rio Palmar, near Palmar village, Cochabamba Department, at 224 m of elevation (Zarske and Géry 2001), but the exact locality is doubtful.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place. Survey work in its historically known range to confirm its presence and taxonomic review of museum collections to clarify possible misidentifications are highly recommended.

rationale: Astroblepus ventralis has a restricted range (extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 9,500 km²) and is affected by threats in the two known locations, especially in the type locality (illegal mining) but also in the remainder of its range (logging). These threats have led to a continuing decline in habitat quality. Hence, it is listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species. However, it is presumed that the habitat quality of this species is declining due to pollution and sedimentation from mining and logging.
threats: The type locality is affected by illegal mining activities, which lead  to a decrease in habitat quality due to sedimentation and pollution.  Logging, which leads to erosion and thus increased sedimentation,  affects the species in other parts of its range.
population: There is no information available on population size or trends.
range: This species is present in the Dagua and San Juan (Río Garrapatas) river basins in the Pacific coastal drainages of Colombia (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2005, 2008). Its type locality is Caldas, in the head of the municipality of Dagua in the Colombian Pacific region (Eigenmann 1912). Its EOO is estimated at about 9,500 km² (calculated as the minimum convex polygon around the known sub-catchment(s) where the species occurs) and it occurs in two locations, based on the main threats affecting the species (pollution and sedimentation from mining and logging).
useTrade: There is no trade or use information for this species, but it may be locally used as a protein source.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It may occur in Parque Nacional Farallones. Research is needed to better determine its population size and trends and the impact of the current threats on its population.

rationale: Bryconamericus miraensis is only known from the type locality and there is no information on population size and trends, as well as the threats that are affecting it. Hence, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about its habitat preferences.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. There is illegal coca plantation in the area of the Mira River that could lead to pollution, but it is not known whether this affects the range of this species.
population: No data are available on population size or trends. It is only known from the holotype and 6 other specimens collected in the same place (Román-Valencia 2003).
range: This species endemic to Colombia is known from the Mira River basin in the Pacific Slope of southwestern Colombia (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008). Its type locality is Ricaurte on the Guebo River (Rio El Guabo), Mira River basin, Nariño Department, at an elevation of 1,200 meters (Fowler 1945).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in any protected area. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from its description and the current distribution is unknown. Because of that, there are no data on population size and trends, habitats and ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: Given that the actual distribution of this species is unknown, there is no information on its habitat and ecology.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species, endemic to Colombia, is known from the Cauca River basin. Its type locality is Medellín (Posada 1909), although the precise location is unknown (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2005). The holotype of this species is lost.
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Cynodonichthys leucurus is only known from its holotype and 14 paratypes. Nothing is known about its population status and trend, or on the threats that are affecting it. Hence, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about its habitat requirements.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia, where it is known from the Pacific coastal basins. Its type locality is Río Juradó, Colombia, elevation 183 m asl (Fowler 1944).
useTrade: The species is probably not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Cynodonichthys pacificus is only known from its type locality. Nothing is known about its population status and trend, or on the threats that are affecting it. Hence, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about its habitat requirements.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia, where it is present in the Pacific coastal river basins. Its type locality is Condoto, in a forest along Condoto to Soledad road, Río San Juan basin (Huber 1992).
useTrade: The species is probably not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Trichomycterus unicolor has a very restricted range (extent of occurrence (EOO) = 750 km²) and it occurs at a single location that is affected by artisanal mining activities, which lead to increased sedimentation, pollution and, thus, a continuing decline in habitat quality. Hence, it is listed as Endangered.
habitat: There are no data on the species' habitat and ecology. However, it is inferred that the quality of the habitat is declining due to mining activities in the area.
threats: Río Condoto is affected by artisanal mining activities, which lead to pollution, erosion and sedimentation.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia, where is known only from its type locality Río Condoto, in the middle San Juan River basin, Pacific system (Regan 1913, Castellanos-Morales and Galvis 2012). Its EOO is estimated at 750 km² (calculated as the minimum convex polygon around the sub-catchments where the species occurs) and it occurs at only one location, based on the main threat affecting the species (mining).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in protected areas. Research is needed to better determine its distribution, population size and trends and the impact of the current threats on its population.

rationale: Trichomycterus romeroi is listed as Data Deficient because of the lack of information on its ecology, habitat requirements, population status and trends, and threats. It is only known from the holotype and four paratypes, despite intense efforts to find it around its type locality.
habitat: The description of the type locality is not specific enough to determine the habitat requirements of this species. It has been searched for in rivers and creeks with sandy grounds around the type locality, to no avail.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: Data on population size or trends are not available. Species of this genus are usually frequently caught. However, despite intense efforts, this species has not been caught in the past 11 years (F. Villa-Navarro pers. comm. 2014). Only the holotype and four paratypes are thus known.
range: This species is only known from the Magdalena river system in Colombia (Castellanos-Morales and Galvis 2012). Its type locality is Honda, Tolima Department (Fowler 1941).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in any protected area. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because there are no data on population size and trends, habitat and ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is only known from the Magdalena River basin, Cordoba Department, Colombia. Its type locality is Río Uré of the upper San Jorge in tributaries of Río Sinú (Dahl et al. 1964).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in any protected area. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because its distribution is not well known and there are no data on population size and trends, habitats and ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is only known from its original description in Western Colombia (Steindachner 1915), in the Magdalena-Cauca river basin (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Monolene helenensis is only known waters north of St. Helena. It is only known from a few specimens. More information is needed on this species distribution, habitat, ecology and impact of any major threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat. The maximum size of individuals taken was 21 cm (Amaoka and Imamura 2000).
threats: It is not known if there are any threats to this species.
population: There is no population information for this species, as it is known only from a few specimens (Amaoka and Imamura 2000).
range: Monolene helenensis is only known waters north of St. Helena in the Eastern Central Atlantic. It is only known from a few specimens taken between 163-460 m depth (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2012).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures for this species.

rationale: Symphurus lubbocki is known from only two specimens collected at Ascension Island. There is no information on the population, ecology, habitat, or impact of any threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Two adult females, both 2.8 cm, were collected at 20 m depth (Munroe 1990). There is no habitat, biology or life history information.
threats: It is not known if there are any threats to this species.
population: There is no population information.
range: Symphurus lubbocki is known from only two specimens collected at Ascension Island at 20 m (Munroe 1990).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place.

rationale: Symphurus reticulatus is known from less than six specimens collected at St. Helena Island. There is no information on the population, ecology, habitat, or impact of any threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no habitat, biology or life history information. The maximum size of the individuals collected is 60 mm (Munroe 1990).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information for this species.
range: Symphurus reticulatus is known from less than five or six specimens collected at St Helena Island at depths from five to 45 m (Munroe 1990).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place.

rationale: The species is listed as Data Deficient due to the lack of good data on its exact range, population size and threats.
habitat: The natural history of this species is very poorly-known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. Populations could be impacted by habitat modification and pollution produced by mining, although this requires verification.
population: Data on population size or trends are not available.
range: This species occurs in the Upper Amazon basin in Ecuador, in the Zamora and Pastaza river. Its type locality is Río Zamora, Ecuador (Tortonese 1942). This species occurs between 800 to 1,400 m asl.
useTrade: It is not believed to be used.
conservationActions: This species occurs into the Sangay National Park. No direct conservation measures are in place. Additional research is needed into the natural history, distribution and possible threats to the species.

rationale: Argopleura conventus is listed as Data Deficient due to the lack of information on its exact range, population status and trend, and the threats that may be affecting it. It is only known from its holotype.
habitat: The habitat requirements of this species are unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species endemic to Colombia occurs in the Magdalena-Cauca river basin (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008), where it is known from Dique de Cartagena, in the Cartagena Department (Eschmeyer 2014). Its type locality is Soplaviento (Eigenmann 1913) and is only known from its holotype.
useTrade: It is not known whether this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected area. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Poecilia mechthildae is listed as Data Deficient because it is only known from its holotype and two paratypes, and due to the lack of information on its population size and trend as well as the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitat requirements of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Colombia. It is only known from its type locality, 6 kilometers upstream of the mouth of Acandí River, near Acandí, Colombia (Meyer et al. 2002).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient due to a lack of information about the species' distribution, population, taxonomic status, and threats. The species has not been collected since the 19th century, when only one specimen had a locality recorded.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species are unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from 3-4 specimens, only one of which has precise locality information, all collected in the 19th century. The current population size and trend are unknown.
range: This species is endemic to western Venezuela, occurring in the Cordillera de Mérida in the states of Mérida and Tachira (Roze 1966). It occurs at approximately 1,200-2,000 m asl.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known whether it occurs in any of the protected areas located in the region where the species was reported. The species belongs to  a group in which the species are difficult to distinguish. Research is needed to understand the taxonomic status, distribution, population, and natural history of this species.

rationale: Lissocampus fatiloquus is a coastal marine species that occurs from Shark Bay to Rottnest Island, Western Australia. The species inhabits shallow waters in algae, sand and seagrass. There are no known threats to the species, and it is protected throughout its range. Therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Very little is known about the habitat and depth that this species lives in. Some specimens were collected from floating Sargassum and Sargassum-covered rocks in depths to 10 m, but others were taken from dredge and trawl samples of unknown depth (Dawson 1985, Kuiter 2000). They have also been noted to occur in seagrass and sand habitats (McClatchie et al. 2006). The species is thought to feed on harpacticoid copepods and gammarid shrimps, as other members of the genus do (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). The species is ovoviviparous and males brood eggs under their tail until giving birth to live young (Dawson 1985).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Lissocampus fatiloquus. Further research is needed in order to understand population size and trends in abundance.
range: Lissocampus fatiloquus has been recorded from Shark Bay to Fremantle and Rottnest Island, Western Australia (Dawson 1977, 1985).
useTrade: Pipefishes are traded at low levels in Australia (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006), and this species has not been recorded. It may be traded for use in aquariums and traditional medicine.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for Lissocampus fatiloquus. The species is protected across its entire range by the Australian Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999). Shark Bay Marine Park also protects one of the localities from which this species is known.

rationale: Notopogon armatus is endemic to the French Southern Territories of Ile Amsterdam and Ile St. Paul in the central Indian Ocean. Although very little is known about the species' habitats, ecology, life history, or population status or trends, there are no known threats. Therefore the species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: No known studies have been conducted about the preferred habitat, food web ecology, or life history of Notopogon armatus. Body shape and development of Notopogon species change with age, and perhaps sex, making identification difficult (May and Maxwell 1986). The species has been found at depths of 28-100 m, and they occur in both shallow and pelagic zones (Duhamel 1995).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Notopogon armatus. Although the species appears common based on museum records and sightings, further research is needed to determine population size and trends in abundance.
range:
Notopogon armatus is endemic to the central Indian Ocean, and is found in waters of 28-100 m depth around the St. Paul and Amsterdam Islands (Duhamel 1995).

***Biogeographic realms were left blank because the map doesn't clearly indicate which realm this species' range falls in. It's possible that the range overlaps with all four Indian Ocean realms (Antarctic, Afrotropic, Indo-Malay, and Australasian), depending on exactly where these islands would fall on that map. The range is not included in any of the coastal Large Marine Ecosystems.
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place, and there are no protected areas within its range.

rationale: Notopogon fernandezianus inhabits the continental shelf slope off the subtropical coasts of South America. There are no known threats to the species or its habitat, therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Notopogon fernandezianus is a bathydemersal species that occurs on the shelf slope (May and Maxwell 1986).  Little else is known about the species' ecology, habitats, or life history.
threats: There are no known threats to this species or its deeper water habitat.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates carried out for this species. Further research is needed to understand population size and trends in abundance.
range: Notopogon fernandezianus is found in the southeastern Pacific from Juan Fernández to Nazca and Salas and Gómez ridges, and in the southwestern Atlantic from southern Brazil, Uruguay, and northern Argentina (Dyer and Westneat 2010, Menezes et al. 2003; Parin et al. 1997). It is a bathydemersal species found on the continental shelf and slope (May and Maxwell, 1986).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation actions in place for this species. The species is not known to occur in any protected areas.

rationale: Doryrhamphus bicarinatus occurs in areas along the South African and Mozambique coasts, as well as in the Maldives. Little is known about their ecology, population numbers and trends, and there is no available information on possible threats to the population and their habitat. This species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Habitats and ecology are unknown for this species.
threats: This species is taken for the aquarium trade in Mozambique, but levels of offtake are not known.  Eutrophication and habitat loss are cited as threats in Reunion (Fricke et al. 2009).
population: Very little is known about the population status of this rarely observed species. There have not been any dedicated surveys or population estimates to date, but the species is suspected to be declining (Fricke et al. 2009).
range: Doryrhamphus bicarinatus is extant in the Western Indian Ocean from Sodwana Bay, South Africa to Bazaruto Island, Mozambique (Dawson 1985). The species has also occurred in the Maldives (Anderson et al. 1998), Madagascar, Reunion, Comoros, and the Seychelles (Fricke et al. 2009).
useTrade: This species has been recorded from the aquarium trade (Pereira 2008). Levels of offtake from the wild are unknown.
conservationActions: There is very little information about ecology, threats, or conservation for this species. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Syngnathus macrophthalmus is assessed as Data Deficient. The species is known only from its holotype and two other occurrences. Further research is needed on the species’ distribution, ecology, life history, and population status in order to properly assess its conservation status.
habitat: Syngnathus macrophthalmus is found in marine demersal habitats. The behaviour and life history of this species are poorly known. Like other pipefishes, this species is thought to be oviviparous, with the male carrying the eggs within a brood pouch on the underside the tail (Breder and Rosen 1966). Males become reproductively mature at 10 cm, with the largest invdividuals of the species attaining 12.2 cm in growth during a lifetime (Dawson 1985).
threats: No specific information is known on the threats of Syngnathus macrophthalmus. With little known about this species’ habitat or ecology, it is impossible to determine threats. However, being a marine demersal species, it is likely that many coastal human activities could potentially impact populations of Syngnathus macrophthalmus.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for this species. Therefore, the population  size and status are not known at this time.
range: Syngnathus macrophthalmus is distributed in the western Indian Ocean in the northwestern Red Sea. It has been observed in the Gulf of Suez, around Hurghada (Al Ghardaqa – Dawson 1985), and the Jordanian coast of the Gulf of Aqaba (Paulus 1992).
useTrade: Use of Syngnathus macrophthalmus in trade is unknown. However, with the popularity of Syngnathus species in the ornamental, aquarium, and traditional medicine trades in other regions (Rosa et al. 2006, Vincent et al. 2011), it is possible that S. macrophthalmus may also be used.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: Bryx veleronis is a poorly known species of coastal pipefish from the Eastern Tropical Pacific. It has not been seen or collected since 1938. More information is needed on this species distribution, population, habitat requirements, ecology and threats. Dedicated surveys are required to ensure that this species is still extant. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is poorly known. It is thought to inhabit soft substrata to 20 m depth. Little is known about its feeding, but it likely consumes small crustaceans such as harpacticoid copepods and gammarid and mysid shrimps similar to other pipefishes (Garcia et al. 2005, Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and males brood the embryos beneath their tail prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985). Maximum size is 6 cm and males are brooding a maximum of 48 eggs at 4.5 cm (Fritzsche 1980).
threats: There is little known about the major threats for this species. In addition, given its relatively restricted range and shallow water habitat, this species may be negatively impacted by oceanographic environmental changes from future El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and global climate change events (Soto 2001, Chen et al. 2004) including increased frequency of storm events.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Bryx veleronis. The species has not been observed since 1938. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Eastern Tropical Pacific, and occurs in waters off the Revillagigedo Islands, Mexico, the Pacific islands of Costa Rica and Panama, Malpelo Island, Colombia, and the Galapagos Islands (Fritzsche 1980, Dawson 1985).
useTrade: This species has not been noted in trade.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species. However, this species distribution falls into a number of marine protected areas in the Eastern Tropical Pacific (WDPA 2016). More research is needed on population, distribution, habitat requirements, and potential threats for this poorly known species.

rationale: Siokunichthys southwelli is known from very few specimens collected prior to 1908. Further research on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population size, habitats, and ecology is needed in order to make a proper assessment. Therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitats and ecology of Siokunichthys southwelli are poorly known. The few known specimens were taken in shallow water (less than 5 m) and the substrate and habitat were not recorded (Dawson 1983). The species is presumably similar to other pipefishes in feeding ecology, feeding on small benthic and/or planktonic crustaceans (e.g., Orth and Ryer 1987, Lim et al. 2011). Other members of the genus exhibit ovoviviparity, with males brooding young under their tale. Brooding males have not been observed (Dawson 1985).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: Almost nothing is known about the population of Siokunichthys southwelli. The species was described in 1910 based on two specimens that have since been lost or destroyed; two additional specimens collected in 1908 are also thought to be this species (Dawson 1983). No surveys or population estimates have been devoted to them to date.
range: Siokunichthys southwelli is known only from four specimens taken at two localities: Marichchukkaddi Bay, Sri Lanka and Mindoro, Philippines (Dawson 1983, 1985).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species, and it is unknown whether it occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Hypselognathus horridus is an endemic pipefish that inhabits waters along the continental shelf of the Great Australian Bight, South Australia. It is known from about 10 specimens, all collected prior to 1983. Little is known about the species' habitat, ecology, or threats, and further research is needed in order to properly assess threats and conservation status. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Hypselognathus horridus is found in the continental shelf and is endemic to the Great Australian Bight. Habitat is poorly known, as specimens were taken from trawls, but the species is normally found at a depth range of 40-55 m (Dawson 1985). All of the known specimens were taken in along with Solegnathus robustus (Dawson and Glover 1982). The prey of H. horridus are unknown, but they are likely to feed on small crustaceans such as harpacticoid copepods, gammarid shrimp, and mysids, similar to other pipefishes (e.g., Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and the male carries the eggs in their brood pouch under the tail before giving birth to live young (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985).
threats: There are no known direct threats to Hypselognathus horridus. Although many pipefishes are caught often as bycatch in trawl fisheries (Vincent et al. 2011), this species has been assessed by the Australian Government as being at low risk of impacts from trawling (Daley et al. 2007). Further information about this species' habitat and biology is needed in order to properly assess threats.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Hypselognathus horridus. The species is known from very few specimens. Further research is needed in order to understand the population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Hypselognathus horridus is a temperate, endemic, Australian pipefish known only from the Great Australian Bight, South Australia, from Penong to Elliston and Flinders Island. The species is found on the continental shelf, is demersal, and inhabits depths of 40-55 m (Dawson and Glover 1982, Dawson 1985).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade, but other syngnathids are traded heavily globally for traditional medicines, curios, and aquarium use (Vincent et al. 2011).  Some illegal trade occurs in Australia, but levels are low compared to other regions (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006). This species may be involved but likely at low levels.The species is protected throughout its range.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hypselognathus horridus. Along with all syngnathids, it is protected from capture under the South Australian Fisheries Act (1982) and the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999). The species is known to occur in the Great Australian Bight Marine Park. It is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations. Further research and monitoring are needed.

rationale: Halicampus zavorensis is a marine pipefish species that inhabits waters of the Western Indian Ocean off of Mozambique and Oman. The species is only known from three specimens with no habitat information. Little is known about the species' ecology, habitats, threats, or population size or trends. Further research and monitoring are needed in order to properly assess this species. Therefore Halicampus zavorensis is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: As this species is known from only three specimens, little is known about their habitat. The diet of H. zavorensis is unknown, but likely consists of small crustaceans such as harpacticoid copepods, gammarid shrimps, and mysids, similar to that of other pipefishes (e.g. Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and the male carries the eggs in their brood pouch under the tail before giving birth to live young (Dawson 1985). They reach at least 10 cm SL (Dawson 1985).
threats: The threats to Halicampus zavorensis are unknown. Pipefishes and other syngnathids are often caught as bycatch in trawl fisheries and/or targeted for use in traditional medicines and aquariums (Vincent et al. 2011). This species has not been recorded in bycatch or trade, and it's not clear whether this is a significant threat. Further research is needed.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Halicampus zavorensis. Only three specimens are known. Further research is needed in order to understand the population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Halicampus zavorensis inhabits the Western Indian Ocean, with only one specimen obtained from Zavora, Mozambique and two from Sur, Oman (Dawson 1981, 1985).
useTrade: Although this species has not been specifically recorded in trade, syngnathids are traded heavily throughout the region for traditional medicines and the aquarium trade (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake, if any, are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Halicampus zavorensis. It's not known whether the species occurs in any protected areas, and it does not appear in any international legislation or trade regulations. Further research and monitoring are needed to properly assess this species.

rationale: Festucalex prolixus is known from six specimens which were collected in 1929. These were juvenile specimens that were in the pelagic stage of their life cycle, and established adult populations have not yet been located. Very little is known about the species' habitat, ecology, population size, or threats. Therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
Very little is known about the biology of Festucalex prolixus. It is only known from juvenile specimens collected during their pelagic phase, and adults of the species have not yet been found. It is suspected that they inhabit depths beyond 40 metres (Dawson 1984).

Other pipefish species are typically male-brooding and ovoviviparous (Dawson 1985). Related species usually feed on small planktonic or benthic crustaceans (e.g. Garcia et al. 2005, Kendrick and Hyndes 2005).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: There have not been any dedicated surveys or population estimates for this species. It is only known from six pelagic juvenile specimens, and the adult population has not been located.
range: Festucalex prolixus inhabits waters of the Indo-Pacific region. It is known from the Sulu-Celebes Sea in the northeast and in waters around West Papua, Indonesia including Cenderawasih Bay. Specimens have been encountered only in trawls coming up from 0-167 m, and it is therefore thought that they inhabit waters deeper than 40 m (the usual maximum depth for the collection of pipefish specimens; Dawson 1984, 1985).
useTrade: This species is not known from trade.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species. It likely occurs in several marine protected areas across its range.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although its distribution is limited (one locality), the species occupies a remote, uninhabited, inaccessible area on the summit of a tepui where there are no threats other than possibly climate change. The entire range of the species is within a protected area.
habitat: All that is known about the habitat and ecology of this species is that it occurs on a tepui summit.
threats: Although the range of the species has not been visited recently, the remoteness of a tepui summit suggests that the only potential threat is climate change. The tepui is nearly completely inaccessible.
population: The species is known from two specimens collected in 1985 and 1992. Although the range of the species has not been visited recently, the remoteness of a tepui summit suggests that the only potential threat is climate change. The tepui is nearly completely inaccessible.
range: Riolama uzzelli is known only from its type locality at the summit of Cerro Marahuaca, Duida-Marahuaca National Park Amazonas state, Venezuela. It has an elevation range between 1,850-2,600 m asl (Molina and Señaris 2003).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in Duida-Marahuaca National Park. Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the relation between this species and R. luridiventris.

rationale: The Pygmy Thornback Skate (Dentiraja flindersi) is a poorly known, small (up to 33 cm total length) South Australian endemic that is believed to be found only in waters adjacent to the Gulfs of South Australia at depths of 27–54 m. Given its endemism, this skate is a key indicator of the Gulfs Province of southern Australia. It is considered to be rare and the population size is likely to be small based on low abundance and narrow range. It has a high catchability in trawl fisheries. Commonwealth gillnet, hook and trap fisheries, and South Australian prawn trawl fisheries operate over a portion of its range, although no information on catch is currently available. The South Australian prawn trawl fisheries are managed by traditional methods of limited licences, vessel and gear restrictions as well as seasonal closures and rotation of trawling grounds. Other measures such as bycatch reduction devices and reduced sorting times have also been implemented. Although the extent of occurrence (EOO) is <5,000 km², there are no available data on its population or range trends. Further information is required on population size and structure, trends, habitat requirements, biology, bycatch, and range to assess it beyond Data Deficient. Further research is also required on the species’ biology, occurrence and capture in fisheries.
habitat: The Pygmy Thornback Skate occurs in waters adjacent to the Gulfs of South Australia at depths of 27–54 m (Last and Stevens 2009) There are no specific details on habitat. Maximum size of this species is about 33 cm total length (TL); males mature at about 29 cm TL (Last and Stevens 2009). There is no information on neonatal juveniles or egg cases (Last and Gledhill 2008) and no further information on the ecology or life history of this species.
threats:
The Pygmy Thornback Skate is a potential bycatch of the Gillnet, Hook and Trap Sectors (GHATS), part of the Commonwealth managed Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF). No fishing effort takes place within the South Australian Gulfs, while fishing effort in Backstairs Passage and Investigator Strait is virtually nonexistent and relatively small, respectively (Goldsworthy et al. 2010). Fishing effort off the south and southwest of Kangaroo Island is higher and more likely to impact the Pygmy Thornback Skate if the distribution of the species extends to that area. However, encounterability, post-capture mortality, and catch susceptibility of the Pygmy Thornback Skate were assessed as low for the gillnet fishery of the SESSF (Walker et al. 2008). The actual bycatch level for the species is unknown.

The Pygmy Thornback Skate is also a potential bycatch of South Australian prawn trawl fisheries which operate over a portion of the range of this species. The species has a high encounterability, a high selectivity and a medium post-capture mortality to otter trawl gear. The fishery operates in waters greater than 10 m with demersal, otter-trawl rigged gear. Prawn fishing in the Investigator Strait was closed in 1987 with the buyback of licences for the Investigator Strait prawn fishery.
