While trawling can still be undertaken by licensees from other areas, fishing effort within Investigator Strait is minimal. No prawn trawling is being undertaken in Backstairs Passage due to unsuitable grounds, effectively providing a refuge area for the Pygmy Thornback Skate (G. Hooper pers. comm. 2011). Similar to Commonwealth catches, no information is currently available on State catches of this species. While the occurrence of the Pygmy Thornback Skate in the South Australian Gulfs is uncertain, Currie et al. (2009) did not report Pygmy Thornback Skate as bycatch in the Spencer Gulf Prawn Fishery in 119 trawls (mostly of 30 minutes duration) possibly indicating the apparent rarity of the species.

No species-specific catch data is available for rays and skates caught by the recreational fishing industry. However, a survey of the South Australian recreational fishery estimated 18,082 rays and skates caught in 2007/08 with 97% of them released (Jones 2009). As such, the South Australian recreational fishery is unlikely to have a strong impact on the Pygmy Thornback Skate.
population: Population size and trend are unknown for the Pygmy Thornback Skate.
range: The Pygmy Thornback Skate is endemic to South Australian waters and is only known from the Investigator Strait and Backstairs Passage off Kangaroo Island. While the range map in Last and Stevens (2009) includes Gulf St Vincent for this species, presence here is uncertain (Last and Gledhill 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).
useTrade: The Pygmy Thornback Skate is not known to be traded and is generally too small to be marketed.
conservationActions: South Australian prawn trawl fisheries are managed by traditional methods of limited licences, vessel and gear restrictions as well as seasonal closures and rotation of trawling grounds. Other measures including bycatch reduction devices such as crab bags (separate cod-end is enclosed within the main cod-end) and crab racks (grates used to sort prawns from larger bycatch) have lead to reduced sorting times. Post release survival of skate species is largely unknown and requires further investigation to gauge the effect of prawn fisheries on the Pygmy Thornback Skate.

rationale: The Elongate Carpetshark (Parascyllium elongatum) is possibly endemic to southern Western Australian waters. The range of this species is known only from a single specimen collected from the stomach of a School Shark (Galeorhinus galeus) caught at 50 m depth near Chatham Island, Western Australia. Due to the lack of knowledge about range, population size, habitat and ecology, and threats facing this species, there is little information available to undertake an accurate assessment of its conservation status. It cannot therefore be assessed beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: The depth range of this carpetshark is unknown as it is only recorded from a single specimen (42 cm total length) collected from the stomach of a School Shark caught at 50 m depth (Last and Stevens 2008, 2009). Little is known about the biology of the family Parascyllidae other than that they are oviparous (Last and Stevens 2009). There is no further information on the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: Threats to this species are largely unknown due to the lack of knowledge on its geographic and depth range, and population size.
population: Nothing is known of the population structure or trends of this species.
range: The range of Elongate Carpetshark (Parascyllium elongatum) is known only from a single specimen collected from the stomach of a School Shark (Galeorhinus galeus) caught near Chatham Island, Western Australia (35°02’S, 116°28’E; Last and Stevens 2008).
useTrade: This carpetshark is not known to be utilized or traded.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation actions are currently in place. All sharks and rays are commercially protected under Western Australian law. This regulation essentially restricts the retention of all shark and ray products by commercial fishing vessels other than those operating in the State's managed shark fishery.

rationale: Parioglossus verticalis is only known from one specimen collected in the Caroline Islands. Information about the distribution, biology and population of this species is extremely limited. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Parioglossus verticalis is only known from a single specimen collected between 0-1.5 m depth (Rennis and Hoese 1985).  The maximum known size is 21.4 mm SL (Rennis and Hoese 1985).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from one specimen.
range: Parioglossus verticalis is known from one specimen collected near Pohnpei, in the Caroline Islands at 0-1.5 m (Rennis and Hoese 1985).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for P. verticalis. Its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: Ptereleotris lineopinnis is known only from the holotype collected off South Africa. Additional records of this species require verification. Information on the distribution, population and biology of this species are very limited. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Information on the biology of this species is limited. The holotype was measured at 9.7 cm SL (Randall and Hoese 1985) and two specimens provisionally identified as this species (Randall and Heemstra 1991) measure 8.1 and 8.3 cm SL (but are in poor condition). The depth distribution of this species is unknown, but specimens were found in the stomachs of fishes caught at depths of 98-110 m.
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: Population information is not available; it is confirmed from only the holotype specimen.
range: The holotype of Ptereleotris lineopinnis was collected from the stomach of a flatfish (Arnoglossus sp.) caught at 110 m depth off Natal, South Africa (Fowler 1935). Two additional smaller specimens thought to be this species were later collected from the stomach of Pristipomoides zonatus caught at 98 m depth at Pathfinder Reef in the Marianas (Randall and Hoese 1985). It likely occurs in the Seychelles (Smith and Smith 1963). There are unconfirmed specimens in FishNet2 from Japan (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 2015-03).
useTrade: Use and trade information is limited for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for P. lineopinnis. Its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: Plectranthias cirrhitoides is known only from the remote island of Rapa, French Polynesia, where there is only a very small human population. It is a common species in near-shore waters around the island. There are no known major threats, therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in inshore waters and has a maximum recorded length of 5.7 cm standard length (SL) (Randall 1980).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is common and occurs in near-shore waters around the island of Rapa (J. Williams pers. comm. 2015).
range: Plectranthias cirrhitoides is a Rapa endemic in French Polynesia. The depth range for this species is 2 to 25 m (Randall 1980, J. Williams pers. comm. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not commercially utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for P. cirrhitoides. The low population density of Rapa Island pose no development threats to the near-shore waters of Rapa, and it is a small, cryptic species that is not likely to make it desirable for commercial uses.

rationale: Pseudogramma australis is known from Easter Island. The information on the biology of this species is limited, but there are no known threats, and it is not commercially utilized. This species' cryptic habits, relatively deep-reef habitat and remote island area are likely to serve as natural protection from exploitation. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum recorded length for this species is 6.7 cm standard length (SL) (Randall and Cea 2011).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: This species is an Easter Island endemic known from at least 14 museum specimens (Randall et al. 2002).
range: Pseudogramma australis is known only from Easter Island; records from elsewhere refer to P. xantha (Randall et al. 2002). The depth range for this species is 21 to 42 m (Randall and Cea 2011).
useTrade: This species is not commercially utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for P. australis. This species' cryptic habits and relatively deep-reef habitat are likely to serve as natural protective mechanisms for this species.

rationale: Rogadius mcgroutheri is known only from the type specimens collected from Australia and New Caledonia. Little is known on its distribution, habitats, or population; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The maximum recorded length for this species is 14.6 cm (Imamura 2007). Little else is known regarding its biology or ecology. Its specific habitats are unknown, as no collection data besides depth were provided in the species description (Imamura 2007).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from type specimens (at least 19 individuals). Little is known regarding its population status.
range: Rogadius mcgroutheri is only known from specimens collected from eastern Australia and New Caledonia. It has been found at depths of 16 to 59 m (Imamura 2007).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for R. mcgroutheri.

rationale: This deep water species has been recently described from New Caledonia and New Zealand. It may have a wider distribution than is currently. It is common where it occurs and there are no known major threats.  It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a bathydemersal species found at depths of 345 to 1089 meters. This species can reach a maximum length of 10.5 centimeters (Motomura et al. 2012).
threats: There are no known major threats for Phenacoscorpius longilineatus.
population: This species is recently described and is known from 94 specimens.  It is relatively common where it occurs (Motomura et al. 2012).
range: Phenacoscorpius longilineatus is known only in the southwestern Pacific Ocean from New Caledonia to New Zealand (Motomura et al. 2012). The type series was collected at depths of 345 to 1089 m (Motomura et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Phenacoscorpius longirostris is a deep water species known from only two type specimens, one from south of Norfolk Island, Norfolk Island Ridge, and one from Lord Howe Rise. Little is known regarding its distribution, biology, ecology, or potential threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Phenacoscorpius longirostris is a demersal species that can reach a maximum length of 6 cm (Motomura and Last 2009). Little else is known regarding its biology or ecology.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from two type specimens (Motomura and Last 2009).
range: Phenacoscorpius longirostris is known from only two type specimens, one from south of Norfolk Island, Norfolk Island Ridge, and one from Lord Howe Rise. The two specimens were collected at depths of 300 to 322 m (Motomura and Last 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is known from a very limited number of specimens and localities in the western Indian Ocean. Little is known regarding its distribution, biology, ecology, or potential threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Pontinus nigerimum is a demersal species found at depths up to 1,200 m (Motomura et al. 2011). Little else is known regarding its biology or ecology.
threats: Major threats to P. nigerimum are not known.
population: Pontinus nigerimum is known from very few specimens (Motomura et al. 2011).
range: Pontinus nigerimum is known from very few specimens collected in the western Indian Ocean from three localities. The type specimen was collected off Natal, South Africa at 146 m depth (Eschmeyer 1983); three additional specimens were collected from Réunion and Madagascar (Motomura et al. 2011). The maximum reported depth of this species is 1,200 m (Motomura et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Pontinus rhodochrous is widely distributed. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern. Further taxonomic research is needed to resolve its potential synonymy with P. macrocephalus.
habitat: This demersal species is deep-living (Motomura et al. 2011). Pontinus rhodochrous is thought to be conspecific with Pontinus tentacularis and possibly Pontinus macrocephalus.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: There are 20 museum records for this species from Oceania (Accessed through Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 2015-01).
range: Pontinus rhodochrous is found in the Indo-West Pacific around Indonesia, the Philippines, New Caledonia, Vanuatu, and the Wallis & Futuna Islands (Motomura et al. 2011). It has been reported from 200 to at least 400 m depth (Accessed through the Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.org, 2015-04). Specimens from Japan and Hawaii, referred to as P. macrocephalus, may also represent this species, but further research is necessary.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is almost unknown and is likely to be a junior synonym of another species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: This species is reported to be endemic to Chile (Simonetti and Ortíz 1980, Troncoso-Palacios and Garín 2013), where it occurs between Caleta Los Hornos (a record held in the Colección Herpetológica del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural de Chile) and Concón (Simonetti and Ortíz 1980, Ortíz 1981). The type locality is "Jalmel bei Los Andes (Mittelchile)".
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is classified as Vulnerable by the Reglamento de la Ley de Caza of the Ministerio de Agricultura (MMA 2014). While presently considered a valid species, this is largely on the basis that the proposal to synonymize it within L. zaparallensis is insufficiently documented rather than any genuine disagreement over its taxonomic status. Further research is recommended to resolve this issue.

rationale: Scorpaena bulacaphala is known from the southwestern Pacific Ocean, where it has been collected from Norfolk Island, Lord Howe Island, and Vanuatu at depths of 86 to 150 m. It is considered to be relatively rare, and known from a limited number of specimens. Although data on this species are limited, there are no known major threats to this species or its deeper water habitat.  It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species is found at depths of 86 to 150 m (Motomura et al. 2011), and can reach a maximum length of 8.8 centimeters (Motomura et al. 2005).
threats: There are no known major threats for this species.
population: This species is relatively rare (H. Motomura pers. comm. 2015). There are 3 museum records of this species (Accessed through Fishnet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, 2015-01).
range: Scorpaena bulacephala is found in the southwest Pacific Ocean, where it has been collected from Norfolk and Lord Howe islands (Motomura et al. 2005) and more recently from southern Vanuatu (Motomura et al. 2011). It is known from 86 to 150 m depth (Motomura et al. 2005, 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This deep-living species is only known from the holotype, found in the Wallis and Futuna Islands. Little is known regarding its population status, biology, ecology, or potential threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only specimen on record was found at 600 m; little is known on its habitats and ecology (Motomura and Causse 2011). This benthic species can reach a maximum length of 4.9 cm standard length (SL).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known only from a single record. Little is known regarding its population status.
range: Scorpaenopsis crenulata is known from a single specimen from the Wallis and Futuna Islands collected at 600 m depth (Motomura and Causse 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This deep-living species is only known from a single specimen collected from a single locality in the northwestern Hawaiian Islands. Little is known regarding its distribution, population status, biology, ecology, or potential threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal, benthic species is only known from a single specimen collected at 110 meters depth. Very little is known on its habitats. Its length was measured at 7.4 cm (Randall and Eschmeyer 2001).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from one specimen; very little is known on its population (Randall and Eschmeyer 2001).
range: Scorpaenopsis pluralis is only known from a single specimen collected from Laysan in the northwestern Hawaiian Islands at 110 m depth (Randall and Eschmeyer 2001, Mundy 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Sichuan Weasel is listed a Data Deficient, because there is too little readily available information to speculate on the effects that hunting, habitat change, and other potential threats operating in the general area of its range might be having on its populations. The population and/or, conceivably (as Area of Occupancy) range, could potentially be small enough, or decline rates steep enough, for it qualify as Critically Endangered under any of Criteria A - D. Equally, it could be Least Concern. It will be impossible to clarify its conservation status without further precisely located records.
habitat: The three collection sites are all montane. No other information is readily available, although specimen labels have not been reviewed for this assessment, and might contain indicative information.
threats: Little meaningful speculation is possible on the threats that this weasel perhaps faces. It lives in an area where hunting by various methods occurs. This could in theory be causing declines, but an apparent close relative, Least Weasel M. nivalis, persists under heavy persecution in some parts of it range; this cannot be assumed to apply also to Sichuan Weasel. Within its range, habitat degradation, fragmentation and conversion have all been extensive. But with no evidence that it is dependent upon forest or any other natural habitat, the effects of such habitat change are unknown.
population: Nothing is known of population levels or trends in this species.
range: Sichuan Weasel is known from only three collection records, from a small area of China: four specimens from Tatsienlu (now Lucheng, 30°03′N, 102°01′E; 4,480 m a.s.l.), in Sichuan province (Thomas 1911a,b); three from Mt Taibai (34°N, 108°E; 1,950-2,750 m a.s.l.), Zhouzhi county, Qinling Range; and one from an unnamed site at 34°N, 109°E ( 2,400 m a.s.l.), also in Zhashui county (Groves 2007).
conservationActions: The conservation priority for Sichuan Weasel is to find an extant population and then understand the basic threats, if any, faced. Otherwise, it is difficult to speculate on its conservation needs, if any. Protected area coverage is extensive in Sichaun, especially at high altitudes, suggesting the possibility that the species might inhabit one or more reserves and, unless it has highly specific habitat use, the possibility that it is not under immediate threat of extinction.

rationale: The Desert Bettong is known from a single modern specimen, collected in 1933 and has not been recorded alive since then, despite extensive surveys. The date of extinction is unknown, but was possibly in the 1950s or 1960s as Woylie Bettongia penicillata and Boodie B. lesueur survived in the Tanami Desert until c. 1960 (Burbidge et al. 1988).
habitat: Nothing is known about what habitat this species occurred in or about its ecology. The Tanami Desert is mostly a dry hummock grassland with scattered shrubs and this was possibly the habitat of this species. However, the Western Australian record from near Morawa suggests a wider array of habitats. Interpretation of the skull and dentition of the Desert Bettong suggests that coarse browse material was a substantial proportion of its diet (McDowell et al. 2015).
threats:
The Desert Bettong was probably driven to extinction because of predation by introduced Red Foxes and feral domestic cats, perhaps combined with inappropriate fire regimes.

There is strong evidence for decline and extinction of critical weight range mammals due to predation by Red Foxes (Vulpes vulpes); Short (1998) documented a close correlation between the extinction of bettongs in New South Wales and the arrival of the Red Fox.

There is strong evidence for decline and extinction of desert critical weight range mammals due to predation by feral domestic cats; attempts to reintroduce Boodies B. lesueur to mainland areas where Red Foxes were controlled failed because of predation by feral cats (Christensen and Burrows 1994).

When Aboriginal people moved to settlements, fire regimes in the western deserts changed from mostly small fires resulting in a mosaic of fire ages to one of infrequent, very large summer fires (Latz 1995), with consequences for food availability and habitat suitability demonstrated for small desert macropods (Bolton and Latz 1978).
population: It is not known how abundant this species was before its extinction. The species has not been recorded alive since 1933, despite extensive surveys.
range: The single modern specimen, a damaged skull, was collected in 1933 from a freshly-dead animal by the explorer Michael Terry near the McEwin Hills, east of Lake Mackay in the Tanami Desert, Northern Territory. Subfossil material of this species is known from Stegamite Cave, southern Nullarbor Plain, Western Australia (McDowell et al. 2015). As these localities are widely separated, it may once have had a relatively wide distribution. Burbidge et al. (1988) did not record any Aboriginal oral history that may show indigenous knowledge of a third species of Bettongia in the central and western deserts; however, they did not ask people about a third species, as the Desert Bettong was not known to be a separate species at the time. If the Desert Bettong's pelage and behaviour was similar to the Boodie's, the two species may not have been differentiated.
conservationActions: The species was not included in any State or Territory legislation and it is not known if it formerly occurred in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because this species is known from a single specimen and nothing is known about its distribution, ecology, population status or threats.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species are unknown (González et al. 2012).
threats: This snake is potentially threatened by introduced species such as cats and mongoose (González et al. 2012). However, there is not much information about how these species affect the population (A. Fong pers. comm. 2016).
population: It is a rare species. It is known only known from the holotype collected in the 1974. There have been no  recent surveys to search for the species..
range: This species is endemic to Cuba. It is known only from one specimen collected at Cueva del 18, Amancio Rodríguez, Las Tunas province (González et al. 2012, Rodríguez-Schettino et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is classified as Critically Endangered (CR) in the Cuban National Red List Assessment. The species is not found in any protected area (González et al. 2012). Further field surveys to search for the species are needed to have subsequent research in population trends, threats, ecology and distribution of this snake.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category. If climate change is found to be a major threat to this species then the conservation status of this species should be reevaluated.
habitat: There is little is known about the habitat requirements of this species, though it presumably has similar habitat requirements to Bufotes surdus; like many members of the genus Bufotes it presumably breeds in still or slow moving waters.
threats: The main threats to this species are prolonged drought and some localized habitat destruction (often through agricultural expansion) in parts of its range.
population: This species appears to be quite rare.
range: This species is endemic to the Zagros Mountains of western Iran. It is known from relatively few localities, mostly the western foothills of Kuzestan, Lorestan and Fars Provinces. The distribution map for this species is largely based on Stöck et al. (2001). It has an altitudinal distribution of 750-1,200 m asl.
conservationActions: It is not known with certainty if the species is present in any protected areas. The exact distribution and natural history of this species is not well known and needs further research. Further research is needed into the possible impact of climate change on this species, especially concerning the desiccation of breeding habitats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It presumably breeds in waterbodies and has a larval development breeding strategy.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The population is not known.
range: This species is known only from the unspecific type locality of "Africa" (Ahl 1931). It is not possible to map its distribution.
useTrade: There is no information regarding any use or trade of the species.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species occurs in protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as nothing is known of the distribution, population status or ecology of this species, or of any threats.
habitat: No ecological data is associated with the known specimen.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known from a single specimen described in 1831.
range: Nothing is known about the distribution of this species, which appears to have no locality data associated with the known specimen.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Nothing can be recommended for this species unless it is rediscovered; as its distribution is unknown surveys are not possible, but surveys of museum collections are needed to determine whether additional material exists.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis this species is known from a single, lost specimen of uncertain provenance and validity.
habitat: There is no information on the natural history of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known from a single specimen, which no longer appears to be extant.
range: This species' distribution is unknown. An origin in Mexico or Guatemala has been proposed (Uetz 2019), but it is not included in checklists of reptiles of Mexico (Smith and Taylor 1950, Liner 2007).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures can be proposed unless this species is rediscovered. The holotype has not been located, but it is possible that it is in the Hunterian collection (J. Campbell pers. comm. 2014 cited in Uetz 2019), and efforts should be made to locate it and clarify the species' validity.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and has not been recorded for 50 years in an area where deforestation is extensive and ongoing, despite regular surveys. In the absence of further information, it is considered to occur in a single location where there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: There is no ecological data associated with the known specimen.
threats: Deforestation in Haiti is extensive, and it is estimated that less than 1% of the island's original primary forest cover remains (Hedges et al. 2018). Although nothing is known of this lizard's ecology and some anoles are tolerant of even extensive habitat modification, this species has not been recorded for more than five decades despite extensive survey work in Haiti, including the presumed type locality. Deforestation, which is ongoing as a result of land clearance for settlement, firewood and agriculture, must therefore be considered a serious threat to this species, and it is thought likely to have a restricted geographic range (Köhler and Hedges 2016).
population: This species is known from a single specimen collected between December 1962 and February 1963. The presumed type locality is accessible and the Massif de la Hotte has been surveyed for anoles regularly over the past 30 years with no further records (Köhler and Hedges 2016). These authors consequently suggest that, if this locality is accurate, this is likely to be the rarest lizard species on Hispaniola.
range: This species is endemic to Haiti, where it is known only from the holotype from "Pourcine" on the Massif de la Hotte. This locality has not been located with certainty, but is considered likely by Köhler and Hedges (2016) to correspond to a community close to Annette and suggests the specimen was collected at "low to intermediate" elevations.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas. Further targeted surveys are needed in an effort to rediscover this species and clarify its distribution, population status and ecological requirements before any conservation recommendations can be made.

rationale: The species is known only from a holotype more than 150 years old, of unknown provenance within Jamaica. While the lack of records during extensive herpetofaunal fieldwork across the island over the last century suggests its possible extinction, the elusive habits of congeners and lack of any information on range, population, habitats, or threats justifies an assessment of Data Deficient. Should the species be re-discovered, it will likely have a tiny range, and so should be re-assessed as an urgent priority.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat and ecology of this species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Although nothing is known of the habitat preferences of the species, it is was forest dependent then it would likely have experienced a decline in its habitat given the extent of deforestation across Jamaica, and if it was commensal with humans it would likely have been seen at some point over the last hundred years.
population: It is known only from the holotype and it is thought to be possibly extinct (Powell and Henderson 2012). Sphaerodactylus are very small, fast, and can be hard to detect, but Jamaica has been relatively well-surveyed by experienced herpetologists over the last century, and Sphaerodactylus can be abundant within their ranges, so the lack of records suggests genuine absence.
range: This species is known from one nineteenth century specimen, presumably from Jamaica but with no locality information associated with the specimen (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Ongoing herpetofaunal survey work across Jamaica should always be alert for the possibility of re-discovering this species. Should it be found, its distribution will likely be tiny, suggesting that site conservation become a high priority.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that this species, while known from only four historical specimens, is considered to have been endemic to Navassa, with an extent of occurrence of approximately 5 km<sup>2</sup>, and if a population survives it is presumed to be undergoing a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals as a result of predation by invasive species as well as to survive in very low - but unquantifiable - numbers. It is thought likely that this species became extinct shortly after it was described, however, as this species belongs to a hard-to-detect genus of snakes and, despite some surveys on Navassa, both the limited extent of these surveys and the complexity of the island's topography make it impossible to state with confidence that the species no longer survives.
habitat: There is no information about habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The causes of this species' apparent extinction are not known, but may relate to some combination of invasive species, historical habitat modification and persecution. Although mongoose have never occurred on the island, both cats and rats have been introduced to Navassa (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016). Rats do not occur, however, in the high densities found on many Caribbean islands where they have been implicated in reptile declines or extinctions (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016). There is no development on this island, which is part of the Caribbean Wildlife Refuge. Past habitat alteration dates to the 19th Century (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016), including mining activity and "almost certainly" associated persecution of snakes; since this corresponds to the period when the only records were taken, it is possible that this could have contributed to or caused this snake's extinction (R. Powell pers. comm. 2020).
population: This species is only known from four syntypes, all from the nineteenth century. No subsequent records have been reported, despite several searches conducted on Navassa including targeted surveys for snakes. Ekman (1929) stated that no snakes then occurred on Navassa, having interviewed the local lighthouse keeper. Although Thomas (1966) found it "hard to believe" this snake is truly extinct, it has not been rediscovered in the subsequent 50 years and it is presumed likely to be extinct by more recent workers (R. Powell pers. comm. 2020). Members of this genus are often difficult to detect, and terrain on Navassa is somewhat rugged with inaccessible areas where snakes may survive, so it remains possible that a population survives, although probably in low numbers (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016). While it is impossible to quantify any remaining population, it is possible that it may exceed 50 mature individuals (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016).
range: This West Indian species is endemic to Navassa (Henderson and Powell 2009). The only known records are from the 19th century. The estimated extent of occurrence is about 5.28 km2. It has an elevation range from sea level to 77 m asl (M. Landestoy and S. Incháustegui pers. comm. 2015).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Although this species may be extinct, few searches have been conducted for it (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016) and it is recommended that efforts continue to search for the species. Navassa lies within the Caribbean Wildlife Refuge. The family Tropidophiidae is included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (González et al. 2012).

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of around 1,600 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur at two locations, and there are presumed to be ongoing threats from both deforestation and predation by introduced species. This species is nonetheless known from only four specimens collected over a period of more than 45 years and there is no information on its ecology, so this listing should be considered precautionary.
habitat: The natural history of this species is unknown. Most species of this genus are found in forested areas.
threats: The range of this species is under pressure from habitat loss and habitat fragmentation due to deforestation for agriculture and timber plantations. As the ecology of this species is unknown, it is unclear how severe impacts from these activities are. Exotic introduced species, particularly the mongoose, are predators of juveniles and adult snakes, but again it is not known how this mammal impacts this snake populations.
population: It is a rare species. Only eight individuals are known for the species, all of them collected in the 1950s, between 1956 and 1957.
range: This species is endemic to Cuba, where it occurs in Cienfuegos and Sancti Spíritus provinces at elevations from sea level to 75 m asl (González et al. 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species, which is not known to have been collected since 1957.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species and it is not found in any protected area. Further research in population trends, threats, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species. Classified as Critically Endangered in the Cuban National Red List assessment (González et al. 2012). The family Tropidophiidae  is included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (González et al. 2012).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because this species is known only from historical records when described in 1959, was confused with Typhlops lumbricalis for more than 50 years, and it has never been rediscovered. As such essentially nothing is known of its true distribution, its ecological requirements, or any threats.
habitat: There is no detailed information about the ecology of this species, which was described more than 55 years ago based on museum specimens. Dominguez and Díaz (2015) infer that it is a fossorial soil-dwelling species ranging from coastal and near-coastal areas to mountains.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species.
population: There is no information about the population status of this species. The most recent specimens referred to this species by Dominguez and Díaz (2015) were collected in 1956; the remainder were all taken in the first half of the 20th century.
range: Typhlops silus is known from eastern Cuba, in the provinces of Holguín (Dominguez and Díaz 2011, Powell and Henderson 2012, Rodríguez-Schettino et al. 2013), Gramma, Guatntanamo and Santiago de Cuba (Dominguez and Díaz 2015). As presently understood the sole records from each of Holguín and Gramma are somewhat disjunct from one another and from the main distribution, which is centred in the border region between Santiago de Cuba and Guantanamo (Dominguez and Díaz 2015).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There is no information about the species. Further taxonomic research and surveys to look for the species are recommended.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: There is no habitat information for this species. Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to breed in streams by direct development, as with its congeners.
threats:
The threats to this species are unknown.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea or the Aru Islands (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the islands. However, lowland frog species, such as this one, are expected to be at low risk from infection due to the warm climate in the Aru Islands and are less likely to be negatively impacted (Bower et al. 2019).
population: There is no information on the population size and trends of this species which are unknown.
range: This species is only known from the type locality on Wokum Island in the Aru Islands, Indonesia. Its exact type locality is unknown so its distribution has been mapped entirely to the island. Its elevational range is unknown, but the island is all below 100m asl (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is unknown whether this species occurs in any protected areas.

Research Needed
Further research is required on this species' distribution, population, ecology and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecology, although it presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown. There have been no recent records, presumably due to lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from Tshimbulu sur Luebi, in Kasai Province, southwestern Democratic Republic of Congo, and from Rio Chingufo, in northeastern Angola.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution and population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It presumably breeds in waterbodies and has a larval development breeding strategy.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The population is not known.
range: This taxon is known only from the untraceable type locality of "Locum Landana dictum, in foliis Musarum" (Rochebrune 1885), Cabinda enclave, Angola. The exact locality within Cabinda is not known, and so attempts to map its distribution can only be considered as approximate.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Research is needed into locating this species in the wild and into the distribution and population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats to this species. There are also continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecological preferences of this species, which presumably breeds in water.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: Its population status is unknown. There have been no records since its discovery, presumably due to lack of herpetological work within its range.
range: This species is known only from the Cabinda enclave in Angola.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade if this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Further surveys are needed to accurately determine this species range. Research is needed into the population status, ecology, use and trade, and threats to this species. There are also continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: No information about habitat or natural history is provided in the original description, which is exclusively based on morphology. The habitat and ecological requirements of this species are not known, although assuming that it breeds in a similar manner to other species in the genus, it lays its eggs in a nest buried in mud near water, into which the larvae emerge and develop.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: There is no information on its population status. It is known only from the holotype, which has been destroyed.
range: This species is known only from Quissange in western Angola.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Further research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology and threats of this species. There is continuing doubt as to the taxonomic validity of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Its habitat and ecological preferences are not well known, but are presumably similar to those of other members of the genus, and this species probably likewise breeds in water.
threats: The type locality is now an urban area, but at the time of the species description it was undeveloped (N. Baptista pers. comm. August 2016). There is no additional information available on threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species.
range: This very poorly known species is known only from its type locality, Luanda, Angola. This does not suggest that the species is not more widespread, but it is currently not known from anywhere else (N. Baptista pers. comm. August 2016).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is unknown whether it occurs in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Research is needed into the distribution and population status, ecology and threats to this species. Its taxonomic validity needs to be reassessed.

rationale: This is known only from a single specimen presented in 1884 to the collection of the National Museums of Scotland; nothing is known of its actual collection date, locality, population, habitat, ecology, or threats, and so it is assessed as Data Deficient. Should any individuals be re-discovered, re-assessment would be urgently needed.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat and ecology of this species (Henderson and Powell 2009). Congeners include cave-dwelling species, and so it is possible that Tarentola albertschwartzi may be as well.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist, but if it inhabits caves (as do some other Tarentola) then harvesting of bat guano might have a detrimental impact. "Large Indian Mongoose" was introduced into Jamaica in 1872, and so may have caused declines, as might feral cats.
population: This species is known from a single specimen.
range: This species is known only from the holotype from 1884, found in the 1990s in the National Museums of Scotland and apparently from Jamaica (Sprackland and Swinney 1998, Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Targeted searches for the species, guided by knowledge of the ecology of congeners, would be worth undertaking. If the species was to be re-discovered, site protection and conservation breeding would become immediate priorities.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct because it is only known from one skull collected in southern Peru. A living specimen has not been located during any surveys (Spotorno and Patton 2015).
habitat: There is nothing known about the ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of the threats to this species.
population: The are no population data on this species.
range: Known only by a single skull from southern Peru, presumably of an animal that lived in recent times. Probably a Plains Viscacha that was taken to Peru (Spotorno and Patton 2015)
conservationActions: None

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient as it is only known from a single specimen, therefore there is currently little information about the distribution, ecology, and threats faced.
habitat: This species is known from one specimen and consequently little is currently known about its habitat and ecology. It is presumed to be nocturnal and arboreal (Denys et al. 2017).
threats: The threats for this species are not yet understood.
population: Nothing is known about the population of this species.
range: Grammomys brevirostris is only known from one specimen, found at Lemesikio, on the Loita Plains on the Kenya and Tanzania border (Kryštufek 2008).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation efforts for this species.

rationale: Dendrochirus tuamotuensis is known only from the holotype collected in the Tuamotu Archipelago at a relatively deep depth. Little is known regarding its distribution, habitat, population, or potential threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only known species was collected at a depth of 120 m, and was measured at 5.7 cm standard length (SL) (Matsunuma and Motomura 2013).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: Little is known regarding the population status of Dendrochirus tuamotuensis, as it is known only from the holotype.
range: Dendrochirus tuamotuensis is known only from the holotype, collected from the Tuamotu Archipelago (Matsunuma and Motomura 2013).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is only known from eleven specimens collected off Singapore sometime prior to 1940. Little is known on its distribution, habitats, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species has not been observed in the wild, and was described from museum records. As such, its habitat preference is unknown. Its maximum total length is 12.5 cm (Fraser-Brunner 1940).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is known from only eleven specimens collected sometime prior to 1940. It may be common in Singapore (Fraser-Brunner 1940), but no studies have been conducted to confirm this.
range: This species is known from only a single locality: Singapore (Fraser-Brunner 1940, Matsuura 2015).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This deep-living species is known from only two specimens collected in the southwestern Indian Ocean. Little is known on its distribution, population, habitat and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is deep-living, and its habitat preferences are unknown. Its maximum known total length is 23 cm (Barnard 1927).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from two specimens and was last collected in 1973 (Barnard 1927, FishNet2 database accessed April 2017).
range: This species is distributed in the Western Indian Ocean and has been taken from only two localities: Natal, South Africa and Madagascar (Barnard 1927, Matsuura 2015, FishNet2 database accessed April 2017). The Madagascar specimen was taken around 500 metres depth (FishNet2 database accessed April 2017).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This deep-living species has a relatively small range in the southwestern Indian Ocean. Little is known on its population. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This deep-living, demersal species has been recorded from rocky reef in submarine canyons (Geldenhuys 2015). Its maximum length is 22 cm (Fischer and Bianchi 1984).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited for this species, likely due to the lack of sampling in the deep depths it inhabits.
range: This species has been recorded in the southwestern Indian Ocean from four localities: KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa) (Geldenhuys 2015), the Mozambique Channel, Madagascar and the western Mascarenes (Matsuura 2015). Its depth range is 100 to 205 metres (Geldenhuys 2015, FishNet2 accessed May 2017).
useTrade: This species occurs as bycatch in minor commercial fisheries (Hutchins 1986).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Little is known on the population, habitats or potential threats of/to this Hawaiian endemic. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known on the habitat of this deep-living species. Its maximum length is about 15 cm (Tinker 1978).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: Population data are limited for this species.
range: This species is distributed throughout the Hawaiian Islands (Matsuura 2015). Its depth range is 58 to 100 metres (FishNet2 accessed May 2017).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is known from only Easter Island and very few specimens. Little is known on its distribution, population, habitats and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known on the habitats and ecology of this poorly-known species. The holotype measured at 30 cm total length (Regan 1913).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: Population data are limited for this species, as it is known from very few specimens. It was described from a single specimen captured in 1911 (Regan 1913).
range: This species is known from only a single locality: Easter Island in the southeastern Pacific (Regan 1913, Matsuura 2015).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is known from only three type specimens captured from a single locality in the Red Sea sometime prior to 1953. There is uncertainty surrounding its taxonomic status. Little is known on its distribution, population, habitats and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known on the habitats and ecology of this species. Members of the genus Brachaluteres consist of small fishes that inhabit shallow inshore waters and are usually found on sheltered reefs, in sea grasses or around jetty piles. The three type specimens measure between 2.7-3.2 cm standard length (Hutchins and Swainston 1985).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is known from only three type specimens captured sometime prior to 1953 (Hutchins and Swainston 1985). Therefore, little is known about its population.
range: This species is known only from the type specimens that were taken from a single locality in the Red Sea near Al Ghardaqa, Egypt (27°17'N, 33°47'E) (Clark and Gohar 1953, Hutchins and Swainston 1985).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is known only from the original collection made over 100 years ago and there is lack of information on its distribution, population status, ecology and threats.
habitat: The habitat for this species is unknown, as is the breeding ecology although it could be presumed to breed by larval development in streams similar to other species in the genus.
threats: Habitat destruction caused by pine plantations might be a threat to this species, although this requires verification of habitat preference.
population: This species has not been seen since its description at the beginning of the 20<sup>th</sup> century and three recent expeditions in 1995, 1996, and 2002 all failed to locate it. The population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the western slopes of the Chilean Andes at San Ignacio de Pemehue, Cautin Province in Chile at 1,000 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 171 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Research Needed
Research on the taxonomy status, population and distribution, ecology and threats for this species is required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is uncertainty regarding its distribution, status, ecological requirements and threats. This species was described by Philippi (1902), based on two specimens given by Ferdinand Lataste to the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural, nevertheless, Philippi (1902) pointed out that regrettably Lataste left these animals with a tag where it indicates only “Potrero” as the name of the place of origin, omitting the word that it was following. Namely the name was incomplete generating many doubts regarding to the original place of collection of these animals. Therefore, more investigation is needed to clarify the origin of the specimen FMNHC 9978, and to know more of the natural history of this species.
habitat: There is no information on this species' ecology and habitat preferences. Based on information on congeners, it is presumed to breed in water by larval development.
threats: There is no information on major threats to this species.
population: It is known only from the type specimen (Cuevas 2013), and the population trend is unknown.
range: This species is only known from the type locality, Potrero, taken to be Potrero Grande, near Santiago, Chile (Cuevas 2013). The type locality has not, however, been located with certainty (Cei 1962 in Cuevas 2013), and there is doubt over whether the locality has been correctly identified (Correa 2017).
useTrade: There is no information on use and trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known whether this species occurs in any protected area.

Research Needed
Surveys are urgently needed to determine if this species is still extant. Studies are also required to clarify the uncertain taxonomic status of this species and to determine its origin, which may require the collection of new biological material for verification (Correa 2017).

rationale: Dusicyon australis was endemic to the Falkland Islands. It was discovered in 1690 and was still present when Charles Darwin visited the Falklands in 1833-1834. However, throughout the 1800s, the population declined drastically due to persecution. The last individual is believed to have been killed in 1876.
habitat: There is no information available on specific habitats favoured by this species. Falkland Islands habitat generally comprises rocky scrub, marsh and grassland, and dwarf shrub heath (Falklands Conservation 2012).
threats: The species was hunted by Argentine settlers in early 1800s, and by US fur traders in the 1830s. Due to being tame and curious and unafraid of humans, it was particularly susceptible to culling. Scottish settlers and their sheep flocks arrived in the 1860s and considered D. australis a pest and a threat to their sheep, setting fire to brushwood and laying out poison baits.
population: Dusicyon australis probably reached the Falkland Islands from the mainland 480 km away during the last glacial age (Slater et al. 2009). A close relative, D. avus, may have persisted in the Pampean and Patagonian regions of Argentina until after 1500 (Prevosti et al. 2015). The Falklands Wolf was discovered in 1690 and was still present when Charles Darwin visited the Falklands in 1833-1834. However, the population of West Falkland was already declining rapidly by then, and by 1865 it was no longer found on the eastern part of East Falkland. The last Falklands Wolf is believed to have been killed in 1876 at Shallow Bay, West Falkland Islands.
range: The Falklands Wolf was endemic to the Falkland Islands, and was present in both West and East Falklands.
useTrade: The species was hunted by Argentine settlers in early 1800s, and by US fur traders in the 1830s.
conservationActions: A Falklands Wolf was taken to Britain and lived in the London Zoo in 1868. In 1870, the surviving member of a pair of animals sent by Mr Byng, the acting colonial secretary of the Falklands, arrived in London Zoo. It lived for a few years. However, no reproduction in captivity was reported.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is known only from one specimen. It has not been recorded again despite surveys in this area, and there are a number of human activities in the surrounding area that may represent threats, but nothing is known of the true distribution, ecology or population status of this species.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat requirements of this species. Based upon the single known location, it is possible that this species inhabits woodland habitat in the region.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by a major threat process. It may be experiencing habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation due to mining and agricultural activity including cattle grazing, which takes place over much of the region.
population: This species is currently known only from the holotype, collected in 1972 (Storr 1974).
range: This species is known only from the type locality at Crystal Creek, Admiralty Gulf, in northwest Kimberley, northwestern Western Australia (Cogger 2000).
useTrade: This species does not appear to be traded or used.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species at the present time, but it is listed as a priority two fauna under the Western Australian Department of Parks and Wildlife, indicating that it is known from between 1 to 5 records and has been recorded on lands managed by the department, with surveys to be undertaken (Department of Parks and Wildlife 2014). Further research into the ecology, threats and habitat status of this species is suggested so that it can be determined whether this species is threatened.

rationale: Tympanocryptis uniformis has been assessed as Data Deficient as there is a lack of data regarding its taxonomic status and distribution. This species may be threatened by habitat degradation, resulting from land clearing, but due to a lack of ecological or reliable distributional data this cannot be confirmed at this stage. It is also unknown whether this taxon is in fact conspecific with a wider-ranging taxon.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat requirements of this species, although lizards of this genus tend to be terrestrial and xerophilic.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats. It may be threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to land clearing for agricultural purposes and mining. As the known specimen was reportedly collected near the city of Darwin, it may face further threats from expanding human settlement and infrastructure development, however no member of this genus has since been found in the Darwin area and it is consequently possible that the locality is in error. At present it is not known if and to what extent these threat processes are affecting this species.
population: This species is known with certainty only from the holotype.
range: This species is known with certainty only from the holotype reported to have been collected "near Darwin". Numerous targeted searches have failed to record Tympanocryptis species in the Darwin area (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed into the taxonomic status, distribution, ecology, habitat and population status of this species, as little is currently known.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as it is only known with confidence from the type specimen and some photos from the pet trade and its occurrence on Halmahera, where the reported type locality is located, has not been confirmed. Consequently, there is very limited additional information for this species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the natural history of this species. It is assumed to be semi-arboreal (Koch et al. 2013).
threats: Ongoing deforestation on Halmahera may threaten this species (e.g., Vetter 2009, Koch et al. 2013), but given the uncertain provenance of this species and the absence of any information on its ecology this requires confirmation.
population: This species is currently known only with certainty from one voucher specimen in a museum collection (Koch et al. 2013), and photographs of probably two different specimens from the pet trade in Indonesia and Japan (Suzuki 2006). Recent field surveys on Halmahera failed to record this possibly secretive species (Setiadi and Hamidy 2006, Weijola 2010, N. Maury pers. comm. 2017, A. Koch pers. comm. 2019).
range: This poorly-known species is reportedly endemic to the island of Halmahera (Moluccas, Indonesia). It is known only from the type specimen, which was found in a museum collection 25 years after it was described and is said to originate from Kampung Pasir Putih (Böhme and Ziegler 2005, Weijola 2010, Koch et al. 2013).
useTrade: Koch et al. (2013) reported at least two specimens in the international pet trade recorded from Japan. A photo of a specimen from an Indonesian trader was first available on the internet about the time when the species was described; the same photo can still be found at (https://www.reptilefact.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Zugs-Monitors.jpg).
conservationActions: This species is included in Appendix II of CITES. It is not known if any populations are present within protected areas. There is a need for general information on the distribution, natural history and possible threats to this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of inadequate information about its area of occupancy, its population status and ecological requirements. Very few specimens are sampled thus far, all are sampled in the karst habitat near the type locality.
habitat: This species is found from the secondary subtropical moist broad-leaf forest on low karstic mountains. But its roost, forage and ecological habit remain unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is inadequate information regarding its population status of the species as it is only known from a few specimens collected at the type locality.
range: Thus far, only known from the type locality, namely Shuifu Village, which is in the vicinity of Maolan National Nature Reserve in Guizhou Province, China (Eger and Lim 2011). Although the presumed records from Jiangxi and Guangdong were reported (Wang et al. 2016), recent phylogenetic analyses indicate they belong to another species with external similarity (Yu W. H. pers. comm.).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Research is needed in the areas of taxonomy, population status, distribution, biology and ecology, habitat status, and threats.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct because it has not been found within or nearby its only known range much after the original collection date.
habitat: There is nothing known about the habitat requirements or biology of this species.
threats: There are no known threats as the species is presumed Extinct.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known only from the holotype, which was collected in 1856 in Upolu, Independent Samoa. While the species is likely extinct, it should be sought after in future survey efforts in Samoa of the extant fauna in isolated habitats or the study of subfossil bats in a pre-human context to determine the extent of its historical distribution (Helgen et al. 2009).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place as the species is presumed Extinct. Additional surveys could be considered in isolated habitats or the study of subfossil bats in a pre-human context to determine the extent of its historical distribution (Helgen et al. 2009).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is known only from the type locality and there is no recent information on its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species is thought to be associated with bamboo forests and or forests with significant amounts of bamboo. It is is found roosting in the internode of larger species of bamboo (Feng et al. 2008). Moreover, it is reported that occurrence of T. pygmaeus and T. robustula inside the same bamboo (Schizostachyum funghomii) chamber at Damenglong, Jinghong County, Xishuangbanna in December 1960, which indicated that the Tylonycteris species sometimes share the same internode for roosting (Feng et al. 2008).
threats: The bamboo forest of type locality was partially destroyed around 2008-2010, and the impact and threats to this species remain largely unknown (Zhou, Z. M. pers. comm.), but likely include deforestation.
population: There are no current data regarding the population status of this species as it is only known from its type locality.
range: This species is endemic to China and is known only from the type locality in Xishuangbanna, southern Yunnan, China, where it occurs sympatrically with T. pachypus and T. robustula (Feng et al. 2008).
conservationActions: Little conservation information is available for Tylonycteris pygmaeus. Beyond the logical actions of protecting bamboo forests, research is needed on the population size, distribution, trends, life history, and threats.

rationale: The species was first described in west Sichuan in China by Thomas  (1911). Besides the holotype, no other specimens are known. There is  inadequate information to make a direct, or indirect, assessment of its  risk of extinction based on its distribution and/or population status.
habitat: There is no information on habitat and ecology.
threats: The threats for this species are unknown.
population: There is no information on population sizes at present.
range: The species is endemic to China. Only one specimen has been recorded in west Sichuan.
conservationActions: There is no information on conservation actions.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because its taxonomy status, distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat of the species.
threats: There is no information about the threats affecting this species.
population: The last known specimen was collected in the 1940s. There have been no recent surveys for the species (W. Bolívar, A. Ramírez, F. Vargas-Salinas, P. Gutiérrez, M. Bernal, G. González, D. Gómez and M. Rivera pers. comm. August 2016).
range:
This species is only known from the type locality in the municipio of the Andes, on Cordillera Occidental of Antioquia Department in the Colombian Andes. There is no information about the altitudinal range for the species due to confusing data about the distribution of the species (W. Bolívar, A. Ramírez, F. Vargas-Salinas, P. Gutiérrez, M. Bernal, G. González, D. Gómez and M. Rivera pers. comm. August 2016). The previously reported specimens from Caldas are misidentifications of Pristimantis veletis (G. González pers. comm. August 2016).

Cochran (1970) recorded one individual from Valle de Cauca Cisneros below 500 m asl, but Lynch (1997, 1998b) and Ruiz-Carranza, Ardila-Robayo, and Lynch (1996) did not consider this to be a valid record. It was probably by mistake that Acosta-Galvis (2000) included Valle del Cauca in its distribution.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species is not found in any protected area (following the assignment of subpopulations to P. veletis).

Research Needed
Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic validity, uncertain provenance, extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its provenance, extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: Since the type locality is not known its habitat and ecology are also not known. Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known only from one specimen and so the population status is unknown. Surveys in Antioquia Department have yet to record this species, however further surveys are needed (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018).
range: The exact location of the type locality in Colombia of this species is not known and so it is not possible to draw a map of its range. It is hypothesised that it is from southern Antioquia Department (Ruiz et al. 1996, J. Lynch pers. comm.).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Its presence in any protected areas is not known.

Research Needed
The exact locality where the species was found needs to be determined and a search for more specimens is necessary to better understand its taxonomic status, distribution and population status.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: Little ecological information about this species exists, since it was described from museum specimens. If similar to other species in the genus, this species may inhabit humid forested slopes of the Andes, and perch on limbs of low bushes and cling to rocks in spray zones of waterfalls (Duellman and Trueb 2015). It is possible that the eggs are carried on the back of the female and the young develop directly, as with other congeners (L. A. Rueda-Solano and F. L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. 2017).
threats: There is no current knowledge about the threats to this species (L. A. Rueda-Solano and F. L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. 2017).
population: There is little information on the population size and trends of this species, since it was described fairly recently (2008) and there have been no surveys since its description (L. A. Rueda-Solano and F. L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. 2017). The species was described from museum specimens collected by Lynch and other collaborators in 1992 (Lynch 2008).
range: This species is known only from its type locality: on the eastern flank of the Serranía de Perijá in the Department of Norte de Santander, at 1,030 m Asl. Two specimens collected from c. 10 km along the road from the type locality, at the same elevation, are likely to belong to this species; however this needs confirmation (Lynch 2008).
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected areas (L. A. Rueda-Solano and F. L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution (including the identity of the two potential nearby records), population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Very little is known about its habitat and ecology, although it presumably breeds in water by larval development.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown, but presumably include habitat loss.
population: There are no recent records for this species, which has a fragmented population that is believed to be declining. There are no quantitative estimates of its population status or trends.
range: This species is known from above 200 m asl in a small number of widely separated localities in Chittor and Nellore (Satyamurti 1967), and Nagarjuna Sagar Tiger Reserve (Pillai and Ravichandran 1986), in the state of Andhra Pradesh in southern India. Intervening areas are devoid of records, though it might yet be found more widely. Its occurrence in the Western Ghats requires further clarification.
conservationActions: It has been recorded from Nagarjuna Sagar Tiger Reserve in Andhra Pradesh (Pillai and Ravichandran 1996) but reports from Bannerghatta National Park in Karnataka require verification. Recent regional studies including this species have been undertaken by Ravichandran. The actual presence of taxa referable to this species at the recorded localities requires investigation.
