rationale: Listed as Data Deficient due to the high degree of uncertainty around its provenance, distribution, and ecological requirements.
habitat: The habitat preferences and ecology of this species are unknown, but it is suspected to breed by larval development in water.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information on the population size and trend of this species.
range: This species is only known from its type locality "Usaramo, Deutsch-Ost-Afrika" in Tanzania, which may be in the area of modern day Ibadakuli, Tanzania (E. Greenbaum pers. comm. February 2016).
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: Further research is required on the species' taxonomy, population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and any threats it faces.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because there is still very little known about   where it actually occurs, its extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, status and ecological   requirements.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat preferences, natural history or reproductive strategy of this species.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species because of uncertainty as to its type locality and habitat preferences.
population: It is only known from four specimens.
range: This species is known from its type locality: "Quilimane, Mozambique". It is unknown whether this refers to the site where it was sampled or whether it is the name of the maritime port to which it was brought; Pfeffer (1893) also noted this uncertainty in the original description of the species.
useTrade: There is no information about use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Research Needed
Further work is required on the taxonomy, population size and distribution, life history and ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence (EOO), status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This is possibly a lowland moist forest species that presumably breeds by larval development, but it is not known where the adults deposit the larvae.
threats: The major threats are not known.
population: The population status and trend of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of "Nauta" (Cope 1874), which has traditionally been thought to be in Amazonian Peru in Loreto Department. However, it is far from certain that the type locality is in Peru, and it is more likely that this species comes from Panama.
useTrade: There is no information on the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known from any protected areas. 
Conservation Needed
It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival

Research Needed
Research on taxonomy, population status, ecology and threats is required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence (EOO), status, threats and ecological requirements.
habitat: The habitat type of this species is not known. It is terrestrial, and it is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: It is possibly threatened by general agricultural activities, however this remains uncertain.
population: There is no recent information on the population status of this species (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, 13 km east-south-east of Yamobamba, in the upper Río Moche (Pacific) drainage in the Cordillera Occidental, Otuzco Province, La Libertad Region, Peru. It occurs at 3,290 m asl. Although it is likely to have a small distribution, the limits of its distribution are not very well known.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Additional surveys are needed to determine whether the species occurs outside of its type locality (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Nothing is known about the natural history of this species.
threats: There is agriculture ongoing in the area of the type locality and likely causing a threat to the species, however the degree to which the species is affected remains unknown (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
population: The species is only known from the one type specimen. No population information is available.
range: This species is only known from the type locality: Caraz,  District of Caraz, Province of Huaylas, Department of Ancash, Peru. This locality is in the northern part of the Callejón de Huaylas in the Río Santa Valley, at 2,290 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is not known from any protected area.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further survey work is needed to determine if it occurs outside the vicinity of the type locality.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Nothing is known about the species' natural history. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: It is possible that deforestation due to agriculture and cattle breeding, as well as associated pollution, may be occurring in the general area where this species occurs (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017). However, given the lack of recent surveys, it is not known whether and to what extent these potential threats could be impacting on this species and its habitats.
population: The species is known only from seven specimens which comprise the type series, collected in 1969. No new surveys have been conducted in the type locality or surrounding area (von May et al. 2008, E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, 10.8 km west of Huancapallac at 2,950 m asl, in the eastern part of the Cordillera Central, Province of Huánuco, Region of Huánuco, Peru (Lehr 2007).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
No conservation actions are currently known for this species.

Research Needed
Additional surveys in the area are recommended to improve understanding of this species' distribution, population status and trends, ecology and threats (E. Lehr pers. comm. April 2017).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity.
habitat: It presumably breeds in water by larval development.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Its population status is not known.
range: This taxon was recorded in Thailand from the approximate locality of "Hat Sanuk, Siamese Malaya, near Tenasserim border".
conservationActions: It is not known if the species occurs in protected areas.

rationale: Madagascan hippopotami may have survived until recent times (MacPhee and Flemming 1999), notably on the basis of local oral tradition, but are now certainly extinct.
habitat:
Hippopotamus madagascariensis retains low orbits and a relatively short muzzle. Stuenes (1989) used these features to propose a more terrestrial way of life for this species than in Hippopotamus amphibius. Similarly, Stuenes (1989) indicated a cranio-mandibular morphology closer to that of Choeropsis liberiensis, the extant Pigmy Hippo from western Africa. She further noted that Hippopotamus madagascariensis exhibited teeth generally more worn than in Hippopotamus lemerlei. These characters both suggest a diet differing from that of the other Madagascan dwarf hippopotamid.

The ecology of Hippopotamus madagascariensis may have been close to that of Mediterranean extinct dwarf hippopotamids, but further investigation of this question is required, notably on postcranial anatomy, stable isotope enamel/bone contents, and dental wear.
threats: Island Dwarf Hippopotamids were probably easy prey for human hunters. This may have lead to their quick extinction in the Mediterranean (Simmons 1988). The same impact from human hunters may have been effective in at least accelerating extinction of Madagascan hippopotamids. MacPhee and Burney (1991) indicate evidence for hippopotamid butchery in south-western Madagascar dated to the 1st century AD. Gommery et al. (2011) proposed an earlier evidence of hippopotamid butchery at least dated to 1400 BC. Co-occurrence of humans and hippopotamids on Madagascar, therefore, could have lasted for a minimum of 2,000 years. How much humans have contributed to this extinction is yet to be determined.
population: This species is now extinct.
range: Hippopotamus madagascariensis is mostly known from localities of highland Madagascar (see a list of locality in Stuenes 1989). Last appearance datum of Madagascan dwarf hippopotamids remains uncertain. Most recent dates were provided through 14C dating and indicate c. 1000 AD (Dewar 1984, Burney et al. 2004). However, MacPhee and Flemming (1999) proposed it as recent on the basis of local oral tradition (Flacourt 1661) and the possible younger age of some localities. However, this may only reflect sporadic occurrence of Hippopotamus amphibius.
conservationActions: This species is now extinct.

rationale: Madagascan hippopotami may have survived until recent times (MacPhee and Flemming 1999), notably on the basis of local oral tradition, but is now clearly extinct.
habitat: Stuenes (1989) indicated that Hippopotamus lemerlei was probably well adapted to the amphibious way of life observed in the extant Hippopotamus amphibius. She based her conclusion notably on the relatively prominent orbits and developed muzzle of this species. In terms of diet, cranio-mandibular morphology may also indicate similarity with Hip. amphibius (Stuenes 1989), i.e. a diet mainly based on fresh grass. Overall, Hippopotamus lemerlei seems to have been a dweller of freshwater rivers crossing the lowlands of Madagascar.
threats: Island Dwarf Hippopotamids were probably easy preys for human hunters. This may have lead to their quick extinction in the Mediterranean (Simmons 1988). The same impact from human hunters may have been effective in at least accelerating extinction of Madagascan hippopotamids. MacPhee and Burney (1991) indicate evidence for hippopotamid butchery in south-western Madagascar as early as the 1st century AD. Co-occurrence of humans and hippopotamids on Madagascar, therefore, could have lasted for a minimum of 2,000 years. How much humans have contributed to this extinction is yet to be determined.
population: This species is now extinct.
range: Hippopotamus lemerlei is mostly known from southern localities of coastal to lowland Madagascar (see a list of locality in Stuenes 1989). Last appearance datum of Madagascan dwarf hippopotamids remains uncertain. Most recent dates were provided through 14C dating and indicate c. 1000 AD (Dewar 1984, Burney et al. 2004). However, MacPhee and Flemming (1999) proposed it as recent on the basis of local oral tradition (Flacourt 1661; and see Burney and Ramilisonina 1999) and possible younger age of some localities. However, this may only reflect sporadic occurrence of Hippopotamus amphibius.
conservationActions: This species is now extinct.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because of lack of information on species population parameters, habitat use, and threats. Further information is required to properly assess the species' extinction risk.
habitat: This species has not been studied in the field, and no data on habitat or life history traits are available (Emmons and Patton 2015).
threats: Although there is no available data on habitat, the gallery forests along the watercourses on Isla Margarita are vanishing. If this species occupies these forests, it could be endangered (Emmons and Patton 2015).
population: There is no information on the population of this species.
range: This species is known only from two localities on Isla Margarita, off the north-central coast of Venezuela (Emmons and Patton 2015).
conservationActions: No conservation measures recorded at this time.

rationale: Crocidura zimmermanni is endemic to Crete where it is restricted to the central areas of the island. It is assessed as Endangered, because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is approximately 3,466 km² and it has been recorded from only three mountain tops. It is estimated that there are fewer than five locations, the population is fragmented, and it is suspected that population decline and range contractions are occurring as a result of out-competition by a non-native shrew, C. suaveolens. This could ultimately result in the extinction of C. zimmermanni.
habitat: It has been collected in open mountainous areas that are dry in summer and snow-covered in winter (Vogel 1999). It is likely also to occur at lower altitudes, but if so its habitat preferences there are unknown. The preferred habitat is high altitude plateaus of various sizes, rather than cliffs and peaks (P. Lymberakis pers. comm. 2018).
threats: The introduction of Crocidura suaveolens in Minoan times (ca. 2,500 to 1,500 BC) may have forced C. zimmermanni into a restricted range  at compatatively higher altitudes as it is out-competed for habitat (Pieper 1990, Nowak 1999). C. suaveolens is abundant in coastal areas, but has also been found in the mountains at the same sites as C. zimmermanni (Vogel 1999). Climate change may affect the altitudinal distribution of C. zimmermanni, as habitats at lower elevations become less suitable (G. Mitsainas pers. comm. 2018).
population: This is a rare and little-known species which is only recorded from a small number of localities. Analysis of owl pellets suggested that Crocidura zimmermanni is more than ten times rarer than its congener C. suaveolens (Vogel 1999). The population trend has not been quantified but it is suspected to be decreasing.
range: Crocidura zimmermanni is endemic to the island of Crete (Greece), where it has been trapped in the central mountains (Lefka Ori, Mt. Psiloritis and Mt. Dikti) at altitudes of 1,150 to 1,400 m. However, owl pellets collected at 140 to 830 m contained remains of this species, indicating that it may also occur at lower altitudes (Vogel 1999).
conservationActions: It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It is also listed as EN ([B1ab(i)+2ab(i)] in the Red Data Book of Threatened Animals of Greece (Legakis and Maragou 2009). Research is required to determine its distribution and population trend, and to investigate potential threats (especially competition with C. suaveolens and potential climate change effects) and identify appropriate conservation measures. A genetic study to understand genetic flow among populations on the the three mountains is needed.

rationale: This fish is assessed as Data Deficient because it is only known based on a single type material of the species (the holotype) and limited information was provided in the original description. Further survey work is crucial to confirm the species' range, to determine the current population status and its trend, as well as to identify the use and any threats to the species.
habitat: No information is available on the habitat and ecology of the species, apart from that it is a freshwater fish.
threats: No information is available on the threats to the species and its habitats.
population: No information is available about the population status of the species at present, as it is only known from the type material as described in the original description (Boulenger 1894).
range: This fish is endemic to northeastern Borneo as it has been recorded only from the Bongan basin in Sabah, Malaysian Borneo (Boulenger 1894).
useTrade: It is not known whether the species is used or traded.
conservationActions: It is not known whether parts of the species range are within any protected areas. Further survey is crucial to confirm the distribution range of the species, to determine the current population status and its trend, as well as to identify the use and threats to the species.

rationale: Apart from the original description of the species, there are no more records or data available on the species. There is insufficient information on the distribution range, population size and trend, habitats and ecology, and threats to make an assessment of extinction risk. Therefore, the species is listed as Data Deficient. Further studies are recommended.
habitat: There are no records available about the habitats and ecology of the species.
threats: No information is available about threats to the species.
population: Given that the species is only known from its original description, there are no data available about the population size and trend.
range: The fish is only known from the original description of the species in Sumatra, Indonesia (Machan 1930). It has never been recorded since then, and it is possible that it was described based on cultivated stock or mislabelled material (Kottelat 2013). Therefore, the distribution range of this species is still uncertain.
useTrade: No records are available about use and trade of the species.
conservationActions: Since the record of this species is only based on the type locality, there are no confirmed data regarding the distribution range of the species. Further studies are important to gain knowledge about the species, including the taxonomy, distribution range, population size and trend, use and trade, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: While this species was collected from "Parambikulam forests" (Rao 1937) there is no confirmed information on its habitat and ecology. It is presumed to breed in water by larval development.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: It is known only from the lost holotype, so its population status is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the Western Ghats type locality of "Parambikulam forests, Cochin State" (Rao 1937), now in Kerala, India. It is possible that the type specimen was collected at around 700 m asl.
conservationActions: Recent sampling in the Parambikulam area has failed to locate any specimens that are referable to the type description, so further sampling of the area's forests is urgently required. It is possible that the type locality might be in a protected area (possibly the Parambikulam Wildlife Sanctuary), but the original site of collection is unclear. This species is protected by national legislation. Its taxonomic validity needs to be investigated.

rationale: The species is listed as Data Deficient, because whilst its approximate distribution is known, there is nothing known about habitat preferences, ecology, and the threats faced by the species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known about the threats for this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population of this species.
range: The species is known from the type locality Zahrud-e Bala (70 km to the south of Keman City) at 2,700 m asl (Roguin 1988), Zarda (Kuh-e Laleh-Zar, 95 km SWS of Kerman City, 3,500 m asl; Roguin 1988) and Deh Bakri (155 km SSE of Kerman City, 2,000 m asl; Obuch 2014), all in South-eastern Iran.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species occurs in protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Nothing is known about its habitat or ecological preferences, though it is likely to occur in moist forest. It presumably breeds by larval development, like other members of its genus, but it is not known whether or not it requires free-standing waterbodies for breeding or whether or not it breeds in habitats such as leaf axils or tree holes instead.
threats: The major threats are not known.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which is known only from the lost holotype.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, "[the] Base of [the] Anamallai Hills, Coimbatore District" (Rao 1937), in the southern Western Ghats of Tamil Nadu, India.
conservationActions: It is not known to occur in any protected areas. Field surveys and the designation of a neotype are required before the species' range; population status and habitat requirements can be determined.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Nothing is known about its habitat or ecological preferences, though it is likely to occur in moist forest. It presumably breeds by larval development, like other members of its genus, but it is not known whether or not it requires free-standing water bodies for breeding or whether or not it breeds in habitats such as leaf axils or tree holes instead.
threats: The major threats are not known.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which is known only from the lost holotype.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, "Saklespur, Hassan [District]" (Rao 1937), in the Western Ghats of India, at 948 m asl.
conservationActions: It is not known to occur in any protected areas. Field surveys and the designation of a neotype are required before the species' range; population status and habitat requirements can be determined.

rationale:
This new species is known only from a single specimen. Rhinolophus species from Sulawesi, almost invariably endemic, have been shown to have either widespread or restricted distributions, with widespread species documented based on survey work. Extensive scientific collecting and survey work in the nearby area have resulted in no novel records for R. belligerator, underscoring the likely rarity of this species. The current distribution in Sulawesi refers to the local distribution of R. arcuatus, from which this species has been split.

Since R. belligerator has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,742 km² and it is experiencing an ongoing decline in its habitat within a single location, it is listed as Endangered (EN) under criterion B1ab(iii).
habitat: Based on the limited information accompanying the specimen, specific information regarding habitat and ecology of this species is unknown at this time. However, other members of the genus are gleaning insectivores capable of highly manoeuvrable flight (Hill 1992).
threats: Deforestation and disturbance of roosts in caves affect closely related members of the genus (Wiles and Brooke 2009). Ongoing civil strife in the area is thought to have contributed to strong declines in undisturbed habitat and wild animal populations.
population: It is not possible to assess population trends at this time as this species is only known from a single specimen, collected in 1987 (Hill 1988, Patrick et al. 2013).
range: This species currently is only known from Permana Cave near Poso, Sulawesi Tengah Province, Sulawesi, Indonesia (Hill 1988), although it is conceivable that it could be found in the Kasiguncu lowlands area as well.
conservationActions: More research on habitats, ecology, and population size and trends is needed for this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct because it has not been found in its only known range, or nearby, much after the original collection date.
habitat: There is nothing known about the habitat requirements or biology of this species.
threats: There are no known threats as the species is presumed Extinct.
population: This species is known only from the holotype and paratype.
range: This species is known only from the holotype and paratype, which were collected during the U.S. Exploring Expedition to the Samoan archipelago in 1839-1841. The expedition explored the islands of Tutuila, Upolu, Savai’i and, the Manua island group, but the precise location from which the specimens were collected is not known. The species is considered a Samoan endemic, but the historical distribution remains to be clarified through more research on Samoa. The species is thought to be extinct from Samoa now, as most encounters by field biologists in Samoa only cite observations being made of two congeneric flying foxes, Pteropus samoensis or P. tonganus. There has been some discussion that perhaps the species survived until recently (in the early 1980s) due to observations by botanist Paul Cox. It is possible that the species could persist in Samoa on the remote montane forests of Upolu and Savai’i, but this is largely speculative (Helgen et al. 2009).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place as the species is presumed Extinct. Additional surveys could be considered, although it is speculative that the species could persist in Samoa in the remote montane forests of Upolu and Savai’I (Helgen et al. 2009).

rationale: The species is listed as Data Deficient due to the high level of uncertainty around its taxonomy, and the lack of information on its distribution, ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: This species' habitat and ecological requirements are presumably similar to those of most other members of the genus, and it likewise presumably breeds in water.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information on the species population size or trends.
range: This species is known only from the type series in Liberia and no further information is available. It is not possible to map the species at present.
useTrade: There is no information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: The taxonomic status of this species requires resolution before any relevant information is available.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because its distribution is not well defined, and there is no information on its population size and trend, habitats and ecology, and the threats that may be affecting it. Further research is needed to better establish its distribution as well as its population size and trends.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: As the precise distribution of this species is unclear, it is unknown whether it is exposed to major threats, however, deforestation is ongoing throughout Kalimantan.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is described based on a single specimen from a museum collection, probably from West Kalimantan.
useTrade: It is not known whether this species is being used or traded.
conservationActions: It is not known whether this species occurs in protected areas. Further research is needed to better determine its distribution as well as its population size and trends.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecological preferences of this species, which presumably breeds in water by larval development.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: It is known only from the holotype, which is now lost, so its population status is not known.
range: This species is known only from a locality at 1,000 m asl in the Batak Mountains, Bandar Baru, north Sumatra, Indonesia (Van Tuijl 1995).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation actions
The type locality of the species lays within the Gunung Leuser National Park, but new surveys are needed to confirm its presence there.

Research needed
Studies on its taxonomy, population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in due to a lack general knowledge. There is still very little information on the status, threats and ecological requirements of this species. More information is needed to properly assess the extinction risk of this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient due to the lack of information on its population, habitat, and threats. More information is needed to properly assess this species extinction risk.
habitat: No information is available about the habitats or ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: No information is known about the population status or trend of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Cordillera Oriental of Ecuador, specifically at the locality of Tungurahua, San Franisco, east of Ambato in central Ecuador at elevations of 2400 m (Patton 2015).
conservationActions: No conservation measures are reported for this species

rationale:
The number of remaining individuals of Cuora yunnanensis are presumed to be exceedingly small, as only three animals have been confirmed since 1946, all since 2004, despite at least 15 years of searches for this species, combined with the intensive collection of all turtle species in China, and monitoring of these trade volumes for unusual turtles. Any remaining population(s) are therefore assumed to be extremely small and localized.

The known animals were obtained from three localities, but in at least two cases are thought to have been purchased in markets and had likely been transported there by humans.

Remaining animals of the species are under exceptional threat from collection, as the species potentially commands a very high price in the (illegal) pet trade, as well as in the consumption trade.
habitat:
No information is available beyond the general assumption that Cuora yunnanensis inhabits streams, lakes and/or swampy wetlands, the typical lifestyle of most Cuora species. The type locality, Kunming, is at just under 1,900 m altitude; a distribution range of 2,000-2,260 m altitude is generally cited (e.g., Yu 1998, Lau and Shi 2000), but has been questioned as being too high (Blanck 2005).

Females reach up to 17.5 cm CL at 850 grams, males about 15 cm at 375 grams (Zhou and Zhao 2004, Zhou 2005, Zhou et al. 2008). In captivity, one or two clutches per female per year, of 4–8 eggs per clutch (maximum eight eggs per year), have been reported (Zhou et al. 2008). Hatchlings emerge after 64–68 days of incubation at 28–30­°C, and measure 32–35 mm at a weight of 6.5–8.3 grams (Zhou et al. 2008).
threats:
The main site of presumed historical occurrence of yunnanensis, Kunming, is now an expansive city surrounded mainly by agricultural fields especially in the flat areas. The adjacent Kunming Lake is heavily polluted; the lake's endemic newt Cynops wolterstorfii is considered extinct as a result of water pollution. Monofilament fishing nets were seen abandoned at the lakeshore in 2005, suggesting a risk of accidental drowning if yunnanensis persists (van Dijk pers obs 2005). Substantial areas of the lake have been encroached upon by expansion of the city of Kunming, though a large area of open water remains. The Western Hills area has been extensively developed for tourism, including roads, trails and a cable car, and contains a long-term settlement of rural people tending vegetable and fruit gardens (and presumably gathering local flora, fungi and fauna, potentially including turtles). Hence, habitat degradation and destruction are believed to represent threats.

Cuora yunnanensis has been restricted from international trade by inclusion in CITES Appendix II in 2000, but is reputed to be worth about USD 50,000 for the first animal to emerge from China into the international pet trade (Blanck et al. 2006), and several USD 1,000 for subsequent animals, generating strong incentives to search for and smuggle out any animal.
population: The type series of Cuora yunnanensis consists of five animals collected at Kunming by a single collector, plus one from Tongchuan [Zhongping] collected by another collector, and another three museum specimens from Kunming, all collected at the same time (Parham et al. 2004, Blanck 2005), suggesting that the species was not particularly rare at this early period of exploration (1900–1906). Four more specimens were subsequently collected and stored in Chinese collections, one of these in 1940 (Parham et al. 2004, Zhou and Zhao 2004, Blanck 2005). Commercial turtle collectors and traders have extensively harvested turtles throughout China (Lau and Shi 2000), and extensive but unsuccessful search efforts had been made to locate Cuora yunnanensis in the wild or in trade. Based on this information, the Asian Turtle Trade Working Group (2000) considered the species extinct. However, a single animal, without data on its origin, was purchased in a Kunming market in 2004 (Zhou and Zhao 2004), showing that this conclusion was premature. At least two animals have subsequently been reported and are held in captivity (Zhou 2005, He et al. 2007, Yang and Rao 2008). There were initial concerns that the single 2004 animal could have been a hybrid animal that resembled yunnanensis in its head and throat pattern, but not its absence of an anal notch; however, the identity of the live animals as yunnanensis was genetically confirmed by He et al. (2007).
range: C. yunnanensis has been reported only from Kunming Fu and Tongchuan Fu [=Dongchuan fide Iverson, 1992, but refers to Zhongping (=Huize) City fide Blanck et al. 2006] in Yunnan, China, at the time of its 1906 description (Iverson 1992, Parham et al. 2004), and a single animal from Xi Shan (Western Mountains) near Kunming collected in 1940 (Zhang and Cheng 1946). It is likely that these animals were purchased in markets and may have been transported by humans, possibly for substantial distances (Blanck 2005). Three more specimens in the Institute of Zoology in Beijing (Parham et al. 2004, Blanck 2005) have no reported locality data or collection date. The origin of three recent specimens discovered since 2004 and now held in captivity has not been recorded (Zhou and Zhao 2004, Zhou 2005, He et al. 2007), and the precise geographic origin of C. yunnanensis remains subject of speculation, with northwestern Yunnan and adjacent Sichuan, northeastern Yunnan close to the Myanmar border, southern Yunnan, and northern Laos having been suggested (Blanck 2005, Blanck et al. 2006, Zhou et al. 2008, Yang and Rao, 2008).
useTrade:
Cuora yunnanensis is of great value and potential demand in domestic and global pet trade; it may have been used for subsistence consumption historically. A few specimens have been used for museum collections and anatomical studies.

No animals have been observed in surveys of commercial trade;  a number of trade and museum animals reported as yunnanensis proved to have been misidentified (Blanck 2005).
conservationActions:
Cuora yunnanensis is protected under Chinese domestic legislation and is included in CITES Appendix II.

Surveys to locate and protect any remaining animals and populations and their habitat are in progress; should one or more populations be found, effective in-situ protection of the species and its habitat are urgently required, alongside the establishment of an assurance colony for future re-introduction and population reinforcement.

A single pair in captivity has successfully reproduced (Zhou et al. 2008) and could represent the nucleus of a captive assurance colony.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as it is only known from the holotype that has indistinct distribution information.
habitat: Nothing is known about the natural history of this species (Das 2010).
threats: The threats to this species remain unknown.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is only known from the original description in Java, Indonesia (Duméril and Duméril 1851) (Das 2010). The locality on Java is indistinct and not mapped (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019). There is a recent unconfirmed report from Brastagi, Sumatra (M. Kamsi pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research is needed to try to rediscover this species, and learn more about the habitat and ecology, distribution and threats.

rationale: Epinephelus chlorocephalus is known from only a single specimen (the holotype) which was collected in Tonga between 1826-1829. As such, little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a demersal species, and almost nothing is known on its ecology or biology otherwise. The single known specimen (holotype) measures 17.1 cm standard length.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from the holotype, which was collected from locals of Tongatapu by J. Quoy and P. Gaimard during the expedition of J. Dumont d'Urville conducted in 1826-1829. The absence of additional specimens is not understood.
range: This species is known only from a single oceanic island locality off Tonga in the western central Pacific. Its depth range is not known.
useTrade: If harvested, this species is probably taken solely for subsistence purposes.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Epinephelus lebretonianus is known from only one specimen with unknown provenance that was collected sometime prior to 1853. Little is known on its distribution, habitats, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No habitat information was given with the holotype.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: Population data are very limited, as this species is known from only one specimen collected sometime prior to 1853.
range: Epinephelus lebretonianus is known only from the holotype with unknown provenance (Hombron and Jacquinot 1853). It was collected during the circumglobal voyage of the “L’Astrolabe” and “La Zélée” in an attempt to find the South Pole, and is thought to have been collected somewhere in the Indo-Pacific (Heemstra and Randall 1993, Craig et al. 2011). Its depth range is not known.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is only known from two specimens collected in a single offshore locality in the Timor Sea at 142 metres depth in 1974. Little is known on its distribution, population, habitats and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species has been collected in tropical waters from the base of an oil rig at 142 metres depth. The maximum size of the two specimens collected was 15 cm total length (Randall and Allen 1987). Little is known on its habitat preferences or biology.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from two specimens collected in 1974 (Randall and Allen 1987); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species is known from only a single offshore locality: Dillon Shoals (11°05`S, 124°00`E) in the Timor Sea off northwest Western Australia. It has been collected from a depth of 142 metres (Randall and Allen 1987).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Hyporthodus perplexus is known only from a single specimen captured in 1909 in relatively deep waters off Cape Moreton in Australia. Little is known on its distribution, population, habitats and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This deep-living, demersal species is known only from the holotype collected by 'FIS Endeavour' between 128 to 137 metres depth. The absence of additional specimens may indicate that this species normally inhabits deeper waters. The total length of the holotype specimen is 56.5 cm. Little is known on its habitats and ecology.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: Hyporthodus perplexus is known only from the holotype that was collected in 1909, as such, population data are very limited.
range: Hyporthodus perplexus is known only from a single locality: northeast of Cape Moreton in southern Queensland, Australia (26° 30' S, 153° 50' E). It has been taken between 128 to 137 metres depth (Randall and Heemstra 1991).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that there is extreme uncertainty surrounding both the distribution and ecological tolerances of this species, and although the only confirmed locality lies in an area that may not be subject to major threats there has been heavy forest loss on the nearby Gunung Marapi.
habitat: The natural history of this species is poorly-known. It was reported from Fort de Kok in Bukit Tinggi. The species with which it has long been confused is widespread and adaptable, but nothing is known of the ecology of this species. The nearby Gunung Marapi consists of montane forest, but most of this has been lost due to conversion for fruit plantations
threats: Bukit Tinggi lies within a protected forest, but is a popular local weekend tourism destination and it is unknown what impact if any tourism has on this species. Hemiphyllodacylus geckos that may be referable to this species have been found in and near villages in this region (M. Kamsi pers. comm. 2019). The nearby Gunung Marapi has been deforested (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is known from a small number of specimens, and a photograph shown in Grismer et al. (2013, 2015).
range: This little-known species has been recorded from the island of Sumatra (Zug 2010). The type locality is Bukit Tinggi. Its distribution is unclear; though naming Sumatra, Zug (2010) mapped it only for a point on Borneo (where it is not known to occur), and the widespread Hemophyllodactylus typus with which this species was formerly confused is also known from Sumatra (D.T. Iskandar and A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: More surveys are needed island-wide in Sumatra for Hemiphyllodactylus geckos to help clarify the identity of records of this species following recognition of H. margarethae as a species distinct from H. typus (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Research is needed to clarify its ecology and its exposure and sensitivity to any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and has not been recorded for 25 years. Nothing is known of its true distribution, population status or ecological requirements, and while the holotype was found in agricultural land it is unknown either whether the species is able to adapt to agricultural development or whether agriculture represents an ongoing threat in this area. Nothing is known of any other potential threats to this species.
habitat: This species has been recorded among rock and brushwood piles in a cornfield situated on a mountain slope (Das 2010). It may be a forest species, but its ecology is poorly-known.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species. The holotype was taken from arable land, but nothing is known of its ecological requirements or ability to adapt to this disturbance.
population: It is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is only known from the type locality Cao Pha in Son La Province, Vietnam (Nguyen 2010).
useTrade: It is not in trade.
conservationActions: This species has not been recorded from protected area. Research is needed to clarify the distribution, population status and natural history of this species, and to identify any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has not been recorded since 1889 and nothing is known of its ecology, any wider distribution, or its exposure or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: There is no information regarding the natural history or ecology of this species (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017), although it has been reported from an upland area in Sumatra (Grismer 2011) at 1,500 m (Doria 1888). The species' close relative S. senja is terrestrial, and this species likely occurs in leaf litter on the forest floor.
threats: There is no information regarding any threats to this species (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: This species is known only from two specimens collected in 1878, and from a specimen accessioned in the Paris Natural History Museum in 1889 (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is known only from Gunung Singgalang, West Sumatra (Doria 1888, Grismer and Quah 2015), and from a record from "Sumatra" in the Field Museum taken by the original collector, presumably from the same locality (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). Reports from Malaysia have been referred to Sphenomorphus senja, and a report from Viet Nam appears to represent a misidentification of S. rufocordatus (see Grismer and Quah 2011 for a discussion).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: Research is needed to clarify the distribution, population status and ecology of this species, and determine whether it is subject to any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a nonspecific locality in Gansu and may not have been recorded for more than a century. Consequently nothing is known about the distribution, population status or natural history of this species, or of any threats.
habitat: There is no ecological information on this species, which was described more than a century.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species, which was described from a nonspecific locality.<span lang="EN-US">
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which may not have been collected since its original description.
range: There is only one record of this species, from a nonspecific locality in Gansu in China (Zhao et al. 1999).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.<span lang="EN-US">
conservationActions: No research can be recommended until this species is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from the original description, more than 90 years ago.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species.
population: There is no information available on population size or trends.
range: The holotype of this species was collected from the Washan Mountain, in Sichuan.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No research recommendations can be made until this species is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from the holotype, from a somewhat imprecise locality in the vicinity of Lake Buchanan. Although there are no known threats in this remote region, too little is presently known about its ecology to confirm that it can be considered Least Concern, and searches have failed to rediscover it.
habitat: The holotype was collected at the foot of a stony hill near Lake Buchanan. Nothing is known of the habitat at this locality or of this species' ecology.
threats: Nothing is known about threats to this species. This is a remote area and there are no known ongoing or proposed threats, however nothing is known of its ecology.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, collected in 1986.
range: This species is currently known from a single specimen from the type locality, a stony hill near Lake Buchanan in the Gibson Desert, central Western Australia (Cogger 2014, Wilson and Swan 2013). Subsequent searches have failed to record this species, although this is a difficult area to access and research has been limited.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from a protected area.

rationale: Single specimen described in 1967, no further significant information. The species is listed as Data Deficient in view of the uncertainty over its taxonomy: it may be conspecific with G. campestris.
habitat: Unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Unknown (only holotype known).
range: Known only from type locality; east coast of Tunisia (between Bou Ficha and Enfidaville).
conservationActions: No specific measures are known.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that the provenance of this species, which is known from a single 19th Century specimen, is unclear and it is consequently unknown whether it is subject to major threats.
habitat: There is no information available for the habitat of this species.
threats: The natural distribution of this species is unknown, and it is consequently impossible to identify whether any threats exist.
population: There is no population information available for this species as it is only known from one specimen collected in the late 1800s (Wilson and Swan 2013).
range: The single known specimen of this species is nominally known from "Wagga Wagga" in New South Wales in southeast Australia (Waite 1894). If this general locality is accurate, the actual collection site is thought likely to be one of two properties owned by the collector: either Lake Albert or Kerarbury Station near Narrandera (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017). It is, however, unclear whether this specimen was genuinely collected in Australia (Wilson and Swan 2013).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species, nor are any possible until further specimens are located.

rationale: Anilios erycinus has been assessed as Least Concern. It is unlikely to be affected by any significant threats, with extensive and  presumably suitable habitat available.
habitat: Little is known about the natural history of this fossorial species.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species.
population: It is known from relatively few specimens.
range: This species is endemic to New Guinea and occurs across the northern coast from the Mamberamo River in Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea east to Lae on the Huon Peninsula in Morobe Province, Papua New Guinea (McDowell 1974, O’Shea 1996). There is a record from Ningerum, in the upper Fly River basin that requires further review. It is a lowland species.
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, potential threats and conservation status. Currently this species appears to be only known from the holotype.
habitat: It is a fossorial species. Little is known about the habitats and ecology.
threats: The threats this species faces, if any, are unknown. Mining is a potential threat, but this requires confirmation.
population: It is known only from a single specimen, with nothing known about the population trend.
range: This species is only known from Koolan Island, Yampi Sound in the northern Kimberley of Western Australia (Cogger 2014). Subpopulations may be present on the adjacent mainland, but this requires confirmation.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: This species is listed as a Priority two fauna under Western Australian legislation, meaning that it is urgent need of surveys but the land it is known to occur on is not currently under threat and is being managed as conservation land (Department of Parks and Wildlife 2016). Research into threats, population size and life history are needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from a single series collected over a century ago from a small island that has not subsequently been surveyed. The island appears to have limited ongoing human activity, but it is not known whether the lack of vegetation apparent from satellite photos is natural or a consequence of habitat change, or whether - if the latter - this species still survives.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: There appears to be little natural vegetation on Sukur based on satellite images, but nothing is known of the habitat status of the island when it was collected and it is unknown whether this is the island's natural state or whether habitat loss has occurred. There appears to be only a single settlement on this island.
population: It appears to be known only from the type series of twelve specimens, which was collected in 1908.
range: This species is known only from the recently-described type series from Sukur Island, a small island north of Flores in the Lesser Sunda Islands of Indonesia (Zug and Kaiser 2014).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This is a remote island that is difficult to access and has been subject to no survey work for more than a century. Survey work is recommended to determine the history of the island and its current fauna, and genetic analysis is recommended to clarify the relationship of Carlia sukur to other C. peronii group species.

rationale: This species is known from the type specimens collected at three localities in the eastern Pacific: Point Lobos, Mexico, Gulf of California; Chacahua Bay, Mexico; and San Jose Point, Guatemala. There is currently no population information available for this species and the threats are unknown. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient until more information is known regarding its population status, habitats and ecology, and possible threats.
habitat: The habitats and ecology of this species are unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are currently unknown. However, it is probably impacted by anthropogenic stressors in the region.
population: The population status of this species is currently unknown.
range: This species is known from the type specimens collected from three localities in the eastern Pacific: Point Lobos, Mexico, Gulf of California; Chacahua Bay, Mexico; and San Jose Point, Guatemala (Wade 1946). The type specimens were collected at depths of 18-37 m (Wade 1946).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full range, population, habitats and ecology, and threats.

rationale: This species is known from 5 specimens collected by trawl at a depth of 350 m off the northeast Queensland coast. The current population status and threats to this species are unknown. Macrocephenchelys soela is listed as Data Deficient with a need for further research regarding its distribution, current population status, and possible threats.
habitat: This species is distinct from M. brachialis in having a more robust body, a more anterior dorsal origin, larger branchial aperture, a longer snout, molariform vomerine teeth, and fewer vertebrae (150–151 rather than 179–82) (Castle 1990).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: The current population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known from five specimens collected by trawl at a depth of 350 m off the northeast Queensland coast (Castle 1990, Karmovskaya 2004). It may also be found in the Philippines and New Caledonia if this species is found to be valid. This species used to be considered a synonym of Macrocephenchelys brevirostris.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation measures in place for this species. There is a need for more research concerning this species' full range, population, and threats.

rationale: This species is known from the holotype which was collected at depths between 175-337 m off Socotra Island, in the Indian Ocean. There is no population information available and current threats are unknown. Therefore, Pseudophichthys macroporis is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitats and ecology for this species are currently unknown.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is currently no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known from the holotype which was collected at depths between 175-337 m off Socotra Island, in the Indian Ocean - 11°33.9'N, 52°54'E to 11°38'N, 52°52'E (Kotthaus 1968).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this species is known only from the holotype of uncertain provenance.
habitat: There is currently no information available on the natural history of this species. It is known only from a single museum specimen deposited in 1885.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is currently known only from a single museum specimen.
range: This species was described as endemic to the island of Ambon in the Moluccas of Indonesia (Hallermann 2000). This description is based on one specimen from 1885, and there are no other members of this genus biogeographically close to Ambon. Ambon has been fairly well-surveyed, with no additional specimens found, and it seems plausible that the type locality for this species is in error, or that the holotype was an introduced animal to Ambon (Hallermann 2000, A. Stubbs and D. Iskander pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species occurs in any protected areas. It seems worth sequencing the holotype of this species to see if it matches any other species in the genus Calotes, and if so its level of divergence from those (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen. Further research to clarify its ecological requirements and exposure to any threats is needed before a more accurate assessment can be carried out, and although the island where it occurs is subject to only small-scale disturbance at present it has not been recorded for more than a century despite subsequent general surveys on this island.
habitat: Presumably this is a terrestrial species occurring in moist habitats, under stones and other ground cover.
threats: There is some farming on Simeleue, but the forest is extensive and in relatively good condition (M. Kamsi and D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019). Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known from a single specimen, apparently collected in 1913 (Das and Lim 2009), although general reptile surveys have since been conducted on Simeleue (D.T. Iskandar and M. Kamsi pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species appears to be endemic to Pulau Simeulue, in the Mentawai Archipelago of Indonesia (Das and Lim 2009).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are protected areas on Simeleue (M. Kamsi pers. comm. 2019). Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and to clarify its ecological requirements and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen collected in 1905 despite multiple recent surveys within its presumed range. Good natural forest remains in the Dawei area, however nothing is known of its habitat preferences and doubts have been raised about the true provenance of this gecko.
habitat: Information regarding this species' habitat and ecology is nonexistent. Dawei is a forested area which still retains good moist forest (G. Wogan pers. comm. 2017), but it is unclear whether this is the true collecting locality.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist to this species.
population: This species appears never to have been recorded since its original description in 1905, despite multiple recent surveys in this part of Myanmar.
range: This species is known only from Dawei, Taninthayi Divison, in Tenassarim in southern Myanmar (Das 2010). The failure to record this species for more than a century despite surveys in this area raises the possibility that the reported type locality is incorrect (L. Grismer pers. comm. 2017). L. Grismer (pers. comm. 2017) suggests that Dawei may have been the name of the collector's base, rather than the actual collection locality.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required, and no research can be proposed unless the species is rediscovered and its true provenance clarified.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from a small series of specimens collected nearly a hundred years ago, with no information on the habitat preferences, or the current threats or persistence of this species.
habitat: Little appears to have been recorded currently about the natural history of this species.
threats: Although most species in this genus are forest geckos, it is difficult to determine the threats to this very-poorly known species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019).
population: It appears that this recently described species is currently known only from the type series of four individuals (collected in 1928) (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019)
range: This species is currently known only from the type locality of Klakah, Lumajang Regency, Jawa Timur Province on the island of Java in Indonesia (Mecke et al. 2016). It was collected in the lowlands at about 200 m asl, between the Tengger and Iyang-Argapura mountain massifs (Mecke et al. 2016). It is considered to be possible that the species has a limited range, although this requires verification (Mecke et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It has been originally collected from close to Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park (Mecke et al. 2016), but it is not confirmed from here. Further research to rediscover this species is needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as essentially nothing is known about this species - described from a single specimen collected more than a century ago - and it is uncertain whether it is a valid species. If the species is valid and genuinely restricted to Mogok, the failure to detect it or any other Cyrtodactylus species in recent surveys of remnant forest in this heavily degraded area suggests that it may be highly threatened or possibly extinct. Nothing is however known of its true distribution or of its ecology.
habitat: This species was based described based on a museum specimen, which has no associated ecological information.
threats: There is very little forest remaining in Mogok, an intensely mined area. Remnant forest is wet evergreen.
population: This species is known only form the holotype with an accession number suggesting a collection in 1900 (Mahony 2009). The holotype is an immature male, raising concerns about the validity of the species (G. Wogan pers. comm. 2017). No Cyrtodactylus have been recorded from this locality in recent surveys (G. Wogan pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from Mogok (1,170 m asl), on the River Ayearwadi, north-east of Mandalay, in the Pyin Oo Lwin District, northern Myanmar. (Mahony 2009)
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas in this range. Research is needed to confirm whether this species still exists.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from three specimens and two localities and has not been reported for more than 80 years.
habitat: Nothing has been reported of this species' ecology.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known from two male and one female specimens (Doi and Kamita 1937). These appear to be the only known specimens.
range: This species was described from two localities: "Sanpoto near Ryuganpo" (=Yongamp'o) and Suiunto (=Sind-do) Island, both in northwestern Korea (now in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK)) (Doi and Kamita 1937). This description, in a little-known publication to researchers outside Japan, has subsequently been neglected and this species is largely unfamiliar to both international and Korean workers (G. Shea and A. Borzée pers. comm. 2019), and due both to its obscurity and the difficulty of surveying in DPRK this species has received little attention
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There is no information on the conservation requirements of this species. Research is needed to rediscover this species before any further studies can be proposed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from four museum specimens from non-specific locality data, none with collection dates later than 1965, and as such nothing is known of its true distribution (though, as it is known from three widely-separated localities, it may be widespread), ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: The localities named in the original description are urban areas, but these are unlikely to be the specific collection localities. As the species is known only from museum specimens, nothing is known of its ecology.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species.
population: This species was described based on four museum specimens, one with an unknown collection date and the others collected in 1927 (two specimens) and 1965 (Hikida and Zhao 1989). It appears never to have been collected or observed since its original description, and so the population status is unknown.
range: This Chinese lizard is only known from individual, widely-separated localities in three provinces: Jiangsu (Nanjing), Zhejiang (Huzhou), and Hubei (Wuhan) (Hikida and Zhao 1989, Zhao et al. 1999). The known localities all lie to the south of the Changjiang River (Hikida and Zhao 1989).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species, which is known only from museum records.<span lang="EN-US">
conservationActions: It is listed in the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife" (B. Cai pers. comm. 2018). Research is needed to obtain new material of this species and obtain data on its distributional extent, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from museum specimens collected over 90 years ago, and nothing is known of its true distribution, population status, natural history, or any threats.
habitat: This species was collected from a montane area. Hikida (1989) hypothesised that it may exhibit habitat partitioning with Plestiodon elegans, and suggest that it may be associated with forested areas on mountain slopes and that the latter species may replace it in open plateau areas.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is known only from the original description, based on two hatchlings and two embryos, all collected on the same date in either 1925 or 1926 (probably the latter) and presumably from the same clutch (Hikida 1989). This species was rarer in Pope's collection than Plestiodon elegans from the same locality, suggesting that it is either rarer or specialised in a habitat this collector did not survey as extensively (Hikida 1989).
range: This species is known only from the holotype, collected in Wu Yi mountain in Fujian (Hikida 1989). No targeted surveys have been conducted in this area.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is listed in the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife" (B. Cai pers. comm. 2018). No research can be recommended until this species is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic status, the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The natural history of this species is poorly known, it may be a fossorial forest species, with animals present under logs and amongst leaf litter (A. Diesmos pers. comm. 2007).
threats: The threats to this species are not known. The type locality has been wholly deforested.
population: It appers to be known only from the holotype, that was destroyed in the bombing of Manila in World War II.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Canlaon Volcano, Negros Island, the Philippines (Taylor 1917). It was collected at around 750 m asl.
conservationActions: This species has been recorded from the Mount Canlaon National Park. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: Further details are needed on the life history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is little information about the abundance of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines, where it ias known only from the type locality of Anuling Mountain, at the eastern tip of the Caramoan Peninsula on Luzon Island. It was collected at 150m asl (Wynn and Leviton 1993, McDiarmid et al. 1999).
conservationActions: Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats to this little-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There currently appears to be no information available on the natural history of this species. Many of the other members of the genus are fossorial forest dependent animals.
threats: It is possibly threatened by deforestation. The island of Cebu is largely limestone, with very few areas containing suitable deep soil, most of these sites have been converted to agricultural use (including the application of inorganic pesticides).
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: This species is known from a single collection (unspecified locality) from the island of Cebu in the Philippines (Savage 1950).
conservationActions: It is possible that this species is present in the Central Cebu Protected Landscape. There is a need to relocate this species and to better determine its taxonomic status.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known from only two sites and there is no information on population size and trends. Further research is needed to better establish its distribution and population status.
habitat: There is no information on habitat and ecology for this species. However, as other blind snakes, it is likely fossorial and nocturnal.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There are no data available on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species occurs in Bunyu Island,  East Kalimantan, Indonesia and Sarawak, Malaysia (FMNH 71579).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: The sites where the species has been collected from are not under protection. Further research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trends.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: While little is known about the species natural history, it is likely to be found in loose soil and leaf litter within wooded habitats. It is not known if the species can persist in modified habitats.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available on the population abundance of this species.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines, where it has been collected from the islands of Luzon, Negros and Marinduque (McDiarmid et al. 1999). The type locality is Mount Maquiling on Luzon Island.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, general ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Little is known about the habitat or ecology of this species. It may be associated with forest habitats, however, this requires confirmation. It is not known is the species can persist in disturbed or modified habitats.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is no information available on the population abundance of this species. It appears to be known from very few specimens.
range: This poorly known species is endemic to the Philippines, where it has been recorded from the islands of Luzon (including Mount Isarog), Tablas and Marinduque.
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: Very little is known about the habitat of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are currently unknown.
population: There is no information on its population size and trend, given this species is only known from few specimens (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to Sulawesi, distributed in the northeastern peninsular of the island, in Indonesia (Koch 2012; G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is likely to occur in some protected areas in the region, which still need to be confirm (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). Research needed to better understand its distribution, population, and ecology (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from the holotype and nothing is known of its distribution, natural history or any threats.
habitat: Nothing is known of the natural history of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist, although the type locality is an area historically subject to regular flooding and much of it has now been converted to rice cultivation.
population: This species is known with certainty only from the holotype (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
range: Chan-ard et al. (2015) report that this species is known only from Nonthaburi, Nonthaburi Province. Nabhitabhata et al. (2000) report it also from Phu Luang, Loei Province, Pak Chong and Dong Phaya Fai, Nakhon Ratchasima Province, but the basis for this is unclear and these authors do not report these records in an updated edition (Nabhitabhata and Chan-ard 2005). It is consequently still known with certainty only from the type locality.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There is little information available about the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Unit recent record, this species is only known from the holotype (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is probably endemic to the island of Sulawesi, Indonesia, where it has been collected in the Mekongga Mountains of Southeast Sulawesi (Koch 2012). A specimen suspected to be this species was collected recently in the central Sulawesi, at high elevation (A. Stubbs unpublished data 2019). The original record was made at 1,500 m asl (G. Shea pers. comm .2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if any populations are present in protected areas. Additional research is needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this skink.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is only known from one record, taken from an imprecise locality more than a century ago, and no enough information is available to list it in a under a different category.
habitat: No data is available on habitat preferences or ecological requirements for this species (D. Iskandar and J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017).
threats: No information is available on any threats to this species (D. Iskandar and J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017).
population: It is only known from the type description and therefore not enough information is available to determine its population trend (J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species was described from from the upper reaches of Sungai Kajan (Kajan River), Central Kalimantan Province, Borneo, Indonesia (Lidth de Jeude 1905). The specific locality on the Sungai Kajan from which the species was described cannot be determined (D.T. Iskandar and J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017).
