It has since been recorded from Ketapang, from the Seruyan River in Bukit Raya-Bukit Raya National Park in West-Central Kalimantan, and from the Katingan river on the border of Central and East Kalimantan (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: It is not utilized (S. Iskandar pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: It is unknown if this species occurs in protected areas. More research on this species' distribution, population, natural history and threats is needed (D. Iskandar and J. McGuire pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status
habitat: The one specimen was collected while digging on a mountain, at 1,700 m asl (de Lang and Vogel 2005). There is no information about the biology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not well-known.
population: It is known only from the type specimen, there is no information concerning abundance or population trends.
range: This snake is endemic to Sulawesi, Indonesia. It is known only from the type specimen collected at Mount Ilk-ile in North-Sulawei, at about 1,700 m asl (de Lang and Vogel 2005).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if any populations of this snake occur within protected areas. Further research is required to determine its distribution, population, ecology and threats (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen, and if it is genuinely from the area of Padang may now be extinct as a result of urban expansion. It is however unknown whether this provenance is correct or whether, if so, this species is genuinely restricted to this area as members of this genus are rarely recorded.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species, which was described from museum material more than a century after it was last collected. One specimen was found in the stomach of a water snake (Rhabdophis rhodomelas) (Doria and Petri 2010).
threats: Padang is an urban centre, and was a relatively large population centre when the species was collected. Members of this genus often have restricted ranges (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019) and this species may be or may have been genuinely localized around Padang. If a population survives in this area it is likely to be under pressure from continuing land conversion to support urban expansion and population growth, including attendant agricultural development (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019), and as this is a heavily populated area it is likely to be subject to persecution.
population: This species is known from three museum specimens, none collected later than 1894 (Doria and Petri 2010), although there are numerous collections from this area. An examination of a large number of museum collections of Pseudorabdion collections has not found any examples of this species (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). The description was based on very old material that included only one adult (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is so far known only from Padang, Sumatera Barat Province, Indonesia (Doria and Petri 2010). The type locality of this and other species described by these authors is in need of confirmation, as they are based on old labels associated with specimen bottles rather than the individual specimens (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and confirm that the type locality is correct (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). As this species has not been recorded since its original description it is expected to be rare and localized, but this requires confirmation.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from only two specimens, and due to historical confusion over its provenance and continuing uncertainty about the identity of the type locality nothing is known of the distribution, population status or ecology of this snake.
habitat: There is no ecological data associated with this species, although it was found close to a waterbody.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species, although the recent specimen was collected near a village.
population: This species is known only from a single specimen collected in 1890 (Doria and Petri 2010) and one in 2012 (Amarasinghe et al. in review).
range: This species is known from Sirambi, claimed to be near the southern shore of Lake Toba in Sumatra, Indonesia (Doria and Petri 2010). This is, however, an uncertain provenance as this is a common name, and examination of a specimen from Salutiwo Village near the Tiwo River in Sulawesi in the LIPI collection indicates that this is identical to the Pseudorabdion sirambense holotype (Amarasinghe et al in review). These authors consequently recommend correcting the type locality to Sulawesi (where the collection locality remains uncertain) and removing this species from the Sumatran fauna.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species' distribution remains unclear and it was only recently identified as occurring on Sulawesi rather than Sumatra, as previously assumed. Surveys are needed to clarify its distribution, population status and ecology, and any threats, and examination of museum records that may have been misidentified as species of Calamaria is recommended (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019),

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There is no ecological data available for this species. It is predicted that its habitat and ecology is similar to Pseudorabdion longiceps, associated with lowland forest (A.A.T. Amarasinghe  pers. comm. 2019).
threats: The threats for this species remain unknown.
population: This species is known from only three museum specimens, one of which has been lost, collected before 1845 (Vogel et al. 2016).
range: This species has been reported from only from Macassar, Sulawesi, Indonesia (Vogel et al. 2016). Its presence on this island has long been considered uncertain (Vogel et al. 2016) and Macassar is a port rather than a collection site. If this species genuinely occurs on Sulawesi, it may occur in a restricted area of the island (Vogel et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is no trade or use for this species.
conservationActions: Additional fieldwork, including in remote areas of Sulawesi, is needed to confirm this species' occurrence on this island and clarify its distribution (Vogel et al. 2016). Extensive research needed to better understand this genus in general (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as although this species has a very limited known range, there is no information on the natural history or potential threats to this species.
habitat: There is little available information about this snake, with virtually no natural history information. The habitat needs are not known.
threats: The threats to this poorly known species are unclear.
population: It appears to be known from very few specimens, with nothing known about the population abundance.
range: This little-known snake is endemic to Buru Island, in the Moluccas of Indonesia. It is unclear what the elevational limits are for this species.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It does not appear to have been reported from any protected areas. Substantial additional research is needed into the distribution, natural history and potential threats to this snake.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as although this species has a very limited known range, there is no information on the natural history or potential threats to this species.
habitat: There is little available information on the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this poorly known species are unclear.
population: de Lang (2013) notes that it appears to be common on Ternate. The population trend is not known.
range: This species is known only from the island of Ternate (west of Halmahera) in the Moluccas of Indonesia. it is unclear what the elevational limits are for this species.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It does not appear to have been reported from any protected areas. Substantial additional research is needed into the distribution, natural history and potential threats to this snake.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from two specimens collected 140 years ago and nothing is known of its distribution, population status, ecological requirements or any threats. The known locality appears to retain good forest, but nothing is known of any changes to the status of habitat at this site since the species was originally collected.
habitat: Nothing is known of the ecology of this species.
threats: The known locality is a public recreation area. This contains some good forest and there is no recent evidence of habitat change (based on Global Forest Watch data), but nothing is known of the elevation where specimens were collected or historical changes in habitat at the locality since this species was collected.
population: This species is known from a male and a female specimen, both collected in 1878 (Doria et al. 2013). It was described from museum material and nothing is known of its population status.
range: This species is known from Mt. Singalang in West Sumatra, Indonesia (Doria et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Surveys are needed to try and obtain new material of this species, as it has not been recorded for more than 140 years and nothing is known of its ecology. The known locality lies within the Gunung Singgalang Tandikat Nature Reserve.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this is a very poorly-known species, with no adequate information on the habitat needs or possible threats to this species.
habitat: Although this is a fossorial snake, little additional information is available on the habitat and ecology of this species (de Lang 2013).
threats: The threats to this species are not known, although there has been much forest clearance on Tidore since the collection of this species.
population: There is nothing known about the population of this species. It is only known from two syntypes.
range: This species has only been recorded from the island of Tidore (west of Halmahera) in the Moluccas of Indonesia during the 1870s (de Lang 2013, G. Shea pers. comm. 2019). It seems likely to be a lowland species.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas on Tidore. Field surveys are needed to rediscover this species, and to determine the natural history and possible threats to the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, threats, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: It is believed to inhabit open areas and rocky Cerrado savanna on the tops of plateaus and mountain ranges. The egg clutch is presumably deposited on leaves above the water, and when hatched the larvae fall into a permanent stream below.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from the holotype, so its population status is not known.
range: Caramaschi (2006) indicates that the species is only known from the Municipality of Jaboticatubas, in the Serra do Cipó, state of Minas Gerais, Brazil, associated to the Espinhaço mountain range.
conservationActions: It is not known if it occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic status.
habitat: Its habitat and ecological requirements are not known, although it is presumed to breed in water.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Its population status is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of "Sénégal: mare de Bata (Sahel de Nioro)" (Chabanaud 1919). The Bata marsh is actually in Mali, not Senegal. The distribution of this species cannot be mapped as it has not been possible to specifically locate Bata marsh.
useTrade: There is no information on use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if it occurs in protected areas. Research is needed on its taxonomy, distribution and population status, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on its habitat and ecology. It presumably breeds in water and develops via a free-living, aquatic larval stage.
threats: Nothing is known about specific threats to this species.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the Tingi Hills in Sierra Leone. It is probably related to the Amietophrynus latifrons complex, and might not be a valid species.
useTrade: There is no information on use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Research is needed into its taxonomy, population and distribution, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: This species is considered to be Data Deficient, owing to limited information about its habitat type and the threats to the species, most especially from increased fire frequency.
habitat: This species has been recorded from narrow sandy dry stream-beds. It is a little-known leaf-litter species.
threats: The threats to this species are not well-known. It may be threatened in its small range by frequent fires, due to its apparent association with leaf litter, and it is suspected that these may lead to population declines over a long period.
population: This species is known from only a few specimens within a restricted area.  The population trend is not known.
range: This species is known from the Bungle Bungle Range in the Kimberley region of Western Australia (Cogger 2014).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is listed as priority two fauna by the Department of Parks and Wildlife in Western Australia meaning it occurs on lands managed for conservation and is in urgent need of further survey work (Department of Parks and Wildlife 2016). Additional research is needed to better determine if any threats are significantly impacting this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing problems with its taxonomy as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements, and threats.
habitat: The holotype of this species was found in litter among sand at the base of a cliff (Cogger 2014).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. It may be potentially impacted by the introduction of invasive species, however, the possible threat caused by these requires additional research.
population: As this species is known from only a single individual, information relating to population trends is unavailable.
range: This species is currently known from a single specimen (and two unconfirmed sightings) from King Hall Island of the Kimberley region of Western Australia (Cogger 2014), however, uncertainty exists as to whether this was an aberrant individual of Lerista griffini (Maryan and Robinson 1997).
useTrade: There is no information available relating to the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place for this species, and it is unknown if it occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and has not been recorded since its description despite targeted surveys. The area where this species was found is close to a homestead and the species may be genuinely localized and possibly at risk from habitat degradation, or alternatively either restricted but tolerant of this disturbance or more widespread and less likely to be subject to major threats.
habitat: While no specific information is available relating to the habitat and ecology of this species, it is likely similar to that of other members of the genus Lerista. Members of this genus are typically burrowing species which are usually found in loose soil or sand beneath stones, logs, termite mounds, and similar ground cover (Cogger 2014). The sole known specimen was apparently found on heavy clay soils (H. Butler pers. comm. to R. Lloyd)
threats: Habitat destruction may be a significant threat to this species if it has a genuinely restricted distribution, however nothing is known of its true distribution or of specific threatening processes. The known locality is likely to be a pastoral area, as it is close to a homestead.
population: There is only a single known specimen of this species, taken in 1980 (Maryan et al. 2015). Multiple people have visited the type locality, conducting fairly intensive targeted searches without rediscovering this species (R. Ellis pers. comm. 2017).
range: This Australian endemic species was described based on one specimen (Maryan et al. 2015) found 25 km south of Karratha Station, Western Australia (Wilson and Swan 2013, Cogger 2014).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is currently listed as a 'Priority One: Poorly known species (on threatened land) (P1)" species in the Pilbara region of Western Australia under the Threatened Fauna (Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Conservation (Specially Protected Fauna) Notice 2014 (Department of Parks and Wildlife 2014). Maryan et al. (2015) report that in spite of its conservation status, no research has been undertaken with respect to this species, which may be among one of Australia's rarest vertebrates. These authors also suggest that it might be extinct. Research is urgently recommended to obtain additional specimens, as the known locality is likely to be subject to some degree of habitat degradation.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: While no specific information is available relating to the habitat and ecology of this species, it is likely similar to that of the genus Lerista. Members of this genus are typically burrowing species which are usually found in loose soil or sand beneath stones, logs (Cogger 2014).
threats: There don't appear to be any threats currently, however the species has a restricted range and may be vulnerable to future habitat degradation (for instance if cattle grazing is introduced).
population: There is no information available relating to population trends for this species. It is known only from a few specimens from a small number of collecting events. Probably a stable population, but this requires confirmation.
range: This Australian endemic species is known from only one locality on the edge of the St Georges Ranges (Wilson and Swan 2013) in the arid southern interior of the Kimberley region, Western Australia (Storr 1990, Cogger 2014). The surrounding area has not been adequately surveyed to locate additional populations.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: This species is currently listed as a 'Priority One: Poorly known species (on threatened land) (P1)" in the Pilbara region of Western Australia under the Threatened Fauna (Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Conservation (Specially Protected Fauna) Notice 2014) (Department of Parks and Wildlife, 2014). By definition of the 'P1' listing, it is unlikely that this species occurs in any protected areas. Urgent further study of this species is recommended.

rationale: The Red Sea Torpedo (Torpedo suessii) has not been recorded since its original collection in 1898. It is known only from a very small area (estimated to be <100 km²) off Mocha, Yemen in the southern Red Sea. It has not been recorded in landing site surveys in adjacent countries such as the Saudi Arabian Red Sea and Sudan, or in underwater survey work in Saudi Arabia. Artisanal and industrial fisheries are ongoing and intense in Yemeni waters, and illegal fishing is a serious issue. Industrial fishing commenced in 1970 and overall Yemen Red Sea catches have undergone a major decline from a peak in the late 1990s. While electric rays are generally not utilized, survival of bycatch is very low. Due to a very limited extent of occurrence, presence in only one location, and an ongoing decline inferred from intensive and ongoing fishing, the species is assessed as Critically Endangered under criterion B1ab(v). Given that it has not been recorded for nearly 120 years (this species has a distinct colour pattern and is very recognisable), it is considered Possibly Extinct.
habitat: Specific details of this species' habitat and depth range are unknown. This species is known to reach at least 29 cm total length (Carvalho et al. 2002).
threats:
Industrial and artisanal trawl fisheries operate off Yemen (Morgan 2006, Tesfamichael et al. 2012). Industrial fishing commenced in 1970 with a peak in catches in the late 1990s, and a decline by the end of the 2000s (Tesfamichael et al. 2012). Illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) is a major issue in Yemen (Alabsi and Komatsu 2014).

This species has not been seen in landings in adjacent areas such as the Saudi Arabian Red Sea or Sudan. The sluggish benthic nature of electric rays make them susceptible to trawl capture and survivorship of discarded electric rays at sea is low.
population: Population size is unknown but is likely very small given that the species has only been recorded from one location off Yemen. The species has not been recorded since its original description in 1898 (Steindachner 1898). Further research is needed in order to determine whether the species is still extant.
range: The Red Sea Torpedo is endemic to the Arabian Seas region, and is known only from the southern Red Sea at Mocha, Yemen (Steindachner 1898, Carvalho et al. 2002). While Carvalho et al. (2002) suggests that a photo provided from the Sudanese Red Sea is thought to be of the Red Sea Torpedo, the photo evidence is not convincing and the species is here considered to be known only off Yemen.
useTrade: No utilization or commercial trade of this species is currently known to exist. Electric rays are usually discarded at sea.
conservationActions: Currently there are no conservation actions in place that might benefit this species in the waters it which it occurs. An urgent assessment of the status of the species is required, particularly through underwater and landings surveys in the area of original collection.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because its distribution, abundance, trend, and threats are too poorly known to allow the species to be placed in another category.
habitat: There is little information on the habitat and ecology of this species. However, like other members of its genus, it is probably associated with streams and waterfalls in montane forest. The eggs are carried on the back of the female, where they develop directly without a larval stage.
threats: There is no information about threats affecting the species. However, the region where this species occurs has been severely affected by mining for salt production, and all possible suitable remaining habitat for this taxon has been destroyed at the type locality. But there is suitable habitat north and south of the type locality (J. Carvajal-Cogollo pers. comm. March 2017).
population: This species is only known from the holotype that was collected in the 1940s. Surveys prior to 2004 in the region of the type locality did not produced any individuals. There have been no surveys between 2004 and this reassessment at the type locality, due to ongoing armed conflict which has recently ceased in the area. There are plans to visit the type locality and near areas in the second half of 2017 (J. Carvajal-Cogollo and F.L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. March 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality of La Salina, Casanare Department, Colombia, at 1,450 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 75 km2.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Conservation recommendations are pending following future surveys and once the population status of the species and habitat requirements are determined (F.L. Meza-Joya pers. comm. March 2017).

Research Needed
Additional survey work is urgently required to determine whether or not it still survives in the wild. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Further taxonomic research is also needed to ascertain the true genus that it should be assigned to [either Hyloscirtus or Cryptobatrachus] (J. Carvajal-Cogollo pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient, in view of the lack of information about its population, habitat requirements and the threats it faces on Bangka.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat requirements and ecology of this species, however, the description of T. glis with which it was previously synoymised said that it was usually found in primary dipterocarp forest, thought tolerant to some degree of habitat modification, as it was recorded from secondary forest, plantations, fruit orchards and trees near housing areas (K. H. Han pers. comm. 2008).
threats: Extensive tin mining on Bangka Island has caused habitat disturbance, damage to natural drainage, and pollution (Nurtjahya et al. 2009). When this species was previously synonymised with T. glis the major threats to T. glis were listed as severe deforestation due to conversion for agriculture and plantations, and commercial logging, although the species can adapt to a degree of habitat modification.
population: There is no information about the population of this species.
range: This species is found on Bangka Island off the east coast of Sumatra, Indonesia (Sargis et al. 2013).
conservationActions: It is not found in any protected areas.

rationale: Syngnathus caspius is a coastal pipefish that is likely endemic to the Caspian Sea. Little is known about the species, and further taxonomic work is needed to confirm its validity. If valid, further research is needed to determine distribution, habitats and ecology, population size and trends, and threats. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known about this species' biology. Other pipefishes tend to feed on small benthic and/or planktonic crustaceans (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). Members of this genus typically are ovoviviparous and the males give birth to live young after brooding the eggs under their tail (Breder and Rosen 1967).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. Synganthid species are often threatened by being caught as bycatch and habitat loss (Vincent et al. 2011), but further research is needed.
population: This species is known from only a few specimens. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance.
range: Syngnathus caspius is endemic to the Caspian Sea (Esmaeili et al. 2017).
useTrade: This species has not been noted in trade. Other pipefishes are often targeted and/or caught as bycatch and sold as curios, aquarium pets, and traditional medicines (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species, and it is  not mentioned in any international legislation. Further research on  distribution, habitats, life history traits, threats, and population  size and trends is needed.

rationale: Synganthus chihiroe is a newly described coastal pipefish that inhabits the East China Sea near Yakushima Island, Japan. It is only known from the type specimen and very little is known about its habitats and ecology, population size and trends, and threats. Further research is needed in order to properly assess the conservation status of this species. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitats and ecology of this newly described species are poorly known. The type specimen was collected from 160-162 m depth (Matsunuma 2017). Other pipefish species tend to feed on planktonic crustaceans such as gammarid and caridean shrimp and harpacticoid and cyclopoid copepods (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). Members of this genus are typically ovoviviparous, and males give birth to live young after brooding the eggs beneath their tail (Breder and Rosen 1967).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. Synganthid species are often threatened by being caught as bycatch and habitat loss (Vincent et al. 2011), but further research is needed.
population: This species is only known from the holotype specimen. Further research is needed in order to determine populations size, structure, and trends in abundance.
range: Syngnathus chihiroe is a recently described species that is only known from its type locality off Yakushima Island in the East China Sea (Matsunuma 2017).
useTrade: This species has not been noted in trade. Other pipefishes are often targeted and/or caught as bycatch and sold as curios, aquarium pets, and traditional medicines (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species, and it is not mentioned in any international legislation. Further research on distribution, habitats, life history traits, threats, and population size and trends is needed.

rationale: Hippocampus casscsio is a recently described coastal seahorse that inhabits waters around Hainan, China and Beibu Bay/the Gulf of Tonkin. It may be threatened by being caught as bycatch in trawl fisheries. Further research is needed in order to establish the full distribution of the species and to determine which seahorses are present and caught in the area. This species' habitats, ecology, population size and trends, and threats are poorly known. Therefore H. casscsio is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat:
This species inhabits shallow coastal waters to 15 m depth (Zhang et al. 2016). Little else is known about their habitat. It likely consumes small benthic and/or planktonic crustaceans such as harpacticoid and cyclopoid copepods, gammarid shrimps, and mysids (Woods et al. 2002, Kendrick and Hyndes 2005, Kitsos et al. 2008, Yip et al. 2015, Valladares et al. 2016).

Like all seahorses, they are ovovivparous and females transfer eggs to the male’s brood pouch where the embryos are nurtured prior to live birth (Foster and Vincent 2004). All seahorse species also have vital parental care, and many species studied to date have high site fidelity (e.g., Perante et al. 2002), highly structured social behaviour (e.g., Vincent and Sadler 1995), and relatively sparse distributions (Lourie et al. 1999).
threats: This species is likely caught as bycatch in trawl fisheries (Vincent et al. 2011), but this has not been recorded or quantified to date. Further research on the species' habitat is needed to determine whether other threats are also present.
population: This species is known only from its original description and there have been no population estimates to date. The range needs to be better delineated in order to carry out population surveys.
range: Hippocampus casscsio was described from off the coast of Hainan, China and from sites around Beibu Bay/the Gulf of Tonkin (Zhang et al. 2016). Further research is required to delineate the full extent of this species' range.
useTrade: Seahorses in general are targeted and/or caught as bycatch and subsequently traded internationally for use in aquariums, as curios, and in traditional medicines (Vincent et al. 2011). Research is needed to determine how this species is used and traded.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hippocampus casscsio. The species is included along with all other seahorses on CITES Appendix II. Further research is needed to determine distribution, ecology, population size and trends in abundance, and threats for this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from four specimens across a wide area, none collected more recently than 1940, and nothing is known of the true distribution, population status or natural history of this species, whether it is subject to any threats, and whether all four specimens correspond to the same species.
habitat: There is no detailed ecological information available for this species, which is known from early 20th century records, but it is characterized as a species of the "Southern rim of the Congo Basin" on zoogeographic grounds by Broadley and Cotterill (2004). The area of Katanga on which these authors focused, and from which most specimens have been taken, exhibits a high diversity of forest, savanna, rocky and wetland habitats, and as such the exact habitat preferences of this species are unclear.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known from very few specimens (only four as of Broadley and Cotterill 2004, the most recent with an accession date of 1940), but potentially has a stable population within the known range.
range: This species is known from at four widely-separated records: two from Shaba Province in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (described as Ablepharus seydeli and A. moeruensis), and two from northern Zambia (one of which was described as A. anselli) (Broadley and Cotteril 2004). No records are known from areas between these localities (Largen and Spawls 2006).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to rediscover this species and clarify its distribution and population status, and to clarify whether the four disjunct records assigned to Panaspis seydeli all represent the same species.

rationale: Cyrtodactylus feae is listed as Data Deficient as there is little information on its range, life history, abundance, or threats. More research is needed on this species, particularly with regard to its distribution.
habitat: Based upon its distribution this species may inhabit evergreen forest in the region, but this is not certain. Das (2010) recorded that it inhabits submontane forests at elevations of 975 - 1,036 m asl., although this appears to be an inference from the natural habitat in this region rather than based on observational evidence.
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by any major threats. Forest in the area of the type locality appears to be in good condition, based on observations from forest workers who have recently been able to visit the region (Kyi Soe Lwin pers. comm. 2017).
population: This area has not been accessible for recent surveys, and as a result no recent records exist. The species may not have been recorded since its original description.
range: The distribution of this species is unclear. The type was collected from Puepoli, Karin Bia-po at around 1,100 m above sea level; its range may possibly include the Karin Hills in Myanmar and adjacent Thailand (G. Zug pers. comm. 2008). Das (2010) suggest it is endemic to southern Myanmar. A checklist report of this species from Thailand (Nabhitabhata et al. 2000) may represent confusion with C. tigroides (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). Sharma (2002) reports this species from India, although no other sources corroborate this and this is considered to be in error (G. Wogan pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into its range and abundance, habitat requirements and threats is needed. Until recently this area was inaccessible due to rebel activity and the presence of land mines, but the area is becoming more open and surveys are recommended (G. Wogan and Kyi Soe Lwin pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: There is a need for additional survey work on Mount Gede to determine the true distribution of this species and understand its habitat preferences. Its apparent restricted distribution could mean that it is threatened by habitat loss. Until more surveys are conducted, information is too limited to ascertain a conservation status for this species, therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little information available about the ecology and habitat preferences of this species, however, habitats within its range primarily consist of lower and upper montane and subalpine forests.
threats: The major threat is likely to be habitat loss, which has been extensive in many areas of Java, however, not enough is known about this species habitat preference to be certain of its level of impact.
population: There is nothing known about the population of this species.
range: C. absconditus has a restricted distribution, known only from the Mount Gede–Pangrango area of West Java, where it was found at an elevation of 1,611 m asl. (Esselstyn et al. 2014). Surveys of surrounding mountains in West and Central Java have failed to locate this species (Esselstyn et al. 2013).
conservationActions: This species is distributed within the boundaries of the Gunung Gede-Pangrango National Park.

rationale: Acanthurus albimento is newly described from isolated records in the Philippines. As such, it is considered extremely data poor. Little is known of the full distribution, ecology, population and potential threats. The type specimens were collected from a fish market, so it is actively fished, but the extent of its use is unknown. This species is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is an extremely data-poor species, with very little available information on species-specific life history and ecology. It is currently known to attain a standard length of 25.2 cm (Carpenter et al. 2017).
threats: Threats to this species are currently unknown. The type specimens were collected in a fish market, meaning that this species is actively fished.
population: This species has only very recently been described, and as such, there are no population data available at this time.
range: This species has only been recorded at, and is thus deemed endemic to, the Philippines. It is known from six specimens found in northeastern Luzon, though there remains some uncertainty as to its true range (Carpenter et al. 2017). As the only known specimens have been collected at fish markets, the depth distribution is currently unknown.
useTrade: There is no information on the use and trade of this species, but it was found in a fish market in the Philippines.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: The lanternbelly Acropoma boholensis is known from only two specimens collected from a fish market in Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental, the Philippines. There is very little information on this species' distribution, population size or life history characteristics. The type specimens were collected from a fish market, so it is actively fished, but the extent of its use is unknown. This species is therefore listed as Data Deficient. Research on its distribution, habitats and ecology, as well as monitoring on its capture and trade, is recommended.
habitat: The only known specimens were collected from the Dumaguete fish market, so the habitat and depth distribution of this species are unknown. Congeners are bottom-dwelling carnivores inhabiting deeper waters, 100-500 m (e.g., A. japonicus: Okuda et al. 2005), and it may be inferred that this species is similar. The maximum recorded size is 13.2 cm standard length (Yamanoue and Matsuura 2002).
threats: Threats to this species are currently unknown. The type specimens were collected in a fish market, meaning that this species is actively fished.
population: It is only known from two specimens and no population information is available at this time.
range: This species is known only from the Bohol Sea, near Negros Oriental, central Visayas (Yamanoue and Matsuura 2002). As the only known specimens have been collected at fish markets, the depth distribution is currently unknown; however, congeners inhabit deeper waters, 100-500 m (e.g., A. japonicum: Okuda et al. 2005).
useTrade: There is no information on the use and trade of this species, but it was found in a fish market in the Philippines.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Xenaploactis anopta is a relatively deep-living species known from only a single specimen captured in 1966. Little is known of its distribution, ecology, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a benthic species that is relatively deep-living. The type specimen measured 3.7 cm total length (Poss and Eschmeyer 1980).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from only a single specimen captured in 1966 (Poss and Eschmeyer 1980); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species is known from only a single specimen, taken off Luzon Island, 4 km west of Calaguaguin Cove, Zambales, Philippines. It was captured between 64 and 81 m depth (Poss and Eschmeyer 1980).
useTrade: This species is not utilised.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Cocotropus roseomaculatus is a marine species known from a single specimen collected in the waters of Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa. Information relating to its population size and trends, life history and ecology as well as threats are extremely limited. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for it. Therefore this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species has only very limited available information relating to its life history and ecology. The captured specimen was measured at 2.9 cm standard length.
threats: There are no known threats to this species, however, given that this species is only known from a single specimen, it is difficult to assess threats to it with any accuracy.
population: This species is known only from its type specimen, identified and recorded in 2004.
range: Cocotropus roseomaculatus is known from a single specimen collected in the waters of Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa, Western Indian Ocean (Imamura and Shinohara 2004).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Ostorhinchus radcliffei is known from only three specimens captured sometime prior to 1918 at an unspecified locality in the Philippines, probably near Manila. Little is known on its distribution, ecology, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a benthic species, but the depth distribution is unknown. The largest type specimen measured 9 cm total length (Fowler 1918).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from only three specimens collected sometime prior to 1918 (Fowler 1918); as such, little is known about its population.
range: This species is known from only three specimens from the Philippines (probably near Manila), collected at an unknown depth (Fowler 1918).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized; however, if it is caught, it is likely to be marketed or consumed.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Ostorhinchus wilsoni is known from a single specimen captured sometime prior to 1918 at an unspecified locality in the Philippines, probably near Manila. Little is known on its distribution, ecology, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a benthic species, but the depth distribution is unknown. The type specimen measured 7.2 cm total length (Fowler 1918).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from only one specimen collected sometime prior to 1918 (Fowler 1918); as such, little is known about its population.
range: This species is known from only one specimen from the Philippines (probably near Manila) at an unknown depth (Fowler 1918).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized; however, if it is caught, it is likely to be marketed or consumed.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Parviparma straminea is known from only two specimens collected prior to 1932 in the Philippines. The holotype was presumably destroyed during the Battle of Manila during World War II. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats. This species is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little to no habitat and life history information available for this species. The holotype was collected from a freshwater stream (Herre 1927), and habitat information is not available for the only other known specimen. The holotype measured 6.5 cm standard length (Herre 1927). It is not known if this species is an estuarine or freshwater fish.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: The only known specimens were collected prior to 1932 (Herre 1927, FishNet2 portal, Accessed: March 2017); as such, little is known on its population.
range: Parviparma straminea is known from only two specimens from the Philippines: the Saug River, Cotabato Province, Mindanao (Herre 1927) and Aparri, Cagayan Province, northern Luzon (FishNet2 portal, Accessed: March 2017). Depth distribution information is not available at this time.
useTrade: No use and trade information is available for this species.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: Nuchequula flavaxilla was recently described from the Philippines, with additional photographic records from Indonesia. Specimens were collected from fish markets, indicating that this species has some commercial value, and leiognathids are commercially important in the Philippines. However, there is very little information on its life history, harvest levels and population trends. Given the geographic range extending from the Philippines to Indonesia, this species is likely much more widely distributed than records indicate. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Very little species-specific information is known about this recently described species. The maximum reported size is 10.9 cm standard length (Kimura et al. 2008).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown. It is exploited and marketed, but effects on the population have not been documented at this time.
population: Population data are limited for this species. It is likely harvested throughout its range, but reported as aggregated leiognathid landings in the Philippines and Indonesia.
range: This species is recorded to occur in waters off Panay Island, western Visayas, the Philippines (Kimura et al. 2008). This species was also reported during surveys of fish landings centers in East Java (Wiadnya et al. 2014). Almost all specimens were reported from fish markets, and given these widely spaced localities, it is likely that this species is more broadly distributed than current records indicate.
useTrade: This species is utilized as a fisheries resource, given that almost all specimens were collected from fish markets, and thus has commercial value. Harvest level, however, is not known.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Its distribution overlaps with marine protected areas in parts of its range (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2017).

rationale: Liparis fishelsoni is a marine, demersal species that is endemic to the Red Sea and known only from its holotype. Information relating to the population, life-history and ecology as well as potential threats are not available at this time. There is no use and trade information for it and no species-specific conservation measures are currently in place, though parts of its range do overlap with marine protected areas. This specie is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Liparis fishelsoni is a marine, demersal species. Information relating to the life history and ecology of this species is extremely limited. This is the only species known in this family to occupy shallow warm waters (Stein et al. 2001).
threats: This species is only known from its holotype and as such assessing threats to it is very difficult.
population: This species is only known from its holotype and as such population information for it does not currently exist.
range: Liparis fishelsoni is endemic to the Red Sea (Chernova et al. 2004, Golani and Bogorodsky 2010). This species is known to exist to depths of 25-30 m (Chernova 2008).
useTrade: There are no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place, though parts of its range overlap with marine protected areas (IUCN-UNEP 2017).

rationale: This species is known from only two specimens collected from an aquarium supply in the Philippines sometime prior to 2008. Little is known on its distribution, ecology, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a benthic species. The largest type specimen measured at 8.4 cm total length (Randall and Suzuki 2008).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is known from only two specimens collected sometime prior to 2008 (Randall and Suzuki 2008); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species is known from only two specimens collected from an aquarium fish store in Manila, Luzon, Philippines (Randall and Suzuki 2008). As such, the distribution of this species is unknown.
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized, however, if it is caught it is likely to be marketed or consumed.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. We recommend further research on this species distribution, population status and basic biology.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen collected in 1885 from an area that is not accessible for surveys.
habitat: There are no data on the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats exist.
population: The only known collection of the species was in 1885 from Tragbul Pas, presently in the politically disputed region between India and Pakistan (fide Das et al. 1998).
range: This species is known only from a historical record from Tragbul Pass, about 50 km northwest of Srinagar in Kashmir, at an elevation of 2,700 m asl (Alcock 1898, Das et al. 1998).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to rediscover this species before any further research or conservation can be proposed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species appears to be known only from historical records from a single area of Inner Mongolia, its validity is uncertain, and nothing is known of its full distribution, population status, natural history or any threats.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species, which is known only from the holotype despite subsequent surveys at and around the type locality (Orlova et al. 2017).
range: This species is only known from A La San Desert, Inner Mongolia.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: More research is needed to clarify the validity of this species and to obtain data on its distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, given it is a rare species with presumably small population size, which might be effected by habitat degradation easily. More research is needed to determine its actual threat status.
habitat: <span lang="EN-US">This species has been found on upper walls of buildings, but its ecological requirements and natural habitat are poorly-known.
threats: It is unclear whether any threats to this species exist, although the habitat quality is degrading due to unknown reasons.
population: It is a rare species, and the total population is presumed to be small (J. Yan pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to Taibai Mountain Range in Shaanxi, China. It occurs at elevations from 900–1,600 m asl.
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is listed in the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife" (B. Cai pers. comm. 2018).

rationale: Although it appears to be locally common at the type locality, there is nothing known regarding its distribution, habitats, and threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The natural ecology of this species is unknown. The type locality is a village.
threats: It is unclear what threats may exist to this species, as neither its natural habitat nor its ecological tolerances are known. Since the known population lies in a village, habitat quality may be deteriorating due to urban development and pesticide use (J. Yan pers. comm. 2019) but any impacts on this species is unknown.
population: It appears to be locally common.
range: This species is found at Danbao Village on the south slope of the west Qinling Mts China, Wenxian County, Gansu Province, China (Zhou and Wang 2018).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use of or trade in this island.
conservationActions: Research is needed regarding this species' distribution, habitat requirements, and threats.

rationale: Festucalex armillatus is a coastal pipefish species that inhabits waters around southern Hainan, China. The species is only known from three type specimens. It may be threatened by targeted and/or bycatch fisheries, but this has not been confirmed. Further research and monitoring on habitat, population size and trends, and threats is needed in order to determine the conservation status of this species. Therefore Festucalex armillatus is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat of Festucalex armillatus is unknown, but other pipefishes tend to live in the shallow photic zone (0-50 m depth). Pipefishes typically feed on small planktonic or benthic crustaceans such as gammarid shrimps, mysids, and harpacticoid copepods (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). They are ovoviviparous, and males carry the embryos in a brood area under their tail prior to giving live birth (Dawson 1985).
threats: This species is likely taken as bycatch in trawl fisheries and may be targeted for the aquarium and/or traditional medicine trades (Vincent et al. 2011). Bycatch may add up to a large offtake even if individual vessels catch low numbers of the species (Lawson et al. 2017).
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for this species. It is known from three type specimens collected in 1959-1960 (Prokofiev 2016).
range: Festucalex armillatus is known only from the type locality in Sanya, southern Hainan, China (Prokofiev 2016).
useTrade: Although Festucalex armillatus has not specifically been found in trade, other pipefishes are traded for use in the aquarium trade, traditional medicine, and as curios (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved but levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into habitat, population size and trends, and threats is needed in order to determine whether conservation actions are necessary. Population and trade monitoring are needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Little is known about the habitat or ecology of this species, however the vegetation at Medje is a mosaic of rainforest and savannah (Kingdon et al. 2013).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known. It is known only from the holotype.
range: Crocidura polia has only been recorded from Medje in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In 1916, Hollister described a set of six species, one of which was C. polia. Five of these were not found again until surveys by A. Dudu and colleagues, while C. polia has yet to be rediscovered.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, general ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: This shrew is known only from a very restricted area, but may range more widely. There is no information available regarding extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, population size or population trends so the species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a poorly known species, with no information available on its specific habitat requirements.
threats: Threats affecting this species are not known at present.
population: This species is only known from type series. There is no information on population size or trend.
range: This species has only been recorded from Dezful, Khuzistan province, southwest Iran, but it may range more widely.
conservationActions: No specific conservation measures are known to be in place for this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its status and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information available on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. It may be vulnerable due to its seemingly quite restricted range and changes to habitats within its known distribution, for example, there have been an increase in the area of bare soil and agriculture in Angola between 1990 and 2009 (Cabral et al. 2009).
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: This species is found in western Angola, where it ranges from Duque de Braganca in the north to Huila in the south (Heim de Balsac and Meester 1977). The type specimen was found at an elevation of 1,098 m asl (at Pungo Andongo).
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. The species has not been recorded from any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, general ecology and threats to this little-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its distribution, status, threats, and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The major threat to this species is considered to be human-induced habitat loss and degradation (Kingdon et al. 2013).
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: Crocidura macowi is only known from its type locality on Mount Nyiro, south of Lake Turkana, Kenya.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. The species has not been recorded from any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, general ecology and threats to this little-known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population sizes, status and ecological requirements.
habitat: Other than being a montane species, little is known about the natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: Crocidura pitmani is known from central and northern Zambia. The type locality for this species is uncertain but is thought to be the Maluwe-Sarengi district.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, breeding biology and general ecology of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: C. zimmeri is a large shrew and one of the most distinctive of the Crocidura species. There is little natural history information available for this species. The Upemba National Park largely consists of wetlands, and the species is thought to be associated with these habitat types.
threats: This species may be threatened by gold and diamond mining in Bakama. In the Upemba National Park there are major threats to the area including from agriculture expansion, from burning, and over fishing in many areas (Timberlake and Chidumayo 2001).
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: Crocidura zimmeri is a very distinct species from Katanga Province, southern Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is known only from Upemba National Park. It was described in 1936 when two specimens were collected but has not been collected or seen again. However, this area has not been thoroughly sampled since its discovery and it is possible that further surveys may provide new records. It is thought to occur at an altitude of approximately 600-700 m asl.
conservationActions: This species occurs in Upemba National Park, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this little known species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species is known only from a few specimens from the type locality. More information on extent of occurrence, population status and habitat requirements is needed before an assessment can be completed.
habitat: It has only been captured in a bamboo clump in the Zoological Gardens. The dentition of this species suggests that it could be insectivorous (Nowak 1999).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The population abundance of this species is not known, and only a few specimens have been collected. It is an extremely difficult species to trap.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of the type locality, in the Zoological Garden of Brazzaville, in the Congo, at around 300 m asl (Petter 1966).
conservationActions: The species occurs in the Zoological gardens which are protected, but it must also occur elsewhere. Further research to establish the species' range, population status and habitat requirements is urgently needed.

rationale: This species is recorded only from a small area in the Alai Mtns, South Kyrgyzstan. Very little is known about this species' distribution, population size and trends, or potential threats hence is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Poorly studied species. Habitat and ecology is possibly similar to that of Ellobius tancrei. The predominant vegetation in the Alai mountain range is high mountain meadow steppe and mountain forest meadow steppe (Jansky and Pachova 2006).
threats: The threats to the species are unknown, however the mountain ecosystems and resources in the vicinity of settlements in the Alai Mountains have been severely degraded, with land use dominated by subsistence-agriculture and animal herding (Jansky and Pachova 2006). Degeneration of alpine steppe vegetation at elevations of 3,100 to 3,400 m asl has been observed within Kyrgyzstan (Arase et al. 2013). Climate change predictions state that steppe, shrubland and forest ecosystems in Kyrgyzstan are likely to become significantly degraded (Lioubimtseva 2004).
population: Unknown.
range: Recorded only from the Alai Mountains, South Kyrgyzstan, at an elevation of 3,300 m asl (Musser and Carleton 2005).
conservationActions: None known. Need further study of habitat and ecology and necessary conservation measures.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of information on its extent of occurrence, threats, status, and ecological requirements. It is only known from three specimens. The island of New Britain is heavily deforested due to logging and planting of oil palms, but it is not clear if this affects the species. The extent of occurrence is probably less than 20,000 km² (and less than the mapped range, which includes all of New Britain Island). Surveys are needed to determine the range and population status of this species.
habitat: It is a lowland species. Like other Hydromys species, it is associated with streams, rivers, or other wetland habitats.
threats: It is thought to be a lowland species, therefore deforestation in these areas could post a threat. Analysis of data from New Britain suggests 12% of forest cover was lost between 1989 and 2000, including over 20% of forest under 100m altitude, with substantial areas cleared for commercial oil palm plantations (Buchanan et al. 2008) and also logging and small-scale agriculture (Shearman et al. 2009). It is also predited that if current rates of deforestation continue, then all forest at altitudes under 200m will have been cleared by 2060 (Buchanan et al. 2008). Wetland habitats across the region. and the native species associated with them. are often threatened by introduced species and the downstream effects of mining and land clearance (Ellison 2009).
population: It is known from only three specimens.
range: This species is endemic to the island of New Britain in the Bismarck Archipelago of Papua New Guinea. It may also occur on the island of Umboi, but surveys are needed to confirm this. Elevation ranges from sea level to 500 m asl.
conservationActions: The urgency of establishing and effectively managing protected areas in suitable lowland forests of New Britain has been highlighted (Buchanan et al. 2008). Further studies into the distribution, natural history, and threats to this species are needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it has not been recorded since it was first described, but there have been limited directed surveys for this species using appropriate trapping methodologies at the type locality and in neighbouring areas. More research is needed to determine the species' extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements before an assessment can be made.
habitat: The type locality is in the forest zone. The dentition and stomach contents point to a partially insectivorous diet the short tail suggests a terrestrial life style (D. Kock pers. comm). Nothing else is known of habits or habitat.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, although West African rainforests in general are under threat from forest loss and degradation, with around 80% of the original forest area covered by agriculture-forest mosaic (Norris et al. 2010). Hunters interviewed in Ghana said that their activities had negatively affected a number of species including Leimacomys buettneri.
population: The abundance of this species is not known. The species has not been recorded since it was first described. There have not been surveys using appropriate techniques, hence it is difficult to draw any conclusions because of the poor capture rate.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Bismarckburg, Togo. The locality name has since changed from Bismarckburg to Adele (Petrozzi et al. 2014). It probably also occurs in Ghana (Awuah-Nyamekye 2014). The elevational range is not known. Leimacomys was first collected by R. Büttner or his local assistant in 1890 and the locality given as Bismarckburg, which was the colonial district headquarter located east of the modern town of Yegué, about 20 km east of Kyabobo Range National Park (KRNP) in Togo (08°15'N; 00°40'E). Only two specimens were preserved at the Humboldt Museum in Berlin and were subsequently described as a new species, but they remain the only known specimens today (Dieterlen 1976; Denys 1993; Misonne 1966). In the 1990s, two expeditions attempted to rediscover Leimacomys buettneri but without success (Decher et al. 2001). At KRNP, the  Wildlife Division field staff claimed they knew the species based on pictures that they were shown and similarly Shiare, which is closer to the original Togo locality, the people appeared to know this species and used the local name "Yefuli" (Decher et al. 2001).
conservationActions: The type locality is not within a protected area. Research to establish the species extent of occurrence, population status and habitat requirements is urgently needed.

rationale: This species is known only from Martinique, from which it has not been recorded since the 1830s. It is undoubtedly now Extinct, although the reasons are unknown.
habitat: Leicocephalus species in the Caribbean are coastal and typically tolerant of human disturbance, and this species was apparently abundant some time after Europeans colonized Martinique (Breuil 2009).
threats: The causes of extinction of this lizard are not established; it seems to have been abundant in the 18th century, but its range could also have been very restricted. It may have been a beach dweller, as are other species in the genus, and if so tsunami waves may have destroyed its last littoral habitats in Martinique. The 1843 earthquake in Guadeloupe produced waves that may have submerged its habitats, as a 1-2 m increase of sea level was detected hundreds of kilometres from the epicentre. It has been suggested that this species possesses morphological characteristics, being terrestrial, that make it vulnerable to predation by the small Asian mongoose, however in the Greater Antilles Leiocephalus survive well in areas where this predator is found, although possibly at depressed densities (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015). As there is a gap of more than 50 years between the last sighting of this lizard and the introduction of the mongoose, this is an unlikely cause of extinction (Breuil 2009).
population: The species has not been collected since 1837 and is classified as probably extinct by Powell and Henderson (2012). There is no reasonable doubt that this species, which would have been conspicuous and likely tolerant of human disturbance on a well-populated large island, is indeed now extinct (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015). It appears to have been abundant where it occurred in the 18th Century, although its range may have been very restricted (Breuil 2002).
range: This species was apparently endemic to Martinique (Henderson and Powell 2009). The precise area where it occurred is unknown, however Duméril and Bibron (1837) identify the collection data for the holotype as "Trinite"; this name refers to a town on the island, and this is the interpretation favoured by Parker (1935). Duméril and Bibron (1837) however refer to Iles de Trinite (=Trinidad), but there is no evidence that any member of this genus ever occurred on Trinidad and the association of the Trinite locality with the island is likely to have been an error made by the describing authors. The locality data associated with subsequent specimens includes records from both Martinique and Trinidad, but the latter may have been simply a transit port (Pregill 1992).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species, which is extinct.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are applicable to this species, which is extinct.

rationale: Poorly studied species with no data on population size, major threats or ecology. Further research is necessary. Probably Least Concern despite the small extent of occurrence of approximately 18,947 km<sup>2</sup>, as population densities are high, but this requires confirmation.
habitat: Poorly studied, habitat preferences and ecology similar to those of Microtus daghestanicus.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, however, there has been a decrease in steppe landscape and increase in semidesert in Azerbaijan (Gasanova 2013).
population: No data available. Population density is high enough for the species to be considered as crop pest.
range: Distributed in piedmont steppes in East Transcaucasia.
conservationActions: Occurs in some protected areas.

rationale: This bat is assessed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty over assigned occurrence records and populations to this taxon. Many of the possible records of this species are assigned to M. chiloensis, so the only confirmed geographic record remains its type locality. Available information is inadequate to make a direct assessment of its status.
habitat: There is no information on habitat and ecology.
threats: Threats for this species are unknown.
population: There is no information available on the population status of this species (Barquez pers. comm).
range: Myotis aelleni is an endemic species known for two localities in southwestern Argentina (Simmons 2005), provinces of Rio Negro and Chubut (Wilson 2008). Barquez et al. (1999:94) questioned the validity of this species, suggesting that it may prove to be a synonym of M. chiloensis.
conservationActions: Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, habitat, ecology, and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is restricted to a very small forested area (about 400 km²) on Tawitawi, which is fragmented and there is continuing decline in habitat. Based on biological inference, the species may be tolerant of secondary habitat, but this needs to be determined. The political situation prevents basic survey work on geographic range and habitat requirements of this species.
habitat: Nothing is known about this species' habitat and ecology.
threats: This species is probably threatened by habitat destruction. The island is in a political conflict zone and there is ongoing large scale illegal logging (H. Garcia pers. comm).
population: The population status of this species is unknown. The species is only confirmed from the type series of three specimens in 1971 (Musser and Heaney 1985). There are unidentified records of Rattus spp from Tawitawi (H. Garcia pers. comm).
range: The species is known only from and is likely to be restricted to Tawitawi island, Sulu Archipelago (Heaney et al. 1998; L. Heaney pers. comm).
conservationActions: Although surveys to determine the geographic range of the species, its habitat requirements and status would be beneficial, its habitat is in an area in which it is very difficult to carry out fieldwork.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements. It is only known from the type series which does not have information on habitat and ecology.
habitat: There is no available information on the habitat requirements of this species. It may be a forest species, but this needs to be confirmed.
threats: The threats to this species are not known. Much of the forest on Peleng has been degraded, and if it is a forest species it may be threatened by habitat loss.
population: It is known only from the 1938 type series.
range: This poorly known species is found only on Peleng island, off the eastern coast of Sulawesi, Indonesia (Musser and Carleton 2005). The elevation at collection has not been recorded.
conservationActions: Field surveys are needed to find out more about the habitat, ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its status and ecological requirements, and continuing uncertainty as to its taxonomic status.
habitat: Little is known about the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: Crocidura bottegi has been recorded from sites in Ethiopia (including the type locality of 'north-east of Lake Turkana, "between Badditu and Dime"' [Hutterer 2005]) and a single locality in northern Kenya (Marsabit). There are taxonomic uncertainties related to this species which need to be resolved. All populations previously recorded in West Africa have been found to be other species such as Crocidura obscurior and Crocidura eburnea. It has been recorded at an elevation of 1,750 m asl.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present within any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, breeding biology and general ecology of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: In Ethiopia this species is found in Charada Forest. In Kenya, it occurs in Kaimosi which is near Kakamega Forest.
threats: The threats to this species are not well known. The Kakamega Forest and its associated forest areas are under huge pressure because of the rapidly growing population in the area (Lung and Schaab 2006; Müller and Mburu 2009).
population: The abundance and population size of this species are not known.
range: This little known species has only been recorded with certainty from Kaffa Province in southern Ethiopia, and Kaimosi in Kisumu District, Kenya. Some records for C. zaphiri, such as those from Gamo Gofo Province in Ethiopia, might be misidentifications of other Crocidura species.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known with certainty if the species is present within any protected areas. Additional studies are needed into the distribution, natural history and threats to this poorly known species.

rationale: There are unresolved taxonomic issues with this species. Very little information is available regarding distribution, population size and trends, and potential threats, hence is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information available on its habitat preferences.
threats: There is no information available on threats affecting this species.
population: There is no information available on population status or trends.
