range: The Caspian Shrew is known only from the southwest coast lowlands of the Caspian Sea in Iran and Azerbaijan. The species is found in the Lenkoran district of Azerbaijan (Baku 2004).
conservationActions: No conservation actions are known to be in place for this species.

rationale: Leptocephalus ophichthoides is only known from larva collected in the Red Sea, so has been assessed as Data Deficient.  Further research is needed on the distribution, ecology, and potential threats to this species before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be made.
habitat: Species of the genus Leptocephalus are found in deep water, but the exact ecology of Leptocephalus ophichthoides is not known.  This species is known only from the larvae, which may have been separately described as an adult (J. McCosker pers. comm. 2008).
threats: It is not known if Leptocephalus ophichthoides is being impacted by any major threat processes.
population: There is no population information available for Leptocephalus ophichthoides.
range: Leptocephalus ophichthoides is found in the Red Sea.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Leptocephalus ophichthoides.  Further research is needed on the distribution, ecology, and potential threats to this species, as little information is currently available.

rationale: Gymnelus barsukovi has been assessed as Data Deficient. While this species is known from a broad geographic range, there is little information on the depth from which this species is known, habitat preferences, or how many specimens it is known from. Further surveys of this species are needed before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: Gymnelus barsukovi is found in Arctic climates, however its specific habitat requirements are unknown at present. This species has a broad depth profile in the upper to mid euphotic zone, from the surface down to around 51 m.
threats: It is not known if Gymnelus barsukovi are being impacted by any major threats.
population: There is no population information available for Gymnelus barsukovi.
range: Gymnelus barsukovi is distributed from the western Laptev Sea to the Bering Straight in the Arctic, and from the Canadian Arctic to Ungava Bay.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Gymnelus barsukovi.

Further research is needed on the population trends, ecology and threats of this species, as little information is currently available.

rationale: Paramonacanthus matsuurai is only known from two specimens and therefore is Data Deficient. Further research is needed on the ecology, threats, abundance and distribution of this species.
habitat: Paramonacanthus matsuurai is thought to be a demersal species found over sandy substrates at shallow depths not deeper than 50 m (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2009).
threats: It is not known if Paramonacanthus matsuurai is being impacted by any major threats.
population: Paramonacanthus matsuurai is known only from two specimens.
range: Paramonacanthus matsuurai is known from two specimens washed up on a beach in the Ogasawara Islands to the south of Japan (type locality: Miyanohama Beach, Chichi-jima).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Paramonacanthus matsuurai.

Further research on the ecology, threats, population trends, and distribution of this species is needed.

rationale: Sebastes koreanus has been assessed as Data Deficient because the species is known from only a few specimens collected from the Yellow Sea. Its range, abundance and potential threats are unknown.  Research to gather data on this species and its threats should be undertaken to be able to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: Sebastes koreanus is a demersal species. It is found in the euphotic zone at depths of 2–30 m.
threats: It is unknown whether Sebastes koreanus is impacted by any major threat processes. The species is known from only a few specimens collected in an area of the Yellow Sea known to be impacted by pollution such as oil and industrial effluents.
population: There is no population information available for Sebastes koreanus.
range: Sebastes koreanus is known only from the Yellow Sea, South Korea.  It has been collected from Munyae Island, Okdo-myon, Okku-gun, and Chollabuk-do (Eschmeyer 2008).
conservationActions: The Global Environment Facility (GEF) is supporting a Large Marine Ecosystem project in the Yellow Sea to address critical threats to the coastal and marine environment, and to promote ecosystem-based management of coastal and marine resources. Further research to determine the suitable habitat, range, and threats to Sebastes koreanus should be carried out.

rationale: Iluocoetes elongatus has been assessed as Least Concern. This species is known from a region which is under-developed and unimpacted by pollution. There is no directed fishery for this species. Further research on the biology, ecology and population trends of this species is needed inorder to better understand the possible threats that might impact this species.
habitat: There is very little habitat or ecology information available for Iluocoetes elongatus. It is thought to inhabit the intertidal zone. This species is found in the euphotic zone and has been found to a depth of 40 m.
threats: It is unlikely that Iluocoetes elongatus is being impacted upon by any major threat processes. The coastline along which this species is found is relatively under-developed and unimpacted by pollution. There is no directed fishery for this species.
population: There is no population information available for Iluocoetes elongatus.
range: Iluocoetes elongatus is found in the southwestern Atlantic from Puerto Madryn, south to Tierra del Fuego in Argentina.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Iluocoetes elongatus. However the distribution of this species may fall within several designated marine protected areas including the Peninsula Valdes and Tierra Del Fuego National Park.

Further research on the biology and ecology, and threats of this species should be carried out, as there is little information currently available.

rationale: Halieutopsis tumifrons has been assessed as Data Deficient as it is only known from two specimens collected off the Galapagos Islands. Further research is needed on the distribution and ecology of this species before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: Specimens of Halieutopsis tumifrons have been collected from the bathyl zone at a depth range of 2,418-2,487 m. There is no other information available on the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: It is not known if Halieutopsis tumifrons is being impacted upon by any major threats.
population: There is currently no population information available for this species.
range: Halieutopsis tumifrons is known from two specimens collected within the vicinity of the Galapagos Islands.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Halieutopsis tumifrons. Further research on the ecology and distribution of this species is needed.

rationale: This species is only known from a single specimen. There is little known about this species distribution, population status, habitat requirements, ecology or threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little known about this species biology or ecology.
threats: It is not known if this species is being impacted by any major threats.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Mexico, and is only known from the holotype taken from the stomach of a White Seabass at Thetis Bank off the west coast of Baja California (McCosker and Rosenblatt 1995).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures for this species. More research is needed on this species distribution, population status, biology, ecology and threats.

rationale: Lepidotrigla venusta has been assessed as Data Deficient.  This species is known from only the type specimen and so there is little information available. The species may be taken as by-catch. Further research is needed on its range, abundance and threats, before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be made.
habitat: Like other searobins, Lepidotrigla venusta is a demersal species. The type specimen was collected from a depth of around 82 m (Eschmeyer 1999).
threats: It is unknown whether Lepidotrigla venusta is being impacted by any major threat processes.  Like its congeners, this species may be taken as by-catch by trawls throughout its range (E. Murdy pers. comm. 2009).
population: There is no population information available for Lepidotrigla venusta.
range: Lepidotrigla venusta is a searobin, known from only one specimen collected from Luzon, Philippines; described with 34 paratypes (Fowler 1938).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Lepidotrigla venusta. Further research is needed on the distribution, abundance, biology and ecology of this species, as well as on its potential threats.

rationale: Dactylanthias aplodactylus has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is only known from a single specimen found around Ambon Island. Further studies on the deep water reefs around Ambon are needed to determine if it is in fact common in deeper waters. If this is the case, it would likely escape the potential threat of blast fishing, that occurs within its range.
habitat:
Dactylanthias aplodactylus is a demersal species. The Serranidae family are usually found on coral reefs or rocky substrata and the majority of species occur on continental shelves in depths less than 200 m. Except for occasional spawning aggregations, most groupers are solitary fishes and are generally resident on a particular reef for a long time (FAO 1999).

Like other species within the subfamily Anthiinae, this species may in fact be a deep reef (greater than 50 m) species and quite common. The shallow waters within this area have been relatively well surveyed (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2009).
threats: It is unknown whether Dactylanthias aplodactylus is being impacted by any major threat processes. Surveys have found the waters around Ambon Island to be severely contaminated by domestic waste, a stress which has indirectly caused an increased parasite load on some reef fish (Evans et al. 1995). The coral reefs around Ambon and other Indonesian islands are also under threat from 'blast fishing' (Harger 1995). Dive teams have reported significant cracks in the coral reef around Ambon as a result of near constant blast fishing. If this is in fact a deep reef species, then it is unlikely to be impacted by blast fishing activity.
population: There is no population information available for Dactylanthias aplodactylus.
range: Dactylanthias aplodactylus is known from a single specimen from Ambon, Indonesia.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Dactylanthias aplodactylus.

Further studies in deeper water around Ambon Island are needed to determine if this species occupies a deep water habitat.

rationale: Patagonotothen thompsoni has been assessed as Data Deficient. This species is only known from the type specimen. Species of the genus Patagonotothen are harvested as a food fish. Further surveys need to be carried out to determine the ecology, abundance and threats of this species before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: Patagonotothen thompsoni is a demersal species. It is thought to be found deeper than 100 m, and this has been inferred from related species, however the exact depth range of this species is currently unknown.
threats: It is not known if this species is being impacted by any major threats. Species of the genus Patagonotothen are harvested as a food source.
population: There is no population information available for Patagonotothen thompsoni. It is only known from the type specimen.
range: Patagonotothen thompsoni is known from the Strait of Magellan, between Chile and Argentina.
useTrade: Species of the genus Patagonotothen are regularly harvested as a food source, however it is unknown if this species is being taken by fisheries.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Patagonotothen thompsoni.

Further surveys need to be made to determine the ecology, abundance and threats of this species.

rationale: Paraulopus maculatus is only known from a single specimen and therefore is classified as Data Deficient. This species could potentially be impacted by fishing activity that occurs within its range. Further research is therefore needed before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for Paraulopus maculatus. The single specimen that was collected was found between a depth between 178 m and 290 m but its depth range is unknown.
threats: The impact of any potential threats to this species is unknown.
population: This species is only known from one specimen.
range: The single specimen of Paraulopus maculatus was found off the coast of Mombasa in Kenya.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Paraulopus maculatus.

Further research is needed on the distribution, abundance, threats and ecology of this species.

rationale: Eleutheronema tridactylum has been assessed as Data Deficient. Though this species is known from a reasonably broad geographic range, there is little information available on the ecology and population trends of this species. Further research is needed on the ecology, possible threats, and population trends of this species before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: Little information is available for the habitat of Eleutheronema tridactylum. However Eleutheronema species generally occur on continental shelves, and are considered to be heavily dependant on large freshwater rivers (Motomura et al. 2002).
threats: Although species of this genus are harvested commercially, Eleutheronema tridactylum is too small to be of major commercial importance (Motomura 2004). It is unlikely that E. tridactylum is being impacted upon by any major threat processes.
population: There is no population information available for the Threefinger Threadfin.
range: The Threefinger Threadfin, Eleutheronema tridactylum, is known from Thailand (either side of Gulf of Thailand and Andaman Sea), Malaysia (Malay Peninsular and Kalimantan) and western Indonesia (Java). However, Motomura et al. (2002) state that this species is 'probably more widely distributed in western Indonesia (Sumatra and Kalimantan)'.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place Eleutheronema tridactylum. However the distribution of this species may fall within numerous designated marine protected areas, including the Had Chao Mai Marine Park.

Further research is needed on the distribution, ecology and population status of this species.

rationale: Gerres infasciatus has been assessed as Data Deficient.  This species is known only from three specimens at the type locality in the Gulf of Thailand, and from markets in India.  The occurrence of this fish in markets in Madras suggests that it is probably taken as by-catch.  Further research is needed into the distribution and abundance of this species and to determine how it may be impacted by threats such as fishing, pollution and coastal development, before a more accurate assessment of its conservation status can be made.
habitat: Three specimens of Gerres infasciatus have been collected over sandy bottoms of shallow, inshore, coastal waters, subject to the outflows of local rivers.  At present, nothing is known of the ecological requirements of this species (Iwatsuki and Kimura 1998).
threats:
The occurrence of Gerres infasciatus in the markets of Madras (Fukuhara et al. 2006) indicates that this species is utilised as a food source.  However, there are no other records of this fish being harvested for human consumption.  It is not known what other potential threats this species may be impacted by, however like other species in the Gerres genus, it is likely to be taken as by-catch by bottom trawls operating within its range.

As this species is found in inshore coastal areas, it is likely to be impacted by habitat degradation caused by pollution and coastal development.
population: Gerres infasciatus was confirmed to be the most abundant Gerreid species in a number of markets in Madras, India.  However, at present, this species has only been recorded from Tamil Nadu in India (Fukuhara et al. 2006).
range: The mojarra, Gerres infasciatus, is known from the Northern Gulf of Thailand (Iwatsuki and Kimura 1998) and Tamil Nadu in India (Fukuhara et al. 2006).
useTrade: Gerres infasciatus has been recorded from fish markets in Madras, India ((Fukuhara et al. 2006).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Gerres infasciatus.  Further research is needed into the distribution and abundance of this species, and to determine how it may be impacted by threats such as fishing, pollution and coastal development.

rationale: Paralichthys schmitti has been assessed as Data Deficient. There is little information available on the ecology, abundance or possible threats of this restricted range species making it difficult to assess its status. Further research is needed before a more accurate assessment of conservation status can be made.
habitat: Paralichthys schmitti is a demersal species. Congeners of this species occur on sandy bottoms in estuarine areas. This species has a pelagic larval stage (J. G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2009).
threats: It is not known if Paralichthys schmitti is being impacted by any major threat processes. Some species from the Paralichthyidae family are caught in bottom trawls and marketed fresh (FAO 2001).
population: There is no population information available for Paralichthys schmitti.
range: Paralichthys schmitti is only known from the Juan Fernández Islands, Chile.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Paralichthys schmitti. However, this species may be found to occur in the Archipiélago de Juan Fernández National Park.

Further research is needed on the ecology, abundance and threats of this species.

rationale: Gobiopterus mindanensis has been assessed as Least Concern. There is no evidence to suggest that this species is undergoing a significant population decline. There is no directed fishery for this species, either as a food source or for the aquarium trade. Further research is needed on the ecology and distribution of this spec
habitat: Gobiopterus mindanensis is a demersal species found in the shallow photic zone. This species has been collected near the mouth of the River Daintree and in salt water swamps in the Philippines indicating a tolerance for a range of environmental conditions.
threats: There are no known major threats currently impacting this species.
population: There is no known population information for Gobiopterus mindanensis.
range: Gobiopterus mindanensis is an Indo-Pacific goby, known from Western Australia and the Philippines.
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species.

Further research is needed on the ecology and distribution of this species.

rationale: Ophichthus altipennis has been assessed as Least Concern.  This species has a large distribution in the western Pacific.  Little is known of its biology, but the lack of any significant known threat to its widespread likely habitat, in combination with its distribution, justifies an assessment of Least Concern.  However, further research on its ecology and threats should be carried out.
habitat: Ophichthus altipennis is a demersal species.  Species of the family Ophichthidae have muscular cylindrical bodies which are well adapted for burrowing, and many species spend most of their adult lives buried in the bottom sediment (Smith and McCosker 1999).  This species has a depth range of 0–40 m.
threats: It is unlikely that Ophichthus altipennis is being impacted by any major threat processes.
population: There is no population information available for Ophichthus altipennis.
range: Ophichthus altipennis has a patchy distribution from Japan, south to northern Australia, and east to the Marshall Islands.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place, or needed, for Ophichthus altipennis.  However, the distribution of this species may fall within numerous designated marine protected areas, including several in Japan.  Further research is needed on the ecology of this species, in order to better understand the impact of potential threats.

rationale: Listed as Extinct on the basis that no records of this large, conspicuous snake have been taken since the 19th Century (when it was familiar to general naturalists), despite extensive survey work on Saint Lucia and the presence of a large human population. While recent literature conservatively suggests that the species is "very probably" extinct, there appears to be no reasonable doubt that this species has indeed been lost from Saint Lucia.
habitat: There is no information about this snake's habitat, but it is known that it fed on other snakes including the viper Bothrops caribbeaus (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Changes to the island's ecology were so varied, and documentation so poor, in the 19th Century that it will probably never be known why this species was lost. It is hypothesized that a bounty system established to encourage killings of vipers may have resulted in the loss of this snake (Underwood 1993), however the loss of a Clelia species from Grenada in the 1960s - where no such bounty was set - calls this into question as a primary cause of extinction. Mongoose were introduced to Saint Lucia in the 19th Century, however adult mussuranas are sufficiently large that mongoose would not threaten them. The precise timing of this species' extinction is unclear, and the species might have vanished or been in decline before mongoose arrived. Habitat clearance for banana plantations was widespread in this period, and may have impacted this species if it relied on moist forest (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2015).
population: Literature from the mid-1800s reveals that the species was familiar to naturalists as late as this period (Breen 1844). It has never since been rediscovered, despite being a conspicuous, large black snake. Extensive searches have been conducted on Saint Lucia without recording it, and the species is very probably extinct (Powell and Henderson 2012).
range: This species is known only from Saint Lucia (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species, which is presumed to be extinct.
conservationActions: This species is extinct. A great deal of survey work has been conducted without rediscovering this species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that any surviving population, having gone undetected for over 100 years despite targeted surveys, is undoubtedly very small and localized, with an area of occupancy likely below 10 km<sup>2</sup>, the island is considered a single location based on a threat from invasive mammals, and there is presumed to be a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals in any surviving population due to predation. The species is however probably extinct; although skinks elsewhere in the Caribbean have been found to survive on small satellite islands, Barbados only has a single satellite and the species has never been detected there.
habitat: No ecological information is associated with this species other than that it exhibits viviparous reproduction (Hedges and Conn 2012).
threats: If this species survives, it faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose; this invasive mammal has probably already led to its extinction. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012). Barbados has one of the highest human population densities in the Caribbean, as well as large numbers of both invasive species and lost (extinct or presumed extinct) native species, and it is thought unlikely that this large lizard still exists (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2016).
population: This species is known from only three specimens. There have been no records since 1889 despite continuous search efforts (Hedges and Conn 2012).
range: This species is known only from the island of Barbados in the Lesser Antilles. The only localities known are Greame Hall Swamp and Chancery Lane, about 8 km apart and at the southern tip of the island (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine if the species still exists, the health of any remaining populations, and threats to the survival of the species. Captive breeding programs should be undertaken if a surviving population is found, because eradication of introduced mammalian predators is not possible on large islands (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: Listed as Extinct on the basis that this species is not known to survive either on Saint Lucia or on any of its satellites, all of which have been well-surveyed over many years, with the likely agent of its extinction being the introduction of mongoose and rats roughly contemporary with the known specimens. Although skinks elsewhere in the Caribbean have been found to survive on small mongoose-free islands, there is no reasonable prospect that this large skink could have survived on Saint Lucia's satellites, which have been subject to intensive work and which represent the only remaining refugia for another lizard species lost from the Saint Lucia mainland. While the continued survival of a remote mainland population cannot be completely ruled out, this island has been subject to sufficiently intensive herpetological survey work that there is thought to be no reasonable doubt that this species is extinct.
habitat: No ecological or reproductive information is associated with this species (Hedges and Conn 2012). This species might have been arboreal, in common with some other Alinea species (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015).
threats: If this species survives it faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose, which has however probably already led to its extinction. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012). If a remnant population survives, the failure to record it for over 120 years despite targeted searches - as well as extensive general herpetological research throughout Saint Lucia and its satellites - suggests that it must be very restricted. Previously widespread skinks on other islands, such as Jamaica, have been found to persist in very restricted areas (Hedges and Conn 2012). This is however not thought likely to be realistic for the Saint Lucia skink, a large lizard on a herpetologically very well-studied island from which another lizard species has been lost following the introduction of rats and mongoose (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2016).
population: This species was considered extinct as early as Barbour (1937). Four specimens are known, all in the British Museum, with an accession date of 1889 (Hedges and Conn 2012). This was a very large terrestrial lizard, but has never been found since despite a number of targeted surveys by herpetologists visiting the island, although there have been very few visits to the highest elevations.
range: This species is known only from the island of Saint Lucia in the Lesser Antilles. No precise localities are known (Hedges and Conn 2012)
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species, which is presumed to be extinct.
conservationActions: While this species is presumed to be extinct, workers should be vigilant for the possibility that an undetected population of this lizard still exists and the health of any remaining populations. Captive breeding programs should be undertaken, if a surviving population is found, because eradication of introduced mammalian predators is not possible on large islands (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because the distribution, abundance, trend, and threats for this species are too poorly known to allow it to be placed in another category.
habitat: All species in the genus are semi-fossorial. Little else is known about the ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of this species' ecology or full distribution, and it is unknown whether it is subject to major threats.
population: This species is known from several specimens collected in a single locality.
range: This species is known only from its type locality in the Cordillera Oriental, municipality of Ocaña, Department of Norte de Santander, northeastern Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Conservation needs include better information on the species' distribution, abundance, life history, population trend, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from the holotype, and while there may be threats to or close to the known locality nothing is known of the species' true distribution or ecology.
habitat: This is presumably a fossorial snake, and may have been collected in forest based on its type locality, but nothing is known for certain about the habitat or ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known about threats to this species. Mining and deforestation are ongoing within Jerico, however, mining is typically associated with rivers at lower elevations in this area (C. Arredondo pers. comm.). While this is likely to be a forest snake, it is unknown whether deforestation within the region represents a major threat as there is no information on its ecological requirements.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, a museum specimen described in the 1930s, and there is no information on its population status.
range: This species is only known from its type locality in the municipality of Jericó, Department of Antioquia, Colombia (Passos and Arredondo 2009, Passos et al. 2009), where it was collected at around 2,000 m asl.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas near the type locality. No targeted searches have been conducted to rediscover this species, which has not been seen for over 80 years, and efforts to rediscover it are needed before its conservation requirements can be determined.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, if this species survives at all, it occurs in a single location defined by the presence of invasive species, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred as a result of predation by exotic mammals. Although skinks elsewhere in the Caribbean have been found to survive on small mongoose-free islands, Marie-Galante has very few satellites where this species might survive. Nevertheless there are a number of very close, vegetated islets that have not been surveyed.
habitat: No information is available on the ecology of this species. Species of the genus Capitellum were likely terrestrial and cryptozoic; none are known to be extant. It was a viviparous species; the type specimen was a female containing embryos (Hedges and Conn 2012).
threats: If this species survives it faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose, however this invasive mammal has probably already led to its extinction. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012). Marie-Galante, unlike most large Caribbean islands with threatened or extinct skink populations, has very few outlying islands where this species could survive.
population: Aside from a single specimen collected at least 150 years ago (possibly in the 1830s), there are no other specimens or observations of skinks from this island (Hedges and Conn 2012).
range: This species is known only from Marie-Galante, Guadeloupe, an island with an area of 158 km<sup>2</sup>. It is possible that it occurred or still occurs on very close offshore islands where vegetation exists; surveys of these have been proposed, but have not yet taken place (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015). There is no precise locality data (hence elevation limits are unknown), and the species has not been recorded for at least 150 years.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine if the species still exists and the health of any remaining populations (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, if this species survives at all, it occurs in a single location defined by the presence of invasive species, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred as a result of predation by exotic mammals. Skinks elsewhere in the Caribbean have been found to survive on small mongoose-free islands, and while no surveys have yet recorded any extant population of Capitellum metallicum on Martinique's satellites, it is possible that it may survive on unsurveyed islets and it is therefore listed as Critically Endangered rather than Extinct.
habitat: No information is available on the ecology of this species. Species of the genus Capitellum were likely terrestrial and cryptozoic; none are known to be extant. It is a viviparous species (Hedges and Conn 2012).
threats: If this species survives it faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose, however this has probably already led to its extinction. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012). Several offshore islands where the species may persist exist, however surveys of a number of these have failed to record a surviving population (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015).
population: The lectotype was collected nearly two centuries ago, and there are no other existing specimens (Hedges and Conn 2012). Multiple general reptile surveys across the island have failed to record this species (M. Dewynter pers. comm. 2016).
range: This species is known only from a single specimen collected at an unknown locality on Martinique (Hedges and Conn 2012); a second specimen illustrated by Bocourt, also apparently from Martinique, has been lost.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine if the species still exists and the health of any remaining populations. Captive breeding programs should be undertaken, if a surviving population is recorded, because eradication of introduced mammalian predators is not possible on large islands. There are islets off Martinique that do not have mongoose and might sustain populations of this skink (Hedges and Conn 2012), not all of which have been surveyed.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, if this species survives at all, it occurs in a single location defined by the presence of invasive species, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred as a result of predation by exotic mammals. Martinique has multiple unsurveyed satellites where it is possible a remnant population survives, and it is possible that an undetected population may exist on the mainland, but it is thought likely that if the species survives it will have an area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup>.
habitat: No ecological data are recorded for any of the specimens, although the species is presumably terrestrial (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015). It has viviparous reproduction (Hedges and Conn 2012).
threats: If this species survives it faces a primary threat from the introduced mongoose, which has however probably already led to its extinction at least on the mainland of Martinique. Secondary threats include habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization, and predation from other introduced predators, including black rats (Hedges and Conn 2012). Any surviving population is likely to be confined to a very restricted area of the mainland, or offshore islands from which mongoose are absent.
population: This species has not been seen since 1889 (Hedges and Conn 2012). Martinique and many of its offshore islands have been surveyed without any evidence of a surviving population. However, targeted searches have not been conducted on many of the mongoose-free offshore islands, and this species may have escaped detection.
range: The species is distributed on Martinique (Hedges and Conn 2012, Powell and Henderson 2012). Records exist from two specific named localities on the west coast of the island: St. Pierre and Fort-de-France. It is however likely occurred throughout the island, or at least the humid north, before the mongoose was introduced (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine if the species still exists and the health of any remaining population. There are islets off Martinique that do not have mongoose and might sustain subpopulations of this skink (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, if this species survives at all, it occurs in a single location defined by the presence of invasive species, and a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred as a result of predation by exotic mammals. The species appears to have survived for nearly a century following mongoose introduction, and may still survive, however in common with other Caribbean skinks that have survived on mongoose-invaded islands any surviving population is expected to be highly restricted, with an area of occupancy probably below 10 km<sup>2</sup>, and still in decline. Developed areas in Sint Maarten/St. Martin, from which mongoose are largely excluded by dogs and other non-native mammals, have been found to act as refugia by other reptiles that have undergone drastic declines on the island since the 19th Century, and this pattern is consistent with the species' discovery at Little Bay. It is therefore possible that an undetected population of this species may survive, although it may be genuinely extinct.
habitat: There are no ecological data known for this species (Hedges and Conn 2012). Old rock walls are likely to represent suitable habitat, and there are many of these where the species might survive in small, probably fragmented subpopulations (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015).
threats: This species, if it survives, is threatened by predation from the introduced mongoose, which has probably led to its near- (or possibly actual) extinction. It is also thought to be under pressure from other introduced mammals, including black rats. It may also affected by habitat destruction from agriculture and urbanization (Hedges and Conn 2012), however as its ecology is unknown this must be considered speculative. A number of species impacted by mongoose on St. Maarten appear to survive only in urban and other heavily-disturbed areas from which mongoose are excluded; as surveys for this species have been limited, it remains possible that this is true also of this skink.
population: The two specimens in the type series were accessioned in 1965, and were probably collected shortly earlier (Hedges and Conn 2012, S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015). Seven additional specimens are known, all collected prior to 1877 shortly before the introduction of mongoose to this island (Hedges and Conn 2012). There have been limited surveys searching for this species, and apparently only a single targeted survey (S.B. Hedges and T. Hsieh, unpubl. data). Photographs from Tintamarre represent misidentified S. powelli (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015).
range: The species is endemic to Sint Maarten/St. Martin, where it is known only from Little Bay. It is assumed to have once occurred island-wide (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies are needed to determine the health and extent of remaining populations (Hedges and Conn 2012), and to clarify its ecological requirements.

rationale: Campichthys nanus is a marine demersal pipefish known from the type specimens collected off Mozambique. It has also been reported from the South China Sea, but this has not been verified. Little is known about population size or trend, the habitat the species uses, or threats. Therefore, Campichthys nanus is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitats used by Campichthys nanus are unknown. Feeding in the species has also not been studied, but other pipefishes tend to feed on harpacticoid copepods, gammarid shrimps, and mysids (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). The species is ovoviviparous, and males brood eggs beneath their tail prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966). The species is one of the smallest tail-brooding pipefishes, reaching maturity at 2.5 cm and not likely growing to be much larger (Dawson 1977, 1985).
threats: The threats to Campichthys nanus are unknown. Further research regarding its habitat and ecology are needed.
population: No population surveys or estimates exist for C. nanus. This species is known from the holotype and a single paratype from the vicinity of Pinda, Mozambique (Dawson 1985).
range: Campichthys nanus is known from its type locality at Pinda, Mozambique in the western Indian Ocean (Dawson 1977, 1985). It has also apparently been sighted in the South China Sea (Randall and Lim 2000, Shao et al. 2008), but the validity of this claim needs verification.
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade. Other syngnathids are often traded for use in the aquarium trade, traditional medicines, and as curios (Vincent et al. 2011), and this species may also be involved.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for Campichthys nanus. The species is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations. It is not known from any protected areas.

rationale: Campichthys tryoni is a demersal pipefish species native to Queensland, Australia. Little is known of this species habitat, as most specimens are not associated with habitat data. One sighting of the species was among seagrasses, which are suffering declines in the region. Further research is needed in order to determine habitat, population size, trends in abundance, and threats to this species. Therefore, Campichthys tryoni is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known about the habitat of Campichthys tryoni, as most examined specimens were collected without such data (Dawson 1977, 1985). Citizen scientists have observed this species in the seagrass Halophila ovalis and within surrounding sandy depressions (Short 2014). Males may begin brooding at 6-6.5 cm, and the maximum known size of the species is 7.2 cm (Dawson 1985).
threats: The threats to Campichthys tryoni are poorly known. Little is known about its habitat, but it has been observed on the seagrass Halophila ovalis, which is listed as Least Concern but is threatened in the area by declines caused by light reduction due to sediment loads in water, coastal development, dredging and marine developments, minor damage from boating and shipping activities, coastal runoff, and trawling (Short et al. 2010). It's not clear to what extent these declines in seagrass are having on wild populations of Campichthys tryoni.
population: No dedicated population estimates or surveys have been undertaken for Campichthys tryoni. Further research is necessary to determine the species population size and trends in abundance.
range: Campichthys tryoni is an endemic Australian species that occurs on the Queensland coast off of northeastern Australia (specimens have been collected from Lindeman Island, Moreton Bay, and Southport). A damaged specimen provisionally assigned to this species was also collected from the Gulf of St. Vincent. No depth data are available (Dawson 1977, 1985).
useTrade: Campichthys tryoni is unknown in trade. However, other syngnathid species are traded for use in the ornamental, aquarium and traditional medicine trade (Vincent et al. 2011), and are traded in Australia (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006). This species may be involved in such trade but likely at low levels.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Campichthys tryoni. The species is protected along with all syngnathids throughout its range under Australia's Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999). Parts of Moreton Bay are protected. The species is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations.

rationale: Choeroichthys smithi is a marine demersal pipefish that inhabits reef flats with tidal pools in the western Indian Ocean. There are no known major threats. Therefore this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Choeroichthys smithi is a demersal species, and inhabits coastal subtropical waters on reef flats with tidal pools. The species is thought to feed primarily on small crustaceans including copepods and isopods, similar to other pipefishes (Garcia et al. 2005). No predators of this species have been identified. This species is ovoviviparous and males carry eggs in a brood pouch located under the trunk prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966; Dawson 1976, 1985).
threats: This species may be caught as bycatch in trawl fisheries, although this has not been documented to date.
population: To date there have not been any dedicated surveys or population estimates for C. smithi.  Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Choeroichthys smithi is present in the western Indian Ocean along the coasts of northeastern South Africa, Mozambique, Tanzania, Madagascar, the Seychelles, Mauritius and Reunion (Smith 1951, 1963; Dawson 1976, 1985; Pereira 2008; Fricke et al. 2013; GBIF 2016).
useTrade: This species has not been detected in trade to date. Other syngnathid species, including pipefishes, are often caught as bycatch and/or targeted for use in traditional medicines and aquariums (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved in such trade, but likely at low levels.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Choeroichthys smithi. Further research is needed to determine population size and trends and the habitat used by this species.

rationale: Leptonotus norae is a marine pipefish endemic to New Zealand. It is known from few specimens collected from midwater and bottom trawls, and therefore little is known about its habitat. There are however no known threats to this species. Therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Leptonotus norae is only known from midwater and bottom trawls from depths of 37-212 m. Very little is known about its habitat or ecology.

The species likely feeds on small planktonic and/or benthic crustaceans, similar to other pipefishes (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). Juveniles have been noted in the gut contents of blue penguins Eudyptula minor (Fraser and Lalas 2004) and snare penguins Eudyptes robustus (Mattern et al. 2009). In one case, Mattern et al. (2009) noted 47 undigested specimens in the gut contents of a snare penguin, possibly indicating that they are an important component of seabird diets and that they may exhibit schooling behaviour.

They are ovoviviparous, and males brood eggs beneath their tail prior to giving birth to live young (Dawson 1985).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for this Leptonotus norae. Further research is needed to determine population size and trends in abundance.
range: Leptonotus norae is an endemic of New Zealand, occurring from Hawkes Bay, North Island south to Stewart Island (Dawson 1984, 1985)
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in trade, but other seahorses are traded heavily globally for traditional medicines, curios, and aquarium use (Vincent et al. 2011).  Some illegal trade occurs in Australia, but levels are low compared to other regions (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006) and they have not been quantified for New Zealand. This species may be involved but likely at low levels.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Leptonotus norae. It's not known whether the species occurs in any protected areas.

rationale: Micrognathus erugatus is a coastal Western Atlantic pipefish species that is only known from its type locality in Bahia, Brazil.  Little is known about the species' biology, but the type specimen was collected in a rock tidepool. Threats to the species are unknown, and further research is needed to determine the population status and trends in abundance. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Micrognathus erugatus is known only from its holotype specimen, which was collected in a rock tidepool (Dawson 1982). Little is known about its feeding, but it likely feeds on harpacticoid copepods, gammarid shrimps, and mysids as other pipefish species do (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). The species is ovoviviparous, and males brood the young beneath their tail prior to giving live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1982).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown. It may be caught as bycatch in trawl fisheries and/or targeted for use in traditional medicine, the aquarium trade, and as curios as other pipefishes often are (Vincent et al. 2011), but this has not been documented.
population: To date there have not been any dedicated surveys or population estimates for Micrognathus erugatus. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Micrognathus erugatus is known only from its type locality in the Western Atlantic off the coast of Bahia, Brazil (Herald and Dawson 1974, Dawson 1982).
useTrade: Micrognathus erugatus has not been identified in trade, but pipefishes in general are traded for use in traditional medicine, aquariums, and as curios (Vincent et al. 2011). This species may be involved, but it has not been recorded and levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Micrognathus erugatus. Further research is needed to learn more about this species' biology, threats, and whether conservation actions are necessary. This species is not known to occur in any protected areas, nor is it listed in any international legislation or trade documents.

rationale: Minyichthys brachyrhinus is a marine demersal pipefish known from scattered records in the Indo-Pacific. The species is known from only a few specimens of planktonic juveniles and one adult male. Further research is needed in order to determine the habitats, ecology, life history, population biology and threats. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: As Minyichthys brachyrhinus is only known from planktonic juvenile specimens and one adult male, the habitat for this species is unknown. One demersal male adult was dredged from a depth of 72-90 m (Dawson 1985). Nothing is known about its feeding ecology, but it likely feeds on small planktonic and/or benthic crustaceans like other pipefishes (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005). The species is ovoviviparous, and males brood the eggs under their tail prior to giving live birth (Dawson 1985).
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or populations estimates for Minyichthys brachyrhinus. The species is only known from a few planktonic juvenile specimens and one adult male. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance.
range: Minyichthys brachyrhinus has been observed in trawls off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia; the Philippines; Fiji; and from Oahu and Kure Island, Hawai'i (Fritzsche 1975, Dawson 1985).
useTrade: There are no records of this species in trade.
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation actions in place or needed for this poorly-known species. Further research and monitoring is needed to understand the ecology, life history, and population size for this species.

rationale: Notiocamnpus ruber is a southern Australian endemic marine pipefish that inhabits rocky and coral reefs, algae, and seagrasses. The species is protected from exploitation throughout its range and is a generalist in that it utilizes several different habitat types. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Notiocampus ruber inhabits coral and rocky reefs, filamentous and other red macroalgae, seagrass beds (McClatchie et al. 2006). Other pipefishes tend to feed on small planktonic and/or benthic crustaceans such as harpacticoid copepods, gammarid shrimps, and mysids, and it is quite likely that this species does the same (Kendrick and Hyndes 2005).  The species is ovoviviparous, and males brood eggs in a pouch, probably under their tail, until giving birth to live young (Dawson 1985). Contrary to what is exhibited by most syngnathids, N. ruber tends to move in a rapid snake-like motion.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown.
population: There have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Notiocampus ruber. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance.
range: Notiocampus ruber is an Australian endemic species that occurs along the coast to 20 m depth from Lucky Bay, Western Australia, to Port Jackson, New South Wales. The species also occurs in Tasmania (Dawson 1985).
useTrade: Although this species has not been identified in trade, unidentified pipefishes have been observed in Australian trade and are likely used for traditional medicine, but levels of offtake are likely low (Martin-Smith and Vincent 2006). It's not clear whether this species is involved in this trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for Notiocampus ruber. The species is protected throughout its range by Australia's Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999). It is not listed in any international legislation or trade regulations. It's unknown whether the species occurs in any protected areas. Most state governments in Australia have or are working towards completing coastal regional management strategies. Further research is needed to better understand this species' habitats, ecology, population size, and threats.

rationale: Ostichthys brachygnathus is a rarely collected, deepwater species known from only two localities and very few specimens. The estimated area of occupancy, based on its depth preferences, is about 524km2. Information regarding its distribution, population, biology or habitat requirements is very limited. Although the current AOO is less than the threshold for listing this species as Vulnerable, the lack of data on threats limits estimation of the number of locations. This species is therefore listed as Data Deficient. Further research is required into population, biology, habitat requirements and threats for this species.
habitat: Habitat and ecology information is limited for this species.
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from very few records.
range: Ostichthys brachygnathus is only recorded from two localities: Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands (Saipan) at a depth of at least 230 m (Randall and Myers 1993). The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at about 524 km2, which is less than the threshold for Vulnerable under Criterion B.
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for O. brachygnathus.

rationale: Ostichthys ovaloculus is known from the type specimen from French Polynesia (Tahiti). Information on its distribution, population, habitat, and potential threats are very limited. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this species are unknown. The maximum recorded length for this species is 21 cm (Randall and Wrobel 1988).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from a single specimen.
range: Ostichthys ovaloculus is known from a single record from French Polynesia (Tahiti), collected at a depth of 300 m (Randall and Wrobel 1988, Randall and Greenfield 1999). As it was recorded from deep water, it is likely that this species could be more widely distributed.
useTrade: This species is not likely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for O. ovaloculus.

rationale: Sargocentron megalops is known from a single specimen from the Pitcairn Islands. Information on its distribution, population, habitat, and potential threats are very limited. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The size of the type specimen is 7.9 cm SL (Randall 1998). Habitats are unknown.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species.
population: This species is known from only one specimen (Accessed through FishNet2 Portal, www.fishnet2.net, July 2015).
range: Sargocentron megalops is known from a single female specimen from the Pitcairn Islands (Randall 2005). This specimen was captured at a depth of 49 m (Randall 1998), which could be at the upper limit of its depth distribution.
useTrade: No information is available for this species; however, it is unlikely that this species is utilized due to the depth at which it was found.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for S. megalops.

rationale: Listed as Extinct on the basis that this species historically occurred on at least four major islands in the Lesser Antilles, three of which have human populations that would undoubtedly have led to the discovery of a living population of this large, conspicuous lizard. While historical literature from Guadeloupe indicates that the species survived into colonial times at least on this island, it is not clear that populations elsewhere were still extant in this period and the reasons for, and date of, its extinction are unknown.
habitat: The species was probably from coastal habitats (Breuil 2002). Du Tertre (1667) indicated that it was agile, bold and active, a terrestrial species that would take food scraps and ate the eggs of other lizards and turtles.
threats: This species became extinct following European colonization of the archipelago, however the reasons for this are not understood. Leiocephalus species in the Caribbean typically survive well in the presence of exotic predators, and this species occurred on multiple large islands (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015).
population: The species is almost certainly extinct (Henderson and Powell 2009), as it is a conspicuous species that occurred on three well-populated islands where a surviving population would very likely have been detected (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015); Barbuda is uninhabited, but the species appears never to have been recorded there in historic times. Du Tertre (1667) reported the behaviour of this lizard, indicating that it survived into historical times.
range: Fossil remains of this West Indies species are known from Anguilla, Barbuda, Antigua, and Guadeloupe (Henderson and Powell 2009). It was probably coastal (Breuil 2002).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species, which so far as is known is extinct.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are required, as this species is extinct.

rationale: No specimens of this species have been found in over 130 years, despite directed searches near the type locality. There are also no known captive specimens, so the species’ status as Extinct (see Broadley 1994) is now confirmed.
habitat: The habitat for this species is unknown.
threats: Conversion of habitat in the Durban area for agriculture and human settlement may have been a major cause of extinction (Bourquin 1988, Broadley 1994).
population: No specimens have been identified in more than 130 years since the description of the species, despite directed searches. There are also no known captive specimens and there is thus high confidence that the species is extinct.
range: Described by Boulenger in 1887 on the basis of a single specimen from 'Port Natal' somewhere near Durban. Has not been found again in more than 130 years, despite extensive surveys in the greater Durban area failing to produce any specimens (Bates et al. 2014). These surveys included Marianhill, where the Reverend Henry Callaway is believed to have found the first and only specimen when traveling by ox-wagon from Pietermaritzburg.
useTrade: This species is not known to have been utilized or traded in any way.
conservationActions:
Not applicable; the species is deemed Extinct.

Renewed searches should be conducted in the greater Durban area. If the original type is still available, re-examination or the use of ancient DNA analysis should be undertaken to look into its taxonom status.

rationale: Scorpaenopsis gilchristi is known only from five specimens, two from South Africa and three from New Caledonia. Virtually nothing is known about the population size and trends for the species, and there are no data on the ecology, habitats and life history traits for S. gilchristi. The species is not utilized commercially, and there are no known threats at this time. Given the lack of certainty for the global distribution of the species, as well as the paucity of data on ecology and life history, this species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitats, ecology and life history traits are poorly understood for S. gilchristi. The maximum recorded length for this species is 6.0 cm total length (Eschmeyer 1986).
threats: There are no known major threats to this species at this time.
population: Scorpaenopsis gilchristi is known only from five specimens. The population size and trends for this species are poorly understood.
range:
Scorpaenopsis gilchristi is known from only two specimens taken off Natal, South Africa, near the mouth of the Tugela River (Eschmeyer 1986, Randall and Eschmeyer 2001). Motomura et al. (2011) have recently identified three specimens of S. gilchristi that were collected from the Chesterfield Islands, New Caledonia; however, additional specimens from both regions are required in order to properly determine the taxonomic status of the New Caledonia material, as all five specimens are in rather poor condition (Motomura et al. 2011).
This species is known to inhabit depths of between 3 and 25 m (Fricke et al. 2011).
useTrade: Scorpaenopsis gilchristi is not utilized in a commercial capacity.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for S. gilchristi; however, it may occur in marine protected areas that intersect with its range, such as the Natural Park of the Coral Sea.

rationale: Cailliet's Angelshark (Squatina caillieti) is a recently described and poorly known benthic shark from Luzon, Philippines. The juvenile female holotype is 32.6 cm total length and was caught in a trawl between 363 and 385 m depth. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends for this species, and its level of interaction with fisheries is uncertain. Therefore Cailliet's Angelshark is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is only known from the holotype, a juvenile female of 32.6 cm total length (TL), which was caught at a depth of between 363 and 385 m (Walsh et al. 2011). Angel sharks are typically lecithotrophic viviparous.
threats: The threats to this species are largely unknown. Globally, other angel sharks are typically targeted and/or caught as bycatch in trawl, gillnet, longline, and trammel net fisheries. Deepwater fisheries that may catch this species as bycatch do operate in the Philippines, including deep-set hook and line fisheries (Flores 2004).
population: There are no data on population size or structure for this species.
range: Cailliet's Angelshark is known only from the type locality, southeast of Luzon, Philippines in the Western Central Pacific (Walsh et al. 2011).
useTrade: Use and trade of this species is unknown. It is likely consumed locally.
conservationActions: Currently there are no conservation actions in place for this recently described species.

rationale: Coryogalops bretti is a marine species that is known only from isolated specimens at South Africa and Mauritius. Other information relating to the population, life history and ecology of this species is not available. Given its lack of available data it is difficult to say if it is utilized or if it affected by threats. There are no species-species conservation measures currently in place for it. This species is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is an extremely data poor species, known from isolated specimens. Information on its life history and ecology is not available. There is no depth information.
threats: Given the paucity of information for this species in general, it is not possible to accurately consider the threats that may be impacting it.
population: This species is extremely data poor and as such population information is not available. It is only known from 2 specimens.
range: Coryogalops bretti is known only from a single specimen caught at Kwelera in South Africa and an unverified specimen collected at Mauritius (Schliewen 2011, Kovacic et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Hetereleotris bipunctata is an extremely data poor species that is known to be distributed in the Western Indian Ocean in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, with a potential record from Dhofar, Oman. It is not known if there are threats to this species, as there is nothing known on its population, depth range, habitat or ecology. There are a number of impacts to marine species in the Red Sea, including pollution, habitat alteration, and coastal development. Given that this species is only known from 7 specimens, It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Hetereleotris bipunctata is an extremely data poor species and information relating to its life history and ecology are unavailable at this time.
threats: It is not known if there are threats to this species, as there is nothing known on its depth range, habitat or ecology. There are a number of impacts to marine species in the Red Sea, including pollution, habitat alteration, and coastal development.
population: This is a data poor species for which population information is extremely limited. It is only known from 7 specimens.
range: Hetereleotris bipunctata is distributed in the Western Indian Ocean in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden (Goren and Dor 1994), potentially also found at Dhofar, Oman (Kovacic et al. 2014).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is insufficient information on this species' range, population and threats for a valid conservation assessment.
habitat: The species' habitat requirements and ecology are unknown. Forest removal is ongoing throughout much of Southeast Asia (Sodhi et al. 2010), however, it is unknown how this particular species' habitat is affected.
threats: Habitat loss and degradation due to rapidly expanding agriculture is an ongoing threat to biodiversity throughout Southeast Asia (Sodhi et al. 2010), however, Kachin State has the lowest rate of forest loss for the country (Liu et al. 2015). The species may be threatened by habitat loss, but further surveys are required to determine this and other potential threats.
population: Nothing is known about this species' population or trends except that it is only known with certainty from a series of two females collected between 1937-39, and possibly from one other specimen collected in 1932 (Smith 1940). The species' population may be in decline due to habitat loss associated with expanding agriculture throughout Southeast Asia (Sodhi et al. 2010).
range: This species is currently known with certainty only from a single locality in Htingnam, Kachin State, northern Myanmar (Smith 1940). A single specimen from approximately 200 km west in the Hkampti Plain was tentatively assigned to this species (Smith 1940) but a more specific locality was never given, and its conspecificity with Philautus tytthus has not been confirmed. No elevation data has been published for this species, but the Htingnam area is approximately 900-1,200 m asl. The species' range probably extends outside of this area, but its likely range cannot be inferred as its habitat requirements are unknown. For this reason, the range map and extent of occurrence (EOO) associated with this assessment are a 10 km2 circle around Htingnam, as well as an area of similar elevation adjacent to Hkampti denoted with 'presence uncertain'.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilised.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
No conservation strategies are in place for this species and it is not known from any protected areas. The nearest protected area (Bumhpabum Wildlife Sanctuary) is 28 km west of its only known locality (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

Research Needed
The first step towards ensuring this species' long-term persistence is addressing the lack of data; additional surveys are needed to understand its true distribution, relative abundance, population trend, life history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as there is no information on the distribution, habitat or threats to this species.
habitat: Nothing appears to be known about the ecology of this species, presumably fossorial.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: Known only from the holotype.
range: This species has been reported from Java, Indonesia, without any more specific locality data (Duméril and Duméril 1851). Known only from a single specimen collected prior to 1850, the stated collector (J. Mueller) has not been identified, although it may be a misspelling of Salomon Mueller who collected widely from Java to New Guinea (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species is present in any protected areas. Further general research is needed to rediscover this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because this species remains known only from the type series, with inadequate additional information concerning the distribution, habitat requirements and possible threats.
habitat: This species is known from a single specimen that was collected from an ant nest among stones (Khan 2006).
threats: The possible threats to this species are not known.
population: Nothing is known concerning the abundance or population trends for this little-known snake.
range: This species is known only from Nadari Village, 2 km east of Goi Madan, Kotli District, in Pakistan-administered Azad Kashmir 33°30 N and 74°00 E, elevation 1,315 m asl (Khan 2006).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if populations are present within any protected areas. Additional surveys are needed to better understand the distribution, ecology and threats to this snake.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that the provenance of this species is completely unknown, and its validity is unclear.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.
range: The distribution of this species is completely unknown. The type locality has been given as North America, but it most closely-resembles members of the Asian genus Indotyphlops (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2016 cited in Uetz et al. 2019).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures can be proposed, as it is not possible to identify this species' research needs unless it is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information (post 1914) on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
habitat: Nothing is known with certainty about the habitat and ecology of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known but the area around Kribi is being extensively developed for a new port.
population: It is currently known from just two specimens, collected prior to 1908 and 1914.
range: This snake is endemic to southern Cameroon, where it has been recorded from Bitye and Kribi. It has been recorded from 10 to 620 m asl.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It seems possible that this species is present in Campo National Park, however, this requires confirmation. Further field surveys are needed to rediscover this little-known snake.

rationale: This species is only known from a few specimens collected in Madagascar and Mauritius. This species may also occur in the Red Sea, in the Gulf of Aqaba. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population, habitat, ecology and impact of any threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Habitat and ecology information for this species is limited. It is known to grow to a maximum total length of 5.9 cm (Randall 1997).
threats: It is not known if there are any threats to this species. If it occurs in the Red Sea, this area is threatened by pollution, urban development, shipping and habitat alteration and these may impact its population stability and trend.
population: There are no population data for this species at this time. It is only known from a few specimens.
range: This species is found in the Western Indian Ocean at Mauritius and Madagascar (Randall 1997, Fricke 1999). It may also occur in the Gulf of Aqaba in the Red Sea, if T. dorsostigma is confirmed to be this species (Larson pers comm. 2017). It is found from 8 – 18 m depth (Bogorodsky et al. 2011)
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized in any capacity.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: Lissonanchus lusheri is a data deficient species known from only a single specimen found in Southern Mozambique. There is no information relating to its population or use and trade. There are no major threats known to impact it. Due the paucity of information and data necessary to assess this species risk of extinction, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Almost no information is available relating to the life history and ecology of this species. Based on one specimen, this marine, tropical species can grow up to 2.1 cm standard length (Briggs 1986).
threats: There are no major threats known to impact this species.
population: There is no population data available at this time.
range: Lissonanchus lusheri is found in the Western Indian Ocean; known from one specimen from Ponte Zavora, Southern Mozambique (Briggs 1986).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: This Extinct species has been newly-described from subfossil remains. It  is little-known but probably became extinct around 1730 as a result of  overhunting, predation by rats, and deforestation.
habitat: Little is known, but it was probably more terrestrial than N. picturatus (Hume and Walters 2012).
threats: This species probably became extinct  as a result of overhunting, predation by invasive mammals such as Black Rats, and deforestation  (Hume and Walters 2012).
population: None remained long enough to be recorded even by the first natural history collectors to visit Mauritius.
range: Nesoenas cicur is known from subfossil remains on Mauritius (Hume 2011). It is thought to have become extinct by around 1730 (Hume and Walters 2012).

rationale: This Extinct species has been newly-described from subfossil remains. It   is little-known but probably became extinct during the 18th century as a result of   overhunting and predation by rats.
habitat: Little is known.
threats: The species was described as being tame and easily hunted, but the presence of Black Rats Rattus rattus was likely the main driver of extinction (Hume and Walters 2012).
population: No extant population remains.
range: Nesoenas rodericanus is known from subfossil remains found in caves on Rodrigues (Mauritius). It may have become extinct between 1726 and 1761 as a result of predation by rats (Hume and Walters 2012).

rationale: This recently-described, probably flightless rail was likely driven Extinct in the late 17th century as a result of hunting pressure and predation by introduced rats and cats.
habitat: Little is known, but it is likely to have been flightless (Hume and Walters 2012).
threats: Presumably driven extinct by over-hunting, and predation by introduced rats and cats (Hume and Walters 2012).
population: No extant population remains.
range: Dryolimnas augusti was described from fossils from Réunion (to France) and thought to correspond to a rail species mentioned by Dubois in 1674 (per Mourer-Chauviré et al. 1999) as 'Râle des Bois'; there are no subsequent reports or birds likely to relate to this species, and its extinction may well have taken place in the late 17th century (Mourer-Chauviré et al. 1999).

rationale: This newly-recognised gallinule may have survived until as late as 1937, but undoubtedly became Extinct soon after. It likely disappeared as a result of over-hunting and predation by invasive rats and cats.
habitat: This species was a small gallinule which probably had reduced flying capabilities (Hume and Walters 2012).
threats: Little is known, but it was presumably driven to extinction by hunting pressure and predation by invasive species.
population: No extant population remains.
range: Porphyrio paepae was known from Hiva Oa and Tahuata on the Marquesas Islands (French Polynesia). It may have survived as late as 1937, but must have become extinct soon afterwards (Steadman 1988, Hume and Walters 2012).

rationale: This species likely became Extinct during the 17th century as a result of predation by rats and hunting by human settlers.
habitat: Remains were found at widely spread locations on both the North and South Islands of New Zealand, indicating that it was presumably common prior to the arrival of the Polynesians and associated commensal animals.
