threats: The main reasons for its extinction are likely to have been predation by Polynesian rats, and hunting by human settlers.
population: None persisted to modern times.
range: Tribonyx hodgenorum is known from subfossil remains on the North and South Islands of New Zealand. It was apparently widespread, but the youngest specimen material dates from the 17th century, when it likely became extinct.

rationale: This species is known only from subfossil remains. It likely became Extinct during the early 17th century as a result of invasive predators and hunting for food by human settlers.
habitat: May have fed on large land crabs (Olson and Wingate 2006).
threats: It was probably driven to extinction by invasive predators such as feral cats, hunting, and perhaps a shortage of prey (Hume and Walters 2012).
population: No extant population remains.
range: Nyctanassa carcinocatactes is known from subfossil remains from Bermuda (Olson and Wingate 2006). Reports from 1610 refer to numerous herons fitting the likely description of this species (Hume and Walters 2012), but it probably became extinct during the early 17th century shortly after colonisation by humans.

rationale: Pherallodus smithi is a very data poor species that is only known from only a single specimen found from Durban, South Africa . There is no population or use and trade information currently available. It is not known to be impacted by pervasive threats. Given the overall paucity of information and data for this species, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a marine, subtropical species for which specific habitat information is not available. It grows to a standard length of 1.88 cm (Briggs 1986).
threats: There are no major threats known to impact this species.
population: There is no population data available at this time.
range: Pherallodus smithi is known from one specimen found at Durban, South Africa (Briggs 1986).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: This species is known from only a single specimen taken from Taiwan. Any information pertaining to population, life history and ecology or threats is unavailable. This species is generally extremely data poor and, as such, is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Information relating to life history and ecology of this species is unavailable.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from a single specimen and, as such, population information is unavailable.
range: Oligolepis formanosus is only known from a single specimen collected in Taiwan (Nichols 1958).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species is thought to have become extinct around the mid-nineteenth century when the only specimen was collected. While its exact provenance is unclear, this was a very large gecko and both New Zealand and New Caledonia have been subject to extensive herpetological survey work, and the existence of an extant population is considered highly unlikely.
habitat: This species was described from a museum specimen with no associated data discovered more than a century after it was collected (Bauer and Russell 1986), and consequently nothing is known of its ecology.
threats: The causes of this species' apparent extinction are unknown, but if it genuinely occurred on New Zealand's North Island the destruction of primary forest following European colonization, and the introduction of mammalian predators including cats, black rats and feral pigs may have been causal factors (Bauer and Russell 1987).
population: This species is known from a single specimen. The collection date is unknown and could have been at any point between 1819 and 1902 (Bauer and Russell 1986). These authors suggest a likely collection date between 1833 and 1869, indicating that it has probably not been recorded for at least 150 years. Although Bauer and Russell (1986) considered that it is possible a small relict population could survive on the North Island, more recent authors have presumed that it is extinct (Hitchmough 2016, R. Hitchmough and A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019). If a population survives, it would not have occurred in large numbers for over a century (Bauer and Russell 1987).
range: This species was described from a partial specimen of unknown provenance, but its morphological affinities have been considered to restrict it to either New Caledonia or New Zealand (Bauer and Russell 1986). It has been included in the New Zealand fauna following Bauer and Russell (1986, 1987), based largely on a suggested association with New Zealand due to features of its morphology and secondarily on the similarity of the known specimen to early reports of a giant lizard in Maori folklore, from which this gecko gets its common name.
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is listed on CITES Appendix III (New Zealand). This species is considered to be extinct (Hitchmough et al. 2016).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) on the basis that, although this species has not been seen in more than a century and its provenance is uncertain, extensive survey and taxonomic work on Oligosoma has never subsequently recorded a surviving population of this lizard or later museum specimens corresponding to the same species as the holotype. Related species are known to have suffered severe declines and mainland extinctions following the introduction of non-native mammalian predators, corresponding to the period when the known specimen was collected, and its subsequent non-detection is thought likely to reflect genuine extinction. Surveys to confirm this are impossible due to the uncertain provenance of the holotype, but if the species survives it is thought likely that it exists only as a remnant population, considered for the purposes of this assessment to consist of fewer than 50 mature individuals.
habitat: Nothing is known of the ecology of this species.
threats: Melzer et al. (2019) state that "There is no doubt that this species is at least seriously threatened, if not extinct". As the species' distribution is unknown the exact threats are not clear, however, invasive mammalian predators in particular have been a major cause of decline for skinks throughout the New Zealand mainland and the fact that this species has not been recorded since the 19th century, a period corresponding to mainland declines and extinctions in many other species following invasion by European mammals, suggests that these may have been the primary agent of decline. It is likely to be or have been subject to similar threats to populations previously believed to represent this species, including modification or loss of habitat due to exotic forestry and agricultural development.
population: This species was described in 1887 and, as no examined museum material appears to be conspecific with the sole known specimen (Melzer et al. 2019), it may never have been recorded since.
range: No extant population is known of this New Zealand endemic, which is described as a "complete enigma" by Melzer et al. (2019). DNA could not be obtained from the holotype for this study, and these authors were able to conclude only that this specimen is not conspecific with any of the other material examined during their revision. They suggest that it may correspond or be close to an undescribed species known from Hokitika, but that more data is needed to clarify this. If it is not conspecific with the Hokitika skink, the species is thought likely to be extinct or to be confined to a remnant population that "awaits re-discovery" (Melzer et al. 2019).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures can be proposed unless an extant population of this species is identified.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its precise distribution, extent of occurrence, status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This is presumably a subterranean species, living in lowland tropical forest.
threats: There is no information on threats to this species.
population: The population status and trends of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of "a small creek tributary to Río Mazaruni" (Taylor 1968) in Guyana, but the precise locality is not known. Another specimen without precise locality data also exists from Cayenne City, French Guiana (Lescure and Marty 2001). Due to these uncertainties a map of this species' distribution has not been drawn for this assessment.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
Further research is needed into its distribution, population, ecology and threats.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient as it is only known from the type collection from an uncertain locality. No further information on this species is available.
habitat: It is a burrowing species, with no additional habitat or ecological information.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species appears to be known only from the type specimen.
range: This poorly-known species appears to have only been recorded from the type locality of Hanha or Capelongo in Angola (Branch et al. 2018).
useTrade: It is not used or traded.
conservationActions: Surveys are required to locate this species and to collect information on this species so that it can be assessed.

rationale: This species, known only from Guadeloupe, has not been recorded since 1914. Its final extinction, presumed to be the result of a hurricane in 1928, follows a long period of decline inferred from fossil evidence and the historical literature. This decline, occurring first on large islands on which invasive mammals are now widespread, with populations surviving longer on satellite islands, is consistent with patterns of extinction following the introduction of mongoose and other exotic predators to Caribbean islands, although literature evidence suggests that the species may have had a restricted distribution on or have been lost from the large island of Guadeloupe some time prior to the first known introduction of mongoose.
habitat: This was reportedly a ground-dwelling species that fed on carrion, including scraps dropped when cleaning fish, plants, and other lizards (including dead members of the same species) (Du Tertre 1659, 1667).
threats: It is thought that a hurricane that passed through Grand Ilet in 1928 was responsible for the final extinction of this species. Historical declines and extinctions on Guadeloupe probably resulted from predation by introduced species - particularly mongoose - and native people (Henderson and Powell 2009). Small island populations that became extinct after the 17th Century may have been lost to stochastic events.
population: Three individuals were collected in 1914. To date these represent the only known specimens although the species is recognizable from historical literature dating as far back as the 17th Century (Breuil 2002). This remnant population is presumed to have been destroyed by a hurricane in 1928 (Honegger 1981). Seventeenth Century sources refer to the species being ubiquitous on islands off Guadeloupe, though only present on part of the main island (Du Tertre 1654, 1667).
range: This species was last known to survive on Grand Ilet off Petit-Bourg on the eastern coast of Basse-Terre, Guadeloupe, from where it was collected in 1914 (Breuil 2002). Fossil records extend its historical distribution to Guadeloupe, Marie-Galante, and their satellites (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species, which is extinct.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are possible for this species, which has apparently been extinct for nearly 90 years.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, while this species was considered extinct as long ago as 1935 and is widely treated as such in recent literature, its true distribution is a matter of informed speculation and until Breuil (2002) was widely believed to be on Martinique, an island where this species almost certainly never occurred. As this author was the first to propose a plausible, specific source of origin for the lizard, targeted surveys have not been possible to confirm beyond reasonable doubt that it is now extinct, and a specimen accessioned in 1965 without a collection date may represent a more recent collection than those reported in the historical literature.
habitat: There is no information about the habitats or ecology of this species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species, as its distribution is inferred wholly from interpretations in recent and historical literature. If, as suspected, it is extinct, the causes of extinction are unclear. Les Iles de la Petite Terre are free of mongoose, an invasive species responsible for extinctions and declines in related species in the Caribbean.
population: The collection date for the two specimens reported in historical literature was before 1825, when the first correspondence referring to this species was dated. It has never been recorded since on any of the islands proposed as the type locality (Breuil 2002). This author located two specimens in the Paris Museum, and an additional one that was given to the Museum of Comparative Zoology in 1965; this latter has no associated locality data or date of collection, and Breuil (2002) reported that the 19th Century literature made no reference to a third specimen. Parker (1935), who first suggested that the species may have been native to Guadeloupe, considered that it was extinct; later authors who believed the species to occur on Martinique reached the same conclusion (Baskin and Williams 1966).
range: This species was once thought to have occurred in Martinique (Baskin and Williams 1966), but more recently believed to have been endemic to Les Iles de la Petite Terre, Guadeloupe (see extensive discussion in Breuil 2002) following the discovery of archive correspondence referring to the collection of this species on these islands. This has subsequently been accepted (Henderson and Powell 2009). The type locality is very unclear; it is given as Cayenne, but this is assumed to be in error (Uetz and Hallerman 2015). An additional specimen has the locality "Trinite", whose identity is uncertain. Historically this has been assumed to be Trinidad, and the locality may have represented a transit point rather than the species' native range (Breuil 2002). The species was named in the first published checklist of Trinidadian reptiles published in 1858, suggesting that the species may have been confused with the native Ameiva atrigularis (J. Murphy pers. comm. 2015). Recently J. Murphy has compared the diagnostic characters of Pholidoscelis major, A. atrigularis, and the extinct P. cineraceus from Grand Ilet, and concludes that A. major is a good species that was "definitely not" from Trinidad or Tobago, and is probably more closely-related to P. cineraceus than to any extant species (J. Murphy pers. comm. 2015).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species, which is thought to be extinct.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are possible for this species, which may not have been recorded for almost 200 years and whose distribution is unknown.

rationale: Assessed as Data Deficient due to the lack of population and accurate distribution data available. Further research into the population, distribution, and threats should be carried out to make a more informed assessment of its conservation status.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information available for this species. However, members of the genus tend to be cryptic and burrow in the leaf litter and soil (Greer 1977).
threats: It is unknown whether this species is being impacted upon by a major threat process.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species inhabits Sri Lanka (Taylor 1950). No specific type locality was given although most of Taylor's collections were made around Trincomalee. It is also possible that a specimen has been collected from the northeast coast of the island (R. Somaweera pers. comm.).
useTrade: There is not thought to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research on the population, distribution, habitat preferences, and threats should be carried out.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of sufficient information on its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The habitat and natural history of this snake species are not known.
threats: The threats to this species are inconclusively known.
population: It is known only from the historical type specimen (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is considered to be endemic to Sri Lanka, where it is known only from the indistinct type locality of '12 miles north of Trincomalee' (Taylor 1950). It has not been rediscovered during extensive surveys and it is not implausible that the specimen may have come from a different country or location within Sri Lanka (Bauer and De Silva 2007, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. Additional surveys are needed to try to rediscover this snake. Further surveys into the taxonomic status of this species may be beneficial.

rationale: This species has a very restricted distribution in northeastern Sri Lanka (extent of occurrence (EOO) = 780 km<sup>2</sup>) and its population is considered severely fragmented. Although most of the population occurs within a protected area, there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to quarrying in the portion of the range outside the protected area. Road construction and the expansion of a church inside the protected area will likely affect some of the subpopulations of this species. Flooding from adjacent dams and from change in rain patterns are likely affecting the species.
habitat: It appears to occur in a drier area than other members of its genus and has been recorded from sandy soils from a depth of 10-30 cm (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). It is a habitat specific species that occurs in small subpopulations, based on available suitable patches. There is a continuous decline in the extent and quality of the habitat due to quarrying.
threats: Most of the population occurs within Wilpattu National Park. However, the areas outside are threatened by quarrying for cement. An area inside the park it is likely to be impacted by the expansion of a church that is expected to gather as much as 700,000 people once a year. Biofuel has accumulated within the park and there is the risk of a fire burning through it, as the region has become drier with climate change. A major road is planned that will cross the park and will likely have an impact on this species' habitat. There has been a proposal to degazette the park and open it for development, which will definitely impact the population of this species. Portions of the park are impacted by flooding from a nearby dam. Flooding from changes in rainfall patterns due to climate change may also affect the habitat of this species.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is rare. Most of the population is in small and isolated subpopulations, with little or no exchange of individuals among them. Therefore, the population is considered as severely fragmented.
range: This species is known only from a small cluster of localities in Sri Lanka's Northwest Province, including Pomparippu, Kalivila and Wilpattu National Park (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009).
useTrade: There is not thought to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Most of its population is present within Wilpattu National Park.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from one specimen from the type locality and it has not been recorded again since. Nothing is known about its population size, trends, habitats and ecology and the threats that may be affecting it.
habitat: The known specimen was collected on a hillock; nothing else is known of its ecology (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009).
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species was described from a single specimen collected in 1944 (Taylor 1950). There is no information on abundance or population trends.
range: This species is known only from a site close to the shore 16 miles north of Trincomalee in Sri Lanka (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). The species has not been collected again, despite several surveys in the area (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is not thought to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if populations of this species are present in any protected areas. Additional research is needed into the distribution, habitat and ecology and potential threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from three specimens collected more than 150 years ago from an imprecise locality, and it has not been rediscovered despite extensive survey work for Cnemaspis throughout Sri Lanka. Based on the impacts facing congeners and the failure of island-wide surveys to rediscover it, the species may be extinct.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species, and no living population is known (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009).
threats: Any threats to this species are unknown. Nevertheless Sri Lanka has undergone extensive deforestation since the specimens were collected, and extensive surveys across the island for Cnemaspis geckos over the last decade have failed to record a population corresponding to this species. The Kandy region has been especially heavily developed and members of this group of geckos typically have highly restricted ranges. As such there is an expectation among Sri Lankan herpetologists that this species is likely to be extinct (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019), but without a clear type locality this is impossible to confirm, and another Sri Lankan gecko thought likely to be extinct - Cnemaspis tropidogaster - was rediscovered recently (Amarasinghe et al. 2016).
population: This species is known only from three specimens previously considered to belong to Cnemaspis kandiana, all collected prior to 1852 (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).
range: This species is known only from the type series with the imprecise locality data "Sri Lanka" (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Extensive surveys for Cnemaspis in Sri Lanka over the last decade have not recorded any living population corresponding to the type series. It is likely to have been collected in the Central Highlands, possibly in the general area of Kandy, as this was the area where Kelaart (from whom the type specimens were purchased) worked (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species, which is known only from historical specimens.
conservationActions: It is not known if this species occurs in any protected areas. Additional research is needed in an effort to rediscover this species.

rationale: This deep-living, demersal species is only known from two remote localities and a very limited number of specimens. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this deep-living, demersal species are poorly known. Its maximum standard length is 28.1 cm (Gomon and Struthers 2015).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from three type specimens, with the two Nazca Ridge specimens collected in 1979 and 1987 (Parin and Kotlyar 1989, Gomon and Struthers 2015); therefore, its population status is unknown.
range: This species is only known from two remote, oceanic localities in the Pacific: the Nazca Ridge (25°43'S, 85°29'W; Parin and Kotlyar 1989) and Rapa Iti in the Austral Islands of French Polynesia (Gomon and Struthers 2015). It has been collected at depths between 160-168 metres (Parin and Kotlyar 1989).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This relatively widely distributed, demersal species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The habitat preferences of this demersal species are poorly understood. It is only known from immature individuals to a maximum standard length of 5.8 cm, and probably attains a large size in adulthood (Hildebrand 1946).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are unavailable. This species is known from only immature individuals collected in 1929, 1933, 1934, 1935, 1941 and 1966 (Hildebrand 1946, iDigBio database accessed August 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern Pacific from Octavia Bay, Colombia and the Galapagos Islands to Lima, Peru (Hildebrand 1946, Vegas-Velez 1980, Bearez 1996, Grove and Lavenberg 1997, iDigBio database accessed July 2019). Its depth range is poorly understood.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This deep-living, demersal species is known from scattered localities in the Western Indian Ocean, and is likely more widely distributed than is currently known. Although little is known on its distribution, population and habitats, there are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths and has maximum standard length of 11.3 cm (Cressey 1981, Randall 2009).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited. It is known only from its holotype and paratype collected in the western Indian Ocean (Cressey 1981, Fricke et al. 2018).
range: This species is distributed in the western Indian Ocean and Red Sea: from South Africa (Ratnasingham and Hebert 2007), Madagascar (Fricke et al. 2018, Bogorodsky and Randall 2019), Tanzania (Ratnasingham and Hebert 2007), and Port Sudan, Sudan (Cressey 1981, Randall 2009, Bogorodsky and Randall 2019). Its depth range is 6-146 metres (Cressey 1981, Ratnasingham and Hebert 2007, Randall 2009); however, the depth distribution of adults is likely deeper, from about 50-150 m (B. Russell pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This demersal handfish is relatively poorly known, and is considered endemic to southeastern Australia. It is known from only three specimens that were collected from three localities in 1984 (about 34 years ago) on the continental shelf and upper slope. Considering other better-known handfish species that are endemic to this same area have experienced documented serious declines, there is particular concern for this species. Due to the lack of information on its distribution, ecology, population and potential threats, it is listed as Data Deficient. Given the intrinsic susceptibility of handfish species to declines, further research is highly recommended.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the continental shelf and upper slope, but very little is known on its specific habitat preferences or biology. It likely occurs amongst the macroinvertebrate community similar to other handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Its maximum known standard length is 6.5 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: Little is known on the threats impacting this species. Other shallow handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) that occur in the same region as this species have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017). Until further studies are conducted on handfishes in deeper depths, the potential threats to their populations remain poorly known.
population: This species is known from only three specimens that were taken in 1984 and has not been observed since. There has been considerable sampling effort by divers to search for handfish species in shallow areas, but the lack of targeted sampling in the deeper parts of its range causes its population status to be unknown (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). There is concern that population declines are possible based on well-documented declines in other shallow handfish species, including the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), Ziebell’s Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus) (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is patchily distributed in southern Australia from Victoria and Tasmania. Specimens have been collected from three localities: off Marlo, Bass Strait, Victoria; east of Maria Island, Tasmania; and east of Flinders Island, Tasmania. Specimens have been taken between 20-226 metres, but it possibly occurs deeper (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Its distribution, though thought to be restricted to southeastern Australia, is poorly understood due to the lack of sampling effort in the deeper portion of its range.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology, distribution and population, and there is a potential that declines may have occurred similar to other handfish species (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).

rationale: This demersal, deep-living species is relatively poorly known. It occurs in at least five subpopulations in a small area off New South Wales and Victoria, Australia and was last recorded in 1996 (about 22 years ago). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,791 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at a minimum of 20 km2, and is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2. Its global population is severely fragmented due to the species' low dispersal capability and serious impacts from trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to have occurred. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. This species qualifies for Vulnerable under Criterion B1 and Endangered under Criterion B2, and is therefore listed as Endangered B2ab(iii,v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the outer continental shelf where it probably occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). It may have special habitat requirements given its rarity and narrow distribution. Its maximum known total length is 6 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: It is likely that the prolonged trawl and dredge effort within the range of this species has caused both habitat destruction and direct mortality (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Other handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017).
population: This species is known from only seven specimens taken in 1983 and 1996. It has not been observed since despite considerable sampling effort by commercial, recreational and scientific entities (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is poorly understood. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to be impacting this species, and this activity could easily extirpate subpopulations very rapidly (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is patchily distributed in southeastern Australia from New South Wales and Victoria. Specimens have been collected from five localities: east of Bermagui, New South Wales, east of Disaster Bay, New South Wales, north-east of Eden, New South Wales, east of Mallacoota, Victoria and off Cape Conran, Bass Strait, Victoria. Specimens have been taken between 74-121 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around these points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 6,791 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the minimum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of five 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 20 km2, and the maximum is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology and population (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). A comprehensive survey of the Bass Strait is needed to clarify the status of this and other deep-living handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: This demersal, deep-living species is relatively poorly known. It occurs in at least two subpopulations in a small area off Victoria, Australia and was last recorded in 1996 (about 22 years ago). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,388 km2. The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 8 km2, and is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.  Its global population is severely fragmented due to the species' low dispersal capability and serious impacts from trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to have occurred. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. This species qualifies for Endangered under Criterion B1 and B2, and is therefore listed as Endangered B2ab(iii,v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the outer continental shelf and upper slope where it probably occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). It may have special habitat requirements given its rarity and narrow distribution. Its maximum known total length is 5.8 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: It is likely that the prolonged trawl and dredge effort within the range of this species has caused both habitat destruction and direct mortality (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Other handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017).
population: This species is known from only two specimens taken in 1984 and 1996. It has not been observed since despite considerable sampling effort by commercial, recreational and scientific entities (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). Rather than biases due to lack of sampling, the paucity of records is possibly due to natural rarity and a patchy distribution (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is poorly understood. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to be impacting this species, and this activity could easily extirpate subpopulations very rapidly (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from only two localities in southeastern Victoria, Australia: south of Cape Everard, Victoria and south-east of Lakes Entrance, Bass Strait, Victoria. Specimens have been taken between 112-218 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around these points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 2,388 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the minimum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of two 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 8 km2, and the maximum is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology and population (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). A comprehensive survey of the Bass Strait is needed to clarify the status of this and other deep-living handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: This deep-living, demersal species is only known from two specimens taken from a relatively small area off southeastern Australia in Tasmania. The most recent specimen was recorded in 1984 (about 34 years ago). Given its intrinsic susceptibility to declines due to its limited dispersal capabilities and that other better-known handfish species are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines, there is particular concern for this species. Due to the lack of information on its distribution, population, biology and potential threats, it is listed as Data Deficient. Further sampling in deep waters is needed.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the mid continental shelf and possibly the upper continental slope. Very little is known on its specific habitat preferences or biology. Its maximum known total length is 4.8 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: Species-specific threats are unknown. Other shallower occurring handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, bottom-fishing activities, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017). Until further studies are conducted on handfishes in deeper depths, the potential threats to their populations remain poorly known.
population:
This species is known from only two specimens that were taken in 1968 and 1984 and has not been observed since (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is unknown. 

Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches.

Other shallow handfish species, including the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), have experienced well-documented declines (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from only two localities in Tasmania, Australia. The first locality is east of Bruny Island in southeastern Tasmania. The second locality is uncertain; it was recorded as being taken off northwestern Tasmania, but may actually have been taken off eastern Tasmania. Specimens have been taken between 135-520 metres depth (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research, especially sampling in deep waters, is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).

rationale: This deep-living, demersal species is only known from a single specimen taken from the Great Australia Bight in the year 2000 (about 18 years ago). Given its intrinsic susceptibility to declines due to its limited dispersal capabilities and that other better-known handfish species are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines, there is particular concern for this species. Due to the lack of information on its distribution, population, biology and potential threats, it is listed as Data Deficient. Further sampling in deep waters is needed.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the continental shelf and possibly the upper continental slope where it likely occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Little is known on its specific habitat preferences or biology. The holotype, which is a juvenile, measured 2.9 cm total length (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: Species-specific threats are unknown. Other shallower occurring handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, bottom-fishing activities, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017). Until further studies are conducted on handfishes in deeper depths, the potential threats to their populations remain poorly known.
population:
This species is only known from the holotype specimen that was taken in 2000 (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is unknown. 

Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches.

 Other shallow handfish species, including the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), have experienced well-documented declines (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from only a single locality in Australia: southwest of Ceduna, Great Australian Bight, South Australia. The only specimen it is known from was taken at a depth of 145 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a single record, it is inferred that this species is restricted to southern Australia.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research, especially sampling in deep waters, is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).

rationale: This deep-living, demersal species is only known from a single specimen taken from western Tasmania in 2004 (about 14 years ago). Given its intrinsic susceptibility to declines due to its limited dispersal capabilities and that other better-known handfish species are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines, there is particular concern for this species. Due to the lack of information on its distribution, population, biology and potential threats, it is listed as Data Deficient. Further sampling in deep waters is needed.
habitat: This demersal species has been captured at a relatively deep depth on the outer continental shelf using a benthic sled. It likely occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Little is known on its specific habitat preferences or biology. The holotype measured 5.4 cm total length (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: Species-specific threats are unknown. Other shallower occurring handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, bottom-fishing activities, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017). Until further studies are conducted on handfishes in deeper depths, the potential threats to their populations remain poorly known.
population: This species is only known from the holotype specimen that was taken in 2004, but this is thought to be a function of lack of appropriate sampling rather than genuine rarity (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is unknown. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Other shallow handfish species, including the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), have experienced well-documented declines (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from only a single locality in Australia: Pieman Canyon, west of Granville Harbour, western Tasmania. The only specimen it is known from was taken at a depth of 176 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a single record, it is inferred that this species is restricted to southeastern Australia.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further sampling effort is needed to determine the status of this species (Last and Gledhill 2009).

rationale: This demersal, deep-living species is relatively poorly known. It occurs in at least five subpopulations in a small area off southeastern Australia and was last recorded in 2003 (about 15 years ago). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 25,394 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at a minimum of 20 km2, and is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2. Its global population is severely fragmented due to the species' low dispersal capability and serious impacts from trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to have occurred. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. The low numbers of individuals collected and insufficient sampling of the area and depth in which this species occurs introduces a not insignificant level of uncertainty to this assessment; however, given the known major threat from active bottom trawl fisheries combined with its inferred intrinsic susceptibility to declines, Data Deficient is not the most appropriate category. This species qualifies for Near Threatened under Criterion B1 and Endangered under Criterion B2, and is therefore listed as Endangered B2ab(iii,v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species has been captured using benthic sleds or demersal trawls at a relatively deep depth on the outer continental shelf and upper slope where it likely occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Little is known on its specific habitat preferences or biology. The largest specimen is 6.1 cm total length (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: It is likely that the prolonged trawl and dredge effort within the range of this species has caused both habitat destruction and direct mortality (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Other handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017).
population: This species is only known from five specimens that were taken in 1984, 1994, 1996 and 2003 (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is poorly understood. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely impacting this species, and this activity could easily extirpate subpopulations very rapidly (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from five localities in southeastern Australia: east of Cape Howe, New South Wales, south-east of Lakes Entrance, eastern Bass Strait, Victoria, south of Gabo Island, Victoria and south-east of Cape Barren Island, Bass Strait, Tasmania. Its depth range is 125–211 metres, but it possibly occurs shallower (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around these points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 25,394 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the minimum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of five 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 20 km2, and the maximum is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology and population (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). A comprehensive survey of the Bass Strait is needed to clarify the status of this and other deep-living handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Amblyeleotris delicatulus is a poorly known shrimp-goby only known from the holotype taken off the coast of Zanzibar. This species may be synonym of Amblyeleotris triguttata, which is reported from the Red Sea, Persian Gulf and Tanzania. However, given that the type specimen of Amblyeleotris delicatulus is in very poor condition, it cannot be confirmed. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Shrimp-gobies occur in symbiotic relationships with shrimps in the genus Alpheus. The type specimen measured 5.0 cm total length (Smith 1958). There is no habitat information available.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information.
range: This species may be a synonym of Amblyeleotris triguttata, which is known from the Red Sea, Persian Gulf and Tanzania. However, given that the type specimen of Amblyeleotris delicatulus (known from Zanzibar) is in very poor condition, it cannot be confirmed (Smith 1958).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: This species is only known from a single specimen collected from a relatively deep depth off Mozambique some time prior to 1953. Very little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only known specimen was measured 18 cm in length (Smith and McKay 1986). Little is known on its habitat preferences or biology.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is known from only a single specimen collected some time prior to 1953 (Smith 1953); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species is only known from one specimen collected at 100 m depth in the southern Mozambique Channel off Lourenço Marques, Mozambique (Smith 1953, Smith and McKay 1986).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is only known from two specimens collected in 1968, off central Kenya. Little is known on its distribution, population, habitats and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little information is available on the habitat preferences of this cryptic species. Its maximum standard length is 5.7 cm (Winterbottom 1982).
threats: The impact of major threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from the two type specimens collected in 1968 (Winterbottom 1982).
range: This species is only known from a single collection off central Kenya 22.5 km north of Malindi (Winterbottom 1982).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Haliophis diademus is distributed in the Western Indian Ocean known only from Oman. There is no population information for it. Despite its limited range, there are no major threats to this species and it is thus listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Although habitat and ecology information is very limited, it has been found inhabiting and hiding within the spines of sea urchins (i.e., Diadema). The maximum recorded total length (TL) for this species is 10 cm (Randall 1995).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: There is no population information for this species.
range: Haliophis diademus is a Western Indian Ocean species known only from Oman (Randall 1995, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Al-Jufaili et al. 2010). It is found at depths ranging from 8 to 12 m (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for H. diademus; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2017).

rationale: This species is restricted to northern and western Madagascar and the most recent collection occurred in 2012. Little is known on its habitat preferences and population. Threats to this species are are not well known, though it may be impacted by habitat degradation. Given its range across Madagascar and the limited scope of potential threats, this species is listed as Least Concern. Monitoring of this species and the threats to its habitat is recommended as a priority, moving forward.
habitat: Very little is known on the habitat preferences of this species. Its maximum standard length is 5.2 cm (Gill 2003).
threats: Threats to this species are largely unknown, however, habitat degradation resulting from coastal runoff could impact it (Raharimahefa and Kusky 2010).
population: This species is known from at least 14 specimens with the most recent collection occurring in 2012 (Gill 2003, Fricke et al. 2018).
range: This species is endemic to Madagascar in the Western Indian Ocean. It has been taken from Diego Suarez, Andilana, Toliara and Nosy Be (Fricke et al. 2018). Its depth range is unknown (Gill 2003).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This deep-living species is only known from a single collection off Kenya in 1964. Little is known on its distribution, habitats, population and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This deep-living, demersal species was collected via bottom trawl, and little is known on its habitat preferences. Its maximum standard length is 4.1 cm (Winterbottom 1979).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from two type specimens collected in 1964 (Winterbottom 1979).
range: This species is only known from a single collection on the Lamu Banks off Kenya (2°42'S, 40°53'E) in the southwestern Indian Ocean at a depth of 140 m (Winterbottom 1996).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This species is known from the type specimen collected at 68 m from the Seychelles. No additional information is available regarding its distribution, population, or potential threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Although there is very little habitat and ecology information available, it is a demersal, marine species and its larvae tend to have a preference for nocturnal movement within the water column (Devi 1999). The maximum recorded standard length (SL) is 5.7 cm (Amaoka et al. 2008).
threats: No major known threats.
population: There is little population data available. It is considered rare within the South China Sea (Devi 2001).
range: Engyprosopon sechellensis was described on the basis of the holotype collected from the Seychelles at 68 m (Regan 1908, Norman 1934). Records from the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, Indonesia, and South China Sea (Devi 1999, 2001) require verification.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2018).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from the original description over a century ago, and the state of preservation of the surviving specimen makes it difficult to refer new material to this taxon. Nothing is known of its distribution, natural history, population status or any threats.
habitat: There is no information on this species' natural history.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 67% of the area within a 10 km radius of the type locality contained natural vegetation, but nothing is known of its ecological requirements.
population: This species is known only from two historical specimens collected over a century ago.
range: The species is known only from its type locality, the Chapada dos Guimarães in the Cerrado (Lema 2001).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are in place. It is found in Parque Nacional da Chapada dos Guimarães.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that, while this species is known from a single specimen collected more than 135 years ago from an unspecified locality apparently on St. Croix, any surviving population is presumed to occur at a single location defined by a threat from mongoose predation and where it is expected to occur as a severely fragmented population, and to be undergoing a continuing decline as a result of predation by invasive mongoose. Both its extent of occurrence and area of occupancy are unknown, however while St. Croix has an area of 230 km<sup>2</sup> this large island is well-surveyed and any surviving population will undoubtedly occur over an area considerably below 100 km<sup>2</sup>, and possibly below 10 km<sup>2</sup>.
habitat: No ecological information is available for this species, and as no Capitellum species has been recorded for well over a century little can be inferred from comparisons with its closest relatives (Hedges and Conn 2012). Morphological analysis suggests a terrestrial or subterranean lifestyle (Hedges and Conn 2012). As foetuses of another species are known (Hedges and Conn 2012) it is presumed that C. parvicruzae too is viviparous, the typical reproductive mode of mabuyine skinks.
threats: A number of skinks found in the Virgin Islands, particularly the larger islands, are known only from historical records, most dating to the 19th Century (Hedges and Conn 2012). This includes another species known from St. Croix and collected at the same time, Spondylurus magnacruzae (Hedges and Conn 2012). The disappearance of these species has been attributed to the introduction of Indian mongoose (Herpestes javanicus) in the islands, which arrived on St. Croix at roughly the same time as this species' only known record was taken (Hedges and Conn 2012). It is possible that other processes, including predation by other exotic mammals and possibly agricultural and urban expansion, may have threatened this species (Hedges and Conn 2012). Forest habitats on St. Croix are now limited as a result of development (Hedges and Conn 2012), however in the complete absence of ecological information it is unknown whether it was reliant on forest habitats at risk from these pressures (Hedges and Conn 2012).
population: This species is known from a single specimen, collected in 1875 (Hedges and Conn 2012). Other Virgin Islands skinks have suffered declines or extinctions following mongoose introduction at about this time, and it is considered highly likely that the same is true of Capitellum parvicruzae (Hedges and Conn 2012, S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2013). Nevertheless, evidence from elsewhere in the Caribbean indicates that Spondylurus species can persist undetected on large, well-surveyed islands where mongoose are ubiquitous, albeit as very small, restricted-range populations (as is the case for S. fulgidus in Jamaica and S. nitidus in Puerto Rico), or can survive on small offshore islets (as with S. magnacruzae on Green Cay) (Hedges and Conn 2012, S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2013). By analogy with these cases, in which surviving subpopulations are highly fragmented or confined to a single locality, and under ongoing pressure from invasive species, any surviving population is presumed to be both severely fragmented and declining.
range: This species is apparently endemic to the large island of St. Croix in the US Virgin Islands, which has an area of 230 km2 (Hedges and Conn 2012). The only known specimen was reported with no more precise locality data (Hedges and Conn 2012). The introduction of mongoose to this island in the late 19th Century, and the seeming disappearance of Spondylurus magnacruzae at the same time, suggests that Capitellum parvicruzae is probably now extinct (Hedges and Conn 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species, which may be extinct.
conservationActions: This species is likely to be extinct, in which case no conservation measures are applicable. Nevertheless, this species was long overlooked in collections and its ecological requirements are unknown (Hedges and Conn 2012) and so no targeted surveys to rediscover it have previously been possible. Following its recognition as a valid species surveys are urgently needed to attempt to rediscover this species and to clarify whether any surviving populations are at risk before further conservation measures can be proposed (Hedges and Conn 2012). Captive breeding programs will probably be required if it is found to survive on St. Croix, as mongoose eradication is impossible on such a large island (Hedges and Conn 2012).

rationale: The Chilean Round Ray (Urobatis marmoratus) is a poorly-known, small (to 39 cm total length) ray known only from the type locality of Quinteros, Chile, in the Southeast Pacific. The holotype and only known specimen is missing and the species is unrecognizable from the drawing in the original description (which is from 1892). No habitat or depth information can be ascertained for the species. The exact occurrence of the species is not defined and as such inferences on fishing activities which may take this species (including as bycatch) cannot be made. The validity of the Chilean Round Ray is uncertain and this taxonomic uncertainty explains the lack of information on the Chilean Round Ray. There is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat or depth range of the Chilean Round Ray. Rounds rays generally inhabit shallow coastal waters at depths <30 m (Last et al. 2016). The size of the holotype in the original description (Philippi 1892) is 38.5 cm total length.
threats: Rounds rays are susceptible to capture in a variety of fishing gear given their occurrence in shallow coastal waters. However, no information is available on the Chilean Round Ray as its exact distribution and depth range are unknown.
population: This species is known only from the lost holotype and as such there is no available information on population structure or trend.
range: The Chilean Round Ray is known from a single specimen collected from Quinteros, Chile, in the Southeast Pacific (Philippi 1892).
useTrade: Rounds rays are generally not utilised due to their small size; they are often discarded when caught incidentally. There is, however, no information available on the Chilean Round Ray.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Chilean Round Ray. There is an urgent need to obtain records to clarify its validity, distribution, and habitat

rationale: The New Ireland Stingaree (Spinilophus armatus) is a small (to at least 17 cm total length) stingaree found in New Ireland, Bismarck Archipelago, Papua New Guinea in the Western Central Pacific. It is known from only one specimen collected on an expedition in 1822–1825 with the depth of collection unknown. There are likely shallow artisanal small-scale fisheries in its known range focused on reef fishes, sea cucumber, and lobster but whether they encounter this species is unknown. There are no deep-water industrial fisheries in the Bismark Archipelago. Further information is required on the distribution, life history, and in particular fisheries interactions, of the New Ireland Stingaree. Given that the depth range is unknown, it is difficult to ascertain the level of overall interactions with fisheries. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: The New Ireland Stingaree is likely demersal however the depth at which the single known specimen was collected is unknown (Séret and Last 2003, White et al. 2017). It reaches a maximum size of at least 17.4 cm total length (TL), which is the size of the juvenile male holotype (Séret and Last 2003). Reproduction is presumably viviparous, and it may have low fecundity, based on other Urolophids (Last et al. 2016), but nothing else is known of the biology of the species.
threats: There are likely to be shallow artisanal small-scale fisheries focused on reef fishes, sea cucumber, and lobster in the area of New Ireland Stingaree’s distribution but whether they encounter this species is unknown (Teh et al. 2014). There are no deep-water industrial fisheries in the Bismark Archipelago in northeastern Papua New Guinea (NFA 2020). This species was captured off New Ireland, which has a national fisheries college and presumably the capacity to undertake surveys of local fisheries markets. The absence of any records of this species in previous fish market surveys suggests that it does not interact with local fisheries in New Ireland.
population: Given the depth range of the New Ireland Stingaree is unknown, it is not possible to determine the interactions with fisheries and it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction.
range: The New Ireland Stingaree occurs off New Ireland in the Bismarck Archipelago, Papua New Guinea in the Western Central Pacific (Yearsley and Last 2016, Fricke et al. 2021). This species is known only from the holotype collected by Lesson and Garnot during an expedition in 1822–1825 (Séret and Last 2003).
useTrade: The use and trade of this species is unknown.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. Research is needed on distribution, population size and trend, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale: The Ecuador Skate (Dipturus ecuadoriensis) is a poorly-known skate known only from the type locality, San Helena Bay, Ecuador in the Southeast Pacific. No information is available other than of a taxonomic nature and no habitat or depth information can be ascertained for the species. Maximum size is unknown as the largest specimen (39 cm total length) was immature. The exact occurrence of the species is not defined and as such inferences on fishing activities which may take this species (including as bycatch) cannot be made. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat and depth range of the Ecuador Skate is unknown, although Last et al. (2016) state that it is 'presumably outer continental shelf and/or upper slope'. It is known only from the type series, with the largest specimen an immature male of 39 cm total length (Beebe and Tee-Van 1941, Last et al. 2016). Oviparous like other skates, but nothing else known of its biology.
threats: The exact occurrence of the species is not defined and as such inferences on fishing activities which may take this species (including as bycatch) cannot be made.
population: The population structure and trend is unknown for the Ecuador Skate. Since the depth range of the species is unknown, and therefore fisheries operating at those depths can't be evaluated in relation to potential interactions with this species, it is unclear if fishing is causing a population reduction.
range: The Ecuador Skate is known only from the type locality of San Helena Bay, Ecuador in the Southeast Pacific (Beebe and Tee-Van 1941, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: No details are available as habitat, and therefore potential interactions with fisheries and utilisation, are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for the Ecuador Skate. Surveys needs to document the distribution and occurrence of this species. Any catches (including as bycatch) of the species in local fisheries need to be examined.

rationale: The Brownspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus garmani) is a small (to at least 38 cm total length) deep-water catshark reported from the waters surrounding the Philippines (possibly Negros Island) in Western Central Pacific Ocean. This species is known from few specimens captured in the early 1900s and nothing is known of depth or full geographic distribution. The effect of regional deep-water fisheries, if any, on the species are unknown. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: The Brownspotted Catshark is likely demersal, but its depth range is unknown. It reaches a maximum size of at least 38 cm total length (TL) (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is likely oviparous. Nothing else is known of its biology.
threats: The effect of fishing activities, if any, on this species are unknown. In the Philippines, deep-water dogfish fisheries (primarily targeting Centrophorus spp and Squalus spp) date back to the 1960s (Flores 2004, BFAR 2017). These fisheries are poorly documented. In Cagayancillo, Palawan, Philippines, there are ~28 vessels in operation, setting demersal longlines to depths between 700–1,400 m (usually 800–1,000 m) (LAMAVE 2017). These deep-water fisheries are known for their boom-and-bust nature, given the lack of management, and collapse over short periods of time (~10 years) before effort is shifted into new regions (Flores 2004).
population: It is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction of the Brownspotted Catshark.
range: The Brownspotted Catshark occurs in the Western Central Pacific Ocean in the waters surrounding the Philippines, possibly Negros Island (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species is not known to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Brownspotted Catshark. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology and life history, as well potential species’ interactions with fisheries.

rationale: Meng's Skate (Okamejei mengae) is a small (to at least 30 cm total length) poorly-known skate that is known from only one specimen collected off Guangdong, China in the Northwest Pacific. The depth range is unknown, though it probably prefers soft-sediment habitats. It may be encountered by Chinese trawl fisheries. Given that the depth range is unknown, and the species’ full distribution has not been clarified, it is difficult to ascertain the level of interactions with regional fisheries. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: Meng's Skate has an unknown depth range and is probably demersal on the continental shelf on soft-sediment habitats (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a size of at least 30 cm total length (TL), though maximum size is unknown as only one immature female of 29.5 cm TL has been recorded (Jeong et al. 2007, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is presumably oviparous, like other skates (Last et al. 2016). Nothing else is known of its biology.
threats: There is no specific information available on bycatch of this species. It may be encountered by Chinese trawl fisheries that operate to depths of 300 m (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019), however the likelihood of this is unknown as the species' depth range is unknown.
population: No data are available on population trend of Meng's Skate. The depth range is unknown and therefore the population trend due to interactions with fisheries is unknown.
range: Meng's Skate is endemic to the northern South China Sea in the Northwest Pacific (Last et al. 2016). It is only known from one specimen, recorded off Shantou, Guangdong, China (Jeong et al. 2007).
useTrade: No information is available on use and trade.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. Research is required to define the species' depth range, distribution, habitat, life history, and population size and trend.

rationale: Wu’s Skate (Dipturus wuhanlingi) is a poorly-known medium-sized (to at least 100 cm total length) skate endemic to the South and East China Seas of the Northwest Pacific. The depth range is unknown, though it is probably demersal on the continental slope at depths below 200 m. It is an infrequent bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast coast of Taiwan which retain all catch for human consumption or fish meal. Given that the depth range is unknown, it is difficult to ascertain the level of interactions with regional fisheries. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: Wu's Skate is demersal with an unknown depth range (Weigmann 2016).
