It is known only from two type specimens with no recorded depth of capture and from Da-xi fish market, Taiwan where it was observed alongside other deep-water skates that implies it was caught on the continental slope in depths below 200 m (Jeong and Nakabo 2008, Last et al. 2016, D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). It reaches a size of at least 100 cm total length (TL) but its maximum size is unknown (D. Ebert unpub. data 2019); a 66.8 cm TL male was immature and a 78.4 cm TL female's maturity status was unknown (Jeong and Nakabo 2008). Reproduction is presumably oviparous, like other skates (Last et al. 2016). Nothing else is known of its biology.
threats: There is no specific information available on bycatch of this species. Some specimens were observed at Da-xi fish market in northeast Taiwan, presumed to be taken as bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast coast of Taiwan at depths of 200–700 m; these fisheries target multiple species of shrimp with all the incidental catch retained (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). It may be encountered by Chinese trawl fisheries that operate to depths of 300 m (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019), however the likelihood of this is unknown as the depth range is unknown.
population: The population trend is unknown for Wu's Skate. It is currently only known from two type specimens and approximately four specimens observed at Da-xi fish market, Taiwan (Jeong and Nakabo 2008, D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). The depth range is unknown and therefore the population trend due to interactions with fisheries is unknown.
range: Wu's Skate is endemic to Taiwan and China in the South and East China Seas, Northwest Pacific (Jeong and Nakabo 2008, Ebert et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: No information is available on use and trade; if retained it may be used for human consumption or fish meal.
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. Research is required to define the species' depth range, distribution, habitat, life history, and population size and trend.

rationale: The Bluespotted Bambooshark (Chiloscyllium caeruleopunctatum) is a small (to at least 67 cm total length) poorly-known demersal carpetshark that occurs in the Western Indian Ocean and is only known from Toliara to Tôlanaro, southern Madagascar. This represents ~600 km of coastline, and therefore area of occupancy is likely to be <2,000 km². This species is known from very few specimens, its habitat and depth range are unknown, and nothing is known of its biology. Since it is currently not possible to assess the level of fisheries mortality to which the Bluespotted Bambooshark is exposed, it is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The Bluespotted Bambooshark is a demersal carpetshark that is known to reach a maximum size of at least 67 cm total length (TL) (Pellegrin 1914). The depth range of this species is unknown, although similar to most other members of this genera, it probably inhabits inshore shallow waters (Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing is known of this species' biology, but it is likely oviparous like other bamboosharks.
threats: The threats to this species are unknown, but artisanal and industrial fishing pressure are high within its known range (Le Manach et al. 2012). Further information is needed on habitat and depth range in order to establish the level of interaction with fisheries.
population: This species is known from only a few specimens and there are no population size or trend estimates. There is no available catch data from congeners across this species' range that could be used to infer population trends.
range: The Bluespotted Bambooshark occurs in the Western Indian Ocean and is only known from Toliara to Tôlanaro, southern Madagascar (Pellegrin 1914, B. Séret, pers. comm., 27 January 2019). Its distribution may not be fully defined, but as currently known, this represents ~600 km of coastline, and therefore area of occupancy is likely to be <2,000 km².
useTrade: The utilization of the Bluespotted Bambooshark is not known.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed on distribution, population size and trends, life history, and catch rates.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because, while the distribution is poorly-known it is suspected that this has a limited range of presumed less than 5,000 km<sup>2</sup> EOO, all of which is under acute development pressure. However, additional surveys are urgently needed to confirm the full range of this species, with a reassessment recommended as soon as more information becomes available.
habitat: There is little habitat or ecology information available for this likely fossorial species.
threats: The type locality has been lost through urban expansion, and there is extensive development ongoing within the probable range of this species.
population: It is known only from a few specimens, and the population trend is not known.
range: This species is only known from type collection from Japoma in Cameroon (Gans 1987). It occurs close to sea level.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research into the biology and ecology, population size and range, habitat preferences should be carried out. There is a need to undertake directed field surveys to locate populations of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as there is insufficient information on this species' range, population and threats for a valid conservation assessment.
habitat: This species has been observed at the Ataran River in Myanmar (Chanda et al. 2000), however, its habitat requirements and ecology are unknown. The species is presumably somewhat arboreal, as are its congeners. Much of its reproductive biology remains unknown and is difficult to infer as frogs in its genus have varying reproductive strategies. Habitat throughout much of Myanmar is undergoing a continuing decline in quality and extent due agriculture and mining (Bhagwat et al. 2017), however, it is unknown how this particular species' habitat is affected.
threats: Habitat throughout much of Myanmar is undergoing a continuing decline in quality and extent due to commercial plantations (oil palm, rubber, sugar cane), shifting agriculture and mining (Bhagwat et al. 2017). The species may be threatened by habitat loss, but further surveys are required to determine this and other potential threats.
population: Nothing is known about this species' population or trends except that it is only known with certainty from a series of four specimens (Chanda et al. 2000). Further research is warranted to determine the species' relative abundance and trends, however, ongoing habitat loss throughout its range (FAO 2015) is likely causing some declines.
range: This species is currently known with certainty only from a single locality in Tenasserim Province, Myanmar (Stoliczka 1870, Chanda et al. 2000). The species' specific habitat requirements and the precise elevation at its type locality are unknown, however, the Tenasserim area is approximately 500-900 m asl and the terrain at the species' known locality does not intricate any likelihood that it is a point endemic. Thus, the species' current or historic range probably extends outside of this area. The species has not been observed in over a century and the local habitat is modified to such an extent that the species' persistence there is uncertain. For this reason, the range map associated with this assessment is a 10 km2 circle around Tenasserim, as well as several adjacent patches of forest of similar elevation, all denoted with 'presence uncertain'.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilised.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
No conservation strategies are in place for this species and it is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
The first step towards ensuring this species' long-term persistence is addressing the lack of data; additional surveys are needed to understand its true distribution, relative abundance, population trend, life history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known only from historical records from a remote archipelago, and while it may not have been subject to significant impacts in the 90 years since it was last collected tourist development now appears to be underway. The impacts of this, and of any threats that may result from greater accessibility of this archipelago resulting from this development, are unknown.
habitat: This species is known only from historical specimens and nothing is known of its natural history (Grismer et al. 2014). If, as presently appears to be the case, it is the only Cnemaspis to occur in the Anambas Archipelago, it is likely to be a habitat generalist due to the absence of competitors (Grismer et al. 2014),
threats: The Anambas archipelago is extremely remote, and direct human impacts are unlikely (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019). Photographs indicate the presence of infrastructure to support fishing on Siantan and tourist development is underway, which may increase accessibility of the island both for research and potentially threatening activities.
population: This species is known from six specimens, three collected in 1899 and the remainder in 1925 (Grismer et al. 2014). There have been no recent surveys of this archipelago (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is known only from Pulau Siantan in the Anambas Archipelago in Indonesia's Riau Province (Grismer et al. 2014). It is likely to occur on other nearby islands such as Pulau Matak, although it was not reported in a survey of the nearby Pulau Jimaja (Grismer et al. 2014). It has been collected at an elevation of 400 m asl (Grismer et al. 2014).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas. More surveys are recommended within the archipelago, as this species is known only from historical records from an unsurveyed area and nothing is known of its ecology.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient since it has only recently been described, and there is still very little information on its extent of occurrence, status, threats and ecological requirements.
habitat: There is no ecological information associated with this species. The specimen was confused with Calanaria virgulata when first collected (Amarasinghe et al. 2015), a species found beneath rotting logs and other ground cover in primary forest.
threats: Although there is no direct evidence, given it is high elevation species  climate change and deforestation might pose threats to this species (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is known from a single specimen collected in 2000 (Amarasinghe et al. 2000).
range: This recent described species is known only from Awan Village, Rindingalo in South Sulawesi Province, Indonesia, at 2,150 m asl (Amarasinghe et al. 2015). It appears to be restricted to the interior portion of central Sulawesi, and may be limited to higher elevations (Amarasinghe et al. 2015).
useTrade: There is no use and trade for this species.
conservationActions: It does not occur in any protected areas. Research needed to better understand its population, distribution and ecology (A.A.T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because it has only recently been described, and there remains limited information concerning the species distribution, natural history, habitat needs and possible threats.
habitat: The habitat needs of this species remain little-known, and require additional research.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: There is limited information on the population abundance or trends of this recently described snake.
range: This species is known only from the vicinity of Nushki east to Ziarat District in northeastern Baluchistan, Pakistan at elevations up to 2,400 m asl (Schätti et al. 2014). It may range further south than is presently known along the Brahui range, and possibly north to the Toba Kakar Mountains (Schätti et al. 2014).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if any populations of this snake are present within protected areas. Further studies into the distribution, natural history and possible threats are suggested.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat or natural history of this species.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species appears to be known only from the holotype (Meiri et al. 2017),
range: This species is known from the Andaman Islands, where its type locality was described as "Narcondum".
useTrade: There is not any trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if populations are in any protected areas. Much further research is needed to rediscover this species, and better understand the taxonomy, distribution, natural history, and potential treats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its status, ecological requirements and possible threats.
habitat: The habitat and ecology of this species is poorly-known, it may be an arboreal species but this requires confirmation.
threats: The threats to this species on Preparis Island are not known.
population: The population abundance and trends for this species are not known.
range: This species is endemic to India, where it is known only from the small and rocky Preparis Island (Andamans Archipelago, Bay of Bengal) (Manamendra-Arachchi et al. 2007).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not present in any protected areas. Much further study is needed into the natural history, population and potential threats to this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen from an indeterminate locality, supposedly in India, and nothing is known if its distribution, population status, ecology or any threats.
habitat: Nothing is known of the ecology of this species.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: It is known only from a single specimen.
range: This species is known from a single specimen with the vague type locality "India". It may be restricted to northeast India, but no extant population is known. It is thought that the type locality may be in error (Murthy et al. 2012) . Two other specimens within the British Museum of Natural History that may correspond to Homalopsis hardwickii have the locality of “Bengal” but do not agree well with the holotype and the locality information is followed by a question mark in the BMNH catalogue. This species remains to be re-discovered and its distribution to be determined (Murphy et al. 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Research is needed to rediscover this species and obtain clarity on its distribution and taxonomy.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its distribution, natural history, threats and conservation status.
habitat: The habitat and natural history of this species are not known.
threats: The threats to this species are not known, however a major portion of Khasi Hills is subject to extensive mining pressure (open cast coal).
population: This species is known only from the type specimen.
range: This enigmatic species is only known from the imprecise type locality of 'Khasi Hills, Meghalaya State', India. The elevational limit is not known.
useTrade: There is not use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species has not been recorded from any protected areas. New field surveys are needed to try to locate this species, and learn more about the natural history, distribution and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient because there is no conclusive information about the distribution of this species, no information on the natural history and the threats to the species.
habitat: This burrowing species likely inhabits wet evergreen forests, but the ecology of this poorly-known and presumably fossorial snake is not known with certainty
threats: Nothing is known about the general threats to this species. The Western Ghats are impacted by multiple human activities including agricultural development and forest degradation, but nothing is known of the species' true distribution or ability to adapt to modified habitats.
population: There are no quantitative data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species is apparently present in the Western Ghats south of the Goa Gap in India, but the lack of a re-description following recent taxonomic changes make its true range limits unclear (Pyron et al. 2016). The type locality is not known with certainty (Pyron et al. 2016). The species is not mapped here because of uncertainty as to where it truly occurs.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if populations are present in any protected areas. Research is needed into the taxonomy of this species, the distribution, the natural history and threats.

rationale: Uropeltis nitida is known only from the type locality based on the type series collected in the late 19th century.  There is no information on the population status, biology and threats for this species. Hence, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Nothing is known about the habitats and ecology of Uropeltis nitida.
threats: Nothing is known about the general threats to this species. However, many parts of Neliampathy Hills are covered by tea, coffee, cardamom and orange plantations, and tourism-related developmental activities are also being carried out. It is unknown whether these represent major threats to this species.
population: Nothing is known about the population status of Uropeltis nitida.
range: Uropeltis nitida is endemic to the Western Ghats, India and is known only from the Nelliyampathy in Anaimalai Hills (at 1,300 m), Palakkad district, Kerala (Smith 1943). There are no recent sighting records of this species.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Uropeltis nitida is known only from the Nelliyampathy area in Western Ghats in Palakkad District, Kerala, which is a reserve forest tract and is presently a famous tourism spot. As this species has not been reported in the recent past, there is an urgent need to establish its existence and distribution.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status, and ecological requirements. The taxonomy of this species needs to be clarified; it is provisionally recognized as a species, however, its taxonomic status needs to be reassessed in the context of a systematic revision of the R. niobe complex.
habitat: The natural history of this species is unknown.
threats: Possible threats to this species are not known.
population: The population of this species is unknown.
range: This species is known from the holotype, collected on the Vogelkop Peninsula of Papua Province, Indonesia at 2,000 m Asl, and some additional specimens in the Australian Museum in Sydney (Helgen 2007). The area has not been well collected, so it could well be more widely distributed in the Arfak Mountains.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species was collected from within the Arfak Nature Reserve. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this species.

rationale: This widely distributed species was only recently re-described as valid. Little is known on its population, and it is likely exploited in artisanal fisheries at some unknown level. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Little information is available on the habitat preferences of this species. Its maximum standard length is 21 cm (Iwatsuki et al. 2016).
threats: Over-fishing may be a threat on a localised level.
population: This species was recently re-described as valid (Iwatsuki et al. 2016); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species is distributed in the Western Indian Ocean from South Africa (Sodwana Bay and Cape Vidal), Mauritius, the Seychelles, Saya de Malha Bank (southwest of the Chagos Archipelago) and the Maldives. Photographic evidence indicates it may also occur in Mozambique, Madagascar and Réunion (Iwatsuki et al. 2016). Its depth range is not known, but specimens have been captured from shallow, nearshore localities.
useTrade: This species is likely taken in artisanal mixed-species snapper fisheries that occur throughout its range.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Eviota nigrispina occurs from West Papua and the Ryukyu Islands, Japan to 20 m depth. Additional information about its population and ecology is needed. However, it is likely more widespread than what is known. It has been photographed sitting on live coral, a habitat that is under threat from local impacts and regional oceanographic changes associated with climate change. As these impacts to its habitat and its requirement for live coral are unknown, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no habitat information available for this species. The maximum recorded length for this species is 1.5 cm SL (Greenfield and Suzuuki 2010).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: Eviota nigrispina occurs from West Papua and Amami-oshima Island, Kakeroma Islands, Ishigaki-jima Island and Iriomote-jima Island in the Ryukyu Islands, Japan. This recorded depth range for this species is 6- 20 m depth (Greenfield and Suzuki 2010).
useTrade: This species is used in the aquarium trade (Greenfield and Suzuki 2010).
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for E. nigrispina.

rationale: The species is known from only two specimens collected in Chile in 1962 and there is some uncertainty about the validity of this species. More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population, biology and potential threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information for this poorly known species. The maximum recorded length is 25 cm total length.
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: Population information is not available, as it is known only from two specimens.
range: This species is known only from two specimens from the type locality in Arica, Chile (Pequeño and Sáez 2000).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures for this species. More research is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population, biology, ecology and potential threats.

rationale: This species is known only from one specimen from Chile. The taxonomic validity of the species has been questioned and the full distribution is unknown. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient. More research on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, habitat and ecology is needed.
habitat: There is no information on habitat and ecology for this species.
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information available, as it is known only from a single specimen.
range: This species is only known from a single specimen from the type locality at Iquique, Chile.
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures for this species. Further fieldwork is necessary to locate specimens and define the distribution of this species, its population status, habitat, and ecology and any potential threats.

rationale: This species is only known from the Yüksekova drainage, an endorheic basin nested within the upper Tigris catchment in Turkey. The species hasn't been recorded since 1974, despite recent surveys in the area. However threats to the species are unknown as it resides in a small, uninhabited, high altitude endorheic basin where impacts from human activities are unlikely. More research is needed on this species to be able to assess its conservation status.
habitat: Specific habitat requirements for this species are unknown. It has only been recorded from an endorheic basin: a close drainage basin with no outflowing tributaries.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown, but it is endemic to a little uninhabited high altitude endorheic basin where impacts from human activities are unlikely.
population: The species has not been found since 1974, despite of recent surveys in the area.
range: The species is only known from the Yüksekova drainage, which is an endorheic basin nested within the upper Tigris catchment, in Turkey.
useTrade: There are no data about the use of this species
conservationActions: None in place. Some research is strongly recommended to search for the species and to learn about its distribution and threats.

rationale: Aphyocharax agassizii é conhecida de apenas dois exemplares, coletados na segunda metade do século XIX, em uma localidade reportada como sendo Jatuarana, Brasil. Desde a descrição original, outros exemplares não foram coletados. A espécie é mal definida taxonomicamente, os síntipos se encontram em mau estado de preservação e a localidade-tipo é incerta, embora se refira a algum local na região Amazônica. Os problemas taxonômicos impedem que a distribuição geográfica da espécie e possíveis impactos sejam detectados. Por estes motivos, A. agassizii foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia de Aphyocharax agassizii. Sabe-se que a espécie apresenta comprimento padrão máximo de 3,32cm (Lima 2003).
threats: Os problemas taxonômicos impedem que a distribuição geográfica e possíveis impactos sobre Aphyocharax agassizii sejam detectados.
population: Não há informação disponível sobre a biologia populacional da espécie ou dados populacionais.
range: Aphyocharax agassizii apresenta distribuição geográfica na bacia do rio Amazonas, no Brasil (Lima 2003). A espécie é conhecida de apenas dois exemplares, coletados na segunda metade do século XIX, em uma localidade incerta, reportada como sendo Jatuarana, Amazônia, Brasil. Desde a descrição original, outros exemplares não foram coletados.
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários inventários para conhecer a área de distribuição real de Aphyocharax agassizii.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: The distribution of this species is not known with precision, as it was imported together with Fundulopanchax ndianus from the border area between Nigeria and Cameroon. More information is needed on its distribution and threats before an assessment of its extinction risk can be made. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is benthopelagic, non-migratory and is not a seasonal killifish. It is a bottom spawner with five months incubation (Huber 1996). Aside from this, there is no known habitat information for this species.
threats: Major threats are unknown as the location is not confirmed, although it has been harvested for the aquarium trade.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: The distribution of this species is not known with precision. It was imported together with Fundulopanchax ndianus from the border area between Nigeria (towards Osombo and Mamfé) and Cameroon (Romand 1992).
useTrade: This species has been harvested for the aquarium trade, but is difficult to maintain in aquaria (Huber 1996).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions in place for this species. More information is needed on the distribution and threats to this species.

rationale: Henonemus intermedius foi descrita da bacia do rio Tocantins-Araguaia, de localidade-tipo incerta, citada originalmente como "Goyaz- Brasil". Existem dúvidas sobre a validade da espécie, que pode ser um sinônimo júnior de Henonemus punctatus. A bacia do rio Tocantins-Araguaia está sujeita a impactos de empreendimentos hidrelétricos, atividades agropecuárias, mineração e desmatamento, o que pode representar ameaças difusas a espécie. Contudo, devido à falta de informação sobre a real distribuição, aliada à incerteza sobre a validade da espécie, não é possível avaliar seu estado de conservação. Portanto a espécie foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Henonemus intermedius alcança tamanho corporal total de 80 mm (de Pinna e Wosiacki 2003). Outras espécies do gênero são demersais de água doce (Fishbase 2012).
threats: Não é possível avaliar ameaças, uma vez que a distribuição geográfica é incerta.
population: Não existem dados de tamanho populacional, o estado populacional é desconhecido.
range: Henonemus intermedius é endêmica do Brasil. Reportada como ocorrendo na bacia do rio Araguaia-Tocantins, (Pinna e Wosiacki 2003, Wosiacki e Pinna 2007, Do Nascimento e Provenzano 2006). A localidade-tipo é incerta, provavelmente algum lugar na bacia do rio Araguaia-Tocantins (Lima 2004, Lote MCZ 9842).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não foram encontradas ações de conservação para o táxon. Não há registro em Unidades de Conservação. Sugere-se que a validade da espécie seja avaliada em pesquisas de taxonomia e sistemática.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: Hypostomus angipinnatus é conhecida apenas do holótipo, que está perdido, e sua localidade-tipo é “Mato Grosso”. Assim, não é possível determinar sua real distribuição e ameaças. Hypostomus angipinnatus foi categorizado como Dados Insuficientes (DD). Pode-se tratar de uma Species inquirendae.
habitat: Não há informação sobre o habitat e ecologia da espécie.
threats: Por Hypostomus angipinnatus ser conhecido apenas de seu holótipo, que está perdido, com localidade-tipo imprecisa (“Mato Grosso”), não é possível determinar sua real distribuição e ameaças.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis.
range: Hypostomus angipinnatus é conhecida apenas do holótipo, proveniente de localidade tipo imprecisa, citada apenas como Mato Grosso, Brasil. O mesmo holótipo encontra-se perdido no Phyletisch Museum, Jena (Weber 2003).
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos a respeito da taxonomia, limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Hypostomus angipinnatus.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: No data since its description from a specimen caught in Oum Erbiah (Talmist river) in central Morocoo. No data on present abundance, population trend or threats.
habitat: No data.
threats: No data.
population: Not abundant (Doadrio, I. pers comm).
range: It is restricted to Morocco, however its distribution is unknown.
conservationActions: None.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and has been considered a junior synonym of another poorly-known species for over a century. Nothing is known of its true distribution, population status, natural history or any threats.
habitat: Nothing is known about the natural history of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known with certainty from a single specimen accessioned at the start of January 1900 (Grismer et al. 2018).
range: This species is known only from Indragiri, Djapura, Sumatra, Indonesia (Grismer et al. 2018). The suggestion by Das (2010) that this locality is Indrajiri, in Riau Province in east Sumatra, appears to be in error, as the type locality listed in the original description is in southeast Sumatra (Grismer et al. 2018). A museum specimen identified as Lygosoma bampfyldei from 10 miles west of Petumbukan in north Sumatra was collected in 1912 (G. Shea pers. comm. 2019) and appears to have been missed by Grismer et al. (2018). The specific identity of this specimen is in need of clarification, but as L. bampfyldei is no longer considered to occur on Sumatra this may represent L. schneideri.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Surveys are needed to rediscover this species and obtain data on its ecology, population status and any threats, as well as to clarify whether the Petumbukan record is conspecific with the holotype.

rationale: Hypostomus variostictus foi descrita em 1912 de um único exemplar jovem e sua diagnose é pouco precisa, dificultando a identificação da espécie. Sua localidade-tipo é Coxim, Mato Grosso do Sul, Brasil. A falta de novos registros confiáveis e a dificuldade de identificação dessa espécie inviabilizam a estimativa de sua distribuição no Brasil, e consequentemente a avaliação de seu estado de conservação no país. Assim, Hypostomus variostictus foi categorizada como Dados Insuficientes (DD). Recomendam-se estudos taxonômicos e de distribuição da espécie.
habitat: Não existem informações sobre a história natural da espécie.
threats: Embora existam ameaças difusas que possam afetar a população de Hypostomus variostictus, os efeitos das mesmas não podem ser dimensionados neste momento devido à ausência de dados sobre a mesma.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis, devido à falta de novos registros confiáveis da espécie.
range: Hypostomus variostictus foi descrita em 1912 de um único exemplar jovem proveniente de Coxim, Mato Grosso (que hoje equivale ao Mato Grosso do Sul), sendo esse o único exemplar conhecido da espécie (Weber 2003). Sua diagnose é pouco precisa, dificultando a identificação da espécie, o que resulta na falta de novos registros confiáveis e a estimativa da distribuição da espécie.
useTrade: Não há nenhuma informação disponível sobre uso ou comercio desta espécie.
conservationActions:
Não existem programas de conservação para essa espécie no Brasil. Não há registro de presença da espécie em Unidades de Conservação. São necessários estudos a respeito da taxonomia, limites de distribuição, tendências populacionais e biologia de Hypostomus variostictus.

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale: This presumably deep-living species is only known from the holotype collected in Hawaii in 1950. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is likely demersal (Mundy 2005). The only known specimen has a standard length of 22.2 cm (Gosline 1954).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species only known from the holotype collected in 1950 (Gosline 1954).
range: This species is only known from the type locality off Mauna Loa, Hawaii (Gosline 1954, Nielsen et al. 1999, Mundy 2005). Its depth range is unknown, as the only known specimen was found floating dead on the surface (Gosline 1954, Mundy 2005), but it likely inhabits deep depths similar to other members of this genus.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This presumably deep-living species is only known from three specimens collected from three closely-spaced localities off southern Japan. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a demersal species, and its habitat preference is poorly understood. Other species in this genus inhabit the continental slope. The largest known specimen has a total length of 40 cm (Machida 1988, Nakabo 2013).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from three specimens (Machida 1988).
range: This species is known from three closely-spaced localities off southern Japan from Tosa Bay, Suruga Bay and Tokyo Bay (Machida 1988, Nielsen 1999, Shinohara et al. 2001, Nakabo 2013). Depth of capture has not been recorded (Machida 1988).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts.

rationale: This deep-living species is only known from the holotype, which is a larval specimen, collected from the Kermadec Trench in 1952. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology or potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is only known from a single larval specimen (Markle and Olney 1990, Williams and Machida 1992), but adults are either free-living or possibly facultative commensals with invertebrate species, similar to other species in this family (Nielsen et al. 1999). The maximum length is not known.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from the holotype collected in 1952 (Markle and Olney 1990).
range: This species is only known from the type locality in the southwestern Pacific in the Kermadec Trench north of New Zealand (Markle and Olney 1990, Nielsen et al. 1999). The only known specimen was collected at a depth between 8,200-8,300 metres (Markle and Olney 1990, Linley et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This deep-living species is endemic to and has a relatively small range in New Zealand waters. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species has a maximum total length of 20 cm (Markle and Olney 1990). This is largely an understudied species, but similar to other congeners, it is either a free-living or possibly facultative commensal with invertebrate hosts such as holothuroids, asteroids, bivalves or ascidians (Nielsen et al. 1999, Roberts et al. 2015).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is only known from six specimens (Markle and Olney 1990, Roberts et al. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to New Zealand waters. It occurs on the Campbell Plateau from the Auckland Islands to the Chatham Islands and Banks Peninsula (Markle and Olney 1990, Nielsen et al. 1999, Roberts et al. 2015). Its depth range is 117-240 metres (Markle and Olney 1990, Roberts et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This demersal species is only known from three specimens collected from three closely-spaced localities off North Island, New Zealand in 1958, 2004 and 2011. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology or potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal species has a maximum total length of 16.5 cm (Parmentier 2012). It is possibly a free-living species or a faculative commensal with invertebrates similar to other related species in the family Carapidae (Nielsen et al. 1999).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from three specimens collected in 1958, 2004 and 2011 (Parmentier 2012).
range: This species is only known from three closely-spaced localities off the North Island of New Zealand. Its depth range is 30-315 metres (Parmentier 2012).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This deep-living species is only known from the holotype collected off southern New Zealand in 1979. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology or potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal species may be free-living or possibly a facultative commensal with invertebrate hosts such as holothuroids, asteroids, bivalves or ascidians (Nielsen et al. 1999, Roberts et al. 2015). The only known specimen has a total length of 23.2 cm (Markle and Olney 1990).
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from the holotype collected in 1979 (Markle and Olney 1990).
range: This species is only known from the type locality in the southwestern Pacific on the southwest slope of the Bounty Trough off southern New Zealand. The only known specimen was captured at a depth between 857-860 metres (Markle and Olney 1990).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Listed as Data deficient, as it is very poorly-known, and it is unclear whether it still persists mostly because of its largely fossorial habitat and extensive habitat conversion within the only collection locality area.
habitat: Nothing is known of this species' natural history. This species is presumed to be semifossorial and to feed on elongate vertebrates such as fish, skinks, snakes and caecilians (Kieckbusch et al. 2016). It appears to be nocturnal and viviparous, in common with other species of Cylindrophis whose reproductive mode is known (Kieckbusch et al. 2016).
threats: This species has not been collected for more than 80 years, and while this is thought likely to reflect undersampling it is possible that extensive historical deforestation and agricultural intensification along Java's south-central coast may have resulted in the extinction of this or other range-restricted species (Kieckbusch et al. 2016). Research is recommended to determine whether this species survives, and if so whether it is at risk from these or other processes (Kieckbusch et al. 2016).
population: This species is known from eight specimens, all collected or presumed to have been collected in 1937 (Kieckbusch et al. 2016). This scarcity may reflect a combination of its presumably restricted distribution and its semi-fossorial lifestyle (Kieckbusch et al. 2016), as well as its potential for confusion in the field with Cylindrophis ruffus.
range: This species is known only from the type series collected at Grabag on the south coast of Purworejo Regency, Central Java, Indonesia, and from two specimens with imprecise locality data which may have been taken in the same area (Kieckbusch et al. 2016). The species probably occurs more widely than presently known but is likely to have a relatively limited distribution in the South Central Java Basin, which is enclosed by mountain ranges to the north, west and east and by the coast to the south (Kieckbusch et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Surveys of the type locality are recommended to clarify this species' distribution and population status and to identify any threats to its survival (Kieckbusch et al. 2016).

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient, as it is know only from three specimens and the habitat needs, adaptability and overall threats to this species are currently unclear. If the species is determined to be a forest obligate, associated with primary tropical moist forest, it seems probable that it would be highly threatened, potentially Critically Endangered.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species. All Cylindrophis are fossorial and appear to be viviparous and nocturnal (Kieckbusch et al. 2018).
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species (Kieckbusch et al. 2018), however, the island has very little primary forest remaining and if it is a forest obligate forest species it may be highly threatened (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is known from three museum specimens, two dated to 1865 and one collected some time prior to the 1960s, that were long confused with other species (Kieckbusch et al. 2018).
range: This species is known only from Boano Island, off the northwestern coast of Seram, in northern Maluku Province, Indonesia, and may be endemic as it was not recorded in surveys of Seram (Kieckbusch et al. 2018). The island has an area of around 125 km2 (Collar et al. 1994). One specimen with no confirmed locality data was tentatively associated with Sulawesi, but the absence of additional material from this island suggests this is in error (Kieckbusch et al. 2018).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas on Boano Island. Additional surveys are needed to rediscover this species and to learn about its natural history, and potential threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from two specimens collected in 1829 from a poorly-surveyed island and it has only recently been recognized as a distinct species.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species. The species with which it was formerly confused is an oviparous snake inhabiting lowland primary and secondary rainforest.
threats: Satellite imagery suggests that relatively little natural forest remains on Semau. The species may consequently be impacted by clearance or burning of the remaining dry forest (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019), but nothing is known of the extent or causes of this activity or of this species' ability to tolerate disturbance.
population: This species is known from two specimens with an unspecified collection date, but which Kaiser et al. (2018) determine to have been in mid-1829.
range: This species is known from Semau Island in East Nusa Tenggara Province in Indonesia (Kaiser et al. 2018).
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas. Research is needed

rationale: This marine, demersal species is distributed in the Western Indian Ocean, specifically known from Sri Lanka and India. It is a data poor species and information relating to its population, life history and ecology is limited. There is no use and trade information for it and it is unknown how threats impact it. Given its reasonably broad distribution, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This marine, demersal species is data poor and information relating to its life history and ecology is limited. It is known to grow to a maximum standard length of 18.2 cm (Russell 1996).
threats: It is unknown how pervasive threats impact this species.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-3236319b-7fff-8d86-6615-e18f4d4e4a4c">There is no population information for this species.
range: This species is known from the Western Indian Ocean. It has specifically been described from Sri Lanka and more recently recorded from India based on 22 specimens collected in Cochin fisheries harbor (Russell 1996, Nair et al. 2016).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-d51b8a3e-7fff-9787-1464-c342c4c38c16">There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: This nominal species is known from a single specimen taken at an unknown depth along northern Tasmania. It is a data poor species and information relating to its life history and ecology is limited. Given the overall paucity of data and its limited distribution, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This marine, demersal species is data poor and information relating to its life history and ecology is limited. The holotype measured 16.9 cm standard length (Amaoka et al. 1997).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f9312f20-7fff-5c59-18e5-fb4de62fb5e8">Threats to this species are currently unknown.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-3efae5b7-7fff-2d05-9c79-1e473d3ffa87">Population information for this species is unavailable.
range: This nominal species is known from a single specimen from northern Tasmania, Australia (Amaoka et al. 1997); depth of capture is unknown.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: This relatively small-sized, marine, demersal species is known only from a single specimen taken in the South China Sea. It is data poor and information relating to its taxonomic status, distribution, population status, ecology and life history is unknown. Therefore, this species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This marine, demersal species is data poor and no information is available relating to its ecology and life history. The holotype is 17.5 cm total length (Chabanaud 1929).
threats: Major threats are unknown.
population: No population information is available. It is known from only one vouchered specimen.
range: This nominal species was described on the basis of a single specimen taken in the South China Sea off Con Son Island, southeastern Viet Nam (Chabanaud 1929). This appears to be the only record for this species for which there is a voucher specimen. It has been reported from Taiwan, Province of China (Shen 1983, 1993, Li and Wang 1995, Hensley and Amaoka 2001, Shao et al. 2008, Shen and Wu 2012); however, these records are questionable because at least one is based on a misidentification and for the other records, no voucher specimens exist to verify the identifications of these specimens (Amaoka and Ho 2019). A record (MNHN 1999-1924) from the Coral Sea off New Caledonia (accessed via the FishNet2 portal, www.fishnet2.net, March 2021) is doubtful.
useTrade: No use and trade information is available. Due to its relatively small size, it is likely not targeted, but may be a component of the bycatch of demersal fisheries.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: This nominal species is only known from the type specimen so information relating to its distribution, population, ecology and life history is very limited. Possibly, this nominal species is a junior subjective synonym of Monolene maculipinna. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This marine, demersal species is data poor and information relating to its ecology and life history is limited. The holotype measured 8.2 cm standard length and 9.6 cm total length (Bruun 1937, Amaoka and Imamura 2000). It was collected pelagically at 274-365 m in an area where the water depth was approximately 2,800 m (Bruun 1937, Woods 1961).
threats: No major threats to this species are known.
population: No population information exists for this species, as it is known only from the type specimen (Bruun 1937, Evseenko 1999).
range: This species is only known from the holotype whose type locality is in the Gulf of Panama, central eastern Pacific. The holotype was collected in the pelagic zone using a bathypelagic ring net at 274-365 m in an area where the water depth was 2,469 m (Bruun 1937, Woods 1961).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are currently in place.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e3e63a35-7fff-7cbf-07ac-33d2e000dbea">This marine, benthic species is known from two specimens collected in Gulf of Suez, Red Sea. Information relating to population, life history and ecology is limited. It is not utilized and threats are unknown. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed on its taxonomy, distribution and life history.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e8102c61-7fff-0cbd-55ab-5e4fb8adb15d">This marine, benthic species is data poor and information relating to its life history is limited. Other members of this genus inhabit soft to coarse sediments occurring on the continental shelf and upper continental slope, in estuaries, and occasionally in freshwater (Menon 1977). The larger syntype measured 33.5 cm (Steindachner 1902).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-5b992260-7fff-f59b-a69f-a3c6a18cefa7">Threats to this species are unknown.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-d36c2633-7fff-850f-9396-e1e219aa5684">This species is known only from two syntypes; therefore, its population status is unknown.
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-ccb009ae-7fff-3556-d7f9-a461671b7d5b">This species is known from two specimens collected from Harmil and El-Tor, Egypt, Gulf of Suez, Red Sea (Steindachner 1902, Golani and Bogorodsky 2010). The depth distribution of this species is unknown.
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-fd9008ad-7fff-c1eb-c9be-501bab16207f">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-0b765698-7fff-3f34-3253-efc260364eb2">There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Research is needed on the taxonomy, distribution and life history of this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because its population is presumed stable and because there are no major widespread threats currently affecting its population. The taxonomy of this species is exceptionally complex, but if future research confirms that it is conspecific with Lankascincus dorsicatenatus it will presumably still warrant listing as Least Concern.
habitat: This species has been observed in leaf litter and beneath large stones within rainforest, often close to streams (Batuwita 2019). It is also found in home gardens.
threats: There are general threats (clearing of the forests) outside protected  areas, but it is unlikely that these are causing significant declines in  the population of the species.
population: Batuwita (2019) considers that the population is presently stable, but cautions that the species is reliant on the persistence of natural forest and waterbodies for its survival, as well as well shaded secondary forests.
range: This species is known from Sabaragamuwa and Central Provinces in Sri Lanka, along the western flank of Sri Lanka's Central Hills (Batuwita 2019).
useTrade: There is not thought to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It is present in protected areas. Ongoing genetic studies suggest that this species may not be distinct from Lankascincus dorsicatenatus. If that is proven to be true, this assessment should be revised.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has not been collected for more than 70 years, possibly as a result of past taxonomic confusion which has only recently been resolved,. and while the two known localities are relatively close to one another nothing is known of the species' true distribution, ecological requirements or any threats.
habitat: The second locality is a tea estate, but nothing is known of this species' ecology.
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: This species is known from two historical specimens, each from a separate locality. It has not been recorded since 1946 and until recently its taxonomic status has been unclear (Agarwal et al. 2018). The absence of recent records may be a consequence of confusion with Cyrtodactylus khasiensis, with which it was formerly a synonym.
range: This species is known from the lower Himalayas in India, where it has been recorded from two specimens: Kurseong (Smith 1935) and Gopaldhara (Ahmad and Dasgupta 1992, as Cyrtodactylus khasiensis, reporting a record taken in 1946), both in Darjeeling.
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Research is needed to clarify its distribution, ecological requirements, population status, and any threats.

rationale: Eviota inutilis is only known from Western Australia. There is no population, habitat or ecology information but it appears to be somewhat widespread in western Australia, and there are no known threats. It is Least Concern. However, more information is needed on this species habitat and population.
habitat: There is no habitat or ecology information for this species. It can attain 2.5 cm SL (Lachner and Karnella 1980).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no population information for this species. There are five museum records for this species (Fishnet2 database accessed 06/2018).
range: Eviota inutilis is endemic to Western Australia (Moore et al. 2014) and has been collected from Albany, WA (Lachner and Karnella 1980) to Broome. It occurs to about 15 m depth (Fishes of Australia database).
useTrade: This species is not targeted in any major fisheries but may be of interest in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place.

rationale: Eviota japonica is known from southern Japan and the Ryukyu Islands. This species has been recorded to 2.4 cm SL. There is no depth information, population, habitat or ecology information, or impact of any known threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little habitat and ecology information available. This species can attain 2.4 cm SL (Jewett and Lachner 1983). It may occur in rivers (e.g. Shitafukigawa River, Hayashi and Itoh, Jewett and Lachner 1983).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown. Without information on habitat or depth range, it is difficult to understand the presence or severity of threats. It may occur in river mouths.
population: There is no population information for this species. There are 33 museum records for this species (Fishnet2 database accessed 06/2018).
range: Eviota japonica is known from southern Japan, the Ryukyu Islands, and Taiwan (Jewett and Lachner 1983, Greenfield and Winterbottom 2016).  There is a record from Palau collected in 1933 that needs verification (H. Larson pers comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is not targeted in any major fisheries but may be of interest in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for E. japonica.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This species habitat and ecological requirements are unknown, although it is presumed to breed in water by larval development.
threats:
The threats to this species are unknown.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea or Tanimbar Island (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the islands. However, if this species is confirmed to occur below 500 m asl, then it is expected to be at low risk from infection due to the warm climate of lowland areas on Tanimbar Island and is less likely to be negatively impacted (Bower et al. 2019). However, if this species is confirmed to occur above 500 m asl, while there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected in Melanesia, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: There are no known records of this species since it was first described and no further survey work has been conducted since its initial collection (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019), so its population status is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Tanimbar Island, in the Maluku Islands, Indonesia. Its elevational range is unknown.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species does not occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. If this species is confirmed to occur above 500 m asl, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

Research Needed
Its distribution, habitat requirements, population status, and threats need to be determined.

rationale: Eviota lentiginosa is only known from 2 specimens collected from a cave in Norfolk Island from 13.5 m depth. More information is needed on this species distribution, population, habitat, ecology and impact of any threats. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Eviota lentiginosa was collected from a cave at 13.5 m depth. The maximum recorded length for this species is 1.34 cm SL (Greenfield and Randall 2017).
threats: Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: Population information for this species is not available.  It is only known from 2 specimens (Greenfield and Randall 2017).
range: Eviota lentiginosa is only known from Norfolk Island. This species was collected from 13.5 m depth (Greenfield and Randall 2017).
useTrade: This species is not targeted in any major fisheries but may be of interest in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for E. lentiginosa.

rationale: Puntius tetraspilus is endemic to Sri Lanka but there are no precise localities to evaluate the species against any criteria. While it is possibly declining in parts of its range, the population size and trend is unknown, and more information is needed regarding the distribution of this species, its habitat preferences, possible utilisation, severity of threats and conservation. Without these data it cannot be categorised as meeting, or close to meeting, the thresholds for any of the Red List criteria, and therefore this species is assessed as Data Deficient and in need of further research to clarify its risk of extinction.
habitat: No adequate data is available for this species' habitat preferences or ecological role, other than it is a freshwater species.
threats: No adequate data is available for this species' threats or those affecting its preferred habitat.
population: No adequate data is available for this species population size or trend.
range: No adequate data is available for this species' geographical distribution or historic localities other than its endemic occurrence within Sri Lanka.
useTrade: No adequate data is available for this species.
conservationActions: No adequate data is available for this species regarding its distribution or population, and so it is not known if it occurs within conservation areas.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: Its habitat and ecological requirements are unknown, but it possibly lives in rainforest, or possibly grassland. There is no information known regarding its breeding habits, though reproduction is presumed to be by larval development in water.
threats:
Insufficient data are available to determine whether there are any threats.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce the fungus to the island. Declines of approximately 10-20% in limnodynastids, myobatrachids, pelodryadids in Australia have been recorded (Bower et al. 2019). Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at high risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Although the elevational range for this species is unknown, so there will be further uncertainty around how susceptible this species could be to the effects of chytrids.
population: It has not been recorded again since it was first discovered, and it is considered to be a rare species. Its population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Aitape, in northern coastal Papua New Guinea. Its elevational range is unknown. There is no additional information on the distribution of this species at present (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is not known from any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). 

Research Needed
Research on its distribution, habitat requirements, abundance, ecology and threats is required.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This species' habitat is presumably rainforest. Like other members of its genus, it presumably breeds by direct development.
threats:
The major threats to this species are unknown.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the island. However, if this species is confirmed to occur below 500 m asl, then it is expected to be at low risk from infection due to the warm climate of lowland New Guinea and is less likely to be negatively impacted (Bower et al. 2019). However, if this species is confirmed to occur above 500 m asl, while there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: The population status and trends of this species are unknown. The one known specimen still exists.
range: This species' geographic range is unknown. The only known specimen was collected in the Digul River area, Merauke Regency, Papua, Indonesia. The precise (and indeed even the general) locality has not been determined, and it has been mapped generally to the Digul River area. Its elevation is unknown.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas and no conservation actions are currently in place for this species and its immediate habitat.

Conservation Needed
Protection of the species habitat at the type locality may be warranted. Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). 

Research Needed
Its distribution, habitat requirements, abundance and threats need to be properly documented.

rationale: This species is considered Data Deficient as it is known with certainty only from the type locality, and nothing is known of its natural history, population status or its exposure or sensitivity to any threats.
habitat: This is a montane species, but nothing else is known of its ecology (Spawls et al. 2002). It is presumably semi-fossorial beneath the surface of the soil or in leaf litter, and is likely to be insectivorous and oviparous (Spawls et al. 2002).
threats: It is unknown whether any threats to this species exist.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: This is an Albertine Rift species, and may be endemic to the eastern side of the Rift. The only confirmed locality is the Nyungwe Forest in southwestern Rwanda (Fischer and Hinkel 1992). It was once believed to occur in the mountains of the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (Musosa, in Katanga along the Zambian border) and northern Burundi (Spawls et al. 2002). Broadley (1998) suggests that both the Musosa and Burundi records may result from mislabeling; it is however, not certain that this locality is in error (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2014) and the species' occurrence in Musosa is in need of confirmation.
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unknown whether any conservation measures are required. Research is needed to clarify this species' distribution, population status, natural history and any threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this is a very poorly-known species, with insufficient information on the habitat needs, distribution and possible threats.
habitat: This snake is very poorly-known, with nothing recorded to date about habitat requirements.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known from two specimens collected in 1875 (Murphy 2012).
range: This species is known only from Andai in West Papua, Indonesia (Murphy 2012). The elevation for this species is perhaps close to sea level, but needs additional research.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if any populations occur in protected areas. Much additional research on the distribution, habitat ecology and threats is needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this is a very poorly-known species, with insufficient information on the habitat needs, distribution and possible threats.
habitat: This snake is very poorly-known, with nothing recorded to date about habitat requirements. It may be associated with primary tropical moist forest, but this requires confirmation.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known from one specimen from each locality, one collected in 1877 and one in 1962 (Murphy 2012). The latter appears to be roadkill (Murphy 2012).
range: This species is known from two localities in West Papua, Indonesia: the Tanrau Mountains and Kebar Valley (Murphy 2012). The elevation is at least 150 m asl.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known if any populations occur in protected areas, although it may be present in the nearby CA. Pegunungam Tamrau Utara protected area. Much additional research on the distribution, habitat ecology and threats is needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as this is a very poorly-known species, with insufficient information on the habitat needs, distribution and possible threats.
habitat: This snake is very poorly-known, with nothing recorded to date about habitat requirements. It may be associated with primary tropical moist forest, but this requires confirmation.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known from only two specimens, both collected in 1875 (Murphy 2012), and a third specimen collected in March 1949 (O'Shea and Kaiser 2016).
range: This species is known only from Mount Arfak and Atinyu, Sorong Selatan in West Papua, Indonesia (Murphy 2012). The elevation of collection is from 260 m asl, upper limit uncertain.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species does not seem to have been recorded from any protected areas, however there are a number of protected areas in the Arfak Mountains. Much additional research on the distribution, habitat ecology and threats is needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: There is no information known about its habitat and ecological requirements.
threats:
If it was found in the Gogol Valley, this area is heavily degraded and this species is therefore likely to be threatened by changes to its habitat.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce the fungus to the island. Declines of approximately 10-20% in limnodynastids, myobatrachids, pelodryadids in Australia have been recorded (Bower et al. 2019). Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at high risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Although the elevational range for this species is unknown, so there will be further uncertainty around how susceptible this species could be to the effects of chytrids.
population: It is only known from one specimen, and there is no other information regarding its population status or trends.
range: This species is known from an unknown locality in northern Papua New Guinea. The collection took place during an expedition along the Ramu River and the river emerging at Madang. There is no additional information on the distribution of this species at present (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is unknown whether this species occurs in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Attempts are needed to discover subpopulations of this species. Further research is also required on its distribution, habitats and ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This species is presumed to live in forest and to breed in water.
threats:
The threats to this species are not known.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the island. As the elevation of this species is unknown, it is unknown what the impact of the disease could be. If it is a lowland frog species, then it is expected to be at low risk from infection due to the warm climate of lowland New Guinea and are less likely to be negatively impacted (Bower et al. 2019). However, if it occurs at higher elevations (above 500 m asl), while there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species may need to be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: It is known only from the type locality, and there have been no recent records, so its population status is unknown. There have been amphibian surveys carried out in nearby areas, but there has been no further information on this species (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
range: This species is known only from "Moaif", the type locality, in the northern lowlands of Papua, Indonesia. Its elevational range is unknown.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species does not occur in any protected areas. 

Conservation Needed
If this species occurs at elevations over 500 m asl, then conservation actions are recommended should chytrid arrive in Melanesia. Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Protected areas are also needed to safeguard its rainforest swamp habitat. 

Research Needed
Attempts are needed to rediscover this species and to document its distribution and population status.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, population status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: Its habitat and ecological requirements are unknown. It is presumed to breed by larval development, as its congeners.
threats:
There is no information on the threats to this species, and the threats are unknown. On Yapen Island, logging is likely to be a threat and habitat tends to be more degraded in lower altitudes around villages, rather than at higher elevations (R. Günther pers. comm. October 2019). However it is unknown whether this is a threat to this species.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea or Yapen Island (Bower et al. 2017, 2019).
