There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the islands. As the elevation of this species is unknown, it is unknown what the impact of the disease could be. If it is a lowland frog species, then it is expected to be at low risk from infection due to the warm climate of lowland New Guinea and Yapen Island and are less likely to be negatively impacted (Bower et al. 2019). However, if it occurs at higher elevations (above 500 m asl), while there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families.
population: It has not been collected again since it was first described, so its population status is unknown. There have been no surveys carried out on Yapen Island in the last ten years (R. Günther pers. comm. October 2019).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, on Yapen Island (probably near Ansus), Papua, Indonesia. Its elevational range is unknown.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species does not occur in any protected areas. 

Research Needed
Urgent efforts are needed to rediscover it and to determine its taxonomic status, distribution, and population status. This will require additional topotypic material to determine its taxonomic identity. It is probably a synonym of Litoria nigropunctata, but no specimens still exist for this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, status, ecological requirements and threats.
habitat: This species is thought to inhabit forest habitat. It is unknown whether it will tolerate habitat disturbance (S. Richards and B. Tjaturadi pers. comm. July 2019). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to breed by direct development, as with its congeners.
threats:
The threats to this species remain unknown. However, the area in which it was collected is disturbed and has been so for some time.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the island. While there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: There is no information on the population size and trends of this species as it has only been collected once in 1979. No surveys have been conducted at the type locality since it was first described (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Angguruk, in Papua, Indonesia, at 1,400 m asl. It is likely to be found more widely (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
No conservation actions are currently in place for this species and its immediate habitat. It has not been recorded in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology and threats.

rationale: This species is known from a single specimen collected off Hainan in the 1930s. No additional information is available regarding its population size and trends, habitats and ecology. Although this species is not likely to be targeted, the area around Hainan has been heavily exploited by demersal trawl fisheries. The potential impacts on the population of this species is unknown. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This demersal species reaches a maximum total length of 12.5 cm (Wu and Tang 1935).
threats: This species is unlikely to be targeted as a food source (J. G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2009). However, the area in which this species occurs has been heavily fished by trawlers. The potential impacts of fishing activity on the population of this species are unknown.
population: Population data are limited.
range: This species was described on the basis of a single specimen collected off Hainan, South China Sea (Wu and Tang 1935). Although no specific information on depth of capture is available, the waters around southern Hainan are generally shallow (< 200 m). The reports from Hong Kong, China (Gaiger 1974 cited in Ni and Kwok 1999) and western India (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003) require verification.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Psettina hainanensis.

Further research is needed on the abundance of, and possible threats to this species.

rationale: This recently-described species is known from a few specimens from the Philippines and Papua New Guinea. It was collected from a fish market in the Philippines, but no additional information is available regarding its capture or population trends. Moreover, there is very limited information on the life history or ecology of this species. Exploitation may present a threat to this species; however, given the lack of available data on harvest levels or population trends, it is listed as Data Deficient. Additional information on its population, habitats, ecology and harvest trends is needed.
habitat: There is limited information regarding the habitats and ecology of this species. The larger type specimen measured 7.2 cm standard length (Randall and Desoutter-Meniger 2007). Although no information on the locality or method of capture was available, the type specimens were collected from a fish market with a specimen of Aseraggodes xenicus (Randall and Desoutter-Meniger 2007), a shallow, benthic species.
threats: Direct and indirect effects of exploitation may present a threat to this species, but data are not available to determine this.
population: Population information is limited. It was described on the basis of two specimens (Randall and Desoutter-Meniger 2007) and a third specimen was reported from a new locality (Papua New Guinea: Fricke 2015).
range: This species is known from the Bohol Sea, near Negros Oriental, central Visayas (Randall and Desoutter-Meniger 2007) as well as Madang, Papua New Guinea (Fricke 2015). Depth of capture of the type specimens is not available, but the new specimen from Papua New Guinea was collected in 2 m depth.
useTrade: The type specimens were collected from a fish market in the Philippines but no further information is known regarding its use and trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This benthic species is known from a single specimen collected in the heavily-impacted Manila Bay sometime prior to 1878. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a benthic species; however, specific habitat requirements and depth are unknown. The type specimen measured 14 cm total length (Sauvage 1878).
threats: The only known locality thus far is Manila Bay, which is heavily impacted by pollution, overfishing, coastal development. It is currently unknown how these various threats (pollution, overfishing, habitat degradation) are impacting this species.
population: This species is known from only one specimen captured sometime prior to 1878 (Sauvage 1878); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species is known from only a single specimen captured off Manila, Philippines. The capture depth is unknown (Sauvage 1878).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded for over 100 years and extensive searches have failed to locate this species.
habitat: There is no information on the habitat requirements of this species. It presumably bred on wet rock surfaces near streams by larval development, like other members of the genus.
threats: The reasons for the extinction of this species are not known.
population: This species is known only from the type series collected more than 100 years ago. It has not been recorded since it was originally described. As of 2020, recent and historical extensive field surveys of the amphibian fauna of Sri Lanka have been unable to relocate this frog, and it is now believed to be extinct.
range: This species is an extinct Sri Lankan endemic, known only from the general type locality of "Ceylon" (= Sri Lanka), where it was collected in 1882. It is not possible to produce a meaningful distribution map for the species.
useTrade: This species is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no trade in nor any uses of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded from any protected areas. The single record that possibly could have been this frog in a protected area was by Karunarathna (1986), however Bopage et al. (2011) consider this record a misidentification.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since 1886. Extensive searches in the appropriate habitat, during the appropriate season within the known range, have failed to locate this species.
habitat: The habitat requirements of this species are not known. It presumably bred by direct development.
threats: The threats that led to the extinction of this species are not known, though habitat loss through conversion of land to agricultural use seems the most likely cause.
population: This species is known only from two specimens and was last collected around 1886. It is now thought to be extinct, as extensive field surveys of the amphibian fauna of Sri Lanka in recent years have failed to rediscover this frog (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species is an extinct Sri Lankan endemic, known only from the non-specific type locality of "Ceylon" (not "Peradeniya" as sometimes stated) and from Nuwara Eliya, a resort mountain town. It occupied an elevational range of 1,700-2,500 m asl (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Only the site of Nuwara Eliya has been mapped. Reports of this species occurring in India (Krishnamurthy and Sakunthala 1993) are believed to be erroneous (S.K. Dutta pers. comm. 2002).
useTrade: This species is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no trade in nor any uses of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place 
This species is not known to have occurred in any protected areas.

Research Needed
There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since 1940, and extensive searches in the appropriate habitat, during the appropriate season within the known range, have failed to locate this species.
habitat: The habitat requirements of this species are not known. It presumably bred by direct development.
threats: The threats that resulted in the extinction of this species are not known, although presumably habitat loss was a contributing factor.
population: This species is known only from the holotype. There have been no records since its original collection and the species is now believed to be extinct because extensive field surveys of the amphibian fauna of Sri Lanka, including at the type locality, have not rediscovered this frog (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species is an extinct Sri Lankan endemic, known only from the type locality of "Queenwood Estate, Dimbulla, Ceylon", at 1,500 m asl, where it was collected in 1933 (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005).
useTrade: This species is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded from any protected areas.

Research Needed
There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

habitat: The habitat requirements of this species are not known. It presumably bred by direct development.
threats: The threats that resulted in the extinction of the species are not known, although presumably habitat loss was a contributing factor.
population: This species is known only from the holotype. There have been no sightings since 1933 and the species is believed to now be extinct, as extensive field surveys of the amphibian fauna of Sri Lanka, including at the type locality, have not rediscovered this frog (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

useTrade: This species is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no use or trade in this species.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since 1882, despite extensive searches, which have failed to locate this species.
habitat: There is no information about the habitat requirements of this species. It presumably bred by direct development.
threats: The threats that led to the extinction of this species are not known, though habitat loss seems the most likely cause.
population: There have been no records of this species since 1882. It is presumed to be extinct, as extensive searches have failed to rediscover this species.
range: This species is an extinct Sri Lankan endemic, originally collected in 1882 from an unspecified locality on Sri Lanka (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). As a result, it is not possible to produce a meaningful distribution map for this species.
useTrade: This species is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no use or trade in this species.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since 1899, and extensive searches in the appropriate habitat, during the appropriate season within the known range, have failed to locate this species.
habitat: The habitat requirements of the species are not known. It presumably bred by direct development.
threats: The causes of the extinction of this species are not known, but presumably habitat loss was a contributing factor.
population: This species is known only from the holotype and there have been no sightings since 1899. The species is believed to now be extinct, as extensive general amphibian surveys have been conducted within its known range with no records to date (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species is an extinct Sri Lankan endemic, known only from the type locality of "Pattipola, Ceylon [= Sri Lanka]", where it was collected in 1899 (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005).
useTrade: This species is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded from any protected areas.

There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since before 1886, and extensive searches in the appropriate habitat, during the appropriate season within the known range, have failed to locate this species.
habitat: The habitat requirements of this species are not known. It presumably bred by direct development.
threats: The causes of the species' extinction are not known, but presumably habitat loss was a contributing factor.
population: This species is known only from the type specimen, which was  collected before its description in 1856. It is believed to be extinct, as extensive general field surveys of the amphibian fauna of Sri Lanka have failed to rediscover this frog.
range: This species is an extinct Sri Lankan endemic, known only from the type locality "Ceylon" (= Sri Lanka) (Dutta and Manamendra-Arachchi 1996). The type locality is too general to allow the production of a meaningful map for this species.
useTrade: This species has not been sighted since the first specimen was collected before 1856 and is considered to be extinct. Thus, there is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded from any protected areas.

Research Needed
There is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

Specimens previously attributed to this species from India (Krishnamurthi and Shakunthala 1993) belong to a separate taxon (Biju 2001), and specimens reported by Karunaratne (1998) are also believed to belong to a different species (K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm. 2004)

rationale: This poorly known, small-sized sole is known from only a single specimen taken off Hong Kong. Nothing is known about its distribution, population size, habitats and ecology, or potential threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed to determine the taxonomic status of this nominal species.
habitat: <span id="docs-internal-guid-1628e3ab-7fff-8871-37e4-dd4022ffc286">No information is available on the habitats and ecology of this poorly known species. The holotype is 9.7 cm total length (Steindachner 1867).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-44d68106-7fff-bf97-da3c-0f2087944f33">Major threats are unknown.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-64ddf3df-7fff-3bab-d0f7-273e55acf16d">No population data are available, as it is known only from the holotype (Steindachner 1867).
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-810f68d1-7fff-21de-8391-868f0d1f0a5e">This species is known only from a single specimen collected off Hong Kong (Steindachner 1867, Li and Wang 1995, Ni and Kwok 1999, Munroe 2000, Voronina 2019, Okamoto and Motomura 2021). No information regarding depth of capture is associated with the type specimen (Steindachner 1867).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-7d1db854-7fff-a726-7dd2-1f784a97d748">This species is not utilized.

rationale: This species is known only from the holotype, collected off Queensland, Australia. No information is available regarding its complete distribution, population size, habitats and ecology or potential threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No habitat and ecology data are available for this species. The holotype measures 23.5 cm standard length (Whitley 1935).
threats: Major threats are unknown.
population: This species is known only from a single specimen collected in 1934 (Whitley 1935); therefore, the status of the global population is unknown.
range: This species is known only from the holotype, taken off Fitzallen Island, Whitsunday Passage, Queensland, Australia (Whitley 1935). No depth information was given for the holotype.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. The type locality is within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

rationale: Trachinocephalus atrisignis is a recently described species known only from its type locality near Socotra Island in the Western Indian Ocean. Very little is known on its population, life history, habitats and threats. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: There is little known of the life history and habitat preferences of this species. The largest of its collected specimens measures 19.8 cm standard length (Prokofiev 2019).
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: This species is only known from three recently collected specimens and no population data are available.
range: Trachinocephalus atrisignis is a recently described species only known from three specimens caught in the Western Indian Ocean near Socotra Island (Prokofiev 2019).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place.

rationale: Amphisbaena neglecta é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida apenas da localidade tipo. Trata-se de uma espécie de difícil encontro e de descrição antiga (1936). Sua distribuição não está bem estudada e é possível que esteja sofrendo redução da população em decorrência da perda de hábitat. Portanto, faltam informações sobre tamanho/estrutura, tendências e distribuição da população que possibilitem a aplicação dos critérios mais adequada à espécie. Por essas razões foi avaliada com Dados insuficientes (DD).
habitat: Não há informações ecológicas disponíveis. É provável que ocorra em savana, baseados no habitat da localidade tipo.
threats: A construção de usinas hidrelétricas próximas ao Parque Nacional em que a espécie ocorre e a perda de hábitat (desmatamento agricultura mecanizada e implantação de empreendimento imobiliário) também podem oferecer riscos para a espécie. No entanto, não se sabe se existem ameaças significativas à espécie.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Trata-se de uma espécie de difícil encontro é possível que esteja sofrendo redução da população em decorrência da perda de hábitat. Faltam informações sobre tamanho/estrutura, tendências e distribuição da população. Uma extensa pesquisa faunística de quatro anos na área da localidade tipo onde foi construída uma usina hidreletrica, não conseguiu localizar a espécie (Strüssmann and Mott 2009).
range: Amphisbaena neglecta é endêmica do Brasil. Conhecida apenas da localidade tipo no bioma Cerrado, no estado do Mato Grosso (Gans 1962). Um registro de Anápolis, em Goiás, foi determinado como sendo mal identificado e correspondendo a A. anaemariae (Vanzolini 1996).
useTrade: A espécie não é usada ou comercializada.
conservationActions: Não é conhecida nenhuma ação específica para a conservação da espécie. A espécie pode ocorrer em Área de Proteção Ambiental da Chapada dos Guimarães. Como a espécie é pouco conhecida, levantamentos de fauna e estudos sobre sua distribuição, história natural e ameaças são necessários para sua conservação.

rationale: Amphisbaena ridleyi é endêmica do Brasil, ocorrendo apenas no Arquipélago de Fernando de Noronha, estado de Pernambuco, excluindo-se ilhas e ambientes rochosos. A espécie é fossorial. A área do arquipélago é de 19,5 km², subtraindo-se os ambientes rochosos estima-se que sua área de ocupação seja menor que isso e superior a 10 km² . No entanto, embora haja alterações no ambiente que poderiam afetar a espécie (introdução de espécies exóticas invasoras domésticas de estimação e de produção e antropização), aparentemente, essas ameaças não afetam a espécie, pois ocorrem em abundância e uma grande proporção da distribução da espécie está sob proteção. Por essas razões, a espécie foi avaliada como Menos preocupante (LC).
habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas e mãos. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). Embora muito semelhante a espécies africanas, dados moleculares indicam que é intimamente relacionado com as anfisbênias Sul Americanas (Gans 1963, Laguna et al. 2010). Endêmica do arquipélago de Fernando de Noronha, ocorre em diferentes áreas, exceto em regiões rochosas (Geraldo Moura com. pess. 2014). 70 % da ilha faz parte do Parque Fernando de Noronha (Mott 2010).
threats: O turismo crescente e a ocupação de espécies exóticas invasoras e domésticas de estimação e produção poderiam impactar a espécie, porém, aparentemente não afetam, pois esta é abundante no arquipélago.
population: A espécie é muito abundante onde ocorre e a população parece estar estável  (Mott 2010).
range: Amphisbaena ridleyi é endêmica do Brasil e do arquipélago de Fernando de Noronha, no estado de Pernambuco (Gans 1963, Laguna et al. 2010, Moura et al. 2011). Sua extensão de ocorrência calculada corresponde à área do arquipélago, 19,5 km2. Sua área de ocupação estimada é superior a 10 km2, subtraindo-se os ambientes rochosos da área total do arquipélago.
useTrade: A espécie não é usada ou comercializada.
conservationActions: Não é conhecida nenhuma ação específica para a conservação da espécie. 70 % da ilha faz parte do Área de Proteção Ambiental de Fernando de Noronha e Parque Nacional Marítimo de Fernando de Noronha. Estudos direcionados a sua história natural são necessários. Controle e/ou erradicação de espécies exóticas invasoras e domésticas de estimação e produção.

rationale: Amphisbaena tragorrhectes é endêmica do Brasil, conhecida apenas para a localidade tipo, município de Oriximiná, no estado do Pará. Trata-se de espécie de difícil encontro. Embora sua extensão de ocorrência seja de 314,1 km2, acredita-se que seja mais ampla pois a área não está bem amostrada. Não há ameaças evidentes que possam afetar a espécie ao ponto de colocá-la em risco de extinção. Por essas razões, a espécie foi avaliada como Menos preocupante (LC).
habitat: Não há informações disponíveis sobre o habitat e ecologia para esta espécie. Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na região de Oriximiná, devido à extração de bauxita, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção, visto que ainda há bastante ambiente preservado, favorável à espécie, que ainda não foi amostrado.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Trata-se de espécie de difícil encontro.
range: Amphisbaena tragorrhectes é endêmica do Brasil, do estado do Pará. Conhecida apenas para sua localidade tipo, perto do Rio Trombetas, município de Oriximiná (Vanzolini 1971). Embora sua extensão de ocorrência seja de 314,1 km2, acredita-se que seja mais ampla pois essa região não está bem amostrada.
useTrade: A espécie não é usada ou comercializada.
conservationActions: Não é conhecida nenhuma ação específica para a conservação da espécie. A espécie não está presente em nenhuma área protegida. Levantamentos de fauna e estudos sobre sua distribuição, história natural e ameaças são necessários para sua conservação.

rationale: Leposternon scutigerum  é uma espécie endêmica do Brasil. Conhecida de poucas localidades na Mata Atlântica da região metropolitana do município do Rio de Janeiro, estado do Rio de Janeiro. Sua extensão de ocorrência calculada é de 635 km². A região de distribuição encontra-se sob intensa pressão de degradação e fragmentação do ambiente desde a época de descrição da espécie (principalmente devido à urbanização), causando também fragmentação severa da população (interrupção do fluxo gênico), assim como, declínio continuado da qualidade do hábitat. Por esses motivos a espécie foi avaliada como Em Perigo (EN).
habitat: Não há informações sobre a biologia/ecologia da espécie. Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas e mãos. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). As espécies do gênero Leposternon possuem sempre a cabeça dorsoventralmente comprimida.
threats: A região de distribuição da espécie passa por intenso processo de urbanização desde a época da sua descrição, com profunda alteração da qualidade do hábitat.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Sua região de distribuição encontra-se sob intensa pressão de degradação e fragmentação do ambiente, causando também a interrupção do fluxo gênico.
range: Leposternon scutigerum é endêmica do Brasil. Conhecida de poucas localidades na Mata Atlântica da região metropolitana do município do Rio de Janeiro, estado do Rio de Janeiro (Perez and Ribeiro 2008, Ribeiro et al. 2011, Martins et al. 2012). Não existem registros recentes para a espécie. Sua extensão de ocorrência é de 635 km2, calculada via mínimo polígono convexo a partir dos pontos de registro.
useTrade: A espécie não é usada ou comercializada.
conservationActions: Ocorre na área de abrangência do Plano de Ação Nacional para a Conservação da Herpetofauna do Sudeste da Mata Atlântica, cuja aprovação está prevista para o final de 2014 (V. Uhlig com. pess. 2014). A espécie não está presente em nenhuma área protegida. Levantamentos de fauna direcionados ao grupo e estudos sobre sua distribuição, história natural e ameaças são necessários para um melhor conhecimento da distribuição da espécie.

rationale: This species is listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since 1960, and exhaustive surveys in suspected habitat throughout its historic range have failed to record an individual. The entire region surrounding the type locality (now Brasila) has been converted from native habitats to an urban centre with extensive ongoing suburban sprawl. The species likely went extinct shortly after being discovered.
habitat: It was considered a semi-fossorial species and was first discovered in 1960 on the site of the capital, Brasília, which at the time was under construction. The species has not been collected since even after many attempts specifically to locate remaining populations.
threats: This species has not been seen since discovered and is presumed to be extinct, as the entire region where it was discovered has been converted to a city and more recently urban sprawl.
population: Many studies have attempted to collect this species in the wild but no individuals have been recorded in the last 48 years (Marinho-Filho pers. comm).
range: This species was described in 1965 and is known only by type locality: Central Brazil, Federal District, Brasilia, Parque Zoobotanico, at 1,030 m (Musser and Carleton, 1993).
conservationActions: This species is considered to be extinct.

rationale: This species has a very small extent of occurrence and area of occupancy (8 km<sup>2</sup>). There are numerous threats to the species from invasive species and loss of habitat to coconut plantations, construction of an airstrip and other development and it has not been seen since 1906. This species therefore qualifies for listing as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct). Surveys to confirm its survival are urgently required.
habitat: This is a semi-fossorial species. The species' ecological requirements have not been recorded, but most of the natural habitat has been destroyed and replaced by coconut plantations and the absence of subsequent records suggests that it is likely to be intolerant of modified environments. Most related species are associated with humid rainforest (Sanchez et al. 2019). Île du Lys contains several remaining large trees with associated leaf litter (Sanchez et al. 2019); while these may have provided suitable habitat historically, it is unknown whether this is sufficient to support an extant population on this island.
threats: The natural habitat has been largely replaced by coconut plantations and the islands are inhabited by invasive feral cats, Black Rats and Etruscan Shrews (Sanchez et al. 2019). Shrews in particular have been implicated in rapid declines and island extinctions of skinks (e.g. in Mauritius - Cole 2011). The construction of an airstrip and other developments would have impacted the habitat of this species, as little natural habitat remains.
population: The species has not been collected since 1906 (one specimen collected in 1905 and two in 1906) (Sanchez et al. 2019).
range: This species has been recorded only from the Glorioso Islands (Grande Glorieuse and Île du Lys), part of the Mozambique Channel Islands in the French Southern Territories. As this species is known only from century old records, it's uncertain that the locality data for Île du Lys is accurate, in which case it may be restricted to Grande Glorieuse (M. Sanchez pers. comm. 2020).
useTrade: The species is not known to be used or traded.
conservationActions: The Glorioso archipelago and Europa have been protected as nature reserves since 1975. Black Rats have been eradicated from Île du Lys (Sanchez et al. 2019).

rationale: Although very little is known about this species, including on its biology, population, distribution and taxonomy, there are no known ongoing threats on the Aru Islands. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is known from freshwater, but is known very few specimens so very little is known about its habitat or ecology.
threats: There are no major threats known to this species on the Aru islands. There were plans to develop oil palm plantations on the island but this was overturned.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This is a poorly known species that has been recorded from the Aru Islands, Indonesia (G. Allen pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species. Research is needed into every aspect of its population, distribution, ecology and taxonomy, as it is a very poorly known species.

rationale: <span id="docs-internal-guid-aa640553-7fff-9db7-5725-6f1e03044920">This poorly known nominal species was described from Ambon Island, Indonesia. No additional specimens are known and no reliable information regarding this species has been published since its description. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is presumably a demersal species. Günther (1862) reported that the “typical specimens” were about 6.4 cm.
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-943ab69f-7fff-5a08-796f-f911f20815f5">Major threats to this species are unknown.
population: <span id="docs-internal-guid-05868059-7fff-d654-299d-45051f82cbe4">No population data are known for this species. It was described by Linnaeus in 1758, probably based on a single specimen as only one set of meristic features are reported. No type specimens are known. No other reliable reports of this species are known.
range: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f080d244-7fff-b356-f9a2-c702ea1f2400">This species was described from Ambon Island, Molucca Islands, Indonesia (Linnaeus 1758). Reports of this nominal species from off Hong Kong are based on specimens of questionable identity (Wu 1932, Li and Wang 1995). No reliable records of this species from Chinese waters exist. No data are available regarding the depth preference for this species.
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-05e870f3-7fff-2ee8-cae7-479025e79bbd">This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e15b2f49-7fff-7b19-b071-4da11cd1ba06">No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: The Ridgeback Skate (Dipturus amphispinus) is a small (to 89.7 cm total length) deep-water skate found in the Western Central Pacific Ocean off of the Philippines. It is presumably demersal on the deep insular slopes of the region but depth of capture is unknown as the species has only been reported from local fish markets. Deep-water shark fisheries in the Philippines are poorly documented. The effect of fishing, if any, on the species is unknown, however, the species likely has some refuge with depth. Further information is required on the distribution, ecology, life history, and in particular bycatch levels, of the Ridgeback Skate. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: The Ridgeback Skate is presumably demersal on the deep insular slopes of the region but depth of capture is unknown (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 90 cm total length (TL) and males mature ~62–66 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is likely oviparous. Nothing else is known of its biology.
threats: The effect of fishing, if any, on the species is unknown, however, and this species likely has some refuge with depth. In the Philippines, deep-water dogfish fisheries (primarily targeting Centrophorus spp and Squalus spp) date back to the 1960s (Flores 2004, BFAR 2017). These fisheries are poorly documented. In Cagayancillo, Palawan, Philippines, there are ~28 vessels in operation, setting demersal longlines to depths between 700–1,400 m (usually 800–1,000 m) (LAMAVE 2017). These deep-water fisheries are known for their boom-and-bust nature, given the lack of management, and collapse over short periods of time (~10 years) before effort is shifted into new regions (Flores 2004).
population: It is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction of the Ridgeback Skate.
range: The Ridgeback Skate occurs in the Western Central Pacific Ocean off the Philippines (Last and Alava 2013).
useTrade: The species has been collected from local fish markets in the central/southern Philippines (Last and Alava 2013), and may be utilized for its meat and leather.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Ridgeback Skate. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology and life history, as well potential species’ interactions with fisheries.

rationale: This nearshore species is only known from the holotype found washed up on the beach of northern New Zealand sometime prior to 1932. Significant taxonomic uncertainty contributes to the overall lack of information. Little is known on its distribution, population, ecology and potential threats; therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The only known specimen measures 11.6 cm standard length (Stewart and Roberts 2015). As the holotype was found washed ashore, no information is available regarding its habitat.
threats: Threats are unknown.
population: This species is only known from the holotype collected sometime prior to 1932 (Stewart and Roberts 2015).
range: This species is only known from the type locality off northern New Zealand, north of Paihia, Bay of Islands. The only known specimen was found washed ashore with no available depth information.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: Listed as Extinct on the basis that this species is known only from fragmentary subfossil remains. The date of its extinction is unknown, but may have been after 1500 AD.
habitat: Nothing is known about the ecology of this species, but it was probably nocturnal (Arnold and Bour 2008). It is presumed to have been a coastal species (Probst 1996).
threats: Nothing is known of the cause of this species' apparent extinction, although molecular clock data suggests that the species survived a "catastrophic" volcanic eruption on Réunion, 180,000-200,000 years ago (Arnold and Bour 2008). Arnold and Bour (2008) discuss the introduction of rats (first observed on Réunion in 1670 - Rattus rattus - and 1750 - R. norvegicus) in the context of the extinction of a larger lizard on the same island. As no historical records of this species exist, however, it is unknown whether the species was still extant when rats were introduced. Other species of Nactus are, however, known to have coexisted with rats and other mammalian predators in the Mascarenes, but to have suffered serious declines following the introduction of the invasive House Gecko Hemidactylus frenatus (Cole et al. 2005). Other predatory species introduced to the islands, including Wolf Snake (Lycodon aulicus) and Asian shrews, may also have been predators of this species if it was still extant when these animals were introduced.
population: This species is known from fragmentary skull elements. No historical reports of this species exist, which is considered unsurprising for a small and inconspicuous gecko by Arnold and Bour (2008), and it is not known to be extant.
range: This species is known only from subfossil remains and DNA data collected from La Réunion (Arnold and Bour 2006).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species, which is presumed to be extinct.
conservationActions: No conservation actions can be proposed for this species, as the species appears to be extinct. Three weeks of intensive surveys on Réunion in 2013 focused on skinks and Nactus geckos (M. Sanchez, C. Raxworthy, J.-M. Probst and S. Caceres unpubl. data) failed to record a surviving population, and it has not been found in a field survey of Petite Ile, an island close to the Réunion mainland from which both rats and house geckos are absent (M. Sanchez, J.-M. Probst and S. Caceres unpubl. data).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen of dubious provenance, and has not been recorded for more than 170 years.
habitat: There is no information on the ecology of this species.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species, as its provenance is unknown and it has not been recorded for more than 170 years.
population: This species is known from  a single specimen. It has not been found in an examination of more than 600 specimens across 25 international institutions, suggesting that if it is genuinely from the Neotropics it is among the rarest skinks in this region and may now be extinct (Miralles et al. 2009).
range: This species was reportedly collected in Guyana (Gray 1839), but no specific locality data is known and it is uncertain whether the South American provenance of this species is correct (Mausfeld and Vrcibradic 2002).  These authors suggested, based on the fact that some other species collected by the same collector in "Demerera" were subsequently found to be endemic to the Caribbean, that the specimen may have been collected from St. Lucia or Barbados. A subsequent examination by Miralles et al. (2009) suggested that the species may belong to the African radiation of Trachylepis, and that if it was genuinely collected in Guyana it could have been an introduced population that may subsequently have become extinct.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No research can be proposed unless this species is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species has not been recorded for more than a century and its type locality is not known with certainty.
habitat: There is no information on the natural history of this species.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species, which is known from a single historical collection from an imprecise locality.
population: This species is known only from a single collection in 1912-1913 (Vogt 1932).
range: This species is known only from the Sepik River Basin in Papua New Guinea (Vogt 1932). The precise locality was not reported, but other Papuascincus occur at high elevations. Slavenko et al. (2021) consequently suggest that the type locality is likely to be in montane areas visited by this expedition, in either the Hunter or Schrader range.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No research or conservation can be proposed unless this species is rediscovered.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen which was probably collected in Brazil, but its true provenance is unknown.
habitat: Nothing is known of this species' natural history.
threats: Nothing is known of any threats to this species.
population: This species is known from a single specimen.
range: This species is known from a single specimen "probably from Brazil" (Werner 1913 translated by Uetz et al. 2019).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation recommendations or research can be proposed unless this species is rediscovered.

rationale: The species is listed as Data Deficient. This is a new assessment of a taxon recently removed from synonymy with S. brasiliensis (Ruedas 2017, Ruedas et al. 2017). There are few studies conducted that can inform a current assessment of the species’ status.
habitat: There is no information about the ecology of this species.
threats: Threats for this species are unknown.
population: No information is available concerning the population status of the Santa Marta Cottontail.
range: The Santa Marta Cottontail occupies the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta,  Colombia – a range that is ecologically distinct from all nearby biomes.  The area is known for its high diversity of endemic species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions at the moment.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient, as the only records of this species are the type specimens used for its description in 1879, and two other specimens collected in the mid-1930s with no apparent associated publication in the literature. Therefore, owing to significant knowledge gaps in terms of habitat and ecological requirements, distribution and population status, there is insufficient data for a valid assessment.
habitat: No information is known regarding this species' habitat and ecology, except that the type specimens were collected from underneath stones within a hill stream (Anderson 1879). This species presumably breeds in water by larval development, as do closely related species for which the reproductive strategy is known. Neither habitat loss nor decline in habitat quality have been documented in the literature for this species’ locality, which can be observed from recent satellite imagery to contain intact forest cover.
threats: There is no information available on threats to this species. Recent satellite imagery of the species' locality shows intact forest cover, suggesting habitat loss may not currently be a threat to this species. This is consistent with a previous study which found Kachin State to have generally experienced relatively low annual forest cover loss rates (~ 0.2%), unlike other parts of Myanmar (Liu et al. 2015). Although satellite imagery reveals small-scale agriculture in nearby villages, it has been previously observed that often in Myanmar, the mere existence of subsistence agriculture and forest resource use, even if distributed in and around protected areas, do not necessarily translate into adverse impacts to local wildlife, in contrast to singular large-scale developments (e.g. dams) which do have major impacts (Istituo Oikos and BANCA 2011). Further research is needed to determine threats to this species.
population: This species' population status and trend are unknown except that it is only known from two individuals collected prior to 1879 (Anderson 1879, Frost 2020), and another two collected in the mid-1930s (AMNH 2015).
range: This species is only known from a hill stream near villages in the eastern part of Shwegu township, just west of Bhamo, in Kachin State, Myanmar (Anderson 1879). Its elevation range is unknown, but its locality consists of lowland areas up to 250 m asl. This is unlikely to represent the actual limits of this species' range; similar habitat and elevations to that of the type locality occur in surrounding areas along the Irrawaddy River. In addition, specimens collected in the mid-1930s (AMNH 2015), that are not associated with any publications, suggest this species may also be present in Myitkyina, further north in Kachin state. Consequently, these areas have been included in the range map associated with this assessment.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilised.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species does not occur in any protected areas, nor is its known locality near any.

Research Needed
Addressing the lack of data is the first step towards ensuring this species' long-term persistence. Further research on its taxonomy, habitat, ecology, true distribution, threats and the size and trends of its population would inform conservation decisions.

rationale: The species is listed as Data Deficient, in view of the lack of information about its distribution, population and habitat requirements and ecology. The species may qualify for a threatened category, as it is only currently known from a small areas, with an extent of occurrence (EOO) estimated to be around 13,199 km².
habitat: The habitat requirements and ecology of this species on Java are not well known. Previously, when it was synoymised with T. glis it was described elsewhere as usually being found in primary dipterocarp forest, however, tolerant to some degree of habitat modification, and was recorded from secondary forest, plantations, fruit orchards and trees near housing areas (Parr 2003, K.H. Han pers. comm. 2008).
threats: The major threat to this species is severe deforestation due to conversion for agriculture and plantations, and commercial logging, although the species can adapt to a degree of habitat modification. Treeshrews inhabit tropical forests, and Java has less than 10% of its natural forest cover left (Lavigne and Gunnell 2006).
population: No information is available on population size or trends for this species.
range: The species is endemic to the island of Java, Indonesia (Sargis et al. 2013).
conservationActions: It is not known if the species is found within any protected areas.

rationale: As this is a recently resurrected species there is little information about the distribution, population and threats to this species, therefore it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat requirements and ecology of this species on Java are not known. However, when it was previously synonymised with T. glis, the assessment described it elsewhere as being found in primary dipterocarp forest, but being tolerant to some degree of habitat modification, and that it was recorded from secondary forest, plantations, fruit orchards and trees near housing areas (Parr 2003, K. H. Han pers. comm. 2008).
threats: The major threat to this species is severe deforestation due to conversion for agriculture and plantations, and commercial logging, although the species can adapt to a degree of habitat modification. There has been significant loss of primary forest cover across Indonesia between 2000 and 2012 (Margono et al. 2014).
population: Information is not available on population size and trends for this species.
range: Is found on the island of Sumatra and the Batu island of Tanahbala (Sargis et al. 2013, Sargis et al. 2014).
conservationActions: It is not known if this species is found within any protected areas.

rationale: The Ambon Catshark (Akhelios suwartanai) is a small (at least to 53.7 cm total length) deep-water catshark known from one adult male specimen recorded in the Western Central Pacific Ocean off the coast of Ambon, Indonesia. Its depth range is unknown, but may be relatively shallow (<100 m) based on the stomach contents of the holotype. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across the range the Ambon Catshark, and demersal coastal fisheries resources have been severely depleted in many areas across Indonesia. Many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude. Further information is required on the distribution, ecology, life history, and in particular bycatch levels, of the Ambon Catshark. Since it is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information available to assess the species beyond Data Deficient.
habitat: The Ambon Catshark is presumably demersal and may be found at depths <100 m based on the stomach contents of the holotype (White et al. 2019). It reaches a maximum size of at least 53.7 cm total length (TL). Nothing else is known of its biology.
threats: The effect of fishing activities, if any, on this species are unknown. The species may be taken incidentally in artisanal and small-scale industrial handline and demersal longline fisheries targeting groupers, snappers, and catfishes. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across Indonesia, and demersal coastal fisheries resources have been severely depleted in many areas across the Indo-West Pacific (Stobutzki et al. 2006). Catches of sharks and rays in Southeast Asia are very high, but are declining and fishers are travelling much further from port in order to increase catches (Chen 1996). Indonesia has a considerable fishing fleet (~600,000 fishing vessels in marine waters) (KKP 2016). Despite a ban in 1980, demersal trawl fisheries still exist in Indonesia; small vessels (<10 Gross Tonnage) have modified their gear into "mini trawls" or cakalang/cantrang which target and retain demersal species at depths <200 m (H. Booth pers. comm. 30/11/2019). Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009).
population: It is unknown if fishing is causing a population reduction of the Ambon Catshark.
range: The Ambon Catshark is known only from a single specimen collected off Ambon, Indonesia in the Western Central Pacific (White et al. 2019).
useTrade: While information is not available, the species is likely to be utilized if landed. Its small size suggests low value, but it would still likely to be used for human consumption and/or fishmeal.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Ambon Catshark. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology and life history, and interactions with regional fisheries.

rationale: This marine, demersal species is known only from Saya de Malha Bank in the western Indian Ocean. It is a data poor species and information relating to its population, life history, and ecology is limited. Given its remote locality, relatively deep depth of occurrence, and small size, it is not likely to be exploited. Major threats are unknown. As it is known from relatively few specimens taken from a single locality, it is listed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed on its distribution, population size and trends, basic life history, and potential threats.
habitat: Limited information is available on the habitats and ecology of this marine, demersal species. It was collected at relatively deep depths, about 150-250 m. The largest type specimen is 10.8 cm standard length (Voronina et al. 2017).
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-f40931b2-7fff-6722-caaf-7ccb0f923000">Major threats are unknown.
population: Population data are limited. It is known from only six type specimens (Voronina et al. 2017).
range: This species is known only from a single locality in the western Indian Ocean on Saya de Malha Bank at 178-250 m (Voronina et al. 2017).
useTrade: <span id="docs-internal-guid-e8e5efcb-7fff-4a84-44e4-f76651db2293">Given its remote locality and depth of occurrence, this species is not often captured and due to its small size, would not be utilized.
conservationActions: <span id="docs-internal-guid-3309f8aa-7fff-8231-cfdc-aeb1f32ab4ef">No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: This nominal species is known only from the type description, based on specimens collected off Suriname. Nothing else is known regarding its distribution, population size, and basic life history features. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient. The taxonomic status of this nominal species requires investigation.
habitat: This is a poorly known, marine, demersal species and no information is available related to its habitat, basic biology, or ecology.
threats: Major threats are unknown.
population: No population data are available. It was described on the basis of many specimens (Bloch and Schneider 1801); Fricke et al. (2021) report 5 syntypes.
range: This species is known only from the western Atlantic Ocean off Suriname (Bloch and Schneider 1801, Paepke 1999).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements.
habitat: This species was collected from soil underneath a large boulder, 5 m from the banks of a stream within a severely degraded type locality (Brown 2015). Little can be inferred about its ecology and natural history (Brown 2015). It is thought to occur sympatrically with Pulchrana grandocula, which has been collected from the same area (Brown 2015).
threats:
At the type locality most areas close to the river below 1,000 m asl have now been converted to agriculture, although patches of forest still exist in higher elevation ravines and small valleys (Brown 2015). When the species was first recorded in 1992, large-scale logging was taking place, however these activities are no longer believed to be taking place (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

The major threat is the destruction and conversion of rainforest habitat on Mindanao due to small-scale agricultural activities, large-scale oil palm plantations, wood collection for charcoal production, and expanding human settlements (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). However, as this is a high-elevation stream frog, the severity of the threats may not be as severe where it occurs.
population: It is only known from one specimen, which is the only record of this species in 20 years despite searches of museum collections and field surveys (Brown 2015). However, there is a lack of comprehensive herpetological surveys in the mountains of southern Mindanao which may account for the lack of records (Brown 2015).
range: This species is only known from its type locality of Mount Busa, southern Mindanao Island in the Philippines, at 1,200 m asl (Brown 2015).
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions 
This species is not known from any protected areas.

Research Needed
Field surveys are needed to gather new information on the range, population status, and habitat requirements of this species.

rationale: Microcebus boraha was identified as a new species by Hotaling et al. (2016) but little is known about this species other than its range, which is limited to Nosy Boraha (Ile St Marie) in eastern Madagascar. Though this species is likely to be declining in population (as a result of habitat degradation and destruction, as well as hunting and the pet trade), it is assessed as Data Deficient pending further studies. Nothing is known about the species’ population or ecology.
habitat: This species is found only on Ile St Marie. The type locality is 68 metres above sea level (Hotaling et al. 2016). This species is considered relatively large, compared to other mouse lemurs (Hotaling et al. 2016).
threats: There is no known information regarding threats facing this species. However, given that this species is found across the Ile St Marie, it is possible that threats include habitat degradation and destruction, as well as hunting and the pet trade.
population: There have been no field studies on this species that can provide this kind of information.
range: This species is limited to Nosy Boraha (Ile St Marie) in eastern Madagascar and has a maximum EOO of 237 km2.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it was described from a vague location and its relation to any extant population of snakes is unknown. Research is needed to determine the taxonomic relationship between this species and other members of the genus Atractus.
habitat: The description of this species did not include ecological information.
threats: Any threats are unknown.
population: The population status is unknown due to taxonomic uncertainty.
range: This species was described from a location "200 km from Caracas," Venezuela. Due to taxonomic uncertainty, the distribution is unknown (Rivas et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Taxonomic research is required to clarify the relationship between this species and Atractus univittatus.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient in light of a complete lack of information on its distribution, ecology and threats. The type locality is unknown and the species phylogenetic relationships with P. caligatus has not been determined. This species should be a priority for future research.
habitat: There are no data available on the ecology of this species. Titi monkeys  are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (E. Heymann pers. comm. 2008), and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000, R. Wallace pers. comm.). Species of the Plecturocebus genus are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (van Roosmalen et al. 2002).The diet of titis comprises mainly fruit pulp, leaves, insects and seeds. They form small, pair-bonded, territorial groups and are considered monogamous. They have small home (1.5-30 km) and day ranges (0.5-1.5 km).
threats: There is no information on major threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.
range: Van Roosmalen et al. (2002) posited that C. stephennashi should occur along the right bank of the Rio Purús between the distributions of C. caligatus and C. dubius in Brazil. As a possible distribution, they suggested the interfluvium of the Rios Purús/Ipixuna/Madeira/Mucuím.
conservationActions: It is not known whether the species occurs in any protected areas.It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Atrobucca geniae is only known from the Gulf of Aqaba and is a relatively deep living species. Although it appears to be relatively common, information about its population and ecology are limited. This species is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This is a deep water species collected from 200-750 m depth (Ben-Tuvia and Trewavas 1987, Goldshmidt et al. 1996). The maximum recorded length is 40 cm TL. Additional information about its habitat and ecology are limited.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. However, pressures from tourism, fishing, aquaculture, and extensive landside development threaten the Gulf's ecosystems (Portman 2007).
population: Atrobucca geniae was one of the eight most common species collected in a survey conducted in the northern Red Sea (Goldshmidt et al. 1996).
range: This species is is a Red Sea endemic known only from Eilat, Gulf of Aqaba, Israel (Ben-Tuvia and Trewavas 1987, Bogorodsky and Randall 2018, Golani and Fricke 2018). This species is found from 200-750 m (Ben-Tuvia and Trewavas 1987, Goldshmidt et al. 1996).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for A. geniae; however, fish farms in the area which to contribute to nutrient loading in the Gulf were removed in 2008. A national monitoring program is carried out by the Inter-university Institute in Eilat (Israel Ministry of the Environment 2009).

rationale: Johnius cantori is is only known from one specimen collected off Penang, Malaysia. Information about its population and ecology is very limited. It is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is only known from a single specimen from Malaysia, stuffed, half-skin, with a length of 10.2 cm standard length (Sasaki 1992, 2001).
threats: There are no major threats known for this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species; it is only known from one specimen.
range: Johnius cantori is known only from the holotype from Penang, Malaysia (Sasaki 1992, 2001).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species is assessed as Data Deficient in view of continuing problems with its taxonomy as well as absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements. It is suspected that the species is threatened but the degree of threat is impossible to measure without more information on the species adaptability to habitat change and remaining area of occupancy.
habitat: The species lives in rain and subtropical forests of the Atlantic Coast. Information on its habits or ecology is very scarce. The species reproduces from January to May, with an apparently semelparous life-cycle (Barros 2013).
threats: The loss of habitat is suspected to have caused a decline in various populations.
population: Very little is known of the populations of this species. A population reduction is suspected based on a severe reduction in extent of occurrence and/or quality of habitat by deforestation.
range: The species is endemic to the Atlantic Forest of southeastern Brazil, where it is found in states of Espírito Santo, Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo, Santa Catarina, and Rio Grande do Sul (Pine and Handley 2008, Pavan et al. 2014).
conservationActions: This species is likely to occur in several protected areas, however, more surveys to establish range of occurrence and occupation, and ecology are needed in order to assess it.

rationale:
This revised assessment is a ruling made by the IUCN SSC Standards and Petitions Committee (SPC) on a petition against the 2018 assessment for this species (published on the IUCN Red List version 2020-1). The full petition ruling is available here.

The SPC received the petition on 20 May 2021. The petition argued that the Extinct (EX) listing of this species was not supported by the available information. The SPC sent additional questions to both the petitioners and the assessors, as well as several independent experts. This ruling is based on the information provided in the justifications and addenda filed by the petitioners and the assessors as part of the formal petitions process, the information SPC received in response to its questions, publicly available information on this and related species, the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN 2001) and the guidelines for their use (IUCN SPC 2019), and relevant scientific literature on extinction.

Both the assessors and the petitioners provided much information on the life history of handfish species. This gave the SPC an important context for its deliberations. However, neither the assessors, nor the petitioners placed sufficient focus on a quantitative evaluation of the extent to which surveys are exhaustive, which is key to the assessment of Extinct listing. Because this is the most critical consideration, the SPC concludes that the information provided in the original assessment does not support the EX listing, and rules that the listing of Smooth Handfish now be changed to DD. However, as discussed in the petition ruling, the SPC suspects that there is actually sufficient information and expert knowledge to quantify the extent to which surveys have been exhaustive, and strongly recommends that a revised assessment is undertaken.
habitat: The habitat of this species is unknown, but other handfish species in southeastern Tasmania occur in rocky and sandy habitats.
threats: Specific threats to this species are not known.
population: This species is known only from the holotype collected in 1802.
range: The only known specimen of this species was collected during a voyage to Australia in 1800 to 1804; it was amongst the earliest Australian fish species collected. No other data are available except a locality recorded as ‘Australian seas’. It is presumed the specimen was taken from somewhere in southeastern Tasmania.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures for this species.

rationale: This species is found only on the island of Timor-Leste, where has been recently detected in three new localities. It possesses a restricted distribution with an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of less than 500 km² and, based on observations of land use trends and experience with similar cave-roosting species of bats, it appears to be threatened by habitat loss/degradation and human disturbance throughout its range. This species is thus assessed as Endangered under criterion B2ab(iii).
habitat: It was first collected from a shallow man-made, humid cave (Quoto Lo Caves), on a heavily forested slope near Lequi Mia village, South of Ermera. It is believed that more than six or seven individuals were inhabiting the cave where the four type specimens were collected (Goodwin 1979).  It has also been identified unambiguously in flight from echolocation call sequences recorded in October 2006 in disturbed but dense riparian vegetation 2.5 km South of Laleia in Manatuto district, on the eastern side of the Laleia River at an elevation of 40 metres asl (Armstrong 2007a); and north of the Paitchau Range in evergreen riparian forest adjacent to the Ira Siquero River in Nino Conis Santana National Park at an elevation of 350 metres (Armstrong 2007b). On the basis of these three records, it appears that R. montanus has a preference for foraging in dense vegetation.  It has also been detected in flight from echolocation calls at 45 m elevation in secondary moist deciduous forest habitat on the southern coast 3 km East of Betano (WorleyParsons 2012). No roost sites were associated with the echolocation records, but in each case a relatively shallow cave was thought likely to be in nearby rocky outcrop.
threats: The primary threat to this species is the removal, fragmentation and decline in the quality of dense native vegetation, particularly evergreen forest and riparian communities. There is also potential for mortality at cave sites from increased visitation following further encroachment of people into natural habitats, plus the potential for significant local decline from overzealous scientific collecting.
population: All three new records are based on echolocation recordings (three or fewer passes in each case). The size of the population is therefore still unknown, but is presumed to be relatively small and subdivided according to the availability of dense natural forest and riparian vegetation communities. Being closely allied to Rhinolophus philippinensis, it is likely that it occurs at relatively low density within its range.
range: This species is known from four sites in Timor-Leste: the type locality at Lequi Mia, 8 km South of Ermera, at 1,220 m asl (Goodwin 1979); the Laleia River, 2.5 km South of the town of Laleia (Armstrong 2007a); the Ira Siquero River near Malahara village in the Nino Conis Santana National Park (Armstrong 2007b); and near Betano on the southern coast (Armstrong and Konishi 2012).
conservationActions: It has been recorded in Nino Conis Santana National Park, and is also represented in habitats outside protected areas. Presence and roost site occupancy can be established unambiguously and non-invasively through acoustic surveys since the characteristic frequency of their echolocation call at 37 kHz is distinct from other rhinolophids, including the Timorese form of R. philippinensis that emits at 27 kHz (K.N. Armstrong unpublished data). Given that the four records of R. montanus are widely separated and part of a complex mosaic of disturbed and intact natural habitat, significant field and analytical effort is required to obtain a better understanding of area of occupancy, and where the species is most likely to suffer from vegetation loss and disturbance at cave sites.
